LENGTH: 1292 words

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN: Reporter's Notebook;
Props and Fuzzy Anecdotes In a Sober, Grown-Up Talk

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22

 BODY:
It was the night Elvis stayed home.
President Clinton came to Congress this evening and spoke without the usual array of facial expressions he often borrows from his childhood idol -- the lip-biting, the downcast eyelids, the tucked-in chin. 
 Instead, he gave a thoroughly grown-up, sometimes stern, sometimes passionate and sometimes even angry speech about health care, with a direct and forceful demeanor and few contrivances.
 
Emulating Reagan
 It was his big chance to regain the momentum he had lost through a series of political stumbles soon after his last address to a joint session of Congress, February's speech on economic policy, when the new President seemed to have Congress eating out of his hand.
He borrowed the best rhetorical devices of his predecessor, Ronald Reagan. He saluted some members of Congress as he walked up to the lectern. He clenched his jaw when he talked about spiraling prices, and his voice cracked just a bit when, with patriotic fervor, he told the members of Congress to "look in your heart and tell me that the greatest nation in the history of the world is powerless to confront this crisis."
He used a Reaganesque prop: a specially made-up blue card with a magnetic strip on the back, a red bar across the top with the legend "Health Security Card," a United States seal, a white stripe and two gold stars.
And, mostly, he avoided his tendency to drift into technical language -- except for a sprinkling of health care jargon like "pre-existing condition" -- and he illustrated his points with warm and fuzzy anecdotes, one about a man whose business lost its health insurance because his mom and pop, both employees, got so old they were considered high risk.
He also returned to campaign themes that had served him well: "personal responsibility" and "the courage to change."
Both sides of the aisle received the President warmly. But when he began talking about raising taxes on tobacco to pay for the plan, or the need to cut Medicare and Medicaid, many on the Republican side of the aisle began snickering, shaking their heads skeptically and making faces at each other.
As any Democratic President knows, when it comes to taxes, there is never consensus.
Nevertheless, Mr. Clinton got several standing ovations from both sides of the aisle. Some members were amused that a man who is not known for his fitness or abstinence drew applause when he offered a list of services that would be covered under his plan and ended with "cholesterol tests, substance abuse and mental health treatment."
 
No Reruns, Mr. President
 After all the writing and rewriting, after all the day's careful orchestrations , what if Mr. Clinton had delivered the wrong speech? It almost happened.
Moments before Mr. Clinton opened his address, he glanced at the Teleprompter, only to realize that it was displaying the State of the Union address he gave last winter.
"He turned to Al Gore and said, 'That's the wrong speech,' " said Mandy Grunwald, a Democratic consultant who was involved in preparing the speech.
Ms. Grunwald said it took White House officials seven minutes to feed the right speech into the Teleprompter. Meanwhile, Mr. Clinton had to rely on a paper text on the lectern in front of him, trying not to look down too much.
The twist is that Mr. Clinton ad libbed much of the State of the Union address, but he closely followed the text in tonight's speech.
 
Late Hours and Jet Lag?
 The Scowcroft award -- given to Bush Administration officials who could fall asleep anywhere, anytime, in any nerve center of the world, with any number of eyes upon them -- went tonight to Secretary of State Warren Christopher.
Like former National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft, who would sometimes nod off in the middle of important meetings and go pitching head first toward the flowerpot on the table in the Oval Office, Mr. Christopher showed true napping talent by yawning surreptitiously and nodding off several times during the President's 53-minute speech, then jerking himself up guiltily.
Mr. Christopher's daring was all the more remarkable since he was seated right in front of the President, in a row of Cabinet members who kept the requisite alert, intrigued, moved and proud demeanors as his chin kept hitting his nattily attired chest.
 
Festival Seating
 In Washington parlance, they are known as "velcroids," officials who go to extraordinary lengths to get into the picture with the President.
The acknowledged vizier of House velcroids is Sonny Montgomery, the Mississippi Democrat who has been a Congressman since Bill Clinton was a student at Georgetown.
At 6:45, two hours and 15 minutes before the President's big speech was to begin, Representative Montgomery, the chairman of the Veterans' Affairs Committee, could be found sitting in an almost empty House chamber, on the aisle of the third row from the back -- prime territory to be seen on television by the folks back home, shaking the President's hand when he arrived at 9 P.M.
Clearly a master of the maneuver, Mr. Montgomery came prepared. Though it is not customary to bring food and drink to the floor, he had lined up at his feet enough junk food to satisfy even Mr. Clinton. While the Republican and Democratic leadership dined in splendor in the Senate dining room, Mr. Montgomery waited patiently on the floor, munching on popcorn and crackers and passing Pepperidge Farm cookies to the handful of colleagues who had also arrived early to claim aisle seats. A large bottle of Coke and a small bottle of Sprite sat on the floor at his feet.
In his rush to get to the floor, Mr. Montgomery put out his prepared "reaction" to tonight's speech -- saying he was "very pleased" with its contents -- at 4:50 P.M.
When Mr. Clinton finally arrived at 9:05, Mr. Montgomery was ready to pounce. He held out his hand and got a shake from the President. Not satisfied with that triumph, he waited again, while the rest of the room cleared out, to pat the President on his way out the door.
 
Opinions on Parade
 In the instant analysis popular among members of Congress looking to see their names in print, lawmakers were prowling the press galleries for reporters to give opinions to, and using the pay phones calling reporters back home with random portentious thoughts about health care.
The large and folksy Senator Howell Heflin of Alabama sat in the middle of the Senate press gallery and opined that the President had given "an excellent presentation."
Asked about the tobacco tax, which would hit the South hard, the Democrat shrugged.
"Obviously we can't pay for it without some taxes," he said. "It depends on how much and what."
Mr. Heflin's lack of concern about the tobacco tax became more understandable when a reporter asked how he would feel paying more for his beloved stogies.
"I don't smoke now," he said in a resigned tone. "I haven't lit a cigar in three, four-and-half months. The doctors cut me off. Can't use 'em."
 
The Rainbow Was Women
 If anyone doubted that the era of the mannish navy blue suit for women in powerful positions was gone, they had only to look across the Democratic and Republican aisles tonight.
The great majority of the female members of the House and Senate, and Clinton Cabinet, wore shades of purple, pink, coral, salmon, red and orange. And that, no doubt, made it the most colorful joint session of Congress in history.
But, proving that rituals in the capital die hard, Hillary Clinton's role on her big night was the same as that of every more domestic First Lady before her: to sit silently in the gallery beside the Vice President's wife, look elegant and gaze admiringly as her husband, the President, talked.

HEADLINE: Hang Tough, Boris

BYLINE: By Stephen Sestanovich; Stephen Sestanovich is director of Russian and Eurasian studies at the Center for Strategic and International Studies.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
By dissolving Parliament and scheduling early elections, President Boris Yeltsin has thrown Russia into one of its periodic fits of political uncertainty. Yet the "crisis" is very peculiar. For all the supposed drama of the confrontation, the most important political forces all have the same interest: to see Mr. Yeltsin succeed. If he holds on to his strength, Russia may turn a crucial corner in creating democratic institutions.
Two groups will be among the arbiters of the confrontation: the military and the heads of provincial governments. Since the failed coup of August 1991, Russia's generals have sought to keep their institution out of politics and have largely succeeded. They say the politicians should sort out their differences. 
 Yet the military leaders understand how risky complete neutrality could be. An indefinite political stalemate and the disintegration of the Government that would follow from it raise the danger that the army would be forced to restore order. This is not the job it wants. That's why it tilted strongly toward Mr. Yeltsin in March, when he called for a national referendum to settle his dispute with Parliament. And it's why the defense and interior ministers strolled the streets of Moscow with him yesterday to show their support. Backing the President today is their way of avoiding more dangerous involvement in politics later.
Similar calculations guide the provincial politicians. The standoff in Moscow offers them an opening to claim broad new powers for themselves, but they cannot press their advantage without risking all they have gained. A full breakdown of national institutions would increase the likelihood that at some point a government would be formed in Moscow with a mandate to recentralize. Seeing this possibility, provincial leaders, though less united than the military, will also back President Yeltsin.
No group has a stronger stake in his success than leaders of the new parties forming across Russia. For them, elections offer a chance to break into the political arena and claim a role in setting the country's direction. These people are not yet power brokers in the sense that the generals and provincial bosses are, but by supporting Mr. Yeltsin now they will strengthen his claim to speak for the nation as a whole.
Seeing how many groups have an interest in President Yeltsin's success makes clear that his moves are hardly the mad dictatorial power grab his critics claim. More than anything, he is preparing the way for the post-Yeltsin era. He will, after all, end up with a legislature whose popular legitimacy rivals his.
The President proposes to open the Government to new politicians who will before long think of themselves as his rightful successors. If he succeeds, he will start to make himself dispensable and cease to be Russia's only true national political leader. Even a big electoral win in December, while greatly enhancing his prestige, would give a still bigger boost to future rivals, who will emerge as leaders of large parliamentary blocs. That's why even some of Mr. Yeltsin's critics, among them extreme conservatives, favor early elections.
By contrast, the members of Parliament -- the Supreme Soviet -- who aim to thwart Mr. Yeltsin are a very small and unprepossessing bunch. Yesterday, the Speaker, Ruslan Khasbulatov, had trouble even mustering a quorum. There may also be a low turnout if he tries to convene a session of the larger Congress of People's Deputies. The power of both bodies depends entirely on stalemate; they are undemocratic, Soviet-era institutions with no real legitimacy.
The lineup of political forces, then, is strongly in Mr. Yeltsin's favor -- so strongly that many have asked why he took so long to act. In particular, he has been criticized for losing the momentum created by his stunning referendum victory in April, when the people expressed strong support for him and his program. Mr. Yeltsin's delay has had very negative political and economic consequences and has made the man who broke the coup two years ago seem, of all things, weak.
Yet the real reason for President Yeltsin's delay has been more serious, and not of his own making. Russian political leaders still fear accountability; they often do not know whom they speak for and thus seek protective cover in consensus.
During Mr. Yeltsin's long confrontation with the Parliament, many of those in the middle wanted him to win without being ready to offer him open support. Instead, they pushed him to seek compromise, to explore every possibility of agreement, so that no new "crisis" would be necessary.
That led to Mr. Yeltsin's summerlong dawdling -- his search for a formula that would unite all political forces in favor of a new constitution and new elections. While he let the momentum of April slip away, the Parliament replied with all-out war against him, passing measures that would have undone his economic reforms, foreign policy and ability to govern.
And yet his position has not eroded as feared. Instead, the Parliament's barrage of anti-reformist votes has powerfully reinforced Mr. Yeltsin's argument that it is unredeemable. Having made his effort at consensus, he is in a much stronger position to reject pressures for one last attempt at compromise.
If he is to prevail, he has to insist that the time for compromise is past. Doubtless some of his supporters will again want to have it both ways. Their timidity will parade as statesmanship -- a noble desire to pull the country back from the abyss -- but it will be timidity all the same.
Once the parliamentary leaders begin to see that they are failing, they too will doubtless float an effort at compromise. If all they want is a face-saving solution, Mr. Yeltsin can safely oblige them. He has already said he is prepared to run for re-election next year. If he now agrees to go further and fix a specific date, no great harm will be done and his fair-mindedness will be loudly praised.
But Mr. Khasbulatov and Vice President Rutskoi may have more than mere face-saving in mind. Getting Mr. Yeltsin into negotiations offers them the chance to come out on top. Mr. Yeltsin surely sees this: he has had brushes with back-room disaster before. Even his confrontation last March was almost undone by bargaining in which Parliament to a very large extent regained the upper hand.
If Mr. Yeltsin now accepts the (legally correct) idea that it is Parliament that calls elections, he runs a real risk that the balloting will never be held. In the meantime, the country will continue to disintegrate.
For Mr. Yeltsin, the stakes are as high as they can be. But some will say the latest confrontation doesn't really matter much: Russia is headed irretrievably toward chaos and elections won't stop the slide.
This view is wrong. Outright defeat for President Yeltsin might well make the breakup of Russia's national political institutions inevitable. The military would slowly begin to split apart as members of the officer corps chose sides politically. The emergence of national parties would be aborted without elections around which they can organize themselves.
But if Mr. Yeltsin succeeds and elections are held this year, Russia will take a long step toward revitalizing its national politics. The job of completing the transition from Communism will remain disorderly, but Russia will at least have institutions more suited to the task -- a working, legitimate legislature, even one that is often at odds with the President, and parties with real constituencies.
It is a lucky country whose problems can be even partly simplified by elections. With all its problems, Russia retains a kind of stubborn luck. Whether that luck holds depends on how its leaders act this week.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1500 words

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN: The President;
President Hints at Higher Taxes If Health Plan Savings Fall Short

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 23

 BODY:
President Clinton said tonight that if the cost savings anticipated in his health plan did not materialize he would either have to slow the introduction of certain benefits or find a way to "raise more money."
Mr. Clinton made his remarks in resonse to a question from John White, an economist who helped Ross Perot draw up his economic policies during the 1992 Presidential campaign. Mr. White challenged the financial underpinnings of the President's health care plan during Mr. Clinton's appearance at a town hall meeting here televised by the ABC News program "Nightline." 
 In response to Mr. White's question, the President seemed to open the door to the possibility of raising additional taxes to pay for his program, beyond the limited levies on cigarettes and some corporations that he outlined in his speech on Wednesday night.
"All of us have to be prepared to face the consequences if the cost savings don't materialize," Mr. Clinton said. "If something happens and they don't materialize, then we're going to either have to slow down the benefits or raise more money. I don't think it will happen."
He added, "That's why we have to phase these things in carefully so it doesn't get away from us."
Mr. Clinton's comments came at the end of a day in which he kicked off what White House aides were calling "health care a-go-go," a nationwide blitz of talk show appearances, town hall meetings and even visits to local diners intended to answer one question: what does the President's health care proposal mean for me?
Late today, he came to Tampa for a two-and-a-half-hour town hall meeting in which he fielded a wide array of questions, many of them pointed, from 1,200 local residents and experts chosen by ABC.
Sitting on a stool on center stage at the Tampa Bay Performing Arts Center, the President, like a politician on a house call, dispensed assurances and massaged doubts of an audience that seemed to share his sentiment that health reform was good for the nation. But the same audience also clearly needed to be convinced that his plan would be good for them personally.
 
Personal Stories
 "I have a 4-year-old son who had a near drowning accident," a woman told the President. "He needs physical and occupational and speech therapy three days a week, and I am concerned that he won't be able to continue long term therapy" under the Clinton plan.
"First of all, it won't get any worse," the President answered. "If you are paying for it now and getting coverage, there is nothing to prevent that. You shouldn't worry about that. But in all probability, because of the changes in our plan, you will have more secure coverage. If this plan passes, you will know that the coverage you have can never be taken away from you, especially in the event your husband has to change jobs."
A psychiatrist in Tampa asked Mr. Clinton whether mentally ill patients will be able to get all kinds of costly treatment services or will be limited to low-rate options.
"I really believe that it is important for us to cover mental health benefits," Mr. Clinton said, "but we won't be able to cover the full range because we don't know how to cost them out well enough." There will not be unlimited coverage of mental health treatment until the year 2000, he said, adding that it would have to be phased in.
 
Care for the Elderly
 A woman who takes care of an elderly mother and husband, both with Alzheimer's disease, wanted to know how the plan might help her.
"It will do three things," Mr. Clinton said. "First of all for people with Alzheimer's, we will continue to cover that and we will cover that at least as good or better as now. Over a period of years we will also reimburse people for in-home care. Often it is less expensive to maintain people in home than in a nursing home."
The President said that under his plan, people taking care of sick family members would even be able to hire in-home nurses for a specified period of days to get a break each week from the pressure of their duties.
Mr. Clinton engaged in a long back and forth with a woman who objected to abortions being covered in his plan. She said that it offended her morally to be indirectly financing abortions, and the President countered that his plan would also be indirectly paying for preventive programs that would help inhibit unwanted pregnancies. The President also added a zinger: "If every pro-life advocate in this country adopted a child this world would be a better place."
 
Treatment of AIDS Patients
 A school teacher who was forced to retire because he had AIDS asked how the plan would affect those who are H.I.V. positive.
People with AIDS, the President answered, often have to quit working to get Medicaid to cover their expenses.
"No. 1, you will be covered while you are able to work," Mr. Clinton said. "You will always have health insurance and it won't break your employer, so more people with H.I.V. positive will be able to work longer without bankrupting their employers. That is a huge thing."
At one point, Ted Koppel, the host of "Nightline," asked Mr. Clinton if he was not painting an overly rosy picture. Who is going to be worse off, the President was asked. "The following people will pay more," Mr. Clinton said. "Single healthy who are insured in big plants will pay about $6 a month more that gentleman up there with AIDS."
Employers that cover only catastrophic illness will have to pay more, said Mr. Clinton, who agreed to continue answering questions well after "Nightline" ended.
"Who will get less?" the President said. "The people who benefit from the paperwork explosion. Hospitals will hire fewer clerical workers. And insurance companies will not grow as rapidly, and there may be fewer of them."
Mr. Clinton's answers varied from the detailed to the general, which underscored the tension in his health care political strategy, between his need to keep things general at this point and his need to meet the public's demand for very specific answers. Now that the debate on health care has started, and the public's interest has been piqued, people want details on exactly how it is going to change their lives. To win over public opinion, the White House knows it must provide precise answers.
But to win over the Congress, the President has been trying to keep his proposals, for now, as general as possible so that opposition will not crystallize early around specific details, and so that the plan will be defined by its whole and not its parts, and so that he can be flexible without appearing to backtrack when the real horse trading starts with Congress in a few months.
 
The Right Speech
 Tonight Mr. Koppel began by asking the President to recall how he felt when he was ready to start his address last night before a joint session of Congress and discovered that the wrong speech was on his teleprompter. Instead of his health care address, his Feb. 17 State of the Union address was rolling before his eyes.
The President said he turned to Vice President Al Gore and whispered to him that they had the wrong speech on his teleprompter.
"He said, 'That's impossible,' " the President recalled. "I said: 'You're not reading it. Read it.' "
Earlier in the day, the White House invited radio talk show hosts to broadcast their shows live from the White House front lawn, where every senior official in the Administration with any knowledge of health care, and a few with no knowledge at all but with enough of a title to fool listeners, was sent to sit for interviews and do their best to answer questions.
Set up on dozens of portable tables and chairs, the talk show hosts created a bizarre cacophony: a health care gabfest that looked and sounded like Larry King meets Dr. Kildare.
 
'How About a Senator?'
 "Who wants Mark Gearan? Who wants Mack McLarty? You want a congressman? How about a senator?" a White House staffer shouted at the radio hosts, offering the communications director and the White House chief of staff. Those who could not get anyone on the White House staff settled for White House reporters, with CNN's Wolf Blitzer in heavy demand by the talk show impresarios.
"Yes, acupuncture will be covered in the President's plan," a nearby broadcaster was telling a listener who had telephoned from his car in Portland.
"The initial reaction from callers has been very specific -- What's in it for me?" said Bill Gallagher of Portland's KXL News Radio. "The union guy wants to know how his plan is going to be affected. The unemployed want to know what it's going to do to them. A lot of people -- I mean a lot -- want to know if alternative medicines will be covered. I got a lot of calls from chiropractors."
Judy Jarvis of Talk America said: "I would say the callers have been 50-50 for and against the plan. I am surprised how much initial support there is. But the attitude is sort of: 'Nice speech, Mr. President, but when can you tell us the details? Come back again.' "

HEADLINE: U.S. LAYS OUT RULES FOR A BIG AUCTION OF RADIO AIRWAVES

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
Kicking off what could be the wildest scramble for public property since the Oklahoma land rush, the Federal Communications Commission announced the rules today for a multibillion-dollar auction of the nation's airwaves to provide a new generation of wireless communication services.
The technology holds rich promise: a broad new family of portable phones and computer services that could be cheaper and more powerful than today's cellular networks. 
 But the bidding could be even richer. The Government hopes to raise $10.2 billion by auctioning thousands of new licenses for the wireless services.
 
Complex Plan Adopted 2-1
 By a vote of 2 to 1, the F.C.C. adopted a complex plan that would license as many as seven new wireless services in every American city and town, each of which could be a competitor to today's cellular companies. For consumers, the competition could bring innovative services at attractive prices.
But for the businesses that would have to spend billions of dollars to win licenses and build networks, the number of potential players may make the risks too high for some companies to enter the game at all, some industry executives complained today.
Andrew C. Barrett, the F.C.C. commissioner who cast the dissenting vote, said he feared that the commission would splinter the market and make it impossible for new entrants to raise money on Wall Street.
"In an attempt to make everyone happy, the majority has created a consensus decision that involves a complicated labyrinth," he said.
 
Competitive View Wins

But the F.C.C.'s majority view, held by the acting chairman, James H. Quello, and Commissioner Ervin S. Duggan, was strongly in favor of fostering as much competition as possible in the hope of spurring low prices for consumers.
Mr. Duggan said the agency was trying to give the marketplace enough flexibility to accommodate different visions of what personal communication services should be. "We are making educated guesses," he said. "But I am confident that we are erring on the educated side of that phrase."
The plan carves the nation into 51 oddly shaped regions with 492 subdivisions. Two licenses will be granted for each of the 51 regions. Each of the 492 subdivisions, roughly corresponding to individual metropolitan markets, would receive up to five licenses. A rich company or group of companies could bid for a nationwide license by combining bids for a license in each region.
The auctions, mandated by Congress earlier this year, will mark a major departure in the way the Government parcels out rights to the airwaves. Until now, the Government has always awarded free licenses through merit-based comparative hearings or lotteries. But those systems have been heavily criticized for inefficiency or vulnerability to exploitation by speculators.
Virtually every big telecommunications company, as well as scores of new upstarts, had been anxiously awaiting today's rulings. Cellular telephones have exploded in popularity since they made their commercial debut 10 years ago. But the shortage of available space on the radio band that was set aside for cellular service has limited the country to just two systems in each market.
 
Auctions Before June
 The F.C.C.'s action today opens up blocks of the spectrum that add up to more than three times the size of the bands used by cellular services today. The first auctions are expected before June, and some companies hope to start offering new services as early as the spring of 1995.
But many industry experts cautioned that the F.C.C.'s plans might have simply created a new way for companies to lose billions of dollars, with consumers left stranded.
"It's just creating chaos," said Cliff Bean, a consultant for Arthur D. Little Inc., who has estimated that 60 million Americans will subscribe to new wireless services by the end of the decade. "There's no way that more than two additional carriers can survive economically."
Misgivings aside, almost every company in the communications industry -- whether cellular or regular telephone company, cable television operator or newspaper publisher -- is already angling for position and lining up investment partners.
On one of the thorniest issues, the F.C.C. ruled that existing cellular telephone companies would be allowed to bid on some of the new licenses in areas where they already provide service.
Aspiring rivals to the cellular industry, like the long-distance company MCI Communications and the cable and media conglomerate Time Warner Inc., had lobbied intensively to keep cellular companies out, because they already have the right to use a radio band width totaling 25 megahertz, or millions of cycles of radio waves a second.
Partly addressing such concerns, the F.C.C. ruled that cellular companies could bid only for a license giving them an extra 10 megahertz in each market, while all other new entrants will be able to bid on as much as 40 megahertz in each market.
That decision received a mixed reaction. Thomas E. Wheeler, president of the Cellular Telecommunications Industry Association, called it a good decision. But the BellSouth Corporation, the nation's third-largest cellular operator, accused the F.C.C. of "squandering a scarce and valuable resource."
There was concern among the cellular carriers' aspiring rivals, too. "We had argued that the commission should issue two or at most three licenses," said Dennis Patrick, president of the Time Warner Telecommunications unit. "We're concerned that the market will be too fragmented."
Many of the nation's biggest companies have already been forming partnerships to compete for the new wireless licenses. MCI, the nation's second-biggest long-distance carrier, has put together a consortium which now includes more than 150 cable and local telephone companies. Time Warner is seeking to build its own nationwide consortium, and it has already teamed up with U S West, the Denver-based regional Bell company, to build high-powered networks that offer wireless services as well as advanced video services over fiber optic and coaxial cables.
Foreign companies are not expected to be allowed to bid on the new licenses.
The new wireless services will have to compete against entrenched cellular networks, and each technology group has different advantages. The new networks will be starting from scratch with the latest in digital transmission technology, which will allow them to be far more efficient and to carry a much broader array of data and images than today's cellular systems can manage.
In theory, the newer technologies make it possible to accommodate 20 times as many customers as traditional cellular technology on the same number of radio frequencies. That should cut a network operator's cost per subscriber to a small fraction of cellular's costs -- and translate into lower prices for customers.
But the start-up costs are still astronomical. Arthur D. Little, the consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass., estimates that the construction costs for a network serving Chicago will cost about $140 million.
Nationwide, billions will be necessary. MCI has said it can build a nationwide network for $8 billion to $10 billion -- not counting the hundreds of millions that may have to be bid for a nationwide collection of licenses -- and the company's executives have already budgeted $1 billion to $2 billion of MCI's own money for the effort.
In many cases, the new personal communications services will be able to exist alongside many current users, but the total capacity of the new wireless services would be constrained.
For current cellular companies, the biggest advantage is their huge head start. They already offer voice communication services and are racing to link their systems into nationwide networks that can patch calls to customers wherever they roam.


GRAPHIC: The F.C.C. will set licenses for new personal communication services in 47 "major trading areas." Circled numbers on a map of the continental U.S. show the largest metropolitan markets, by population; some areas contain more than one or these cities.
Map/Chart: "The Boundaries in the $10 Billion Wireless Auction"
 Terms of the Federal Communications Commission's plan for personal communications services:
 
THE AIRWAVES
 The F.C.C. is setting aside blocks of radio frequencies, more than three times the amount now devoted to cellular telephone service, for a broad family of new portable telephone and computer services.
 
THE LICENSES
 More than 2,500 licenses are to be awarded by the F.C.C.
 Two licenses will be awarded for each of 47 "major trading areas" on the continental United States and Hawaii. In addition, four other areas will each receive two regional licenses: Alaska; Guam and the Northern Mariana Islands; Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands, and American Samoa.
 Within the 51 regions, there will be 492 smaller "basic trading areas," each roughly corresponding to a single metropolitan area. Five licenses will be awarded for each basic trading area.
 
THE BIDDING
 By next June, the F.C.C. will begin a series of auctions. A company or group of companies can make a nationwide bid. If that bid is higher than the combined total of the highest bid in each region, a nationwide license will be granted.
 Most companies will be allowed to bid for more than one license in each market, as long as they do not acquire frequencies totaling 40 megahertz -- a swath of radio bandwidth about 60 percent bigger than today's cellular licenses. Cellular telephone companies would be limited to acquiring only 10 additional megahertz beyond the 25 megahertz covered by their current cellular licenses.
 
THE WHEREWITHAL
 The F.C.C. has proposed requiring bidders to make big non-refundable deposits -- perhaps 20 percent of the amount bid -- and to pay the remainder immediately if their bid wins. Small businesses and minority-owned companies, however, could make payments over a longer period.
 All winning bidders be required to complete networks serving at least one-third of their potential customers within five years or risk losing their licenses. EDMUND L. ANDREWS

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS;
Nunn Says He Wants Exit Strategy Before U.S. Troops Go to Bosnia

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
As President Clinton's top national security advisers traveled to Capitol Hill to test Congressional support for sending American troops to enforce a cease-fire in Bosnia, a leading Senate Democrat said today that the Administration would have to prove that it had an exit strategy before deploying troops.
Reflecting deep anxiety among lawmakers over American involvement in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said, "My big question will be not how do we go about it, what our goals are, but how do we get out if the parties begin fighting again?" 
 He told a group of editors and reporters for The New York Times that the United States must not repeat the mistakes made in Somalia, where a United Nations peacekeeping mission is bogged down in fighting with Somali militiamen.
"We ought to have a much better sense of what the mission is than we did in Somalia," Senator Nunn said. "That's coming back to haunt us."
He said it was not at all certain that Congress would support the deployment of American troops.
"I don't believe people have decided yet," he said. "It depends on what case is made by the Administration."
 
A High-Profile Team
 Making the case on Capitol Hill today were Secretary of State Warren Christopher; Secretary of Defense Les Aspin; Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, Anthony Lake; Madeleine K. Albright, the chief American representative at the United Nations; and Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. They met in separate sessions with the House and Senate leadership and with lawmakers involved in foreign and defense policy in separate sessions.
Although the officials also discussed the peacekeeping mission in Somalia, the turmoil in Russia and the Middle East peace, the main purpose of today's meetings was to brief lawmakers on the likelihood and pace of a negotiated settlement in Bosnia, the conditions for sending American troops as part of a NATO operation to enforce the agreement and the cost of such an operation, a senior Administration official said.
Just as important, the Administration officials sought to gauge the level of political support for sending American troops into Bosnia, a mission that some lawmakers fear could become not only dangerous but also unpredictable. By sending such a high-level team to Capitol Hill, the Administration was also sending an important signal that the views of lawmakers were crucial to Mr. Clinton's decision making.
But it was not clear whether today's consultations were the beginning of a campaign to win Congressional support for eventually sending American troops to Bosnia or to lay the political groundwork to pull back in the face of widespread opposition.
After the meeting, Representative Tom Foley, the House Speaker, declined to discuss the substance of the meeting, but praised the Administration's effort "to consult fully and adequately and meaningfully with members of Congress."
 
Presenting the Facts
 Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, Republican of New York, said that the officials did not try to win Congressional support for deploying American troops, and that their sober presentation had left him more, rather than less, concerned.
"It wasn't so much advocacy as to make sure that all the facts were presented to us for the first time in an extensive consultation," he said in a telephone interview. "It gave us all a great deal of concern about what could be up to the road."
As the three factions in Bosnia have moved closer to agreement on a partition of the country along ethnic lines, the Administration has moved closer to having to make good on its promise to the parties and its allies that it would help enforce an agreement with American troops.
Mr. Clinton told reporters this month that he would seek the approval of Congress before agreeing to let American troops join a peacekeeping force in Bosnia -- the first time he had ever made such a vow. Mr. Clinton also stressed that such peacekeeping forces would have to be under NATO command and not United Nations control.
 
$4 Billion Operation
 In his confirmation hearing on Wednesday to become Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. John M. Shalikashvili said the overall NATO operation in Bosnia would cost $4 billion in the first year. At the end of August, the United States was $799 million in arrears in its dues at the United Nations, and with new peacekeeping assessments it will be more than $1 billion behind by the end of the month.
General Shalikashvili made a strong case for sending the peacekeeping force, which he said had a good chance of being able to succeed in its mission.
But General Powell seemed far less certain this morning, reflecting questions within the Administration about whether the mission involves unrealistic expectations.
Asked at a breakfast with military reporters today whether the American people would support sending 25,000 troops to Bosnia, he said, "I think if the mission is well understood, if it has finite limits, if there is some understanding of how long we're going to be doing it, if there is a feeling of shared sacrifice on the part of others -- others are contributing to it and we are, you know, one of many contributing to it -- and if we make that case to the American people, I think the American people will support it."
 
Nunn Wants a Detailed Map
 But Mr. Nunn said public support was not assured, asking:
"What it's going to cost? What's the projected mission? How do we exit? Do we exit if it gets to be a war rather than peacekeeping or peacemaking? If we exit, what are the conditions for getting out? If we leave, do we leave equipment for the Muslims? Leave people defenseless over there? I don't think we should. There will be a lot of questions about this."
Asked how long it would take the United States to deploy troops after the parties reached a settlement, Senator Nunn said: "I think it would be a matter of weeks. It wouldn't be overnight."
Mr. Nunn estimated that the United States probably have to pay 30 to 50 percent of the cost of the operation, or $1.2 billion to $2 billion, in the first year.
 
Albright Lists Conditions
 In a speech at the National War College earlier in the day, Ms. Albright expressed the Administration's reservations about the future of United Nations peacekeeping, proposing stiff conditions for creating peacekeeping operations and calling for a restructuring of the way the United Nations makes decisions on peacekeeping. She also said the United States was now "insisting" that certain questions be asked before the United Nations creates a one:
*Is there a real threat to international peace and security?
*Does the proposed peacekeeping mission have clear objectives and can its scope be clearly defined?
*Is a cease-fire in place and have the parties agreed to a United Nations presence?
*Are the financial and human resources to accomplish the mission available?
*Can an "end point" to participation by the United Nations be identified?
Critics of the Clinton Administration's foreign policy have suggested that the Administration was ceding too much authority to the United Nations and putting too much faith in multilateral solutions to intractable ethnic or intrastate problems.
The speech also reflected the widespread anxiety within the Administration over open-ended peacekeeping operations in Somalia and Bosnia, and Ms. Albright stressed the limits rather than the strengths of multilateralism.
 
Presenting Foreign Policy Map
 "The Berlin Wall would be upright today if we had relied on the U.N. to contain Communism," she said.
Ms. Albright's speech was the third in a series of speeches by senior Administration officials this week designed to set out the principles of American foreign policy. On Monday, Mr. Christopher outlined Administration plans to finance the Middle East peace efforts, and on Tuesday, Mr. Lake said the Administration aimed to replace the cold war policy containing the Soviet threat with one that would enlarge the family of democratic market economies.

The Economy
The F.C.C. announced rules for an auction of the nation's airwaves to provide a new generation of wireless communication services. HEADLINE: Traffic Agents Battle for Respect;
Can Blue Uniforms or Positive Ads Protect a Battered Force?

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
Many New Yorkers seem to view traffic-control agents as sinister troublemakers in ugly brown uniforms who exist solely to harass upstanding citizens and feather the public nest.
It seems to matter little that without parking enforcement, there would be even fewer places to park. It is but a trifling detail that without traffic tickets, lanes would be hopelessly clogged to ambulances and fire trucks. The bottom line to many New Yorkers is that parking is warfare and the enforcers are the enemy. 
 "Extremely rude is the best thing you can say," Lucius J. Riccio, the Transportation Commissioner, said of the public's treatment of his agents.
 
Enforcers Under Fire
 Actually, mere rudeness would be almost a relief. Each day, on average, at least two of the 1,500 ticket-writing agents are assaulted. Each year, a third are threatened, spit at or otherwise harassed; a tenth are assaulted outright.
Clashes on the job are so routine, in fact, that some agents are being used as subjects of a university psychologist's study of interpersonal conflict.
The Transportation Department has been campaigning on several fronts to improve the image of the department, raise the morale of agents and, most important, protect the beleaguered troops from irate motorists.
In February, a two-year-old program to replace the hated brown uniforms with spiffy police-like blue will be complete. Agents have been directed not to enforce minor technical violations that do not impede traffic. The psychologist has begun teaching agents better ways of dealing with dangerous situations. And a public-relations offensive complete with subway posters may be on the way.
So far, at least, the efforts do not seem to be having the desired effect. Assaults against agents rose from 158 in 1990 to 190 last year and are running still higher in 1993. Particularly alarming is that attacks are becoming more vicious and injuries more serious, department officials say.
Take the case of Dawn Davis, who on Sept. 13 was confronted by two men who began ranting and raving against traffic agents, although neither even had a car. One sliced her arm with a razor blade, causing a wound that required 22 stitches.
"You don't know who to trust," said Ms. Davis, who has also been hit by a car and had her jaw broken by a fist in her three years on the job. "People feel they have to hit you."
 
Agents as Fair Game
 Beyond the motorists who turn ugly or violent, traffic agents are alarmed by what they see as a broader public perception -- expressed only half in jest -- that they are fair game. A New York Post cartoon last year showed an agent flattened against a car's grille, with the caption "Motorist's Fantasy." A recent editorial in a Queens neighborhood newspaper seemed to condone violence against traffic agents. Similarly, news accounts of attacks on agents routinely ignite readers' letters in support of the attackers.
Still another example is the almost annual failure of a bill in the Legislature to stiffen sentences for those convicted of assaulting agents to the same as those for attackers of sanitation workers, dog wardens, toll takers and park rangers.
The defeated legislation would have made assaulting an agent -- now generally a misdemeanor, like any other simple assault case -- a felony and set a maximum sentence of seven years' imprisonment. Currently, said Edward W. Luczynski, an assistant commissioner, "assaulting an agent is usually about the same as a traffic violation," usually resulting in a fine of $300 or less.
"At a minimum, the bill's passing would be a signal to the agents that they are respectable people," said Mr. Riccio, who fumed with rage at a news conference after the legislation's most recent defeat.
The uniform change is also intended to foster respect for agents -- whose salaries start at $20,000 a year and can rise to $24,000 -- and give pause to potential attackers who might at first think they are tangling with a police officer. At the very least, the agents will no longer be confused with doormen or United Parcel Service workers.
Benjamin Ward, then the Traffic Commissioner, ordered the change to brown from blue in 1974. His goal was to make agents look less like letter carriers at a time when their enforcement powers were being expanded. But the brown uniforms quickly became distinctive of nothing but the hated function they represented, and agents came to be derided as "brownies." That the vast majority of agents are members of minority groups made this appellation doubly distasteful, department officials say.
Accordingly, officers in 1991 began spending their $400 annual uniform allowance on blue uniforms. Some immediately noticed the difference.
"I feel a lot better," said Steve Kopczynski, an eight-year veteran. "I think we get a little more respect."
Other officers say nothing has changed. "Blue, brown, it doesn't matter," said Theon Phillips.
Also underway is a pilot project in which some agents are using handheld computers to produce tickets instead of pen and pad. Agents say it makes them feel more professional, while increasing efficiency and perhaps facilitating quicker escapes.
Most helpful, perhaps, has been an effort to weed out regulations that have little to do with traffic flow, such as the requirement that cars park no more than 12 inches from the curb.
Similarly, traffic authorities have begun discussions with community boards to hear their enforcement priorities, partly in the hope of reducing hostility to agents.
The primary reasons for those changes are traffic control and community relations, but Mr. Riccio said he hopes they will also lessen abuse of agents. That might lead to better enforcement, since officials believe that agents' concerns over confrontations may be a factor in a sharp drop in the number of tickets issued last year.
Despite the drop, agents more than pay their way. In the current fiscal year, the department's payroll and benefits will total $40.5 million, while revenue from tickets is expected to reach $200 million -- $123 million this year, with the rest coming in over the next seven years.
 
Defusing Conflict
 Another new initiative grew out of research by Elizabeth Brondola, a psychologist at St. John's University, who saw agents as the perfect subjects for a study of interpersonal conflict. Among other things, she has been measuring agents' blood pressure at 15-minute intervals.
A key early result is a growing body of observations about how some agents are able to cope peacefully with situations that turn nasty for others. This appears to involve filtering out low-level annoyances, as well as an ability to make instant critical judgments, Dr. Brondola said.
Often, the agents who best handle stress cannot say why, she said. But she hopes that she and her team can learn useful techniques from watching agents' responses. The first class begins next month. Another class to help supervisors ease agents' stress has already begun.
Dr. Brondola said her goals are realistic. "There are a number of situations in which the agents in fact can do nothing," she said. "The people are sufficiently out of control that even the best conflict-management skills are not going to help the person calm down."
Another tactic the department is exploring is public relations, though funds are scarce. Tom Jelliffe, assistant commissioner, hopes to create an "image enhancement campaign," with radio spots and subway ads. The goal, he said, would be to "create a constituency for the service we provide." One possible message: Agents are not paid by the ticket.
Meanwhile, the agents' war stories pile up. One officer tells of being assaulted by a priest wearing his clerical collar; another tells of being taken to the hospital with broken bones and discovering that his X-ray technician was his attacker.
Many say that police officers do not do enough to help or protect the agents. "They talk down to you and make you feel like you're nothing," said Felice North, an agent in Queens. "And people figure if the cops can do it, they can, too."
Despite the hardships and indignities, the poor economy and tight job market are prompting agents to stay on the job twice as long, on average, as they used to four years ago.
Mostly, agents say, they would just like a little respect. "They are somebody's family member, somebody's neighbor," said Mr. Luczynski. "They go to church and Little League. They're human beings like every other citizen of the city."

HEADLINE: After Big Gains, Angolan Rebel Offensive Is Halted

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GANDA, Angola, Sept. 17

 BODY:
After months of euphoric advances in which his guerrillas extended their reach over more than two-thirds of Angola's territory, the rebel movement of Jonas Savimbi appears to have been fought to a standstill, and in some places turned back, by a rebounding Government army.
Here on the embattled central plateau that is Mr. Savimbi's political base and the war's greatest symbolic prize, the Government has expelled the insurgents from several towns conquered during their great surge, and is slowly amassing troops and weapons for a promised major offensive. 
 But while the tide may have turned again in Angola's relentless civil war, neither a decisive military outcome nor a diplomatic settlement appears to be within reach.
 
Long Standoff Seen
 Officials and diplomats in Luanda, the capital, say the country seems doomed to months or years more of a lethal standoff that has already created some of the most wretched pockets of misery in Africa and demolished what little remained of the Angolan economy.
The prevailing view of diplomats and military analysts is that the Government has not yet mustered the strength to throw a knockout punch. Mr. Savimbi, in turn, is considered largely immune to diplomatic pressures, such as the United Nations Security Council's threat on Sept. 15 to declare an oil and arms embargo unless the rebels stop fighting and show signs of accepting their defeat in elections a year ago.
"We're looking at a protracted stalemate," said a Western military expert in Luanda. "The most realistic hope is that the Government can eventually push Savimbi back to where the country has a degree of normalcy, but with a guerrilla threat continuing indefinitely."
By most accounts, the last year of war has been the most punishing in 30 years of fighting -- first against Portuguese colonialists, then, after independence in 1975, between rival Angolan factions, armed and abetted by the superpowers. The patrons of Mr. Savimbi's National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, known by its Portuguese acronymn, Unita, were the United States and South Africa
Since Mr. Savimbi spurned the election outcome and led his guerrillas back into the bush, an estimated 50,000 people have been killed, and 2 million more of the country's 12 million people have fled the fighting to crowded city slums and refugee camps.
The rebels' swift advances isolated many cities and towns that were not disturbed in the earlier bush war, disrupting food supplies and raising fears of famine.
 
Government Massing Troops
 The Government has been massing forces on two fronts: one just north of Luanda, where the main targets are the rebel-held oil town of Soyo and two northern provincial capitals, the other at a Cuban-built air base in Catumbela, on the Atlantic coast. From that base the army directs its advance toward Huambo, Angola's second-largest city and Mr. Savimbi's headquarters.
"Huambo has no military value," conceded Gen. Armando da Cruz Neto, the commander of the central front, in an interview. "But it has great psychological value for Savimbi."
In the field, the only noticeable impact of diplomatic maneuvering is to set off periodic struggles for position, in the event a cease-fire takes hold.
Just outside Ganda, a highland agricultural town that is as close as reporters are allowed to the front line, rebels attacked from behind the eucalyptus trees early Thursday morning.
Col. Jose Manuel de Sousa, the 30-year-old commander whose troops had recaptured Ganda from the rebels just a month ago, said the attackers were routed with heavy losses. But the fact that they could muster such an attack behind Government lines reflects the see-saw nature of the battle.
Despite his party's reputation for corruption, President Jose Eduardo dos Santos, a colorless petroleum engineer, won the elections last year by running as the peacemaker against the bellicose, charismatic Mr. Savimbi.
The demobilization and elections were sparsely monitored by international observers, and it soon became obvious that while the Government's battle-weary army had virtually collapsed, Mr. Savimbi had kept plenty of firepower in reserve.
Denouncing the election as a fraud, he ordered his 30,000 guerrillas back into the bush, and salvaged the heavy weapons he had secretly cached. This time he has tended to portray his war less as an anti-Communist crusade and more as a defense of his minority Ovimbundu people, although the Ovimbundus are sharply divided in this war.
Mr. Savimbi's forces gobbled up territory far beyond what the rebels had held during the earlier war. He is still estimated to have loose control of about 65 percent of Angola's land area, including 4 of 18 provincial capitals and roughly a third of the population.
He conquered the important diamond fields of Lunda Norte province, menaced the outskirts of Luanda with hit-and-run attacks and in March, after an eight-week battle in which thousands died, he took Huambo.
"If Unita was going to win the war militarily, their chance was between October and April," said a Western military expert. "They didn't do it."
Slowly the Government has built a new army from inexperienced teen-age conscripts, and distributed assault rifles to thousands of urban civilians.
Western officials believe the Government has already mortgaged its oil income for the next three years to raise money for weapons.
 
Besieged Provincial Capital
 The fiercest fighting of the renewed war now centers on the provincial capital of Cuito, northeast of Huambo, where 2,000 Government troops have held out since January.
Government radio broadcasts from the besieged city tell of dogs devouring unburied corpses in the streets.
The United States, after supporting Mr. Savimbi for years, recognized the dos Santos Government in May, but some Angolan officials are bitter that this has not brought military help.
"In my opinion the United States does not want to abandon the monster it created," asserted Reis Esteves, the Vice Governor of Benguela province.
"We didn't create Savimbi," retorted an American official, when asked about American responsibility for the situation. "We may have rented him for a couple of years, but I don't believe we owned him." Washington, the official added, has no popular mandate for any deeper involvement in Angola.
It is generally believed Mr. Savimbi uses money from his captured diamonds to buy black market weapons, bringing them in through neighboring Zaire and Namibia.
A United Nations embargo, diplomats in Angola say, might raise the price of his weapons, but would not cut off his access to arms merchants.
As for diplomacy, neither Mr. Savimbi nor the Government has shifted position since the last peace talks ended in failure in May.
Margaret Anstee, then the United Nations special envoy to Angola, now retired, has said the talks might have succeeded if the United Nations had been willing to invest in a small, symbolic presence of peacekeeping troops.
But other participants in the talks said Mr. Savimbi would not agree to withdraw from territories he captured after the election.
The Government, in turn, flatly rejects any settlement that allows Mr. Savimbi to keep his gains.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN: Interest Groups;
Lobbyists of Every Stripe Turning to the Grass Roots on Health Care

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
Anheuser-Busch is outfitting its trucks with placards urging Bud drinkers to dial 1-800-BEER-TAX. Thousands of consumers have responded and then received pamphlets describing how the Clinton health care overhaul could drain their pockets if it includes "sin taxes."
IVAC Corporation, a San Diego-based company that manufactures intravenous pumps, has set up a telephone bank staffed by 20 employees to call other health industry workers and urge them to write to their representatives to oppose proposals to limit hospitals' access to medical technology. 
 It is all part of a frenetic nationwide effort to mobilize citizens that has picked up speed since President Clinton's speech on Wednesday night. Tonight, for instance, he went to Tampa, Fla., to take part in a special edition of the ABC News program "Nightline," in which the President fielded questions about his plan at a town hall meeting. [Page A21.]
And it is also emblematic of the changes that have transformed the old lobbying arts of political arm-twisting into a more populist enterprise.
"It's the largest mobilization since the establishment of Social Security," said Frank Mankiewicz, a former Kennedy Administration official who is a partner at Hill & Knowlton Inc., a public relations firm that is lobbying for the Medical Rehabilitation Education Foundation. "I have the feeling the big-name lobbyists will mean less."
 
From All Walks of Life
 Lobbyists successfully turned to the grass roots in this year's budget battle, when the oil industry mobilized constituents in oil-producing states with high-priced advertising campaigns to urge their lawmakers to vote against higher energy taxes. Now special interest groups have an issue on which they can find spokesmen from all walks of life, from all over the country.
Hundreds of R. J. Reynolds employees, for instance, volunteered to take vacation time this spring to travel to Washington and, with some guidance from the company, lobbied the North Carolina Congressional delegation against higher cigarette taxes.
Because health care is so large an industry and affects virtually every American, competing citizen armies appear to be emerging. AIDS activists are staging 1960's-style street theaters. Doctors are raising their concerns to patients during physical examinations. And members of Congress say they don't have the time to schedule all the face-to-face meetings that have been requested from dance therapists, masseurs, chiropractors and podiatrists, armed with scripted palm cards from one trade association or another.
Much of the grass-roots pressure is being artificially stirred. Pharmaceutical companies, for instance, are writing to their shareholders warning them that profits could suffer if price controls impede drug research. Planned Parenthood is encouraging its members to deluge Congress with a post-card campaign demanding that abortion, prenatal care and estrogen replacement therapy are covered under a proposed insurance blanket.
But there are also signs that spontaneous grass-roots lobbying is also beginning to catch fire. Stationery store owners, restaurateurs and other small business owners, who face the prospect of having to pay for health care coverage of their lower-wage employees for the first time, are flocking to Capitol Hill from all over the country.
"The telephone lines are burning up," said Representative Mel Reynolds, a freshman Democrat from Chicago who is a member of the Ways and Means Committee.
 
Balancing Concerns
 Mr. Reynolds said owners of eight Mom-and-Pop groceries accompanied by a tobacco industry lobbyist came into his district office last week to warn that higher cigarette taxes would cost them sales and force them to lay off workers. "When constituents come in like that, it gives you a moment of pause to think," he said.
But Mr. Reynolds said he would still support the "sin tax" because his inner-city constituents "die disproportionately from cigarette smoking."
Still, major interest groups like the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association and the American Academy of Family Physicians are spending millions of dollars hiring lobbyists. Political action committees linked to groups like the American Medical Association, the National Association of Life Underwriters and the American Dental Association have greatly increased their campaign contributions to lawmakers of both parties with the intention of increasing their access and influence.
Most of the special interests are diversifying their strategies, to drive home different messages inside and outside the Beltway. Pfizer Inc., for instance, is offering a new drug giveaway program for people not covered by insurance.
 
Passing the Word
 At the same time, four Pfizer executives recently sent checks totaling $5,000 to Senator Orrin G. Hatch for his legal defense fund. The influential Republican from Utah is facing an Ethics Committee investigation into his efforts to help a business associate obtain a loan from the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, which was closed amid charges of fraud.
The Health Insurance Association of America, a coalition representing commercial health insurers, enlisted Bill Gradison, a former Republican Congressman who was popular with his colleagues, to lead their lobbying.
But the major emphasis of their campaign is glossy advertising and grass-roots organizing. The organization has set up an "800" number and telephone bank to get out their message that the Clinton plan would mean higher insurance premiums and fewer health care choices for consumers. It is also encouraging insurance sales people to give their clients literature that says the Clinton plan could raise their taxes and enmesh them in regulatory red tape.
 
Ads and More Ads
 The association quickly attracted the ire of competing special interest groups because of a television advertisement it ran showing a young couple sitting over their kitchen table grumbling that the President's plan will grant Government bureaucrats powers that will serve to limit their choices of doctors and insurance plans.
"The Government may force us to pick from a few health-care plans designed by Government bureaucrats," the spot said. "If we let the Government choose, we lose."
The commercial was run before Mr. Clinton even announced his program, inciting the Democratic National Committee to air a competing commercial accusing the insurance industry of jumping the gun and using scare tactics to protect profits.
 
The Kitchen Table
 The brouhaha developed into a case of dueling interest groups. The Health Care Reform Project assembled what it called a "truth squad" to urge local insurance companies to use their influence on the association to pull the commercial, which they did today.
Charles N. Kahn 3d, executive vice president of the Health Insurance Association of America, denied that his group dropped the commercial under pressure. "We felt the ad served its purpose," he said.
The Health Care Reform Project is planning its own advertising campaign, one that is likely to be friendlier to the Administration. Formed by a coalition of such diverse organizations as the A.F.L.-C.I.O., American Airlines and the League of Women Voters, the group hopes to encourage a Congressional compromise by organizing town hall meetings for members of Congress. They hope to build a consensus around some compromise for slowing the inflation rate for medical care and covering the 37 million who are uninsured.
The American Association of Retired Persons, one of the most powerful lobbies in Washington, has begun an advertising campaign to include coverage of prescription drugs and long-term care in the health insurance overhaul. But in an exercise of participatory democracy, the A.A.R.P. will not take a firm position on the Clinton plan until after it holds town hall meetings to solicit the opinions of its members.
"This thing will be won or lost around the kitchen tables around the country," said John Rother, the A.A.R.P.'s chief lobbyist. "If people say it's too complicated and don't get involved, then its Gucci Gulch -- the high-priced lobbyists, through their campaign financing -- who will prevail."

LENGTH: 799 words

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN: The H.M.O.'s;
Health Professionals Brace for a New Age

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 23

 BODY:
No group was listening more intently to President Clinton's appeal to the nation to adopt a sweeping program that would guarantee all Americans health insurance than the professionals in the health care fields. Mr. Clinton is proposing nothing less than an upheaval in the way one-seventh of the American economy operates. These are some of the immediate reactions to the President's speech on Wednesday night from doctors with a health maintenance organization, insurance company executives and medical students.
 
 
The Faithful Hear the Sermon
 Sixteen years ago, newly married and embarking on their life's work, Dr. Sharon Levine and Dr. Jay Crosson decided to abandon the prestige and perquisites of East Coast medicine and head for Northern California, where the modern health maintenance organization was born.
"The question for the next two decades was not going to be what was the newest therapy," said Dr. Crosson, who was one of 50 executives and policy analysts from the nation's largest H.M.O. who gathered here on Wednesday to watch President Clinton address Congress. "The major question was going to be how were we going to deliver the health care we already had." 
 If ever there was a choir to preach to, it was here at Kaiser Permanente's regional headquarters and the crowd was hushed and attentive as Mr. Clinton spoke. Those who stayed after work to watch the President listened to a recitation of health care principles that had long been their credo. Even though Mr. Clinton did not mention them by name, they knew that the Kaiser model was the heart and soul of his formulation.
"He touched people where they live to move them where he wants them to go," Dr. Levine said. "The six principles he's identified are absolutely right. This is not a medium to deliver the details but a medium to approach a broad group of people and I think he did that very effectively." For years, the H.M.O. model, pioneered by Kaiser, drew fierce opposition from the mainstream medical community, which barred Kaiser doctors from joining professional organizations and practicing in most hospitals. But that gradually gave way to grudging admiration, and lately to Presidential acclaim.
It is a source of gratification, Dr. Levine said, to be cited by the President, his wife and their squad of health care planners as a prototype for national reform. "But at the same time," she said, "it's a real trumpet call to do what we do even better because people are looking at us."
What Kaiser does is deliver relatively low-cost health care to 6.6 million Americans, 16 percent of those enrolled in H.M.O.'s across the nation. It is the predominant provider of health care in Northern California. Each member pays a fixed fee (between $130 and $150 a month for an individual and between $340 and $400 for a family of three).
Under President Clinton's health plan, which encourages the use of prepaid health plans rather than fee-for-service medicine, very little would change here at Kaiser. Dr. Crosson, an executive with the regional medical group as well as a practising pediatrician, said that Kaiser would be likely to expand greatly under the Clinton plan and get more involved in training others.
The uneasiness elsewhere in the nation over the proposal dates to a bygone idea of health care, Dr. Crosson said. "Most people have grown up with a clear vision of what medicine is about," he said. "It's one physician, and it was usually a him, practicing by himself in a small office with a nurse."
But with technological advance, Dr. Crosson said, "the black bag could not hold all the tools of the trade, the small office could not contain all the tests and interventions a patient could need." Thus group practices became more common and "the new challenge became how to deliver that complicated care in a way that's still personal."
Dr. Levine, also an executive and a pediatrician, said the fear that a large, prepaid system diminishes the quality of care disappeared quickly among new Kaiser patients, who have their own doctors, just as they did before. "The loyalty I have to my patients and my patients have to me exists outside the payment system," she said.
Fear also disappears quickly for new Kaiser doctors, Dr. Levine said, who discover the pleasure and challenge of practicing in a system where "physicians are taught from Day 1 to talk about the art of medicine, the science of medicine and the business of medicine" and where each member of a group practice has the responsibility to make cost-conscious decisions.
Dr. Levine said 50 percent of the new Kaiser doctors in the last three years have come from fee-for-service practices. "The word on the street has changed," she said. "Our success is now accepted as legitimate."
JANE GROSS

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN: Principles;
Experts' Grades: 'A' in Security, 'C' in Simplicity, 'D+' in Savings

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
In proclaiming six principles as "guiding stars" on the journey to health care reform, President Clinton set forth a benchmark to measure the plan he presented to Congress on Wednesday. By those standards, he is being given high marks for some parts of his health plan and low marks for others.
Consumer advocates, economists and health policy experts said today that they generally accepted Mr. Clinton's principles as criteria by which to judge health care legislation. The six principles, in the shorthand used by Mr. Clinton, are security, simplicity, savings, choice, quality and responsibility. 
 Experts analyzing Mr. Clinton's plan agreed that it would go far toward providing security of health insurance coverage for all Americans. Under his proposal, people would be assured of coverage even if they lost their jobs or had a history of medical problems.
But Mr. Clinton's proposal received a mixed grade on another criterion, simplicity, and a comparatively low mark on a third, savings.
The current health care system is immensely complex. The President said he would simplify life for consumers by establishing a uniform package of health benefits and a standard insurance claim form, in place of hundreds now used by different insurance companies.
"For consumers, it will be simpler than the current system," said Edwin S. Rothschild, a spokesman for Citizen Action, a consumer group with three million members.
But in other ways Mr. Clinton would make the system even more complicated. He would create new agencies and a complex new apparatus to buy insurance. There would be regional health alliances, health plans, a powerful National Health Board, a new Federal advisory committee to assess the reasonableness of new drug prices and a new Government agency to decide the number of young doctors entering each medical specialty.
Theodore R. Marmor, a professor at the Yale School of Organization and Management, said: "Simplicity is the Administration's standard for reform, but its proposal is incredibly complicated. The President's plan is a fragile Rube Goldberg contraption."
The process of setting and enforcing a national health budget, as described in White House documents, is exceedingly complex. It involves rate-setting mechanisms, "weighted-average premiums," inflation factors and a "base-line per capita budget" for each alliance.
 
Skepticism on Savings
 Prof. Uwe E. Reinhardt, a health care economist at Princeton University, said the Clinton plan "would produce some administrative savings and would substantially reduce administrative hassles."
"What the insurance industry burns up in commissions, marketing and claims processing costs is almost unspeakable," said Mr. Reinhardt. "Clinton would reduce those costs."
But there is still widespread skepticism that the Government could squeeze as much money out of the system as the President contends. On Wednesday, Mr. Clinton defended the numbers he had used to estimate the cost of his proposals. But on Capitol Hill, some lawmakers said today that Mr. Clinton made David A. Stockman and Richard G. Darman look like amateurs in the use of "smoke and mirrors" to balance the budget.
Mr. Stockman, as budget director for President Ronald Reagan, and Mr. Darman, in the Bush Administration, were repeatedly criticized by Democrats who said they used overly optimistic economic assumptions and underestimated Federal budget deficits.
If Mr. Clinton's program is not adequately financed, the guarantee of "health security" could be compromised because there would not be enough money to pay for all the promised benefits.
Another principle cited by Mr. Clinton was choice. Many people, especially the uninsured, would have more choices under Mr. Clinton's plan than they do now. But many others would have fewer choices. There would be strong incentives for people to join health maintenance organizations or other networks that limit their ability to select doctors and hospitals.
Consumers could select a traditional fee-for-service health plan, offering free choice of doctors and hospitals, but they would probably have to pay more. Senator Paul D. Wellstone, Democrat of Minnesota, said, "Many Americans would not be able to afford the health plans that offer free choice of doctors and other health care providers."
Bill Gradison, president of the Health Insurance Association of America, a trade group for commercial insurers, said that Mr. Clinton would eliminate a choice that consumers now have. Under the President's proposal, consumers and small businesses would not buy coverage directly from insurers, but would have to go through purchasing cooperatives known as regional health alliances, he said.
The alliances could thus restrict insurers' access to potential customers. Insurers, Republican lawmakers and conservative Democrats say the alliances should not have such power. "By giving so much regulatory power to the alliances, Clinton's plan will undermine the competition we are trying to promote," said Representative Michael A. Andrews, Democrat of Texas.
Mr. Clinton wants to issue "report cards" allowing consumers to evaluate and compare the performance of competing health plans, doctors and hospitals. These data would presumably enable consumers to make more intelligent choices. But other parts of Mr. Clinton's proposal, including significant cuts in the growth of Medicare and Medicaid and strict Government limits on private health insurance premiums, could adversely affect the quality of care, consumer advocates and health care executives say.
Michele A. Davis, an economist at Citizens for a Sound Economy, which advocates conservative policies, said Mr. Clinton's plan would force insurers and H.M.O.'s to ration care to survive under federally established premium caps. And Carl Feldbaum, president of the Biotechnology Industry Organization, warned that Federal limits on new drug prices "threatens to squelch research and development" that may produce cures for various cancers, AIDS, multiple sclerosis and other diseases.
The last of the principles cited by the President was responsibility. Mr. Clinton would create new financial incentives for consumers to take responsibility for their health care. Employees are now often insulated from the true cost because employers pay most of it. But under Mr. Clinton's plan, consumers who choose costly health plans would pay more, and those who choose less expensive plans would pay less.
