HEADLINE: Market Place;
Nike stumbles amid a pack of troubles in its market.

BYLINE: By Michael Janofsky

 BODY:
HALFWAY through the 400-meter final at the world track and field championships last month in Stuttgart, Germany, Quincy Watts's left shoe fell apart. With his heel flapping, the American runner finished fourth in the race.
While this was bad enough for Mr. Watts, the 1992 Olympic champion, it was ghastly luck for Nike Inc., the athletic apparel company that made his shoes and prides itself as being the worldwide leader in marketing shoes for runners. 
 Yet a broken shoe could not have been a more fitting symbol for the company at the moment. Just as unusual heat on the track might have softened the glue that held Mr. Watts's shoe together, an unusual confluence of events has helped cut Nike's stock price nearly in half in less than a year.
In late November, Nike class B shares traded at $90.25 on the New York Stock Exchange. After an announcement this week that earnings for the first quarter fell by 7 percent from a year earlier, the class B shares closed at $46.50 yesterday.
Of all the factors for Nike's decline, several are worth noting for investment guidance.
Foremost is economic trouble in Europe, especially in Germany and France, where unemployment has steadily increased in the last year: in Germany, from 6.5 percent in October to 8 percent in July; in France, from 10.3 to 11.7 percent over the same period.
Track stars like Mr. Watts enjoy much greater celebrity in Europe than they do in the United States, where track and field is considered a minor sport.
"Especially among those 18 to 30 years old," said Willard Brown, a stock analyst for Dean Witter, Discover & Company in Boston. "That's Nike's target audience."
But as much as Europeans yearn to run -- or dress -- as Mr. Watts does in athletic shoes that can be priced at $75 or more, hard times may mean making do with an old pair of shoes, and that has affected Nike. Its international sales of athletic shoes fell 10 percent for the first quarter, and sales of athletic apparel fell 13 percent.
Another factor has been the American market for athletic shoes. While Nike still commands the dominant position, with 33 percent of a market approaching $2 billion, Reebok International Ltd. continues to make a formidable challenge. Reebok holds about 25 percent of the market and seeks to grow with new directions in advertising and promotion.
Last week, Reebok switched advertising agencies, consolidating its $140 million worldwide brand account with the Leo Burnett Company of Chicago and leaving Chiat/Day, which had done impressive work with the Dan and Dave campaign last year, among others. A Reebok vice president said the move was made to help make Reebok "a world global brand."
Another factor is more difficult to quantify but is not so hard to spot: the growing popularity of the grunge look among young people. Torn trousers, frayed shirts and clunky boots are now fashion icons, not symbols of spare living. Doc Martens, the British working-class boots popularized by Madonna, among others, have played a major role in the trend. Those boots and mountain boots, chukka boots and military boots are replacing athletic shoes as the favorite choice of many youths for everyday wear.
For all its problems, Nike has made an indelible mark on the popular culture with its promotional admonition "Just Do It," a phrase that has rocked more than a few people out of a sedentary life style. In Stuttgart, it was amended to "Just Glue It," and the same might be true for the company's finances until more favorable conditions return.

HEADLINE: A Vow to Keep Battling Gambling Laws

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MERIDEN, Conn., Sept. 22

 BODY:
The roulette wheel was gone, confiscated by the police last weekend, but Paul Giacobbe sat at a table in his restaurant with a handful of gambling chips made of chocolate and vowed to continue challenging state laws that prohibit gambling.
Mr. Giacobbe created a stir last week when he announced he would operate a roulette wheel in the banquet room of Jacoby's, the East Main Street restaurant he has owned here for 21 years. 
 The authorities seized his roulette wheel even before the gambling began, but he said he was not giving up his fight, and said he planned to bring back another roulette wheel or some other game of chance.
 
Opposes a Monopoly
 Mr. Giacobbe is upset with what he calls a monopoly on gambling in the state by the Mashantucket Pequot Indians, who operate the Foxwoods High Stakes Bingo and Casino on their reservation in Ledyard.
"I'm just fed up with not having the same right as the Indians," Mr. Giacobbe said. "It's an unfair advantage for them, and every restaurant owner in the state is being hurt by it." He said that the combination of the casino and the recession had cut his business in half.
Even though Ledyard is more than 75 miles away, the casino is hurting his business, Mr. Giacobbe insists. "People who used to come in here all the time on weekends tell me they're up at the casino now," he said. "Look, this is a small state and everybody's being hurt by it."
Mr. Giacobbe and his lawyer, John Donovan of Meriden, say he has a legal right to operate a roulette wheel as long as he does not profit from the game's operation.
 
The 'Roulette Club'
 Mr. Donovan says that because Mr. Giacobbe established "the Connecticut Roulette Club," with about 90 people signed up for $1 annual memberships, he is adhering to state laws that only require a bona fide social relationship to exist among the gamblers for it to be a legal activity as long as there is no house profit.
"With no house profit, no law has been broken and we will demand the return of all the equipment seized by the police," Mr. Donovan said.
State authorities say that is not going to happen. In fact, they say that Mr. Giacobbe faces possible criminal charges and could face up to a year in jail because the mere possession of gambling equipment is against state law. Even charitable organizations that run Las Vegas nights must apply for permits, said the New Haven County State's Attorney, Michael Dearington.
"The fact is, he broke the law, you cannot possess or operate a roulette wheel," Mr. Dearington said. "If he thinks he is being treated unfairly, he should pursue it through legal channels, not by setting up an illegal activity." Mr. Dearington said his office is still considering whether to prosecute Mr. Giacobbe for criminal activity.
Gerald Langlais, director of the State Department of Liquor Control, said his office was awaiting a decision by the State's Attorney as well. He said he could not remember an establishment openly publicizing its intention to offer gambling.
Paul Bernstein, manager of the state's Charitable Game Section of the Division of Special Revenue, which issues permits to charitable groups, organizations and clubs that wish to operate Las Vegas nights, bazaars and raffles, says Mr. Giacobbe has clearly broken the law. He said a permit can only be issued to a nonprofit group after it has been in existence at least two years. Even then, groups are only permitted to hold four Las Vegas nights a year, Mr. Bernstein said.
"I don't see how he has a leg to stand on," Mr. Bernstein said. "There is nothing in the state statutes that would allow him to operate a roulette wheel in his restaurant."
But the people who showed up to play roulette at Jacoby's last weekend say they want the right to gamble without making the 90-minute drive to Ledyard.
"I like to gamble and I should be able to do it locally," said William Tomkiewicz of Berlin, who despite winning the state's $3 million lottery in 1989 said he still enjoys gambling and signed up to play in Mr. Giacobbe's roulette club.
Cindy Hebert of Middletown said that although she is not a gambler, she joined the club because "it would be fun to have a drink and play some roulette."
"I don't see how they can stop him from trying to compete with the Indians," she said.
Mr. Giacobbe said the state should just give him and other restaurateurs the same opportunity as the Pequots.
"Look, I just want to be able to play on the same field as the Indians," he said. "I've had a tough time with the recession and I feel I have a right to do the same thing they're doing in Ledyard to help my business."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Paul Giacobbe is left with a toy roulette game, since the state confiscated the wheel he planned to operate in his restaurant in Meriden, Conn. Upset with what he calls a monopoly on gambling by the Mashantucket Pequot Indians, he said, "It's an unfair advantage for them, and every restaurant owner in the state is being hurt by it." (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Microcosm, New Jersey Senate Race Tests Party Power

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EWING TOWNSHIP, N.J., Sept. 23

 BODY:
If any legislative district could stand for all New Jersey, the capital region's 15th is it. Here, the Trenton poor and the Princeton Ivy Leaguers vote Democratic, the prosperous business suburbanites favor Republicans, and Gerald R. Stockman and Richard J. LaRossa are struggling in a Senate race for the same shifting middle that will probably decide the race for governor as well.
For Democrats like Mr. Stockman and Gov. Jim Florio, the 15th was once considered so safe a seat that Mr. Stockman, then a 10-year incumbent State Senator, was chosen to sponsor Mr. Florio's $2.8 billion tax increase in 1990. The next year, Mr. La Rossa harnessed anger over the taxes to his fame as the man who called the state lottery results on television and won a humbling upset over Mr. Stockman. It was a defeat that the state Democrats ardently want to reverse.
 
'Not Something I Brag About'
 "This was the most Democratic district in the state until I lost," Mr. Stockman, a 57-year-old trial lawyer, said recently as he doggedly worked the sidewalks and front porches of Trenton's West Ward. "It's not something I brag about." Indeed, Mr. La Rossa is the first Republican to represent the city of Trenton in the Senate since 1946, the year, he likes to point out, when he was born. 
 Now, three years after the tax increase and after two years of Republican control of the Legislature, the tax issue that once cut like a knife through New Jersey politics has become a duller and more ambiguous memory to many voters.
For some, the memory was revived by the three-year plan to cut income taxes by 30 percent announced Tuesday by Christine Todd Whitman, Mr. Florio's Republican challenger. At the same time, the Whitman proposal seemed to to harden positions instead of shifting them, as well as to stir uneasy memories of the aftermath of other tax cuts.
In what could turn out to be a lesson-laden preview of how Mrs. Whitman's proposal might turn out, many voters still talk about how the Republican legislative majority rolled back a one-cent Florio sales-tax increase last year. Today, people in the 15th seem to be talking more about the state-employee layoffs that followed than about the tax savings.
"People certainly weren't happy with the $2.8 billion tax increase, but then again they weren't so happy about the one cent they did roll back, because it put so many people out of work just when the economy was bad," said Jack Ball, the two-term Republican Mayor of Ewing, Mr. La Rossa's home township. "So I think for a lot of people, getting that penny back wasn't as important is keeping people working."
Mayor Ball helped nominate Senator LaRossa in 1991, but says he believes Mr. LaRossa double-crossed him by supporting a rival in the Mayor's losing re-election primary race this summer. Now Mr. Ball plans to become an independent, and will vote for Mr. Stockman.
 
Concern for G.M. Plant
 In the Cadwalader Heights section of Trenton, meanwhile, Edith Lieber recently lost the first prospective buyer for her house in five years. The deal fell through earlier this year after General Motors announced it would close its Ewing parts plant, which would idle 2,000 workers, including her prospective buyer. The township is trying to save the plant, which is still operating with a reduced staff.
Mrs. Lieber, a widow, is also firmly for Mr. Stockman, because, she said, Mrs. Whitman's tax cuts would shift the burden to homeowners, a point Trenton's Mayor, Douglas H. Palmer, has been pounding home.
"Our property taxes are already so high, we just feel like we're stuck," she said. "If Mrs. Whitman cuts the income tax, who's going to make up the difference?"
But in West Windsor, where new suburban developments and new high-technology factories are nestled among the cornfields at the 15th's northeast corner, Arthur Kaminer, a self-employed reinsurance consultant, said he was with Mr. LaRossa and Mrs. Whitman to the end.
 
'Taxes Are Too High'
 "Politicians can explain things a million different ways to make it look like it's not their fault," he said at the Princeton Junction train station on Wednesday as he waited for the commuter run to New York. "Florio is a master at it. But what we need are people who can stay focused on the main problem, which is that taxes are too high to keep businesses going in New Jersey, and I think Mrs. Whitman is on to that."
West Windsor is a LaRossa stronghold, a township he won two-to-one over Mr. Stockman in 1991.
The other townships in the 15th -- New Jersey state legislative districts do not cut township lines -- unfold to the west and south. "The Princetons," township and borough, arehome to liberal academics and a cadre of campaign volunteers from the college dorms that helped Mr. Stockman roll up a two-to-one margin there over Mr. LaRossa.
Below Princeton is Lawrence Township, also coming to be known as Lawrenceville, a mix of new and old Trenton suburbs, and in this year's elections a toss-up. Ewing, heavily blue-collar, is home to thousands of state employees who are angry at Governor Florio's layoffs but perhaps worried about further cuts under a Republican. It was Senator LaRossa's power base two years ago.
 
Son of Trenton Detective
 At the south end of the district lies Trenton, Mr. Stockman's hometown, where he still lives.
Mr. LaRossa, whose father, Mickey LaRossa, was a much-loved Trenton detective, has worked hard in Trenton's heavily Italian, working-class South and East wards to undercut Mr. Stockman there. If early election returns show him running ahead there, Senator LaRossa says, the Democrats will be in trouble.
Like Mr. Florio, Mr. Stockman is a longtime Democrat, a Roman Catholic, a lawyer-politician with roots in New Jersey's fading urban centers. To explain his candidacy, he speaks sentiments about "giving something back to society," and seems to know more people on Trenton's streets than the people who live there.
Mr. LaRossa, a professional singer with a performer's personality, had received almost all his recognition from spending 11 years calling the state's weekly lottery drawing on television before succeeding in his first campaign for office in 1991. He runs without a political history and often seemingly without a label, criticizing politics-as-usual among Republicans and Democrats equally. He has already set his eyes on a higher prize than the 15th District.
"People are desperate; they're fed up with the usual political bull," he said. "If Jim Florio gets back in, I think you'll see Dick LaRossa's name in the governor's race in four years." He is making no allowance for losing in November.

SECTION: Section A; Page 13; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 867 words

HEADLINE: U.S. IS UNEQUIPPED TO DISARM A-BOMBS

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The Federal Government is facing enormous technical challenges in disassembling the nation's nuclear arsenal and is ill prepared for the job, according to a report released yesterday by the Office of Technology Assessment.
The costs of the effort may already have reached $1 billion a year, the study found, but the job has been slowed because there is no more storage space for plutonium. The office, an arm of Congress, also said the delays were caused by a lack of national policy on what should be done with nuclear fuels -- plutonium and highly enriched uranium -- and by a lack of attention to the problem on the part of the White House. 
 Senator John Glenn, the Ohio Democrat who asked for the study last year, said yesterday that the report showed that the current management team, consisting of the Departments of Energy and Defense and the National Security Council, "is designed to supervise the nuclear arms race and not to end it."
Dismantling the arsenal, the Senator said at a news conference in Washington, will require environmental sensitivity and safeguards against material going astray, rather than expertise in the military use of weapons. "Unfortunately, the ability of our cold-war-created bureaucracies to respond to these changes is proving slow and disjointed," he said.
 
Ending Much Secrecy
 Senator Glenn, who is chairman of the Governmental Affairs Committee, said the report "raises serious questions" about meeting the weapons-disassembly schedules laid out in agreements with the former Soviet Union.
Energy Secretary Hazel O'Leary said in a phone interview yesterday that the study portrayed the department as it operated in the Bush Administration, and that new personnel, including two from the Office of Technology Assessment, would prove more able than their predecessors.
Mrs. O'Leary noted that the report criticized the department for continuing to keep secret many of the details about its nuclear bomb fuel. But she said that since May her department had been working to declassify material and that in the next month, "substantial information will be available."
The report comes as the Energy Department is trying to decide what parts of its weapons production complex to close and what parts to preserve. Those decisions, which have attracted far more attention than the problems of weapons disposal, are sure to be heavily affected by the need to store tons of bomb materials that will remain highly radioactive for hundreds of thousands of years.
 
Turnabout in Agency's Mission
 The report hinted strongly that it was time to bring other agencies and public oversight into the process. While not making explicit recommendations, the report said the Department of Energy's Office of Defense programs "may not be well suited to carry out the new nonmilitary mission."
"Historically, its activities have been subject to minimal regulation," the report stated. "Its operations have been conducted in secret, and it has not sought or welcomed public involvement or been concerned about the international implications of its actions. Its priorities continue to be maintaining the warhead stockpile."
But Mrs. O'Leary said that "handing off" the problem to another agency would delay the process by years.
The report says Government efforts so far have not been adequate because of weak management at the Department of Energy and a lack of public trust in the agency. Mrs. O'Leary said she was working to build trust by increasing outside input.
The report also noted that the technologies available for dismantling warheads and storing nuclear materials are quite limited. Russia, which faces a similar task, has even fewer resources and faces problems its government considers more pressing, the report said.
 
Dangers for Pantex Workers
 Among the problems cited by the report was the shortage of storage space for plutonium at Pantex, the Energy Department's plant near Amarillo, Tex., where nuclear bombs have been assembled for decades. Pantex has already sustained environmental damage from the intentional burning of high explosives from old bombs that have been disassembled, and report warned that the exposure of workers to radiation could soar if they handle more weapons.
Pantex disassembled nearly 1,300 bombs last year and more than 13,000 since 1980. If all goes according to plan, at least 10,000 more will be dismantled in the next decade, the report said. The office also warned that decommissioning weapons could be delayed by environmentalists who fear that without long-term planning Pantex will become a de-facto permanent repository for plutonium.
There is currently no plan for long-term disposal of plutonium or highly enriched uranium, the two primary bomb fuels, the study noted, although the uranium can be diluted for use in commercial power reactors. Plutonium can also be used in reactors, but the study predicted that would be unlikely, because of unfavorable economics and public opposition.
The Government might be able to build a fission reactor to destroy the plutonium, perhaps producing electricity in the process, but the research to build it could require decades, the report said.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Soybeans and Corn Climb On Threat of Midwest Chill

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Soybean and corn futures surged yesterday amid the threat that a cold air mass heading for the Midwest next week may kill crops.
Gains in those commodities helped drive the Commodity Research Bureau's index to its highest level since Aug. 30. The index, which tracks the performance of 21 commodities and is a widely watched gauge of inflation, rose 2.31, to 217.49. 
 Gains in coffee, cocoa, precious metals, livestock and lumber futures also contributed to the rise in the index.
The National Weather Service said temperatures across most of the Midwest will be much below normal during the next six to ten days, reinforcing worries about a crop-killing frost.
"In most areas of the central and northern Corn Belt, harvest hasn't begun because the soybean and corn crops aren't mature." said Victor Lespinasse, a grain analyst with Dean Witter in Chicago. "A frost would just stop their growth, and that means lower yields,"
Soybeans for November delivery closed 11 cents higher at $6.4925 a bushel, the highest price in almost three weeks, on the Chicago Board of Trade. Corn for December delivery closed 2.75 cents higher at $2.4875 a bushel, the highest price in about two months.
A cold air front headed south from Canada will bring colder temperatures though the week. The next significant threat of a frost will be Sept. 30 and Oct. 1, although the intensity and the duration of the cold air system is still uncertain, said Jon Davis, a meteorologist with Smith Barney-Shearson.
Meanwhile, heavy rains in the southern portion of the Midwest raised additional concerns about those crops, said Gary Wilhelmi, an independent analyst, based in Chicago.
On other commodity markets, crude oil prices rose as traders grew optimistic that a meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, scheduled to begin tomorrow, would yield an agreement to limit production. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for November delivery gained 4 cents, to $17.63 a barrel.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar and Gold Rebound Amid Russian Uncertainty

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the German mark and other European currencies yesterday amid continuing political tension in Russia, while gold rebounded from a sharp loss the day before.
Traders said both the dollar and gold were bolstered by reports that a group of gunmen tried to storm a military headquarters in Moscow, along with the uncertainties about the power struggle between President Boris N. Yeltsin and his opponents in the Russian Parliament. 
 "The market is going to be vulnerable to that for the time being," said Bob Ortiz, vice president for corporate foreign exchange at the Continental Bank in Chicago.
But some traders said much of the activity reflected a knee-jerk market reaction to buy dollars and gold as a safe haven in times of international turmoil. Yesterday, Mr. Yeltsin called for presidential elections in June, two days after he seized control of the Government to break a deadlock over economic and political changes in Russia.
A group of hard-line opponents in Parliament elected Vice President Aleksandr V. Rutskoi as their president.
In late New York trading, the dollar jumped to 1.6435 marks, from 1.6285 marks on Wednesday. And the British pound fell to $1.5055, from $1.5181. But the dollar slipped to 105.90 Japanese yen, from 106.20 yen.
Gold for October delivery gained $4, to $358.10 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Other precious metals prices also rose.
William O'Neill, a senior strategist at Merrill Lynch Futures, said gold prices were being pushed up in part by short-sellers who had bet on Wednesday that prices would go down but now were reluctant to maintain those positions overnight because of the shaky Russian situation.
Curtis Perkins, a currency trader at the Chemical Bank, said the dollar was also being pushed up by uncertainties surrounding this weekend's meeting of finance ministers from the Group of Seven large industrial democracies.
Mr. Ortiz also said that many large investors had been buying dollars even before the political troubles in Russia. "The market may have been looking for excuses to buy dollars," he said.
The Group of Seven meeting has traders concerned partly because of the array of potential topics on the agenda: aid to the Palestine Liberation Organization, interest rate reductions and trade policy.

HEADLINE: Initial Jobless Claims Rise

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
The number of newly laid-off workers filing claims for jobless benefits rose to a seven-week high last week, but analysts said the recent trend still suggested continued employment growth.
First-time claims for unemployment insurance totaled 335,000 last week, up 11,000 from the previous week and more than what many analysts had expected. It was the highest level since 339,000 new claims were filed during the week that ended on July 31. 
 Michael P. Niemira, an economist for Mitsubishi Bank in New York, attributed much of the increase to the delay in opening New York City's public schools, which left bus drivers and cafeteria workers without jobs.

HEADLINE: Inside Art

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

Picasso's Turn
Matisse fever gripped the New York art world last season, with the giant Matisse retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art and a flurry of important Matisses setting record prices at auction. This season, everyone is selling Picassos. No fewer than 88 go on the block at Sotheby's in New York one night in November, and, as it happens, several important Picasso exhibitions are in the works.
"We seem to be periodically reminded of the singular status of Picasso," said Richard Gray, a Chicago dealer. "The breadth of interest and curiosity in his work is such that no one can compete." 
 Mr. Gray is a player in the latest Picasso craze. The dealer recently was tipped off about a pastel, "Woman and Child by the Seashore" (1902 to 1903), in a private collection inFrance. He was able to buy the work and export it to the United States. "No one has known its whereabouts since World War I," he said.
Mr. Gray would not say exactly what he was asking for the pastel, just "somewhere in the mid-seven figures." Other experts value the work at more than $5 million. So far, Mr. Gray said, several American institutions have expressed an interest, but he predicted that it would probably end up in a private collection.
 
88 in One Night
 For Picasso collectors, this fall should be something of a field day. Picassos in every medium and nearly every price range can be found at the New York auctions in November. The biggest stash, 88 works dating from 1899 to 1972, will be offered in a special single-owner sale at Sotheby's on Nov. 4.
The collection is being sold by Stanley J. Seeger, an American collector living in Switzerland who has been buying Picassos since 1980. Mr. Seeger, whom Picasso experts describe as a reclusive collector, bought about 95 percent of the works in his collection at auctions here and abroad.
"He set out to do what he accomplished," said David Nash, the head of Impressionist and modern paintings for Sotheby's. "Every phase of Picasso's work is represented."
And every price range. The big-ticket items in the sale include "Women and Children at the Seashore" (1932), expected to fetch $2.5 million to $3.5 million; "Glass, Flowers, Guitar and Bottle," a 1919 still life estimated to bring $2.5 million to $3.5 million; "Playing Cards, a Pack of Tobacco, Bottle and Glass" (1914), $1.5 million to $2 million and "Nude Woman With a Bird and Flutist" (1967), $1 million to $1.5 million. The sale also includes many less expensive works, beginning at $10,000. Sotheby's estimates that the entire collection will bring $22 million to $31 million.
 
Warhol Redux? Not Likely
 Christie's in New York is also auctioning several Picassos in its sale of Impressionist and modern artworks on Nov. 2. Among the works are "Woman in an Armchair" (1929), estimated at $900,000 to $1.2 million; "Still Life With Bird and Cage" (1947), $600,000 to $800,000, and "Bullfight" (1956), $400,000 to $600,000.
Are all these Picassos coming on the market the same week too much of a good thing? Auctiongoers will no doubt remember last May's disaster when 16 Warhols went on the auction block in New York within 24 hours and only two sold. (Sotheby's, in particular, flooded the market by trying to sell 12 Warhols in one sale, 10 from the collection of Frederick W. Hughes, the artist's business manager.)
But experts are hoping this November will be different. Reasonable estimates, good quality and varied selection, they suggest, could attract buyers even in this depressed economic climate.
 
In the Museums
 Meanwhile, several museums have announced Picasso exhibitions, two scheduled for next year. Opening Feb. 16 at the Tate Gallery in London is a show of about 200 sculptures, paintings, drawings and ceramics, many on loan from Picasso's family. The show will explore the wire works and iron sculptures of the 1930's and the paintings associated with them, the still-life paintings of World War II and after, and works from the 50's and 60's.
"This will be the first show that explores how sculpture and paintings inform and influence each other," said John Golding, a painter and art historian, who organized the show with Elizabeth Cowling, a senior lecturer in art history at Edinburgh University.
In the United States, a traveling exhibition, "Picasso and the Weeping Women: The Years of Marie-Therese Walter and Dora Maar," opens on Feb. 10 at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, then travels to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in June and the Art Institute of Chicago in October. The show, which includes 60 works, has been organized by Judi Freeman of the Portland Museum of Art in Maine.
In the spring of 1996, William Rubin, director emeritus of the department of painting and sculpture at the Modern, is planning yet another Picasso show there, "Picasso and the Portrait: Representation and Transformation." He is organizing with the Picasso Museum in Paris, where it is to travel in the fall of 1996.
 
Disputed Silver
 It's been a week for international disputes over ancient artifacts. On Wednesday, the Metropolitan Museum of Art ended a six-year legal battle by agreeing to return to the Turkish Government what has been popularly called the Lydian Hoard, more than 200 gold, silver and bronze objects from the sixth century B.C. Another dispute is much further from a conclusion.
The jury selection began in State Supreme Court in Manhattan in a long-awaited case that will decide the rightful ownership of the $70 million Sevso treasure, a hoard of 14 ornately cast pieces of silver dating from the fourth and fifth centuries. The collection's name comes from an inscription on one piece that refers to an official of the Roman Imperial Army named Sevso.
The case, which has been unfolding for years, has become something of an art-world epic. It involves the Marquess of Northampton, who says the silver is his to sell, and the Governments of Lebanon, Croatia and Hungary, each of which has been trying to prove title to it, contending that the silver was illegally excavated and smuggled out of its territory and is therefore its national property.
Lord Northampton began buying pieces of the silver in the 1980's, in partnership with Peter Wilson, the former chairman of Sotheby's, who died in 1984, and Rainer Zietz, a German art dealer. They bought the silver from Halim Korban, a Lebanese dealer who purchased it from a Yugoslav dealer living in Vienna. Mr. Wilson and Mr. Zietz bought the first pieces and included Lord Northampton only when their money ran out.
Questions about the silver's origin began 10 years ago when Lord Northampton, Mr. Wilson and Mr. Zietz began negotiating to sell the silver to the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., and an export license was denied because of questionable signatures dating from before the three men purchased the silver. They eventually obtained an export license, but the Getty declined to buy it. In February 1990, Lord Northampton consigned the silver to Sotheby's.
When the auction house announced it would sell the treasure, representatives of Croatia, Hungary and Lebanon raced to lay claim to the pieces. (Lord Northampton became the owner of record for selling purposes, but 37 percent of the proceeds are to go to Mr. Zietz and to Mr. Wilson's estate.)
 
A Dismissal, a Dropout
 On Tuesday, Justice Beatrice Shainswit dismissed the fraud claims brought by Croatia against Sotheby's and Lord Northampton. Croatia contended that both parties knew or should have known that the silver had come from inside its borders; the judge ruled that "Croatia can point to no damages compensable in an action for fraud." Croatia is still pursuing the court action seeking to prove the treasure is part of its heritage.
Lebanon withdrew its claims to the silver on Tuesday, leaving Croatia, Hungary and Lord Northampton's trustee to fight it out. To defeat Lord Northampton, Croatia or Hungary needs to prove that the silver was found within its borders, its laws give it title to the silver and the United States should recognize these laws.
"Croatia and Hungary are engaged in a treasure hunt," said Harvey Kurzweil, Lord Northampton's lawyer in Manhattan. "Neither one has any evidence that they saw the pieces excavated from the ground."
Sotheby's isn't totally out of the woods yet. "We're thrilled; we feel we've been vindicated by the judge's decision," said Marjorie E. Stone, general counsel for Sotheby's, after Croatia's fraud claims were dismissed. "But we're still holding the silver in our possession until the court decides the case."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Picasso's "Woman and Child by the Seashore," purchased by the Richard Gray Gallery in Chicago from a private collection in France. (Richard Gray Gallery)

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Bruce Weber

 BODY:

Questions, but No Answers
With an odd mixture of pride and paranoia, the producers Robert Michael Geisler and John Roberdeau announced a new play headed for Broadway, providing a phone-book-sized volume of information about the production. Then, through a spokesman, they refused to answer any questions about it.
The play, an adaptation of the Japanese film "Sansho the Bailiff," from 1954, is to have a six-week workshop at the Brooklyn Academy of Music beginning Nov. 1, and the producers say it will be ready for a Broadway opening next October. 
 One might ordinarily dismiss such chin music as mere bravado, particularly since the subject matter -- it's a parable about oppression, set in 14th-century Japan -- sounds a tad ponderous to be economically feasible as Broadway fare. But a remarkable creative team has committed to the project, and met this week in New York to prepare for the workshop. Its members include the lighting designer Jennifer Tipton ("La Bete"); the scenery and costume designer Eiko Ishioka ("M. Butterfly"), and the sound designer Hans Peter Kuhn ("Dr. Faustus Lights the Lights"). The show is to be directed by the prolific Polish film and theater director Andrzej Wajda, and most notable of all, the script has been written by Terrence Malick.
Mr. Malick, who wrote and directed two acclaimed films, "Badlands" (1973) and "Days of Heaven" (1978), is also the author of a notable disappearing act, having been absent from creative life -- publicly, at least -- for 15 years. He has apparently been living in Texas (of late, at least), working on this script and two screenplays. All three of those projects were commissioned by Mr. Geisler and Mr. Roberdeau, whose unwillingness to speak to a reporter is likely tied to Mr. Malick's reluctance to reveal what he has been up to for a decade and a half.
"It's definitely odd," said the show's spokesman, Adrian Bryan-Brown. "I've never been involved in a situation where a producer didn't want to talk about good news."
 
Answers, but No Questions
 Then there's a show in the opposite situation: It's just about ready to open and anybody connected with it will talk, but nobody seems to be asking any questions. The show is "Cyrano," a musical version of the classic story about a woman, a man and his nose, which is set to begin previews at the Neil Simon Theater on Oct. 19.
The show is a large one: 32 actors and 20 musicians. The budget, said Peter Kulok, an American who is co-producing with a Dutchman, Joop van den Ende, is in the neighborhood of $7 million. Still, in spite of this and some rather prominent print ads the past few weeks, it seems to be the Broadway equivalent of a child throwing a tantrum and being ignored anyway. Mr. Kulok said advance sales had been better than he expected, but admitted that the numbers aren't huge: about half a million dollars, he said.
Part of the reason is that it all seems a little highbrow on the one hand and foreign on the other, two tough images with which to court a mass audience. Though the show played for nearly a year in Amsterdam, the Netherlands isn't exactly a place with a strong tradition of exporting musicals to America. And though the producers made inquiries as to the availability of some American actors to play the lead (among them were Mandy Patinkin and Terrence Mann), they will open with Bill van Dijk in a reprise of the title role that made him a star in Europe. The show is sung through. "It's operatic in style in that way," Mr. Kulok said, "though I hate to use that word because it really doesn't have that weight."
And it has been translated from Dutch into English by an Englishman, Peter Reeves. Some lyrics are now being Americanized, and others are being added, by Sheldon Harnick. Mr. van Dijk's accent -- his English is flawless but rather formal, Mr. Kulok said -- is being Americanized, too.
"We're forging new territory, no question about it," Mr. Kulok said cheerfully. He said that at capacity -- the Simon has 1,366 seats -- the show's investors, who are Dutch, would get their money back in about a year, probably a rosy assessment given the weekly cost of running such a sizable show. He added it was clear the success of the show would depend upon the critical response and word of mouth. He admits to being an optimist.
"If you're asking me what we're selling, we're trying to decide that. At the moment what we're selling is that the Cyrano story is well known, a great, classic love story. What we're selling is that we're doing a full, lush production of that story on the Broadway stage in the musical form."
 
Tribute to a Producer
 In what was certainly the most stirring theatrical experience of the week, R. Tyler Gatchell Jr. was remembered in a memorial service on Tuesday at a nearly packed Shubert Theater. Mr. Gatchell, a prolific general manager and producer long associated with the musicals of Andrew Lloyd Webber, died in July of a heart attack at 50.
He was saluted in speech and song by a variety of industry luminaries, among them Bernard B. Jacobs, president of the Shubert Organization; the advertising executive Nancy Coyne, and the performers Betty Buckley and Laurie Beechman, who sang rather heartbreaking renditions of ballads from Gatchell shows. Mr. Gatchell was remembered, with both sadness and humor, for his fastidiousness, professionalism, wit and, above all, his gift for creative problem-solving, a talent best represented by a story told by Bill Evans, a press agent who knew Mr. Gatchell for 18 years.
Mr. Evans recalled that for all his other talents, Mr. Gatchell had a black thumb, which was a particular irritation to his companion, Mark Shannon, an actor and something of a home horticulturist who got tired of returning after weeks on the road to a houseful of dead plants. Disputes ensued.
Mr. Gatchell's solution? "The day Mark left, Tyler would take photographs of all the houseplants," Mr. Evans told the assemblage at the Shubert. "Then the day before he returned, he'd race to the florist with the photos and tell the florist he had to have plants that looked exactly like the photos, delivered immediately."
 
Footlights
 *Jennifer Jason Leigh decided this week to accept a role in Sam Shepard's new play, "Simpatico," which goes into rehearsals in November for an opening, probably on Broadway, early next year. To accept the role, she declined an offer from David Rabe to appear Off broadway in his play "Those the River Keeps."
*The Ensemble Studio Theater's 13th Annual Octoberfest, a 25-night marathon of plays, musicals, readings, etc., begins on Oct. 6 at the theater's performance spaces at 549 West 52d Street. Among 80 projects to be staged is a new work by John Ford Noonan and Romulus Linney. Admission is free.

HEADLINE: City Opera Chief Takes Leave of Absence

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
Christopher Keene, the general director of the New York City Opera, told members of the company's board on Wednesday evening that he would take an immediate leave of absence to be treated for alcoholism at the Betty Ford Center in Rancho Mirage, Calif.
Mr. Keene flew to California yesterday. Susan Woelzl, the company's spokeswoman, said that there was no firm date for his return, but that he expected to be in New York to conduct the New York Philharmonic in the first week in November. 
 Mr. Keene, who conducted a performance of Sir Michael Tippett's "Midsummer Marriage" on Wednesday evening, left a statement that was read to the company's staff and musicians yesterday afternoon.
 
Pressures and Tragedies
 "During this past year, with its load of personal tragedy," Mr. Keene's statement read, referring to the deaths of several company members and personal friends, "and all the relentless pressures of the economy upon the continuing survival of our company, I have finally had to acknowledge to myself that I have developed an alcohol problem which is beyond my own control.
"The situation is not only threatening to my own health but endangering the futures of both my family and the company."
He added that "I know this is an illness which can be cured -- and I look forward to returning to you refreshed and cleansed, able to contribute my very best to solving the problems which confront us."
Mr. Keene took over the directorship of the City Opera from Beverly Sills in 1989. His first season was curtailed by a musicians' strike, and in recent seasons the company has posted operating deficits totaling about $4.5 million.
Yet Mr. Keene has been widely credited with raising the company's performance level. His departure takes him away from the company just before it celebrates its 50th anniversary with a week of world premieres, starting Oct. 6. Donald Hassard, the managing director for artistic administration, will be in charge in Mr. Keene's absence.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
COMPUTER MAKER FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
System Integrators Inc., which makes computers for newspapers and magazines, has filed for Federal bankruptcy protection. The company, based in Sacramento, Calif., said the Chapter 11 filing on Wednesday was an effort to get banks to refinance a $56 million loan at lower interest rates. "We haven't been able to get a satisfactory resolution, so we filed for Chapter 11," a company spokesman, Roger Peterson, said. "We thought that through the assistance of the court we could get a fairer hearing." The bankruptcy filing listed $30 million in assets and $81 million in liabilities. The company plans no layoffs of its 297 employees, Mr. Peterson said.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN: The Students;
Health Professionals Brace for a New Age

BYLINE: By, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
No group was listening more intently to President Clinton's appeal to the nation to adopt a sweeping program that would guarantee all Americans health insurance than the professionals in the health care fields. Mr. Clinton is proposing nothing less than an upheaval in the way one-seventh of the American economy operates. These are some of the immediate reactions to the President's speech on Wednesday night from doctors with a health maintenance organization, insurance company executives and medical students.
 
 
Marcus Welby Is Disappearing
They cheered on President Clinton for pledging to extend health insurance to all, to simplify paperwork, to crack down on malpractice lawsuits. That was all good. But for two dozen young medical students here, the President's speech on health care offered a glimpse into their own future as doctors, and many came away profoundly nervous.
"We're going to have a nation of Doc-in-the-Boxes," said 24-year-old Richard Gardner, a fourth-year student at Baylor College of Medicine here. "His idea seems to be that all doctors are going to go right into H.M.O.'s." 
 Most of the students who gathered in the medical school lounge to watch the speech on Wednesday night readily acknowledged that with or without the President's plan, the era in which both doctors and patients could enjoy a sense of intense familiarity and mutual trust was long gone. "No one gets to be Marcus Welby anymore," said Matt Kim, a third-year obstetrics student from Dallas. "Times have changed. You've just got to watch your back all the time. They'll sue you no matter what."
Still, while they hoped to hear more from the President about how his proposal might strengthen the doctor-patient relationship, many said the speech left them with an image of a giant national factory in which, even if all were served, not all could possibly be served well.
"One of my main reasons for being a doctor was I wanted to run my own clinic," said David Williams, 24, who is from a suburb of Salt Lake City and is interested in rural medicine. "I wanted do it on my own, and it sounds like he's trying to force all doctors into larger health care organizations instead of allowing any kind of entrepreneurial spirit in doctors."
Many students said they took it as a given these days that they would not make a huge amount of money as doctors. But, as one said, even the most stringent controls would probably still allow them to live "a solid upper-middle-class existence." The issue that really seemed to preoccupy them was not money anyway, but their autonomy.
"Let's face it," broke in Christopher G. Tobin, a second-year student from Wichita Falls, Tex. "A physician is the kind of personality type where we like to be in charge. We're mostly Type A's here."
A giant national health care system, many feared, would only aggravate a trend toward having to practice medicine by bureaucratic decree, whether from the government or a private insurer.
"A lot of doctors I know have to punch a timer when they go in to see a patient," said Monica Serrano, 26, of Dayton, Ohio, who wants to be a family practitioner. "You have to follow the form. If you feel you need to spend 20 minutes with this patient but the insurance company says it's only 15, that's it. And that's appalling to me. That's an appalling way to have to practice medicine."
Not surprisingly, many said their own vision for a health care system would include much more independent authority for doctors to evaluate patients and prescribe treatment, and a much more limited scope for malpractice lawsuits, but no one expressed any optimism it would really come to pass.
"Congress is filled with lawyers and how are we going to pass that through a bunch of lawyers?" Mr. Tobin said. Someone suggested that more doctors should go to Congress but Rob Cook, a third-year student in general surgery, shot back, "Nah, that would be such a waste of good medical training"
Whatever their qualms with the mechanics of Mr. Clinton's plan, all the students who discussed the speech with a reporter afterward embraced the concept of universal health insurance, which they said could free them to treat a whole range of patients without worrying about who has insurance and who does not.
"When I used to think about my future, I thought I had to make a choice," Mr. Kim said. "I had to do the Beverly Hills doc sort of thing or be at our local county hospital. There was no happy middle. But with Clinton's plan, I think there's a possibility you could help a lot of people."
Many of the students seemed genuinely moved by Mr. Clinton's portrayal of a country where no one would have to worry about affording the care of a sick child or having to stay in a job or a town simply for fear of losing their benefits. But hashing out the plan amongst themselves afterward, many said it all seemed too good to be attainable.
"There are three areas of health care," said Tracy Lyon, a second-year student from Dallas. "There's quality, there's cost and there's availability. You can't have the best of all of those three worlds. It can't be done, and that's not something the President brought up tonight. He didn't say some things the public needs to know, such as, there's going to have to be rationing. Nobody likes to use that word, nobody likes to hear it, but there's going to have to be rationing."
SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

"No one gets to be Marcus Welby anymore," one of them said. (F. Carter Smith for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN: The Insurers;
Health Professionals Brace for a New Age

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BLOOMFIELD, Conn., Sept. 22

 BODY:
No group was listening more intently to President Clinton's appeal to the nation to adopt a sweeping program that would guarantee all Americans health insurance than the professionals in the health care fields. Mr. Clinton is proposing nothing less than an upheaval in the way one-seventh of the American economy operates. These are some of the immediate reactions to the President's speech on Wednesday night from doctors with a health maintenance organization, insurance company executives and medical students.
 
 
Copious Notes On Legal Pads
There was little dread in the bright, green-carpeted employee lounge of the Cigna Corporation as executives of the insurance giant gathered here watch President Clinton's health care speech on Wednesday night.
Disagreement, yes: Lawrence P. English, the president of the company's health care unit, shook his head and grimaced at some points, and raised his hands and shrugged at other moments. And with every reference to price controls, however oblique, nearly every pen in the room leaped to attention, scribbling hostile notes on legal pads. But ultimately the insurance executives had more suggestions about fine-tuning the President's plan than fundamentally changing it. 
 "I think I have more to feel good about than there is to be concerned about," said Mr. English, who came back to the office with his wife Carol to watch the speech with colleagues in the health care unit on a small lounge TV with a fuzzy picture and rabbit ears for an antenna. "How could you not agree with the principles he has articulated?" Mr. English said.
Cigna, along with two other insurance giants -- Aetna Life & Casualty and the Travelers Corporation, both based in nearby Hartford -- are considered likely winners in the great reshuffling of the health care deck implied by Mr. Clinton's plan. All three companies, which collectively dominate much of the central Connecticut's white collar economy, have already moved aggressively into an area that the President's proposal would push even faster: managed health care. Cigna is one the largest operators of health maintenance organizations in the nation, with 2.6 million patients served by 44 plans.
Dr. W. Allen Schaffer, the national medical director for Cigna Healthcare, said he thought that Mr. Clinton's withering critique of the current health care system was five years out of date. The explosion of H.M.O.'s, he said, which now care for one in five Americans, is already achieving some of the economies of scale that is part of the President's goal.
"We're experiencing negative cost trends, actually less than inflation, in some managed health care products," Dr. Schaffer said.
Other employees were skeptical that a vast new Government bureaucracy could streamline anything, let alone medical care paperwork. They said the most up-to-date H.M.O.'s already had more ambitious goals, like getting rid of all paperwork.
"We want to get to a paperless environment," Mr. English said.
Some people said they thought that the potential costs of the plan, especially in the beginning, were underestimated by the President, and several said the speech was notable for what it omitted entirely. A managed, universal health care system, they said, would invariably create questions of rationing. For example, what levels of treatments were justified for frail, terminal or simply very old patients.
"The R-word, rationing, didn't come up," Dr. Schaffer said. "But certainly it's a component. It's a big part of the proposal."
KIRK JOHNSON

HEADLINE: Two Stock Exchanges Drop Plans to Build Complex

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
The New York and American Stock Exchanges have canceled a plan to build an enormous new trading complex and office tower on Wall Street, public and private officials familiar with the project said yesterday.
There was no immediate indication why the exchanges canceled the undertaking, as neither would comment. 
 The exchanges project would have been an economic and psychological shot in the arm for lower Manhattan's distressed real-estate market by showing that major downtown institutions had enough faith to build on a large scale. It would also have been a tangible symbol of New York City's continuing role as an international financial center.
Even in its earliest stages, however, the project had hurdles to clear, perhaps the most daunting being that the New York Stock Exchange had already spent $600 million to modernize its existing trading floor.
And it was not at all apparent where tenants would have been found to fill one million square feet of office space -- as much as in the Chrysler Building -- at a time when another 20 million square feet are available downtown.
 
Near Both Exchanges
 The complex would have been built directly across Broad Street from the New York Stock Exchange, on a block bounded by Wall Street, William Street and Exchange Place. The site is four blocks east of the American Stock Exchange, which is on Trinity Place.
At the base would have been a great boxlike structure with two 50,000-square-foot trading floors. That would have been topped by a skyscraper of some 50 stories, with more than one million square feet of space.
Much of that block is owned by J. P. Morgan & Company, whose headquarters were once on the site, at 23 Wall Street. Morgan had formed a development team for the exchanges project with the Hines Interests, Rudin Management Company and Sterling Equities. The architects were Skidmore, Owings & Merrill.
 
Many High Hopes
 No cost estimates were ever released, nor had it been settled how much the city's Economic Development Corporation would have pumped into the project.
The Dinkins administration had pinned high hopes on the project, as had local business interests.
"We're very disappointed," said Dr. Barbara L. Christen, president of the Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association.
"We had been very hopeful that it would have come to pass," she said. "We saw it as having much the same effect on lower Manhattan as Chase Manhattan Plaza had in the late 50's and early 60's." That tower was the first major project after a long hiatus following World War II, when downtown lost much of its ground to mid-Manhattan.
John H. Alschuler Jr., a partner in the real-estate firm of H. R. & A. and a consultant on the exchanges project, said: "Lower Manhattan needs to be redeveloped. The redevelopment process means the recycling of obsolete space and the creation of new and viable opportunities for tenants.
"The exchanges project would have been a catalyst on the order of Chase or Battery Park City and would have been a symbol for the revitalization of the core of lower Manhattan, which is where the significant problems lie."
Despite the loss of the exchanges project, Dr. Christen said several things contributed to her optimism about the future. One is the impending release by Mayor David N. Dinkins of new planning guidelines for the area. Another is the possible development of a downtown business improvement district.
"Lower Manhattan has tremendous potential," she said. "We have 20 million square feet of vacant office space but we also have 90 million square feet of occupied office space."
About the site itself, a spokesman for Morgan said, without elaboration, that the company "plans to evaluate alternatives."

HEADLINE: TRANSITION IN AFRICA;
Mandela Calls to an End to Sanctions

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Proclaiming that "the countdown to democracy in South Africa has begun," Nelson Mandela called today for the lifting of all remaining economic sanctions against his country.
Almost instantly, governments and cities, including New York, initiated measures to end the years-old sanctions, which have been maintained despite a steady erosion of the racial separation policies known as apartheid. The call by the leader of the African National Congress, made here the day after South Africa's Parliament adopted a package of laws giving blacks their first say in the country's Government, is expected to eventually revive investment in South Africa.
 
'Stability and Social Progress'
 "To strengthen the forces of democratic change, and to help create the necessary conditions for stability and social progress," Mr. Mandela told the the United Nations Special Committee Against Apartheid, "we believe that the time has come when the international community should lift all economic sanctions against South Africa." [Excerpt from the speech, page 5.] 
 South Africa's President, F. W. de Klerk, who made his first appearance at the United Nations on Thursday, endorsed the call by Mr. Mandela.
"I have always been of the opinion that the A.N.C. should have taken this decision sooner," President de Klerk told The Associated Press. "I am glad now that they have come on board. The sanctions harmed the interests of all those in South Africa."
 
Influence of Violence
 Although almost all American Federal sanctions against South Africa were lifted by President Bush in 1991, remaining restrictions prohibited lending by the Export-Import Bank to companies operating in South Africa and required the United States to vote against loans to South Africa by international lending agencies.
Officials in Washington and the rest of the country acted quickly to remove economic and trade sanctions against the Pretoria Government. But experts warned against any expectations of an immediate flood of capital into South Africa, in part because of the continuing political violence there. [Page 5.]
In addition, about a hundred American cities and 27 states still enforce various financial measures against South Africa and firms doing business there, including California, Massachusetts, Illinois and Florida as well as Los Angeles, Miami and Chicago.
Pension systems, endowments for colleges and universities and other funds with assets totaling $300 billion do not put money into South Africa or into gold mines and other companies doing business there, according to calculations by the Africa Fund, based in New York. Most major banks in the United States also do not extend credit to South African businesses.
Unaffected by Mr. Mandela's appeal to lift economic sanctions, however, is the 1977 mandatory Security Council embargo on the sale of weapons to South Africa. This led South Africa to develop an arms industry of its own and become an important exporter.
Mr. Mandela also left it up to the General Assembly to decide whether to repeal an ineffective voluntary embargo on oil deliveries to South Africa that was adopted in 1986.
He urged nations that do not have diplomatic ties with Pretoria to establish them. But he said they should treat the Transitional Executive Council, established by Parliament on Thursday as the vehicle for black majority rule, as the true representative of all the peoples of South Africa, rather than the current Government.
Mr. Mandela stressed that lifting sanctions would allow new investment to flow into South Africa, whose economy is mired in recession and unemployment, as companies that withdrew in protest against apartheid start doing business there again and as new investors enter the market.
 
De Klerk Meets Executives
 Echoing that hope, President de Klerk met in New York with 50 American business executives at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. People in the audience said later that he had been received "very positively," as one put it, but many remained cautious about investment out of fear that the transition to majority rule might be disrupted by violence or other problems.
Mr. Mandela's appeal today is also expected to lead to the repeal of a 1992 nonbinding General Assembly resolution urging governments, private banks, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund not to advance new credit to South Africa, an action that crimped that country's ability to raise international loans.
Noting that millions of South Africans "have no food, no jobs, no homes" Mr. Mandela said South Africa needs "a massive injection of funds" to prevent its recession from getting worse, to halt the spiraling rise in crime and violence that threatens to undermine its move toward democracy and to prevent the country from becoming "another Somalia or a Bosnia."
Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York accompanied Mr. Mandela to the United Nations and said at a joint news conference that he had already acted to reverse city rules that restrict relations with South Africa. These include ordinances barring pension funds from investing in companies doing business with South Africa and giving preference in awarding city contracts to firms that have no South African ties.
"New York City, a world leader in implementing and upholding sanctions against South Africa, is now ready to unlock those economic chains," said Mr. Dinkins, who added that he had written to the United States Conference of Mayors to urge civic leaders to repeal similar laws and ordinances that discourage business dealings with South Africa or stop pension and college endowment funds or foundations from investing there.
 
Commonwealth Ends Sanctions
 Meeting in Nassau, capital of the Bahamas, Finance Ministers of the 50 Commonwealth nations announced the immediate lifting of all trade, investment and financial sanctions that they have imposed against South Africa.
"The lifting of these sanctions confirms the beginning of a new relationship between the Commonwealth and South Africa, a country that is now irreversibly committed to joining the community of democratic nations," said Eleazar Chukwuemeka (Emeka) Anyaoku of Nigeria, the Commonwealth Secretary General.
At the news conference, Mr. Mandela sought to reassure foreign investors, saying they had nothing to fear from a majority government and stressing that his African National Congress was no longer committed to nationalizing South Africa's mining industry. Foreign investors would be allowed to repatriate profits and dividends, he said.
Mr. Mandela also appeared to confirm reports the Congress had been holding secret talks with right-wing Afrikaaners about their demand for a semiautonomous white homeland in South Africa after majority rule.
Although he called their fears "baseless," he acknowledged that they were "real" and said that the congress must "address these fears realistically and seriously." While rejecting what he called "an ethnic solution," he said he could imagine a compromise based on "the basic demand of a people wanting a particular region in which to run their affairs." The Afrikaaners have been seeking about 16 percent of South Africa for themselves, mostly in the Transvaal and Orange Free State.
In his address to a meeting of the United Nations Special Committee Against Apartheid, held in the huge General Assembly hall here, Mr. Mandela, who received a standing ovation as he entered, said that with Thursday's Parliamentary vote, South Africa had turned its back on white-minority rule and was now heading irreversibly toward democracy.
While he said sanctions had helped bring about this change, he made clear that his first concern was with the country's fast deteriorating economy and the rising tide of violence.
"The apartheid system has left a swath of disaster in its trail," Mr. Mandela said. "We have an economy that is tottering on the brink of an even deeper recession than the one we are experiencing. What this means practically is that millions of people have no food, no jobs, no homes."

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH CARE PLAN: White House Memo;
On Health, Clinton Finds Heaven Is in the Details

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 24

 BODY:
Before ABC News's "town hall" on health care went on the air Thursday night, Ted Koppel came out to instruct the audience on the pace of live television.
The "Nightline" host told those in the crowd in the Tampa Bay Performing Arts Center to keep their questions for President Clinton "pithy and to the point." 
 Not one to mince words, even with a President, Mr. Koppel gave Mr. Clinton the same instructions, telling him to "zip" right along.
Mr. Clinton nodded sympathetically, as he is wont to do, and then unleashed two and a half hours worth of highly detailed "first, secondly" and "let me just add this" and "I want to make this very clear" and "Can I say one thing real quick?" and "I would like to amend that answer" answers about his health care plan.
 
Putting Me First
 If health care is an issue that everyone in the country wants explained individually -- What about my acupuncture bills? My aunt's lumbago? My massage therapy clients? My husband's favorite chiropractor? My protection against malpractice suits? My pharmacy's problems with drug manufacturers? -- this is a President who is willing, nay, eager to do it.
"Bulimia?" he repeated after an elegant red-haired woman who had pushed up to the stage after the program. "That'll be covered."
The President had promised to stay as long as anyone had a question -- a promise that alarmed his staff members, who envisioned the policy equivalent of the dance-marathon movie, "They Shoot Horses, Don't They?"
"Do you want a Xanax?" asked Robert Boorstin, a White House health policy aide, jokingly offering a tablet of the anti-anxiety medication to a reporter who planned to stay up as long as the President.
Other Presidents would have retreated to a majestic distance after introducing the plan with a masterly speech to Congress: Float above the fray. Let the public absorb the general idea while the Administration experts fanned out to explain the tricky, politically thorny details. Preserve political capital.
Not this President. He did not wait a day, after his dignified, well-received speech on Wednesday night, to return to his cherished role as a chatty national talk show host. Although Ira Magaziner, the chief White House adviser on health care, was seated on the aisle of the fourth row so that he could field the questions that were too technical for Mr. Clinton, the President never called on him for help.
"It's the most personal, specific issue in the world," said Mandy Grunwald, a media adviser to the President who helped set up the program. "Why shouldn't he be the one to educate people and reassure them about their fears?"
 
Presidential Gratification
 And, in an insight into the gratification Mr. Clinton draws from this kind of format -- the same enjoyment George Bush got from the freewheeling news conferences that showed he was more a master of details than Ronald Reagan -- she added, "I don't know of any other President who could have answered those questions about his own policy."
Mr. Clinton is supremely confident in this sort of setting, although Mr. Koppel lost patience with the torrent of words at one point and complained that the President was being glib to the point of obfuscation.
As the President was giving a long, politically careful answer to a woman who opposed the prospect of her health care payments' going into a common fund that could be used to pay for abortions, Mr. Koppel interjected, saying, "Mr. President, this is a curious criticism to make, but sometimes I think you're so specific in your answers or so detailed in your answers that it's a little hard to know what the answer to the question was."
Mr. Clinton looked cross in reply, his mouth like the rim of a purse snapped suddenly shut, just as he did at another moment when he was tossing around remarks about things that would be covered in the year 1996 or 2000 and the moderator drily noted: "There's a little thing called 're-election' that has to kick in before you can be sure that you're going to be able to continue doing these things into a second term."
As Mr. Koppel looked on bemusedly, the increasingly hoarse President continued to take questions from people in the front rows during commercial breaks, even though his microphone was turned off -- making him look, from the rear of the hall, like a gesticulating figure on a television set when the mute button is on.
When Mr. Koppel interrupted a long story by a questioner with AIDS, trying to speed up the man, Mr. Clinton jumped in breathlessly, like a high school contestant on "It's Academic."
"I know the question," the President proclaimed, proceeding to ask the question he felt the man was working up to, about Medicaid coverage of AIDS patients, and then answering it at some length.
Long after Mr. Koppel, who had a bad cold and kept checking his watch, looked as if he was ready to be on his way, Mr. Clinton was still eagerly scanning the crowd for questioners and jumping up from his black leather swivel chair to get a little roving room while he talked.
He was deeply involved now in explaining things about long-term care benefits and basic benefits, and about model forms for doctors, variations on the model forms and variations on the variations -- all intended to elucidate a plan that is supposed to simplify the process of getting health care.
Mr. Clinton was live from 10 P.M. to 11 P.M. in the "town hall" portion of the program; then the network began taping the questions and answers for more than an hour of broadcasting on "Nightline."
He continued to take questions from people who crowded around the stage for another 20 minutes after ABC News finally pulled the plug on the program at 12:15 A.M. Mr. Koppel said that was at the suggestion of White House aides who were worried that Mr. Clinton needed his rest.
But he ignored his advisers, David R. Gergen and Mandy Grunwald, and his personal aides, Andrew Friendly and Wendy Smith, who surrounded him like sheepdogs and, tugging and nudging, tried to herd him off the stage.
At one point, at 12:30 A.M., the usually smooth Mr. Gergen started to look a little desperate when the President stopped talking about anorexia and got into an argument about the North American Free Trade Agreement. "Prove it!" he challenged a man who had yelled the Ross Perot argument at him that Nafta would cost American jobs. Then he began reeling off trade statistics and environmental data.
 
He Knew About Cobra
 The President paid no attention to the ABC technician who reached under his jacket and took off his microphone. He was busy with a question from a woman who had lost her job and was worried about transitional health insurance.
"That's the problem with Cobra," Mr. Clinton told the woman, easily using the acronym for the Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1986, which concerns people who lose insurance coverage when they lose or leave their jobs.
Renata Major walked away impressed. "He knew what Cobra was right away," she said. "He told me I asked an excellent question."
Of course, with this President -- who subscribes to that famous Dashiell Hammett line from "The Maltese Falcon" that "talking's something you can't do judiciously unless you keep in practice" -- just about any question is an excellent question.
By 12:35 A.M., Mr. Gergen had coaxed Mr. Clinton over to the edge of the stage, close enough where they could actually pull him backstage without too much effort.
 
Looking for More Converts
 But Mr. Clinton was still looking longingly at the crowd, hoping to win a few more converts. His hoarse voice could be heard fading in and out on dozens of different aspects of the plan:
"That's the problem with health centers in rural towns. . . . If you had a heart attack tonight? No. . . . Lifetime limits to the policy, the thing can turn out to be a real trap. . . . To my knowledge, the F.D.A. approved the drug. . . . We're in the process of redesigning the entire unemployment system, so there's a whole lot of these things that have to be readjusted because the nature of unemployment is different."
With one last tug from his advisers, the President was finally backstage. But it did not stop there. He went up to his health care advisers, Mr. Magaziner and Christine Heenan, wanting to go over various points he had made. "Now, was I right about this?" he asked them.
Laughing that it took "hours" to get the President off stage, Mr. Gergen said, "I told him if we stayed a little longer we could just go straight into 'Good Morning America' with Charlie Gibson."
