HEADLINE: Think Nationally, Stump Locally: Democrats Move to Dinkins's Aid

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
The White House and the national Democratic Party, increasingly worried about Mayor David N. Dinkins's prospects for re-election, are organizing a series of efforts to help his campaign, capped by a visit from President Clinton on Sunday to help the Mayor raise a million dollars.
A Presidential appearance to raise money in a mayoral race, even one as important as New York's, is unusual enough. But the White House is not stopping there -- it is dispatching Vice President Al Gore and several Cabinet members to the city to campaign for Mr. Dinkins and sending money to help the state party get people to the polls. 
 The reasons are both narrowly tactical and more broadly strategic. Although the New York mayoral race, with its many local issues, is far from a referendum on national Democratic urban policy, the Democrats are concerned that their troubles are spreading and that a Dinkins loss would only make it harder to rescue their image as the voice of the inner cities.
 
Stunned in Los Angeles
 The Democratic Party was stunned by the election last spring of Richard J. Riordan as Los Angeles's first Republican Mayor in 36 years, and party officials feared that it sprang from a perception that the party has nothing to offer to solve inner-city problems like racism and poverty.
Democrats here are even more nervous that the election of a Republican Mayor in a Democratic stronghold like New York would complicate Mr. Clinton's re-election campaign in three years. "We'd rather be running in '96 with a Democratic mayor than a Republican mayor," said Joan N. Baggett, the White House political director.
The efforts on behalf of Mr. Dinkins address immediate political concerns, but do nothing about the broader issue of devising concrete answers to the cities' problems. Nor do they provide what Mr. Dinkins would probably find most beneficial: Federal money that he has lobbied for but never received as the Clinton Administration put other priorities ahead of urban aid.
Mr. Clinton's visit comes at a crucial moment for the Mayor's campaign coffers as Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate, has outpaced the Mayor by better than 2-to-1 in fund raising in recent weeks.
"There's a lot riding on it." said David Wilhelm, chairman of the Democratic National Committee. "We're going to do whatever we can to help win what promises to be a very close race."
Where the Democrats see danger, the Republicans see political opportunity. Because the New York campaign is so tightly contested, and because there are few other elections of national interest this year, the Republican Party is also giving the race unusual attention, sending party leaders to stump for Mr. Giuliani.
White House officials said the decision by Mr. Clinton to appear with Mr. Dinkins shows the depth of his commitment in the face of polls that suggest a difficult race for Mr. Dinkins. The officials said it was decided that the potential payoff to the Mayor and to the party of a high-profile appearance by Mr. Clinton outweighed the risks of his alienating the white ethnic Democrats who do not support Mr. Dinkins, as well as the embarrassment if the Mayor loses.
 
Closer Ties to Dinkins
 By contrast, only after much internal debate did Mr. Clinton appear briefly at a news conference in Los Angeles last spring with Michael Woo, the Democrat who ran against Mr. Riordan in what was officially a nonpartisan race. One reason Mr. Clinton did not give more than a lukewarm endorsement was that some of his top advisers were friends of Mr. Riordan. Both Mr. Clinton and several of his aides have closer ties to Mr. Dinkins.
Presidents hardly ever deliver local elections, and most New Yorkers are certain to base their votes on their views of Mr. Dinkins's performance in office, something much closer and more tangible than a visit from Washington.
But as the Dinkins campaign is struggling to keep Democrats from defecting to Mr. Giuliani, the President's support could make a difference by dramatizing the Mayor's ties to the White House.
"I think the connection between a Democratic Mayor and a Democratic President is a very persuasive argument to vote for David Dinkins," said Harold M. Ickes, a New York lawyer who is a close adviser both to Mr. Clinton and to Mr. Dinkins. "The fact that the President is committed to helping the Mayor sends a strong message to New Yorkers that there will continue to be a good working relationship between Washington and New York City."
The President's visit, especially after a week when he drew positive reviews from his health-care speech to Congress, is certain to draw much-needed favorable publicity for Mr. Dinkins.
But the Democrats' ability to help in more tangible -- that is, financial -- ways is hampered by several factors, among them election laws that limit the amount that national parties may funnel to local races. On a larger scale, Mr. Clinton lacks the traditional ability of some past presidents to woo voters by funneling Government resources to the city or some other favored constituency because of the tight budget in Washington and the Congressional defeat of the Administration's economic stimulus package.
But despite these limits, Mr. Ickes said that the Clinton Administration is scrambling to find ways to send Federal help to New York City. "The City Hall people are working with various Cabinet departments to get some dollars into New York," he said. "If we lost New York to the Republicans, obviously it would be disturbing."
Another fear among Democratic officials is that a Dinkins defeat would suggest that Mr. Clinton lacks leverage in local races, giving Republicans a boost in recruiting candidates to run next year in elections around the country.
Citing not only Los Angeles, but also the election in May of Mayor Bret Schundler in Jersey City, the city's first Republican Mayor since 1917, Republicans are trying to portray the New York race as part of a pattern and thus a high-stakes urban referendum on Mr. Clinton and the Democrats.
"Rudy Giuliani's election would be another powerful demonstration that Republican ideas will sell in the big cities," said Haley Barbour, chairman of the Republican National Committee. "People are looking for alternatives to the big government, high-tax Democrat administrations that have been controlling these cities."
Although the Administration is limited in the Federal money it can dispense for New York, there are other ways it can try to help Mr. Dinkins. Some Republicans have suggested that Attorney General Janet Reno had sought to protect Mr. Dinkins by putting off an expected announcement that her agency would not prosecute civil-rights violations in the Crown Heights disturbances. The Justice Department denied any political motivation.
 
Looking to 1996
 While Democratic officials speak of the need for a Democratic mayor who is in sync with Mr. Clinton's agenda, the President has more pragmatic reasons for wanting Mr. Dinkins to hold on to his job: Winning New York was crucial to Mr. Clinton's campaign last year. Though issues like the economy and health care will likely determine Mr. Clinton's popularity in New York, the last thing he wants is a Mayor who actively works against his re-election, forcing him to spend time and resources securing what should be a secure Democratic base.

HEADLINE: White House Scraps Welfare Rule Change

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration retreated today from a plan to relax work requirements for thousands of married parents on welfare after lawmakers angrily objected to the change.
The Administration's plan would have allowed welfare recipients from two-parent families to spend as few as eight hours a week on the job, instead of the 16 hours Congress required when it passed the law in 1988. 
 The change had been announced in a Sept. 21 memorandum to state welfare agencies in advance of the Oct. 1 deadline for finding jobs or training for as many as 120,000 unemployed parents.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, accused the Administration of weakening the work requirements while promising to force recipients to take a job after two years on the rolls.
The Administration had argued that the changes would have given states flexibility to design programs to help participants find permanent jobs.

HEADLINE: Japan's Premier Stands Firm on Trade

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Preparing for his first visit to the United States since taking office, Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa suggested today that despite sweeping changes he was seeking in his country's political and economic systems, Japan would continue to take a hard line on trade disputes with Washington.
Two months after ousting Japan's aging and corrupt leadership in elections, Mr. Hosokawa said that he and his Cabinet were leading "a revolution in peacetime" in Japan, but he staked out a position showing that his Government would take much the same approach as past Governments on closing the trade surplus. 
 In a wide-ranging discussion tonight with a group of American correspondents, the 55-year-old leader of the Japan New Party still seemed a bit surprised to find himself in the Prime Minister's residence.
 
Plans for Major Changes
 In sharp contrast to his predecessors, the leaders of the Liberal Democratic Party, whose 38-year control of the country ended in scandal and a party revolt, Mr. Hosokawa talked at length about his plans to use his office to "break the collusion between politics, the bureaucratic system, business and industry."
Mr. Hosokawa said he was following three simultaneous paths to "the restructuring of Japan": political reform, economic reform -- including a review of the country's budgeting and tax system -- and deregulation. "All these reforms will see their direction by the end of this year," he said. "That is the time limit that has been set."
But on the issue of trade, he dismissed the thought that governments could mandate an end to trade surpluses with targets for exports and imports, as demanded by Washington, saying that the huge trade surpluses Japan had run up with the United States "are the natural outcome of free market activities" rather than any mercantilist Japanese policies.
In his meeting with President Clinton, scheduled for Monday in New York, Mr. Hosokawa said he would continue to voice Japan's opposition to any use of "numerical targets," which the United States has been seeking.
Later, though, he said he had a commitment to "reduce the surplus in a significant manner" by improving American access to the Japanese market and reviving the moribund economy here, which he said the other day was in a state of emergency.
 
Calls for Efforts by Clinton
 He placed an equal burden on Mr. Clinton, saying the United States "would be expected to make various efforts," including increasing industrial competitiveness, boosting the savings rate and reducing the budget deficit. Past Japanese Governments have made identical demands.
Mr. Hosokawa argued that the changes he was trying to bring about, including a broad deregulation of Japanese industry, would accomplish many of the goals the United States sought. "I have to explain to President Clinton," he said, "that what I am trying to do will take time to bring about."
Over the last few weeks Mr. Hosokawa, while enjoying popularity ratings over 70 percent, has often been accused of letting his oratory overstep his action. And today he was relatively unspecific about many of the details of his plans.
Looking relaxed and clearly enjoying the chance to talk about how he had shaken the political establishment here, Mr. Hosokawa said he had used one of his first official appearances to apologize for Japan's atrocities during World War II because "unless we do this, we will not be able to make a fresh start" with Japan's neighbors in Asia.
Many have speculated that Mr. Hosokawa's comments would make it easier for Japan to claim a place on the United Nations Security Council, a move the United States has endorsed.
But to the dismay of many bureaucrats here, including those in the Foreign Ministry, Mr. Hosokawa has been reluctant to press the issue. He said today that his country was "in neither active pursuit nor lukewarm retreat" on the matter.
 
Ready for a Larger Role
 Mr. Hosokawa made it clear, though, that while Japan was concerned that its "peace Constitution" -- with its sharp limits on the actions of the military -- could come into conflict with its responsibilities under the United Nations Charter, the country was ready to take the leap.
He also denounced North Korea, saying its growing arsenal of missiles and its attempt to build nuclear weapons were definitely "a threat to our country." Although he said he was interested in building a "defensive shield" to protect Japan, he stopped short of endorsing a proposal made by the United States this week for an elaborate, American-designed missile defense system. But he said the proposal "would be a matter of interest to us."
A descendant of one of Japan's leading samurai families that ruled southern Japan for centuries, Mr. Hosokawa sees his rise to power on a reform platform in a broad historic context.
"In the modern history of Japan, there were three instances of major change," he said. "One was the visit by Commodore Perry, and the ensuing Meiji Restoration," he said, referring to the era in the 1860's when the United States forced the opening of Japan and with it helped speed the downfall of the feudal regime. "The second major change was the end of World War II" and the American Occupation, he said.
But both of those changes "were induced by gaiatsu," he said using the Japanese word for external pressure. "Whereas this time around, for the first time in the modern history of this country, the major change is being generated from inside. This by itself, I believe, is a remarkable thing, almost revolutionary."

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN;
A Cure for Paperwork, Or Just New Headaches?

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
President Clinton's promise to cut the mounting paperwork clogging the American health system will be welcomed by consumers befuddled by complex benefit forms. And it could save a great deal of money for doctors and hospital administrators who have to employ staffs to cope with the bewildering range of forms and requirements imposed by insurers.
But at the same time, critics are asking whether Mr. Clinton's proposed new layers of state and Federal agencies will simply replace one set of costly bureaucratic headaches with another. 
 Under the Clinton plan, hundreds of existing insurance forms would be replaced by a single simplified claim sheet for both doctors and patients. And because standardized benefits packages would replace the widely varying benefits now offered by insurers, consumers would find it easier to compare plans, and doctors and hospitals would save billions now spent paying administrators to decipher what is covered under each patient's policy.
But even if the Clinton plan makes life simpler and less expensive in these ways, a range of health care experts are asking just how much huge new Federal and state agencies and boards will cost, and whether they will simply create more red tape for consumers, doctors, hospitals and businesses.
 
Specter of Monster Agencies
 "There is a tremendous potential for this to become highly bureaucratic and highly regulatory," said Uwe E. Reinhardt, a professor of political economy at Princeton University. "The kind of people who run the department of motor vehicles would be the kind of people who would staff the alliances. Who else would staff it?"
Under the Clinton plan, most people and companies would buy health insurance through large regional alliances that would represent perhaps a million consumers or, in big cities, even more. These alliances, set up by state governments, would determine which medical groups and insurers could offer health plans to the public and how much they could charge. They would collect and distribute most insurance premiums and collect and publicize data on the performance of health plans.
Because these alliances are charged with so many responsibilities, critics say they could grow into monsters that would be unresponsive to consumers' problems and become the focus of a new industry for lobbyists and regulatory consultants. The result, they say, is that overall savings in administration may not be as great as the President hopes.
"In the end, I frankly don't think it will simplify things at all," said Joseph A. Califano Jr., a domestic policy aide under President Lyndon B. Johnson and Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare under President Jimmy Carter.
 
Staffs of Paper Shufflers
 Still, everyone agrees that paperwork and duplication plague the current system, and some of the Clinton proposals are widely cheered.
Large hospitals now employ entire departments of highly specialized workers just to determine what each patient's insurance policy covers, what information each insurer demands, whether a second or third type of insurance may supplement the patient's primary coverage, and how to redistribute the costs of the uninsured among the bills of insured patients.
In his speech, the President cited the example of Washington Children's Hospital, saying it spent $2 million a year filling out unnecessary forms. If doctors and other medical providers were freed of that paperwork, he said, the hospital could treat 10,000 more children a year.
 
20 Hours a Week on Paperwork
 Medical groups say that many private offices have also been forced to hire administrative staffs to handle forms, and that some doctors spend more than 20 hours a week on paperwork.
The White House estimates that administrative costs account for at least 15 cents of every dollar paid to insurance companies in premiums. The Clinton plan, would cut four to six cents in current administrative costs, an Administration officials say. The new alliances and other new administrative costs would add about 2.5 cents in costs, they say, for a net reduction of between 1.5 cents and 3.5 cents for each dollar spent on health care.
"If you are familiar with the incredible disorder now, you know that things can be better," said Paul Starr, one of the President's advisers on health care. "This plan will be a huge help to small businesses and to consumers."
The White House contends that the Clinton plan would simplify things in several ways.
In addition to the standardized benefit packages and streamlined claims forms, the Administration hopes that employers will no longer need to employ health benefits specialists or pay health insurance agents and brokers to find their employees the best health plans. That would be left to the alliances and the employees themselves.
 
'Major New Bureaucracy'
 The White House also says the Clinton plan would simplify Federal regulations on Medicare and Medicaid and cut bureaucracy by merging the medical benefits of workers compensation and automobile insurance policies with the health plan's coverage.
Mr. Starr said consumers would be safeguarded by the requirement that the alliance's boards include equal numbers of representatives of employers, consumers, the self-employed and other covered groups.
The alliance boards would not include people associated with health care providers, law firms involved with health care, pharmaceutical companies or suppliers of medical equipment and services.
But a number of health economists and public policy specialists say the plan could create bureaucracies that would be at least as expensive as those in the current system. Their concerns center on the alliances.
"I am not sure there is going to be that much savings," said Patricia M. Danzon, a professor at the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania who has studied the administrative costs of health care in Canada and the United States. "It all adds up to a major new bureaucracy that is duplicating functions that today are being performed elsewhere in the system."
Experts predict many alliances will collect and distribute more money than the governments of the states in which they operate.
 
Spawning New Lobbies
 Professor Reinhardt said he feared that in cases where consumers find that the alliance has an incorrect address or Social Security number, they might face civil servants who are even less responsive than workers at large insurance companies. To compound the problem, the consumer would no longer have a company benefits manager to argue his or her case.
Mark Pauly, the chairman of health care systems at the Wharton School, said another cost to society of the Clinton plan would be new industries of lobbyists and consultants who specialize in guiding their clients through the various alliances in each state or through dealings with a new Federal entity, the National Health Board, which will oversee the state alliances.
When the states established a comparatively modest process in the 1970's -- requiring certificates of need for hospitals that wanted to expand or reduce their services -- they found they needed to hire teams of experts to help them through the regulatory process.
Mr. Califano said he, too, feared that boards of alliances, which could be appointed by a governor, might become a major source of patronage. In addition, he said, powerful lobbies in Washington and state capitals might protect their clients' profits by preventing crackdowns on excessive costs.
"Most large companies would have a lab test provided by the lowest bidder, for example," Mr. Califano said. "Attempts to do the same thing with Medicare were repeatedly stymied by Congress. Those are the kinds of things that are quick to do in the private sector and are hard to accomplish in the public system."

Tony Parks filed papers at DeKalb General Hospital yesterday in Decatur, Ga., where on a busy day the stack of bills is three feet tall. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

 The Economy
The Federal Reserve decided against any move to raise interest rates last month because economic growth was sluggish and inflation was abating. Most economists say they believe the Fed embraced a similar neutral stance this week. President Clinton reaffirmed the central bank's independence, saying he opposed nominating the heads of the Fed's 12 district banks. [Page 37.]
The Administration's nominee to head the agency in charge of cleaning up bankrupt failed savings and loans, Stanley Tate, has been waiting since July for a Senate vote on his nomination. He says the delay is prolonging problems at the Resolution Trust Corporation. [37.]
Orders for big-ticket items like cars and computers rose in August for the second time in three months, advancing 2 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $131.2 billion in August. [45.]
 
Companies
Pressure is mounting on Paramount's board to consider QVC Inc's $9.9 billion offer at Monday morning's special board meeting, because it could be worth far more than Viacom's bid, which has tumbled in value to $7.8 billion from its initial $8.2 billion. [37.]
General Motors is headed toward employing only 200,000 hourly workers, down from 265,000 now, but a deadline of 1996 seems too early for either G.M. or the U.A.W. [37.]
An Apple Computer executive was laid off and sued the company. Albert A. Eisenstat, executive vice president, had been in charge of Apple's legal affairs. [39.]
Oracle Systems agreed to pay a Federal fine of $100,000 to settle an S.E.C. complaint accusing it of accounting irregularities. The software design company did not admit wrongdoing. [39.]
 
 International
A Federal appeals court removed a large obstacle from President Clinton's effort to pass the North American Free Trade Agreement, deciding the pact could be submitted to Congress without an environmental impact statement. [1.]
OPEC ministers are considering how to push up prices in the midst of their worst crisis in seven years, with prices around $17 a barrel -- equal to the price 20 years ago, adjusted for inflation. [45.]
Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. chose George Bull chief executive, succeeding Sir Allen Sheppard, who remains chairman. [39.]
 
Markets
The New York and American stock exchanges canceled a plan to build an enormous new trading complex and office tower on Wall Street, officials familiar with the project said. [25.]
Nasdaq shares sold short and not yet covered rose to another record high in the latest month. [49.]
The stock market's worst week since February ended with a whimper, as most market indicators were flat or up only modestly. The Dow average lost 70.14 points for the week. [38.]
Treasury bond prices rose on the Fed's neutral stance. The 30-year Treasury bond rose 13/32 of a point. [46.]
Coffee futures prices settled above the key level of 80 cents a pound as the new Association of Coffee Producing Countries made a bid to shore up the market by withholding a portion of beans. [48.]
The dollar slipped against the German mark and other European currencies. Gold prices also retreated. [48.]
 
Your Money
The level of health insurance proposed by President Clinton is more generous than most Americans now have. But people who work for large corporations that provide a wealth of benefits at low cost could eventually see their benefits dwindle. [35.]
Wireless cable partnerships are being promoted, but whatever the lure of technology deals, there are no guarantees. Allen R. Myerson: Investing. [35.]
Asset allocation funds are the latest mutual fund offerings, and experts caution buyers should check managers' credentials. [35.]

HEADLINE: Stocks End a Bad Week On a Mostly Flat Note

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
The stock market's worst week since February ended yesterday not with a bang but a whimper, as most market indicators were flat or up only modestly in slow trading.
The Dow Jones industrial average lost 70.14 points for the week -- after losses of 37.45 points on Monday and then 38.56 points on Tuesday -- to give the Dow its worst loss in points since the trading week that ended on Feb. 19, the week President Clinton's budget plans sent the market down 70.25 points. 
 But yesterday, the early Yom Kippur weekend and the exhaustion from a tough week left the Dow Jones industrials to close up a modest 3.36 points, at 3,543.11, on volume of 248.3 million shares, down from 275.4 million shares on Thursday. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 index finished at 457.63, down 0.11 point.
 
 
Another Nasdaq Record
 The Nasdaq composite index closed up 2.39 points at 754.65, the second consecutive record high.
While events in Russia were part of the reason for Tuesday's big selloff, the situation there yesterday had little discernible effect on the market. The bond market posted gains on a mildly positive economic report, the Commerce Department's announcement that August durable goods orders were up 2 percent, the third increase in seven months and a better gain than most economists had foreseen.
The durable-goods report appeared to have also brought some strength to blue-chip stocks. Among the best performers in the Dow Jones industrial group were Exxon, up 1, to 65 1/2; Caterpillar, up 1 1/8, to 78 1/8, and American Express, up 7/8, to 35 3/4.
Deere was up 2 1/2 at 70 1/8 on a report of an increased earnings forecast. Procter & Gamble rose 7/8, to 47 1/4, on an upgrading from Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Some television networks did well yesterday, with CBS closing up 8 1/2 at 274 and Capital Cities/ABC up 22 1/8, to 571, after the Clinton Administration said it would help broadcasters in their efforts to own and syndicate reruns of prime-time television shows.
Andrea Electronics, which is working on noise-reducing technology, closed down 1 7/8 at 30 7/8. Andrea had gained about 10 points in the last week before its sudden drop.
Integrated Circuit Systems advanced 2, to 17 3/4, on an upgrade from Alex. Brown & Sons.
 
 
Perrigo Plunges
 Perrigo, a maker of over-the-counter drugs and health care products, got a lower rating from Oppenheimer & Company, the day after shareholders filed a plan to sell 13 million shares. The stock plunged 4 1/2, to 29 1/4.
Amgen, the biotechnology company, was downgraded by Merrill Lynch. The stock fell 1 7/8, to 39 3/4.
Autoimmune, which makes a drug for rheumatoid arthritis, gained 2 3/8, to 9, when a study found that the drug helped ease symptoms of the disease.
BEI Holdings, an asset management company, closed up 2, to 6 1/2, when it agreed to a merger.
In Tokyo yesterday, Japanese stocks rose in slow trading. The Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 132.91 points, to 20,307.53. For the week, the Nikkei lost 83.51 points.

HEADLINE: TRANSITION IN AFRICA;
American Culture (and Goods) Thrive in South Africa

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Sitting in a Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurant, sipping Coca-Cola and listening to a Whitney Houston tape, Gift Neku does not seem like a man starved for Americana.
Indeed, after years of anti-apartheid sanctions -- and, in a perverse way, because of them -- South Africa is a country awash in American consumer goods, colonized by American pop culture, and obsessed with American celebrities. 
 About the only important thing missing is American capital, and that is what Mr. Neku, a 23-year-old black student, hopes will flow as a result of Nelson Mandela's urging for the end of sanctions against his country.
Investment, jobs and prosperity, not Big Macs, Chevys and "Sesame Street," are the bounty Mr. Mandela must deliver, black and white South Africans say.
 
Optimism on the Street
 Although economists have warned that foreign investors will return only warily to a country they see as violently unpredictable, at street level hopes are running high.
"Everyone is just waiting for sanctions to be lifted," said Shabier Samrod, describing the excitement among businessmen who are clients of his burglar-alarm company. "You'll see a lot of investment. You'll find unemployment going down now."
Mr. Neku endorsed the hope, although he cautioned, "It doesn't mean things will go easily. When sanctions are lifted, these companies will still want to come and see the situation. Are they going to invest in a country where people are being killed?"
Rumored projects aside, the only imminent surge of cash is an $850 million loan from the International Monetary Fund, which may become available by the end of the year with Mr. Mandela's blessing.
So far, most of the American companies scouting opportunities here have been bent on selling, not producing. But upon arrival they are often astounded to discover that South Africans are not lacking for things to buy.
 
Well-Stocked Shelves
 Throughout the years of South Africa's moral isolation, about 130 American companies and numerous European concerns retained subsidiaries here, and others that ostentatiously withdrew during the 1980's continued to sell their products through distributors and franchise arrangements.
Supermarket shelves are stocked with Kellogg's cereals, Colgate toiletries, and Johnson floor products. Shopping centers feature Pizza Huts and Benettons.
"Most of the things we want from overseas, we are getting," said Frank Dube, a black schoolteacher, as he towed his young son through the cavernous Toys 'R' Us outlet at a shopping mall in suburban Roodeport.
Where sanctions created gaps, local entrepreneurs have filled them with South African knock-offs.
One brazen entrepreneur recently announced plans to open his own "McDonald's" chain, golden arches and all, asserting that the company had forfeited its trademark.
Culturally, the Americanization of South Africa has been accelerated by a sanctions anomaly.
Although 40 percent of South African whites are of British descent, and many hold United Kingdom passports, South Africa has been denied most British films and television programming because the British actors' union d imposed a stringent boycott.
As a result, seven of the 10 most-watched entertainment shows on South African television are American, topped by "Who's the Boss."
 
A Cultural Predicament
 "We're faced with a predicament," said Johann van Rheede, a spokesman for the South African Broadcasting Corporation, contemplating the end of the English sanctions. "Our children have been weaned on American programming. Though a lot of our population is of British origins, it would be quite a radical change going to British programming."
Likewise, American films monopolize the theaters and American music fills the air, in black townships no less than in white suburbs.
Some whites, like two Afrikaner women studying the ware at Toys 'R' Us, take pleasure in seeing Mr. Mandela imploring the West to invest.
"Mandela's going to get a bankrupt country he himself begged for with his sanctions," said one, who would identify herself only as Marie. "He's beginning to think about that."
"It's mostly his people who are without jobs," added her companion, Hannelie.

HEADLINE: Fed Took A Neutral Rate Stand

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Concluding that economic growth was sluggish and inflation was abating, the Federal Reserve announced today that it had decided last month that there was no need for it to lean toward raising interest rates.
In a surprise to many economists, the Fed took this action unanimously at its Aug. 17 meeting, and most economists say they believe it embraced a similar neutral stance at its meeting on Tuesday, meaning it was not leaning toward raising or lowering rates. 
According to a report released today about the August meeting, Fed officials believed that "economic growth did not seem particularly robust" and that "more favorable performance of key measures of prices in recent months had tended to relieve earlier concerns about a possible worsening of inflation."
 
Usually Consults Members
 Concerned about a spurt in inflation earlier this year, the Fed's policy-making committee, the Federal Open Market Committee, adopted a bias toward higher rates in May. Such a bias means the Federal Reserve is likely to raise interest rates if there is a month or two of bad inflationary news.
By tradition, this meant that its chairman could raise short-term interest rates by a quarter of 1 percent without consulting other members. But Fed officials say that Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, does not usually act without first consulting his colleagues.
"They moved to a neutral position because of the obvious softness in the economy and the slower price increases in the summer," said Jay Woodworth, vice president and chief domestic economist at Bankers Trust. By tradition, the neutral position means Mr. Greenspan would have to consult his colleagues before raising rates, though he could act on his own in an emergency.
In a letter released today, President Clinton reaffirmed the central bank's independence by stating that he was opposed to proposals under which the President would nominate the heads of the Fed's 12 district banks.
 
Gonzalez's Argument
 Federal Reserve officials have been wary of that proposal, pushed by Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the House Banking Committee, because they say it would reduce the central bank's independence from political pressures. At present, the presidents of the 12 district banks are chosen by their boards, which are dominated by local bankers and business executives.
Mr. Gonzalez argues that elected officials, rather than bankers, should appoint the regional presidents, who help determine the central bank's monetary policy. For more than a year, he has accused the Fed of preventing a robust recovery by not allowing more growth in the money supply.
The regional presidents hold 5 of the 12 votes on the Federal Open Market Committee, which helps determine policy on short-term interest rates. The other seats are held by the Federal Reserve Board's seven members, all of whom must be nominated by the President and confirmed by the Senate.
In a letter sent to Mr. Gonzalez on Sept. 20, President Clinton said his proposal had merit, but there were also arguments on the other side.
"I am disinclined to seek a change in the Federal Reserve Act at this juncture," the President wrote.
In what some economists construed as praise for Mr. Greenspan, Mr. Clinton said the Federal Reserve System "is functioning well and does not need an overhaul just now."
"Changing the way bank presidents are elected at this time," he added, "runs the risk of undermining market confidence in the Fed."
Mr. Clinton also said, "There is virtue in having the Federal Open Market Committee input (and votes) that truly come from outside Washington."
 
Factors Against Increase
 In the Fed's summary of the August meeting, the central bankers said several factors argued against changing rates in the near future: slow economic growth in the first six months, the drag on growth associated with the President's deficit-reduction efforts, and the encouraging inflation statistics of recent months.
Nonethless, the central bankers made clear that a rate increase was inevitable eventually.
They again voiced concern that inflation might pick up steam because real interest rates -- interest rates minus the inflation rate -- were zero and sometimes negative in recent months.
The summary stated: "This conclusion was seen as reinforcing the view that monetary policy probably would have to move in the direction of restraint at some point to resist any incipient tendency for inflationary pressures to intensify."
David M. Jones, chief economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a New York brokerage firm, said he was surprised by the Fed's abandonment of its bias toward higher rates. He said there was a chance the central bank went back to its tilt to higher rates at Tuesday's meeting because of some signs of stronger growth and because the August rise in inflation of three-tenths of 1 percent was slightly larger than expected.

HEADLINE: Lillian R. Kessler Is Dead at 85; Established an Export Company

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY

 BODY:
Lillian Ruth Kessler, founder of the Kessler International Corporation, which exports railroad parts, electronics and heavy industrial equipment to Asia, Africa and South America, died last Saturday at a nursing home in Washington. She was 85.
Her daughter, Elinor Fuchs, said her mother had Alzheimer's disease. 
 Ms. Kessler founded the company in 1946. It is now based in Rockville, Md.
Before she established the business Ms. Kessler served for a year as an analyst for the Foreign Economic Administration, a Federal agency, conducting studies of postwar industrialization in Ethiopia and China. She then worked as an industrial economist for an international engineering firm and as a foreign markets consultant for the Sinclair Oil Corporation.
 
W.P.A. History Project
 While still a doctoral student in economic history in what is now Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland, Ms. Kessler was asked to direct a pilot history project for the Works Progress Administration, the New Deal program established in 1935 to provide employment through public works projects; eventually, the history project grew into the W.P.A.'s Historical Records Survey.
Ms. Kessler was named the director of the project for Ohio in 1939. During her work with the W.P.A. she wrote a guidebook to American folk songs, "Songs of Yesterday: A Song Anthology of American Life," with Philip D. Jordan.
She was born in Cleveland and attended Radcliffe College before enrolling at the Cleveland university, where she received an undergraduate degree in 1929.
In 1930 she married Joseph Fuchs, the violinist, who was then with the Cleveland Orchestra. They divorced in 1940.
Besides her daughter, Ms. Kessler is survived by a brother, Dr. Edwin S. Kessler of Washington, and two granddaughters.

HEADLINE: Panel Approves Proposal For a Stadium in Hartford

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Sept. 24

 BODY:
A select committee of the General Assembly today approved Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s proposal to build a $252 million football stadium in Hartford if -- and the ifs are still many -- the New England Patriots of the National Football League can be induced to move here from Foxboro, Mass.
The 28-to-4 vote set up a final debate on Monday before the full House and Senate that supporters believe will be just as lopsided in favor of a measure that for the moment is entirely conditional: only if the team is sold to an investors' group that has promised to relocate here, and only if the league then approves the move, which has not even been formally proposed, would any state money be spent. 
 But even as a resolution, and perhaps indeed partly because it was a resolution that in the end might signify little or nothing, much of the committee's debate was couched in broad terms about the future of Connecticut's capital city.
 
Proposal Called Irresponsible
 Several dissenting lawmakers said that with gang-related crime on the increase, the school system in trouble and layoffs continuing in core industries like insurance, making a commitment to build a stadium for use perhaps 22 times a year by the Patriots and the University of Connecticut football team was irresponsible. Others cited studies showing that football stadiums in some cases have been notorious money losers for the home-team cities.
People on both sides of the issue cited concerns about the Travelers Corporation, the city's second-largest employer, which this week announced a merger with the Primerica Corporation of New York, raising the fear that another old-line Connecticut company will be answering to a corporate parent with allegiances elsewhere.
"How do I say to somebody in my district that's been laid off by Travelers, or laid off by Aetna, or laid off by Pratt & Whitney, well don't worry, at least you can go to the football game?" said Representative Robert Farr, a Republican from West Hartford and one of the dissenting voters.
 
Attracting Suburbanites
 One supporter responded that the stadium would be worth its cost if suburban residents who now shun downtown could be induced to make the trip -- even if it was only 22 times a year. Besides, having a football team would put Hartford on the map as never before.
"I don't think that even though the state is in bad times we must put on a hair shirt and never enthusiastically grab at something that might give a lot of pleasure to some people," said Representative Andrew McCall Norton, a Republican from Colchester who voted yes. "I don't think that just because things are quite bad you should neglect to do some things that are perhaps no better described than fun."
Because of all the caveats and hedged bets, supporting the 70,000-seat stadium is also for now an idea that carries very little risk, and many lawmakers and local officials have jumped aboard enthusiastically.
Hartford's Mayor, Carrie Saxon Perry, who is running a hard-fought three-way race for re-election in November, pledged this week -- to cheers from a noontime crowd at a downtown rally-- that she would exchange her trademark big floppy hat for a Patriots' helmet at the first home game.
Mr. Weicker, who is credited with putting the Patriots plan in motion earlier this summer, also said today that he would announce his plans on whether to run for a second term as governor next week, perhaps even as "Pumped for the Pats" buttons are expected to reach their maximum degree of visibility on Capitol lapels.
State economic development officials in Massachusetts, meanwhile, said today that they believe the chances of the Patriots' moving out are almost nil. This summer Gov. William F. Weld proposed building a $700 million convention and sports center to house the Patriots in Boston's South Bay. And even if the plan is not approved by the Massachusetts Legislature this year, a spokesman for the Massachusetts Office of Economic Affairs, Kevin P. Kutz, said that "our calls on these things suggest that the Patriots will stay."
With the new Massachusetts stadium approved, Mr. Kutz added, "a long shot would recede to the infinitesimal."
Paul Tagliabue, the commissioner of the N.F.L., has also expressed the view that the Patriots should not be moved.
"The commissioner thinks a downtown Boston stadium would best serve the long-term interest of the Patriots," said a league spokesman, Greg Aiello.
Mr. Weicker said in comments to reporters, however, that simply by making the commitment to build a stadium, the state is playing in the big leagues and that team owners everywhere -- perhaps the Patriots, perhaps someone else -- will notice.
"Nothing could send a stronger message than that Connecticut is in the position to provide a stadium," he said. "That's probably the single most important factor in getting the Patriots here."

HEADLINE: Durable-Goods Data Show Rise in U.S. Manufacturing

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Orders to American factories for big-ticket items like cars and computers rose in August for the second time in three months, the Government said today.
Economists took the report as evidence that manufacturing was starting to recover from a slump earlier this year, but they said the rebound was not fast enough to produce significant hiring. 
 Orders rose 2 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $131.2 billion in August, following a 2.8 percent drop in July and a 4.3 percent gain in June, the Commerce Department said. From March through May, new orders declined for three consecutive months.
 
 
'Slowly Picking Up the Pieces'
 Mark M. Zandi, an economist with Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa., said the latest gain "is just one more piece of evidence the manufacturing base is slowly picking up the pieces from the dismal performance it had in the first half."
Shipments of durable goods, a measure of current production, increased 3.6 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $133.9 billion, their largest rise since December 1992.
Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown said the latest increase in orders "confirms our confidence that economic growth will pick up in the second half of the year."
Mr. Zandi and other analysts, however, noted that a key indicator of future factory employment continued to deteriorate in August.
 
 
Backlog of Orders Falls
 The backlog of unfilled orders fell six-tenths of a percent, to $432.9 billion, the lowest level since July 1988. It was the sixth consecutive decline and the 25th in 30 months.
With the backlog falling, hiring is generally not needed.
"Shipments are still going out faster than orders are coming in, so the backlog whittled down somewhat," said Stuart G. Hoffman, an economist with the PNC Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh. "That says there won't be a robust jump in production. But it doesn't preclude a more moderate improvement in production and some leveling off in layoffs."
Analysts say that manufacturers have worked down inventories that built up in the spring and that sales have improved, especially for autos. But manufacturing cannot begin growing strongly, they say, until the Japanese and Germans recover from recessions and start buying more American goods.
"The critical factor for boosting growth in the remainder of 1993 will be the performance of trade and, currently, exports are achieving only slow gains in the face of sluggish global demand," said Gordon Richards, an economist with the National Association of Manufacturers.
In August, orders for transportation equipment jumped 7.9 percent, following a 16.3 percent drop in July. The latest increase was bolstered by gains in aircraft and autos.
Excluding the volatile transportation sector, orders rose three-tenths of a percent, the third consecutive increase.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Against Mark As Concern on Russia Eases

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against the German mark and other European currencies yesterday as concerns about Russia's political crisis eased. Gold prices also retreated.
Even so, investors refrained from selling dollars aggressively, to protect themselves in case President Boris N. Yeltsin's power struggle with his rivals in the Russian Parliament intensifies during the weekend, traders said. 
 "People are still nervous about what might happen in Russia over the weekend," said Carl Amendola, vice president at Bayerische Hypotheken- und Wechsel-Bank. "They're in a wait-and-see mood."
In late New York trading, the dollar dropped to 1.6395 marks, from 1.6430 marks on Thursday. And the British pound rose to $1.5090 from $1.5060. But the dollar edged up to 106 Japanese yen from 105.90 yen.
Meanwhile, gold for October delivery slipped 60 cents, to $357.50 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
Considered a haven from international strife, the dollar had risen almost 3 percent against the mark since Tuesday, when Mr. Yeltsin dissolved the Russian Parliament to thwart hard-liners who oppose his economic policies.
The dollar surged against the mark in London amid reports that Mr. Yeltsin had ordered his supporters to disarm crowds guarding the Parliament building. But it later retreated after Mr. Yeltsin said he would not storm the building, and the Parliament's leader, Ruslan I. Khasbulatov, said he would not use force to defend it.
"Yeltsin seems to have everything under control," said Ezra Zask, president of Ezra Zask Associates, a currency trading fund with $105 million under management that is based in Norfolk, Conn. "It's hard to see how he could be undermined."
Still, the situation remained tenuous enough to keep the dollar in demand. "Anything can happen in Russia over the weekend," David De Rosa, foreign exchange manager at the Swiss Bank Corporation, said.
Meanwhile, the dollar finished slightly higher against the yen afterTreasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen was quoted as saying the United States was comfortable with the dollar's value. Traders had driven the dollar down as much as 20 percent this year amid signs that the Administration wanted the yen to strengthen in order to curb Japan's swelling trade surplus.

HEADLINE: For Computer Convention, Be Sure to Pack Vision

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Sept. 23

 BODY:
Not since George Bush was under fire for what he called "the vision thing" has any chief executive -- whether government or corporate -- drawn so much criticism and commentary on that subject as Louis V. Gerstner Jr. after a remark he made two months ago. At the time, the new I.B.M. chairman was announcing a dreadful financial result for the company, a dividend cut and another round of shedding workers and plants.
"The last thing I.B.M. needs right now," Mr. Gerstner said, "is a vision." 
 His statement, if nothing else, showed that Mr. Gerstner, who previously headed a cigarette maker and before that a credit card company, is an untutored newcomer to the computer industry. Mr. Gerstner explained his remark by saying that the most pressing need for the International Business Machines Corporation was to get the basic economics of the company in order so that it could stop losing billions of dollars a year.
 
Regular Rules Don't Apply
 In most industries, that might seem a reasonable view. Not in the computer business, where to call someone a "visionary" is the highest accolade, and chief executives are expected to market not merely products but "visions" of America's high-tech future and how their companies will help shape it. Which is why Mr. Gerstner's comment hit such a nerve: he spoke heresy.
One way to understand the importance of "the vision thing" to the computer digerati was to spend the early part of this week here, where a few hundred executives gathered to talk to themselves about their industry's future. Called Agenda, and presided over by the wry, chubby editor of Infoworld, Stewart Alsop, the annual conference attracts most of the big names in the personal computer industry: Bill Gates of Microsoft, John Sculley of Apple, Jim Manzi of Lotus, Eckhard Pfeiffer of Compaq, Michael Dell of Dell Computer, Philippe Kahn of Borland, and many others.
The topic for this year's gathering, held at a sprawling luxury desert resort, the Phoenician, was "digital convergence," which means the expected technological melding of computers, telecommunications, television and publishing.
Convergence is a big conceptual ball of string that wraps in 500 television channels and the information superhighway, hand-held personal digital assistants and massively parallel supercomputers, computers that talk back and intelligent software "agents" programmed to act as a person's alter ego. It is the ultimate high-tech vision -- and a $3.5 trillion business, by one estimate -- beckoning on the horizon.
The personal computer business is still young and self-confident. To the people here, it is more than a business. The industry's mission, one executive said, is to "make great products, build companies and change the world." The notion that the business combines capitalism, progress and virtue is an implicit part of the vision. And they take their high-minded mission, and themselves, seriously.
A telling moment came during an after-dinner speech given by the publisher Rupert Murdoch's emissary to this gathering, John Evans, the president of News Electronic Data. Mr. Evans pointed out that his company was interested in the new fields not to pursue "the great cause of the electronic media," but to pursue profit. "I don't know about you, but I'm in it for the money," he declared with refreshing candor. When he paused, there was dead silence; not a chuckle or a clap to be heard.
Whether the vision animating most computer executives is really any different from the vision driving other business executives -- namely, stringing together enough financially respectable calendar quarters to hold on to their jobs -- is open to question. Another question is whether vision and success are much related in the computer industry, or any other.
It can be argued that the success of Mr. Gates, the foremost entrepreneur of the last decade, did not have much to do with vision. Not much, that is, unless getting plucked from anonymity in 1981 by I.B.M. to supply the software operating system for the I.B.M. PC and eventually developing a program, Windows, that mimics the easy-to-use software of the Apple Macintosh qualify as startlingly original visions.
Maybe they do, and Mr. Gates is undeniably brilliant. But drive, timing and sheer energy would seem to be a big part of the vision thing. Mr. Gates held court into the nights here, all but shutting down the hotel himself, debating any and all comers in his combative style, clearly enjoying the sheer sport of it.
High-tech executives seem to possess the most vision when their companies are doing well, and their vision vanishes when fortunes change. This, of course, is a computer industry reworking of the economist John Kenneth Galbraith's adage that genius is a rising market.
 
A Fickle Accolade
 Not long ago, Mr. Sculley of Apple was hailed in the financial press and on Wall Street as a "technovisionary." But since Apple has been pummeled in the personal computer price wars, with losses and work force cuts, Mr. Sculley has been replaced as chief executive and no one talks about his vision anymore.
"It's a roller coaster ride," Mr. Sculley said. "We're either given more credit than we deserve, or it's the other way. It's not much in the middle."
Yet high-tech visions, properly marketed, can be useful and profitable. Roger McNamee, a general partner of Integral Capital Partners, an investment firm specializing in the computer industry, cited a possible byproduct of the hype about a brave new digital future: a financial mania.
"We could find ourselves at the center of some truly loony behavior," he told the group. "And we could benefit if we're quick and smart."
Some essential conditions for a speculative mania are in place, Mr. McNamee. The digital revolution is new and it has people excited, and the excitement is fueled not only by greed but also by patriotic fervor, with the likes of Vice President Al Gore promoting the data superhighway.
Still, Mr. MacNamee told the computer executives that some care and caution is advisable. Remember, he said, "Several of the business visionaries of the 1980's, like Mike Milken and Ivan Boesky, served jail time."

HEADLINE: Lunch Break

 BODY:
It's refreshing to have an Administration in Washington that finally takes child nutrition seriously. Last week Secretary of Agriculture Mike Espy promised to improve the quality of federally financed school lunches.
The link between diet and chronic disease makes this a serious issue. About 25 million children -- nearly 60 percent of all public-school students -- are fed through the Agriculture Department's lunch program, most at reduced cost or no cost. For many children this is the only meal of the day. 
 Too often the lunches are crammed with fat, cholesterol and sodium. The average school meal, the Agriculture Department estimates, derives about 40 percent of its calories from fat -- violating common dietary guidelines, which recommend a maximum of 30 percent.
A disturbing new report by the consumer advocacy group Public Voice for Food and Health Policy finds that more than half the children in the school lunch program eat less than one serving of fruit a day. About a third of them consume less than one daily serving of vegetables, and their vegetable of choice is fried potatoes.
Under its new "Fresh Start" initiative, the Agriculture Department plans to reduce fat and salt, and double the amount of fresh fruits and vegetables provided to schools under the commodities program, from 8.8 million to 16 million pounds, beginning this school year. That's not much of an increase for each student. But it's progress -- if the department can solve some daunting delivery problems in getting the produce to the schools in good condition.
Mr. Espy promises no more cuts in the financing of the school lunch program. But improving the offerings on the tray may require some increase in funding, which, adjusted for inflation, has decreased over the past decade.
Obviously, any attempt to change kids' eating habits comes up against all those junk food ads on television and the entrenched patterns of many school lunch administrators. But Ellen Haas, the former head of the Public Voice group, whom Mr. Espy has chosen to lead the new effort, is right to be optimistic. "It's not alien for kids to eat fruits and vegetables," she observes. What they need, for starters, is fresher, tastier choices.

HEADLINE: The Black Caucus Gets Mugged

 BODY:
In the days ahead, the Congressional Black Caucus may find itself in an advantageous position. In a Congress riven with discord over Nafta, the economy and other issues, the Black Caucus counts 39 votes in the House, and 1 in a Senate that often produces squeaker votes.
But the Black Caucus's chairman, Kweisi Mfume, Democrat of Maryland, seems not to understand the uses of power. When Mr. Mfume embraced Louis Farrakhan last week in Washington, he temporarily lost the savvy he has shown while legislating, and behaved like a novice. Mr. Mfume was had. So was the Black Caucus. 
 The occasion for this mugging was the Caucus's annual legislative meeting, specifically a panel on race and politics at the Washington Convention Center. The participants included Mr. Mfume, Mr. Farrakhan, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Benjamin Chavis of the N.A.A.C.P. Mr. Farrakhan's presence was an invitation to trouble, given his previous anti-Semitic railings and especially his description of Judaism as "a gutter religion."
Mr. Mfume declared a detente between the Caucus and the Black Muslims, among others. "No longer will we allow people to divide us," he said, adding that such a union was needed to bring about "change." Some say Mr. Mfume, who only recently abandoned radical for mainstream politics, was "caught up in the moment" and broached the issue without consulting the Caucus.
Perhaps. But his conduct suggests a misconception about what constitutes genuine leadership and whence its power flows. The members of the Black Caucus were given mandates and missions by the voters who sent them to Washington. They have a real political foundation of voters who expect "change," all right, but expect it in legislation that will benefit them.
It's reasonable for the Caucus to reach out. But Mr. Mfume and his duly elected colleagues needn't be threatened or guilt-tripped into sharing platforms with people without portfolio who would soon drop from sight if the press ceased to cover them -- or if the Black Caucus ceased to invite them to conferences.
Mr. Mfume diluted his hard-won authority of office by extending it to a freelance rhetorician well known as a hater. The Caucus gets only bad karma and negative publicity in return.
That's a political mugging, pure and simple. The chairman of the Black Caucus ought to know better. Perhaps his membership can teach him.

HEADLINE: Viewing the Stock Market as a Savings Vehicle;
Greed and Fear Cycles

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your article on the surge in mutual fund investments (Sept. 7) deserves our full attention. The greed cycle that has dominated the market and led to historic highs will yield, as it always must, to fear, compounded by the growing realization that the malaises that plague us run exceedingly deep. The economies of the Western world aren't likely to "recover" any time soon. 
 If stocks plunge, billions of dollars in real savings will be transferred out of the pockets of investors, accompanied by loud cries of woe. This is likely to deal yet another in a long series of blows to our economy, most of which may be directly attributed to Wall Street's obsessive concentration on short-term gain.
When it is over, the move to very low interest rates that drove this money out of the banks and into the market will (like the deregulation of the savings and loans) suddenly appear to have been a huge mistake, but by then it will be too late.
Capitalism may indeed be the best system we know of for improving the global standard of living and creating wealth, but it has become a slave to bankers and economists who are unable to look any further than the next balance sheet. Recent history suggests these professionals have collapsed into a sociological black hole, from which they are unable to observe the real world or the human beings in it.
The best proof of this is that economists cannot understand why Americans aren't out there "feeling more confident" and spending again. Apparently they don't realize that the middle class has no disposable income left. Most of us can no longer afford to live in the brave new world that bankers, lawyers, insurance brokers and health care professionals have created, a world where we cannot save for the future even if we do have the means.
No, in order to realize "reasonable rates of return," our investment gurus now advise us to pump our cash into the growth of our national short-term economic cancer. This after years of being told that America must save more! How surreal. If the market does indeed drop, and our savings do evaporate, you may be sure we will be treated to lectures from our economists about how that's really actually good for us, just like leveraged buyouts and junk bonds.
Unless things start to change, we may ultimately all live to see Karl Marx's prediction that capitalism carries the seeds of its own destruction within itself proved correct. What comes next? I'm not sure I want to know.
 
LEE VAN LAER
New York, Sept. 15, 1993

HEADLINE: Trials of a Small Business in New York City

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Every day I see something in the newspaper or on television explaining how New York City is going to make it easier for small businesses to operate because they are the nucleus of a successful economy. 
 I am the owner of just such a business. I have run a small discount store for the last eight years on the West Side of Manhattan, during which I have been continually harassed. Here is a typical week:
Monday: Truck making a delivery gets a $55 ticket for parking in front of my store for 10 minutes to unload.
Tuesday: I get a $50 summons from a Sanitation inspector because someone tore up some Lotto tickets on the sidewalk. (I'm supposed to have an employee outside all day with a broom.)
Wednesday: Two storm troopers from the Department of Environmental Protection enter my store with cameras to take a picture of my bathroom. I'm handed a violation because it has improper ventilation. (I've served on jury duty in city courts where not only is the toilet not ventilated but did not even have running water.)
In previous weeks, I have been given summonses for having a "We develop film" sign outside the store, having a sign with my name atop it, and having a tiny hole in a basement step where I store merchandise downstairs. That's a summons on each of three levels. Where should I conduct business, in a helicopter?
Is this my reward for paying sales, commercial rent, occupancy, city, state and Federal taxes, plus a $2,500 monthly rent for a store worth no more than $700 a month? Shouldn't somebody reassess how to make it easier for small businesses to operate in New York City?
 
ROBERT RUSSO
New York, Sept. 15, 1993

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds That Play the Markets for You

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
Mutual fund companies are casting a wide net for neophyte investors who lack the desire or the skill to construct their own fund portfolios. The product of the moment? Asset allocation funds.
These funds can buy stocks, bonds and cash in any combination. Their selling points are instant diversity and the flexibility to respond to market conditions. But that built-in flexibility means that funds flying the asset-allocation banner may have very little in common. 
 "The whole category is so loosely organized that there are no hard-and-fast rules," said Thomas A. Desmond, associate editor of Morningstar Mutual Funds, a Chicago newsletter.
 
Know Your Manager
 To know what you're getting, you need to look much more closely at the fund's investment strategy and at its manager than you would with other types of funds. "I'd want to have a lot of confidence in the manager," Mr. Desmond said.
Some asset allocation funds are free to shift nearly their entire portfolio into stocks or bonds, or even cash. In fact, the Blanchard Strategic Growth Fund used a huge cash position to create an outstanding return of 16.4 percent in 1987.
Since then, asset allocation funds have grown in number from 12 to 64. Fidelity Investments has heavily promoted its Asset Manager for retirement accounts in full-page advertisements, and the fund's assets have doubled from $3.4 billion in January to $6.9 billion. The Dreyfus Corporation jumped in the market in July.
These hybrid funds are close cousins to the better-established balanced group. As a rule, balanced funds own relatively fixed ratios of stocks and bonds, usually in a 60-40 mix.
 Balanced funds have been the better performers. For the three years ended in June, they returned an average of 11.6 percent a year, compared with 9.9 percent for asset allocation funds, according to Morningstar Inc.
Some critics say the lag in performance may come from the huge amount of data that the allocation funds must follow: central bank policies, business cycles, stock values, inflation rates and sector performance in markets here and abroad.
"We have yet to find a single organization with all the necessary expertise in stock, bond and money markets," said Michael D. Hirsch, president of Hirsch Investment Management in New York.
Investors who have designed a mix of stocks, bonds and cash in a portfolio of funds may want to shy away from these funds and their unpredictable combinations. Mr. Hirsch says investors would be better off combining several growth funds with bond funds and a money market fund.
 Still, investors who own just one fund or who like the concept of one-stop shopping might go the allocation fund route. They should look for a fund whose strategy matches their risk tolerance and investment goals.
Picking a fund may be dicey, given that the top 10 performers in the last three years excelled using very different tactics. Cash holdings recently ranged from zero to 43 percent, stocks from 18 to 67 percent, and bonds from 2 to 64 percent.
Among them, Fidelity Asset Manager has kept a relatively stable mix over the last four-plus years, with cash a quarter of the portfolio, bonds 35 percent and stocks the remainder.
 Phoenix Total Return generally puts half its portfolio into stocks and splits the remainder between bonds and cash. Right now, more than half its assets are in cash. "The big decision has been to get out of bonds -- and it's been a bad decision so far," said Robert Milnamow, its manager.
 Quest for Value Opportunity also has a small amount in bonds, just 5 percent. It is heavily invested in stocks, with 10 percent in cash.
Merrill Lynch Global Allocation has changed its spots a few times. Cash has jumped from 15 to more than 25 percent, stocks from 40 to 45 percent, and bonds, 35 to 40 percent.
FBL Managed marches to a different drummer. In the last two years, the fund has averaged 80 percent in bonds, mainly convertible bonds. Its manager, Roger Grefe, calls convertible securities "the most undervalued part of the market."

HEADLINE: A Corporate Image Problem;
Fighting for the Rights To the Ameritec(h) Flag

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Ameritec v. Ameritech is more that just a battle over an 'h' this time. Now it's over a $30 million image campaign.
As part of the promotional campaign, the Ameritech Corporation, the Chicago-based telephone company that serves much of the Midwest, is wiping out its old signature as a Baby Bell company and raising a freshly designed corporate logo. 
 Therein lies the latest problem. The new logo's typeface and red- white-and-blue color scheme resembles the flag and hues of the Ameritec Company, a Covina, Calif., manufacturer of phone-testing equipment.
The companies have already been at loggerheads over the similarity of their names, and in 1986, they reached a licensing agreement over the Ameritec name and its variations.
Privately owned Ameritec sold $30 million worth of equipment to local and long-distance phone companies and businesses last year. Its logo has been the same since its founding in 1980.
Earlier this week, Ameritec filed suit in Federal District Court here seeking to prohibit Ameritech from rolling out its new logo.
Mike Brand, an Ameritech spokesman, said nothing in the 1986 agreement "precludes us from changing the logo."
But Jeff Briggs, Ameritec's lawyer, said that part of the agreement included the promise that both companies avoid taking steps that would create confusion. "They've done exactly what they said they wouldn't do," he said.
Mr. Brand said: "We're not creating confusion. We're putting $30 million into further differentiating us from other communications companies in the industry."
Typically, disputes like Ameritec v. Ameritech result from an oversight by a designer rather than deliberate imitation, said David Stewart, a University of Southern California professor and consumer behavior expert.
"Given that the phone company changed its logo, the small company will have a stronger leg to stand on because of first use," he said.
Courts often use a test of economic harm in disputes involving confusion over trademarks. There, Ameritec's cause is undercut because the companies share few common markets, Mr. Stewart said.

ACROSS THE BRIDGE: Stories, by Mavis Gallant. (Random House, $19.) In these 11 lucid urban stories, most of which are set in Paris or Montreal, Mrs. Gallant's wit and exactitude subvert the antiquity of her material.
THE CULTURE OF DISBELIEF: How American Law and Politics Trivialize Religious Devotion, by Stephen L. Carter. (Basic Books, $25.) A professor of law at Yale examines what he calls a 20-year-old tendency to ban religion from public discourse, and argues that a just balance of mutually respectful forces is required, not a victory for church or secularism.
FIDEL CASTRO, by Robert E. Quirk. (Norton, $35.) An indictment, often devastating, of its ego-driven subject and his works, drawn chiefly from public materials by orthodox scholarship.
FLY FISHING THROUGH THE MIDLIFE CRISIS, by Howell Raines. (Morrow, $22.) The editorial page editor of The New York Times nobly describes his passionate fishermanship and the fly-fishing guru who helped him attain it.
HENRY JAMES' MIDNIGHT SONG, by Carol De Chellis Hill. (Poseidon/Simon & Schuster, $23.) A grand, ebullient novel, set chiefly in 1890's Vienna, where James, Freud, Jung and Edith Wharton are up to some naughty conduct.
THE MORNING AFTER: Sex, Fear, and Feminism on Campus, by Katie Roiphe. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) A tough book by a 25-year-old who argues that women are too brave and too smart to fit the role of eternal victim imposed on them by some ideologies that expand the meaning of rape.
MUDDY BOOTS AND RED SOCKS: A Reporter's Life, by Malcolm W. Browne. (Times Books/Random House, $23.) The memoir of a bold foreign correspondent who has seen 20th-century mayhem from Indochina to the Persian Gulf.
NO OTHER LIFE, by Brian Moore. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $21.) A brilliant meditative novel about a place that is and is not Haiti and a visionary who is and is not Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Haiti's once and future President.
SEXUAL VIOLENCE: Our War Against Rape, by Linda A. Fairstein. (Morrow, $23.) Manhattan's chief sex crimes prosecutor explains recent sensible changes in the law and walks readers through some successful prosecutions.
SILENT PASSENGERS, by Larry Woiwode. (Atheneum, $18.) In Mr. Woiwode's collection of short stories, events matter less than epiphanies, mystical networking, usually intrafamilial, between human beings.
A SIMPLE PLAN, by Scott Smith. (Knopf, $21.) Each bad deed leads to a worse one in this disturbing first novel, a morality tale told by an ordinary man who became a multiple murderer.
A TIDEWATER MORNING: Three Tales From Youth, by William Styron. (Random House, $17.) The author's memory plays upon the painful moments of his life at the ages of 10, 13 and 20; the result is a trio of stories, each of whose sadness is multiplied by the presence of the others.
