SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 2; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2167 words

HEADLINE: ART VIEW;
Of Candy Bars and Public Art

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
There is a new paradigm for public art in this country. It is not always easy to distinguish from social work, and it is certainly a long way in conception from the old model of "plop" art, with its casual regard for the relationship between sculpture and site. The new public art also goes beyond the percent-for-art programs that emerged during the 1970's and 80's and aspired to bring artists and architects closer together in planning new buildings and urban designs.
The latest brand of public art is something else again: artists collaborating directly with the communities that will come into contact with the work, the process of collaboration becoming, in many cases, as important as the end result.
The approach, strictly speaking, isn't new. Its roots -- and the problems it poses -- go back at least to the 1960's, grounded as they are in movements like Process Art and Performance Art, and in the left-wing political activism that moved artists of that time from their studios to the streets (not only here but abroad, as in London, where Conrad Atkinson and Stephen Willats collaborated with workers from the East End). The political art of recent years has spawned a new generation of artists and curators who have picked up strands of 60's thinking and adapted them to 90's issues.
The latest manifestation of the new public art has been in evidence here, during the last few months, in a program that winds down this week called "Culture in Action." It was sponsored by Sculpture Chicago, supported by money from the National Endowment for the Arts and various private groups and organized by Mary Jane Jacob, an independent curator. The program (total cost around $800,000) is actually eight separate projects, mostly in neighborhoods distant -- if not geographically, then economically and sociologically -- from Chicago's gleaming commercial heart.
The outcomes of such projects have been about as far from the towering Picasso and Calder sculptures that adorn Chicago's Loop as can be imagined; they have taken the form of block parties and parades, paint charts, chocolate bars and hydroponically grown leafy vegetables.
One project is based in the hotly contested area near Maxwell Street, for a century a thriving Old World bazaar in the shadow of the Loop. There, city planners and a nearby university have combined to raze blocks as part of a scheme to build athletic fields and other structures and eliminate the busy marketplace that still caters mostly to low-income people.
Another project took place on a West Town street, a couple of miles west of the Loop, occupied mainly by Latinos and fractured by competing gangs. Yet another took place in a factory where a dozen union workers from a large chocolate company banded together to design their own candy bar and wrapper. And a project that involved hundreds of people united members of disparate communities across the city, including a Mexican-American neighborhood around Harrison Park and the black neighborhood around Garfield Park.
The Chicago program is only one example of the new public art. In a kind of collaboration with their South Bronx neighbors, John Ahearn and Rigoberto Torres have produced sculptures depicting residents of that community. Other public art blurs the division between advertising and art, volunteerism and Conceptualism. The red ribbon that has come to symbolize concern about AIDS was conceived by artists who belong to a group called Visual Aids -- a whopping success by the standards of the new public art.
Programs like the one here in Chicago highlight many of the knotty questions that the new public art raises. The questions are not only about esthetics. They are also about the often fine line dividing exploitation and collaboration in the relationships between artists and their communities. Such programs raise the now inevitable questions about public financing, too: Would the money be better spent on established social programs, not to mention art that aspires to something more visually ambitious than a leafy vegetable?
How, in fact, do you compare a leafy vegetable with a park designed by Vito Acconci, much less with a Titian? For that matter, how do you compare the social service provided by these art projects with the work done by real social service organizations?
AND HOW DO YOU COMPARE SUCH projects even with the political art that filled the last Whitney Biennial and the Aperto at the Venice Biennale? An essential element distinguishes this new public art from much of what was on view in New York and Italy: it eschews galleries and museums, where such art often takes on a boutiquish odor. The work may stem from the same ideas and idealism that inspire artists to make sculptures and installations for more conventional sites, but it takes those ideas in a different direction. It is not primarily about addressing the traditional art public and its debates over quality.
What may come to mind is the recent brouhaha involving three artists in Southern California who doled out $10 bills to undocumented migrant workers. By all accounts, that publicity stunt masquerading as art had nothing to do with serious collaboration between the artists and the workers; both as social service and as a meditation on the problems at the Mexican-American border it was laughably meager. Its real audience was the art world and its critics, among whom the gesture of giving away public money for the arts had precisely the intended incendiary effect. Had it not provoked a response from that group, the whole gesture would have been, on the face of it, empty.
One can think of that California project as the new public art at its worst. But much of the new public art is different. It almost always derives from good intentions. Of course, the streets of Chicago's West Side are paved with them.
Some of the "Culture in Action" projects are examples of such well-intended duds. Suzanne Lacy, who for years has been putting together spectacles and performances that involve large groups of people, organized one of the most disappointing and tradition-bound projects with a group of women from around the city. The group drew up a list of 100 local women of distinction, dead and alive, chosen from more than 400 nominations solicited through newspapers and women's organizations; then limestone rocks, each embedded with a brass plate bearing the name of one of the women, were distributed around the Loop.
The impulse to recognize the achievements of these mostly unheralded women was admirable. But the rocks, with their small and difficult-to-read plaques, turn out to be undistinguished testimonials to distinguished women, clunky obstacles on busy streets where they may be likelier to annoy than to enlighten passers-by. As to an even more questionable component of Ms. Lacy's project, a dinner party to which Gloria Steinem, Anita Hill and a small group of other prominent women have been invited, it is difficult to see why such a private event, oddly caricaturing Caryl Churchill's caustic 1983 play, "Top Girls," should be underwritten by a public art program (even if it is videotaped for outsiders to see).
Another dubious project involved the artists Kate Ericson and Mel Ziegler, who asked a group of residents of Ogden Courts Apartments, a housing project, to help them design a paint chart, each color relating to some event in the history of public housing or some aspect of life in such housing -- Urban Renewal Lime, Cabrini Green, Pruitt-Igoe Dust. (It is being distributed in paint stores.)
Some Ogden Courts residents, Ms. Jacob volunteered, wondered quite understandably what possible benefit they derived from contributing to this artsy exercise, especially one that reduced catastrophes like Pruitt-Igoe to something as decorous as a wall coloring. It was agreed that after completing the chart, Ms. Ericson and Mr. Ziegler would collaborate with the residents on thinking up something more to the point.
Yet another well-meaning but fuzzily conceived project is by a quartet of artists who call themselves Haha. In a storefront in Rogers Park, near Evanston, they have joined a group of residents and others to create a hydroponic garden. The aim is to make the storefront a meeting place for AIDS volunteers and people interested in discussing AIDS, the garden becoming both a source of therapeutic food for people with AIDS and a metaphor for nurturing and caring.
The artists in Haha are sensitive people dealing with an immense problem about which they are trying, as artists, to make some constructive statement. But with all the serious work to be done and already being done by volunteer AIDS organizations, the project seems hopelessly precious, not to say ineffectual. The garden is too small to be much of a contribution, and in any case, its physiological benefits are questionable. And where is the art in all this? As metaphor, the garden is trite. As interior design, the storefront is unexceptional. Surely this can't be described as good Performance or Process Art, either, even by the most generous definitions of those terms.
SO WHAT ARE THE BEST OF THE "Culture in Action" projects? A local artist named Inigo Manglano-Ovalle organized a block party on Erie Street near Wood Street in West Town, collaborating over many months with children and teen-agers, gangs, and community organizations. For the party, which took place late last month, more than 70 video monitors were set up along the street. They displayed videotapes of neighborhood residents made by the young people with whom Mr. Manglano-Ovalle collaborated. The young people were trained in the use of video; they decided on the subject matter of the tapes, and some of the equipment they used was contributed to the neighborhood after the project was finished so the young people could continue to make videos with it.
Gangs that usually fight over turf banded together for the party and for the supervision of the street. And where was the art here? In the more than 40 visually lively tapes made by the young people. In the theater of the party. And in the peculiarly artistic demonstration of community solidarity.
Another project was put together by Daniel J. Martinez, the artist responsible for the notorious "I Can't Imagine Ever Wanting to Be White" buttons at the Whitney Biennial. For "Culture in Action" he did something as sensitive and upbeat as the buttons were crude and off-putting. He spent around two years enlisting 800 volunteers from Mexican-American and black neighborhoods that don't generally mix with each other. The group organized a colorful, costume-filled parade that moved from one neighborhood to the other, stopping in between at Maxwell Street. Like Mr. Manglano-Ovalle's project, this was an artistic, theatrical illustration of community organization and embrace.
At the same time, Mr. Martinez created an installation on a fenced-in lot near Maxwell Street that is owned by the University of Illinois at Chicago, which is trying to drive out the market. The installation (done without the university's involvement) consists of a platform made from giant granite blocks. The blocks come from a plaza that the university designed during the mid-60's for its campus several blocks away.
That plaza partook of the sort of now discredited liberal design mentality of the time that obliterated old neighborhoods and replaced them with housing projects. Its destruction, and the use of its remains on the disputed site of an old neighborhood that the university asserts it will improve by eliminating is thus full of reverberations and double-entendres. The platform Mr. Martinez has created also suggests a giant soapbox, a place for speakers to exhort crowds. His sentiments are clearly with one side. But his spare installation avoids preaching and, like good political art, aims at provoking serious debate without pretending to be able to effect major change.
There are obviously plenty of pitfalls with the new public art. One of the most dangerous, condescending assumptions that can underlie it is ghettoization under the guise of public outreach -- that art for lower-income communities, immigrant communities, must take the form of social activism, that the history of Western culture as presented in museums is irrelevant to such people.
Yet another danger -- perhaps an inevitability -- is that such projects as "Culture in Action" will be imitated by every arts organization that wants to seem trendy and politically correct, turning what should be painstaking and long-term community involvement into the quick-hit, radical-chic, plop art of the 90's. Fly in the artists, stage an event with the city's downtrodden, alert the media! Ms. Jacob says she has already received calls from organizations around the country that would like her to put together in their cities something similar to what she put together in Chicago. No wonder she is reluctant to speak of paradigms.

HEADLINE: EUROPE: FALL AND WINTER;
Stronger Dollar Eases Pain of Prices

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING; ALAN RIDING is chief of the Paris bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
FOR European governments, currency speculators are quite simply the personification of evil. Time after time over the past year these shadowy manipulators have imposed their will on exchange markets and forced once-proud currencies into humiliating devaluations. Just ask central bank officials in London or Rome or Paris what they think of currency speculators. Greedy, irresponsible, dangerous . . . the epithets pour out.
But wait! Why not ask an American arriving in Europe with dollars to spend? Thanks to the speculators, the dollar has made significant gains against European currencies since the late summer of 1992. The dollar has yet to recover its privileged (or overvalued) status of the mid-1980's, but it has shaken off its image as the currency no one wants. 
 First, a quick warning. Most West European countries are no longer outrageously expensive for Americans, but the likes of Germany, the Netherlands, Switzerland, Austria and France are still expensive compared to the United States.
Even with the dollar variously worth between 10 and 50 percent more than last year, it is amazing how quality hotels, restaurants and boutiques continue to escape being bargains. Nonetheless, good deals are easier to find.
In truth, prices invariably fall as travelers distance themselves from capital cities and major tourist resorts. In this case, though, it is on the periphery of Western Europe itself that the dollar has jumped most in value -- in Italy, Spain, Portugal and Greece to the south and in Sweden, Norway and Finland to the north. Even the British pound has slipped by around 20 percent against the dollar in the past 13 months.
It is still a problem, of course, trying to keep up with currency swings. For several years, it was relatively simple. The dollar's rate in Europe varied as the dollar strengthened or weakened against all European currencies, but there was little movement among European currencies themselves. Then, in September 1992, the European Community's system of tightly linked exchange rates buckled and disarray followed.
The pound and the Italian lira pulled out of the system and promptly lost value, while the Spanish peseta, Portuguese escudo and Irish punt stayed inside but were sharply devalued. Soon the infamously pricey Nordic countries were also forced to cut their currencies loose from the German mark. Then, early last month, the system cracked again, with all but the mark and the Dutch guilder freed to float by 15 percent above or below the system's official rates.
What this means is that today the dollar has its own ever-changing rate against each of the European currencies, which are in turn floating against each other. The European reference point, though, remains the German mark. And if the European Community currencies are to have any hope of meeting their target of fusing into a single regional currency by 1999, it will be because they have regained their stability against the mighty mark.
For the moment, though, things are still confusing. Sharp swings are now unlikely because with most European currencies floating, speculators can no longer gamble on forcing -- and reaping the profits of -- a sudden devaluation. Yet, even between the time this article is written and read, dollar rates in Western Europe will change. Early in August, for example, a dollar was worth 6.10 French francs; early in September, it was worth 5.70 francs. But in mid-August 1992 the dollar fetched just 4.92 francs -- so vive la difference!
Elsewhere -- in Mediterranean and Nordic Europe -- la difference has been much greater, enough to ease the cost of a good vacation, enough perhaps to entice a traveler to head for, say, Italy instead of France. Why not? With the dollar's value in Italy jumping from 1,100 to around 1,560 lire in barely one year, a $100 dinner for two in Siena last summer now costs just $70, a $250-a-night double room in Rome in August 1992 now goes for $176. The same applies to Spain, where the dollar, trading at 94 pesetas last summer, is worth around 131 pesetas now. And to Sweden, where the krona has lost 33 percent of its value against the dollar in less than a year.
AN economist would probably argue that these devaluations have really been against the German mark -- and the dollar has simply benefited. But who cares? The American traveler can expect only between 7 and 10 percent more for his dollar when he visits Switzerland, Austria, Germany and the Netherlands -- and that is hardly enough to take the sting out of prices in those countries. But, for the first time in several years, it is worth having a currency table handy when looking through holiday brochures for Europe.
The Nordic countries have become particularly interesting. Italy and Spain only became exorbitantly expensive in the late 1980's and are now reasonable again, but it seems that Sweden, Norway and Finland have always been pricey -- and now their fjords, lakes, mountains and majestic emptiness are also within reach. In winter? Well, they do have skiing -- and Lillehammer in Norway will be host of the Winter Olympics in February.
For travelers looking for sun and food cooked in olive oil next summer, the best bargains are likely to be Greece and Portugal, two countries that had not reached "European" prices even before their currencies began to slide.
But will the exchange situation still be this favorable next year? The answer lies in the dollar. After the convulsions of the past year, most European currencies have now found their natural levels in relation to each other. The unpredictable variable is how the dollar will perform. From now on, if Western Europe is to become still cheaper, it will be because the dollar has strengthened -- and not because European currencies have crumbled.

HEADLINE: EUROPE: FALL AND WINTER;
Sir Peter Hall Is Star Of London's Season

BYLINE: By BENEDICT NIGHTINGALE; BENEDICT NIGHTINGALE is the chief theater critic of The Times of London.

 BODY:
WHO is the busiest theatrical director in London this fall? Surprisingly, it is not Stephen Daldry or Sam Mendes or another of the drama's bold young Turks, though they too have lively-sounding productions about to bubble to the surface. No, it is the Grand Old Man of the British theater: the creator of the Royal Shakespeare Company, former chief executive of the National Theater, the 62-year-old Sir Peter Hall.
Here he is with no fewer than five productions already arrived in London or soon to hit town. His revival of Terence Rattigan's "Separate Tables," a double bill about outcasts and loners in the dowdy British 1950's, continues to run successfully at the Albery, as does his version of Aristophanes' "Lysistrata" at Wyndhams. On Oct. 12 his production of Shakespeare's seldom-performed "All's Well That Ends Well," with Sophie Thompson (Emma's younger sister) as the heroine, comes to Royal Shakespeare headquarters at the Barbican. A week later Goldsmith's genial "She Stoops to Conquer" opens on Shaftesbury Avenue, followed by yet another of Sir Peter's autumn offerings, Pam Gems's portrait of the greatest of French chanteuses, "Piaf." 
 "Piaf" won Jane Lapotaire a Tony Award when it was first produced in New York in 1980. This time it is Elaine Paige, still best known for creating the title role in "Evita," who will be huskily insisting that "Je ne regrette rien." It is a performance sure to get plenty of attention when it reaches the West End, probably at the beginning of December. But by then critics and audiences alike may be feeling a bit glutted, and not only with work by Sir Peter. Given that Britain is still precariously clambering out of recession, it promises to be one of the theater's fuller falls.
Already, Harold Pinter's first full-length play in 15 years, a dark and fascinating piece called "Moonlight," has opened at the tiny Almeida Theater in Islington, north London. The National's magical production of "Carousel" has been revived at the Shaftesbury. And the Royal Shakespeare Company has given Tom Stoppard's "Travesties" its first major airing for nearly 20 years, casting Antony Sher as our guide to Lenin, Joyce and the other inhabitants of Zurich circa 1917. But there is more to come from both the big companies, not to mention Mr. Sher himself.
He has become one of the most highly-regarded performers in the British theater, an actor of such charisma and energy that you feel a lightning rod should be installed on any stage he occupies, just to insure he doesn't electrocute the rest of the cast. For those not familiar with his work, an ideal introduction would be the title character in Terry Hands's production of "Tamburlaine the Great," which was seen at Stratford last year and resurfaces at the Barbican on Oct. 14. Imagine a blend of wolf, snake and noble savage, and even then you have only just begun to define the complexities of his personal zoology.
Later in the year, the Shakespeare company is offering two other productions of particular interest. One is a new play by Alan Ayckbourn called "Wildest Dreams," about the lurid fantasies and drab lives of a group of Dungeons and Dragons fanatics. The other is a "Macbeth" that promises to be somewhat unusual, since the protagonist is being played by Derek Jacobi, an actor whose subtle, sophisticated skills will certainly be stretched by the challenge of playing Shakespeare's rough thane.
"Macbeth" opens on Dec. 16 and will continue through Christmas and into the new year. Those in search of more seasonal fare would do better to try the National, where Alan Bennett's gently bucolic "Wind in the Willows" is being revived for the second time. But that does not mean a bland, undemanding fall season on London's South Bank. With the National presenting both parts of Tony Kushner's AIDS saga, "Angels in America," in November and staging what it calls "The David Hare Trilogy" a month earlier, the very opposite would seem to be the case.
David Hare is the dramatist who sent New York the superb "Plenty" and, more recently and less successfully, "The Secret Rapture." His work has always been highly political, and usually pretty skeptical about the state of Britain itself; but his trilogy is more systematically so. The first play, "Racing Demon," in 1990, was a look at the Church of England. "Murmuring Judges," which followed in 1991, examined the judiciary, the police and the other forces of law and order. Both will be revived in tandem with the new "Absence of War," in which the Hare blowtorch will be turned onto Westminster and Whitehall.
On Oct. 15 Stephen Daldry, whose production of J. B. Priestley's "An Inspector Calls" won every major directing award last year, is tackling a still obscurer nearly 20th-century play. That is "Machinal" by the American dramatist Sophie Treadwell, the expressionist crime story that back in 1928 introduced a boyish Clark Gable to Broadway. Also in October, Eileen Atkins and Penelope Wilton come to the West End in a new piece called "Vita and Virginia," about the relationship, both personal and literary, of Virginia Woolf and Vita Sackville-West. And on Nov. 11 a highly promising younger actor, Alan Cumming, brings his performance of Hamlet to the tiny Donmar Warehouse in Covent Garden.
The Donmar is a theater well worth discovering. In the 1970's the Royal Shakespeare Company presented some of its most important productions there, including the world premiere of "Piaf." Now it has been remodeled and rebuilt and, less than a year after its reopening, is becoming the pacemaker in the aging heart of the West End. New plays by Michael Frayn and Athol Fugard have been performed there, as has the most successful production yet of Stephen Sondheim's "Assassins." But nothing is likely to attract more notice than its last offering of the year, a revival of the musical "Cabaret" with the gifted Jane Horrocks as Sally Bowles.
That will be staged by the theater's director, Sam Mendes, who at 28 is just two years younger than Peter Hall was when he formed the Royal Shakespeare Company in Stratford. Thirty-five years from now, will he too be a Grand Old Man, with productions pouring into town like honeybees into a hive? I would not be at all surprised.

HEADLINE: Life in the Baltics

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In her review of "The Baltic Revolution" (Aug. 29), Liah Greenfeld on the one hand states that the Baltic countries started the breakup of the Soviet Union and on the other says that Anatol Lieven has written a detailed book on only marginally significant countries. Are the Baltics really so insignificant as Ms. Greenfeld seems to think? 
 The subhead of her review says that even though there is no more Soviet Union, "that doesn't mean life in the Baltic states has got better." By every liberal standard, life in the Baltics is better now. People can travel as they wish, nobody is sent to Siberia, the governments are latitudinarian, and the press is pre-capitalist pluralistic. Vigorous parliaments exist in the Baltics and, surprisingly, economies are stable -- stores are filling up. Human rights in the Baltic countries, a special concern of Ms. Greenfeld's, meet the world's highest standards.
Citizenship rights, in comparison even with the United States, are liberal. Eighty percent of Russians living in Latvia, for example, had the right to vote in Latvia's elections. The Baltics have always, except for longer or shorter periods of occupation, been multicultural societies, and nothing since the liberation has occurred in any one of them to threaten that.
 
A. EZERGAILIS
Ithaca, N.Y.

HEADLINE: EUROPE: FALL AND WINTER: What's New, From Soho to Salamanca -- Hungary;
A theater festival, fashions and food

BYLINE: By Jane Perlez

 BODY:
In the early 1980's, as Hungary's politics began to thaw a little, so did the cultural scene. It was then that a group of actors broke away from the establishment Nemzeti theater and established the Katona Jozsef Company. The group of 30 actors quickly became known at home and abroad for its spectacular style, a reputation that helped Budapest to be selected for this year's festival of the Union of European Theaters.
The festival's arrival in Budapest is yet another sign that Eastern Europe is fast joining Western Europe spiritually, if not politically and economically. 
 From Oct. 22 to Nov. 7, 10 companies ranging from Britain's Royal Shakespeare Company to St. Petersburg's Maly Drama Theater will perform in Budapest theaters, including the pretty Arany Janos Szinhaz and the turn-of-the-century Operettszinhaz.
The plays were selected by each company wanting to show its work to colleagues from other countries rather than by a festival director imposing a certain taste. The choices are varied. The Royal National Theater of London will bring its new production of "Sweeney Todd," directed by Declan Donnellan. The Piccolo Teatro di Milano will stage "Il Campiello" by Carlo Goldoni, the 17th-century Venetian writer.
Perhaps the biggest attraction will be the drama from St. Petersburg called "Gaudeamus," written and directed by Lev Dogyinm. The play is based on a novel about life in the Soviet Army and is described as satirical and cruel.
The Royal Shakespeare Company will perform Adrian Noble's version of "The Winter's Tale;" the Teatre Lilure from Barcelona is staging Heiner Muller's "Quartett;" and the Odeon from Paris will show Ibsen's "John Gabriel Borkman," directed by Luc Bondy. Running parallel to these main performances will be six productions of the Katona Jozsef Theater's small-stage, 100-seat theater, Kamra. They include "Hamlet," scheduled for Oct. 30 and Nov. 5.
Most performances will offer simultaneous translation by earphones. Tickets to the festival are on sale at Budapest's Central Box Office at Andrassy ut 18 near the Opera House. Of more permanence are two restaurants popular with the city's stylish young crowd. Luau, a Polynesian restaurant, is as strong on visual effects as on eating. A large Gauguin-inspired painting of the tropics hangs in the entrance. The seafood -- lobster, crab and shrimp -- comes from the United States and Australia. About $10 for a five-course meal. 5 Zoltan Street, Budapest V;, (361) 131 4352.
At Remiz, the owner, Alise Mezody, has fashioned a simple, airy bistro with an outside terrace. The waiters are chosen as much for their looks as their service. The food is European and Hungarian, but it's mostly the table hopping and chatter that the patrons come for. 5 Budakeszi ut, 1021 Budapest; (361) 176 1896.
Before World War II, Budapest had many fine couturiers. A new generation is beginning to emerge, led by Lucia Hegyi, who was born in Ukraine, grew up in Prague and is now in Budapest where she has opened a salon for ready-to-wear. In the fall she will introduce her first haute couture collection. The clothes, known by the label Luan by Lucia, are full of color -- bright emerald, purples. The coats are glamorous at either floor length or mid-calf. The suits, with pants or skirts, hug the body. 62 Bajcsy Zsilinszky Street, Budapest V1; (361) 111 5895.
Budapest's first French bookshop opens this fall in the green-hued French Institute on the banks of the Danube, a companion to Bestsellers, the English-language bookstore on Oktober 6 Street.
 JANE PERLEZ

HEADLINE: The Big City Newcomer Housing Blues

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
AFTER growing up in Cincinnati and graduating from college, Tracy Hildebrand and Cheryl Braje moved to Manhattan earlier this year and embarked on what is, perhaps, the city's first and most daunting survival test: finding an apartment.
With little trouble, Ms. Hildebrand found the apartment of her dreams. She moved in with two other young women in an affordable three-bedroom apartment in a modern doorman building in a safe, affluent block on the Upper East Side. 
 "It was smooth sailing for me," she said.
Ms. Braje's search, meanwhile, was a nightmare. She briefly lived in a Murray Hill apartment, where she was conned out of a month's rent by an landlady who yelled at her in Arabic. She then bounced between a family friend's co-op, a Staten Island flophouse, a Day's Inn in Stamford, Conn., and a spartan $155-a-week room in a building in an undesirable part of Manhattan, on 34th Street at 10th Avenue. She now lives in a one-room third-floor walk-up in SoHo that she shares with two roommates.
"It's cheap, but it's small," she said.
The stories of Ms. Hildebrand and Ms. Braje, who knew each other in Cincinnati but attended different universities, illustrates the wide range of experiences that 20-something out-of-towners have when they move to Manhattan and look for their first apartment.
Though the stream of young newcomers moving to New York is much smaller than in recent years, in large part because of the almost half-million fewer jobs in the region, they still arrive each summer and autumn by the thousands, eager, if not to settle in the thousands, eager, if not to settle in the city permanently, then at least to pursue its pleasures and parry its perils for a few years.
SOME, the lucky ones, come with well-paying first jobs; new associates at law firms often start at about $90,000 in Manhattan, and management consultants just starting out often earn $75,000. Or, they may have spouses or live-in companions to help pay the rent.
Or, like Ms. Hildebrand, who is 23 years old and graduated from the University of South Carolina with a degree in marketing, they may have an easy time finding roommates who will help cut living expenses in half, or in thirds or even more.
They also may have a combination of street-smarts from living near or visiting the city. Or they may have a few years of added maturity thanks to graduate school,law school or an M.B.A. program.
Or -- most important, perhaps -- they may be fortunate enough to work for a company with a relocation policy that not only pays moving expenses but also brokers' fees and security deposits and puts up their recruits in temporary housing while they look for an apartment or a roommate or both.
Others, though -- the unknowing, the unconnected, the unattached, those earning $18,000 a year as administrative assistants or $28,000 as account executives for a public relations firm or $35,000 as management trainees for a department store -- are more likely to have an experience like that of Ms. Braje, who is 23 and graduated from the University of Miami of Ohio with a marketing degre. They wander nomadically from sublease to sublease or share to share. Or they move to an outer borough or to suburbs like Jersey City or Hoboken. Or, worse, they move back home.
"It is exciting for the first couple of hours and then you start to get worried when you find out what you get for your money," said Brad Gibbs of Rye, N.Y., who graduated from Brown University and moved to Battery Park City, on the southern tip of Manhattan, this summer to take a job as a $35,000-a-year analyst with an investment bank on Wall Street. "You worry that you might have to move home with Mom and Dad, which crossed my mind."
Though recent arrivals in New York may find it difficult to believe, the lower end of the rental market is more affordable than it was five to eight years ago. In 1986, as a previous generation of new New Yorkers will attest, it was almost impossible -- without bribing a superintendent with "key money" or knowing someone who would illegally lease a rent-regulated apartment -- to fin a decent large studio or small one-bedroom apartment in a nice Manhattan neighborhood for under $1,000 a month.
Today, though finding such an apartment without a broker may still be difficult and require hours scouring classified ads, it is at least possible. Moreover, the term "key money" has virtually disappeared from the real estate lingo. And, in some less desirable neighborhoods, market-rate apartments may actually be lower priced than some rent-regulated units.
NEVERTHELESS, for many young newcomers to the city, living alone, even at what is considered the bottom price range of the market -- the $800-a-month studios and $1,100 one-bedroom apartments -- is still an option too expensive to consider.
"In the lower price ranges there is a very large proportion of people sharing apartments," said Nancy Packes, owner of the Feathered Nest, a real estate brokerage that specializes in rentals.
Living in Manhattan, as opposed to the other boroughs or the suburbs, is also much more of a possibility in the 90's. In the mid-80's, for instance, a large percentage of newcomers were priced out of Manhattan and moved to -- and helped gentrify -- cities like Hoboken or neighborhoods like Carroll Gardens, Park Slope, Boerum Hill and Cobble Hill in Brooklyn. Today, however, tose neighborhoods are fading in popularity among new arrivals to the city.
Michael Santomauro, owner and founder of Roommate Finders, a 14-year-old service that matches people seeking apartments with apartment renters seeking roommates, said he had stopped taking listings for Hoboken and Jersey City and was thinking about doing that for Brooklyn and Queens by year's end. "People with apartments in these areas aren't getting responses," he said.
Mr. Santomauro added that overall his business had dropped about 50 percent since the mid-80's, to about 3,500 clients a year, and that most of his competitors from that era had gone out of business. He noted, in particular, that the number of people with apartments seeking roommates had swelled.
"We are getting more apartment listings than people looking," he said. "It wasn't like that in the 80's. A big chunk of our clientele are those coming to New York for their first job, but unfortunately there aren't as many jobs, so the influx isn't as big as it was."
He also said that the type of person seeking a share situation was different than in the 1980's. Back then, he said, it was an economic necessity for many people moving to Manhattan, while now more people in their 20's are likely to take a roommate because they know no one in New York and they hope it will make their social adjustment easier.
"In the mid-80's they would usually come to us when they were exasperated," said Mr. Santomauro, who charges people seeking to share an apartment $195. For those who have an apartment and need a roommate, the fee is $39; formerly, there was no charge.
Virtually all of Roommate Finders' clients are under 35; most are between 25 and 30. The exceptions are usually the recently divorced, often newly single mothers.
UNLIKE the lower end of the rental market, the middle and higher ranges are as tight and expensive as ever, largely because of the dearth of new construction and because so many recession-shocked would-be buyers are renting.
Thus, finding a large one-bedroom unit in a quality building in a fashionable neighborhood for under $1,600 a month is not only difficult but also beyond the means of many young people starting their careers, particularly those who want to live alone. Agents, moreover, are also more needed in this price range. They generally charge tenants 15 percent of a year's rent.
Newcomers to the city are often stunned to find that New York is one of the few places in the nation where brokers usually collect fees from tenants. In most other places, landlords pay the fees.
In few cities, however, is the supply and demand for apartments so off-kilter. This, in large part, is because of the city's controversial rent-regulation system, which has taken many of the city's apartments off the market and given them to long-time occupants, regardless of need, at reduced rents.
"The product that people can find without brokers isn't there anymore," said Mrs. Packes of Feathered Nest. "There is a very limited offering by management companies, and if you counted the private person ads there are maybe a quarter to a third of the number of broker ads. And those ads are a small sampling of what is available through brokers."
Ms. Packes of Feathered Nest said that most of the clients who were recent graduates and new to the city had their fee paid for them by their employer, usually as part of their relocation package. "All of the companies that recruit the big banking, accounting, law, management consuting, investment banking firms, they usually pay the fees," she said.
She added that most of these clients know what to expect in the city's real estate market. "During recruitment, they give them an idea of what they should be prepared for," she said. "The last thing they need to do is offer a job and they come here and it's shock city."
Ms. Packes, who has one of the city's largest listings of rentals, also cautioned about the city's many unscrupulous brokers. "There are brokers that advertise nonexistent apartments to attract tenants in the hope that they can convert them to the paltry listings that they have," she said. "You're not going to know from the ads."
She advised new apartment hunters not to waste their time with ads that tout apartments that sound too good or too affordable to be true.
"There are very few anomalies in this market,"' she said.
Because of fears about crime and daily commuting by subway, newcomers often seek apartments that are close to their jobs. Battery Park City, for example, a short walk to Wall Street, is popular with new employees in the financial industry. Many apartments there, moreover, do not require the tenants to pay broker's fees.
There are drawbacks to Battery Park City, though. Brad Gibbs, for example, said that many of the people living there were older and had children. The development also is somewhat isolated from the rest of Manhattan and suffers from a lack of nearby nightlife and cultural amenities.
"But," he added, "I figured I would rather walk to work and commute to play than commute to work and walk to play."
Even in Battery Park City, however, sharing the rent is almost a necessity for those just starting out. Mr. Gibbs, for instance, lives with a girlfriend, Robin Peterson, also a Brown graduate, who earns about $30,000 and also works as an analyst for a financial firm on Wall Street.
Mr. Gibbs, 23, and Ms. Peterson, 22, live in a junior one-bedroom of about 650 square feet in one of the development's high-rise doorman buildings; they live on the fifth floor and do not have a view of the Statue of Liberty, which would have cost them several hundred dollars a month more than the $1,250 they now pay.
"A doorman was one of our major considerations," Ms. Peterson said, echoing the sentiments of many women in the city. "And we wanted to be in a safe area, so you pay a premium for that."
During their four-day search, the couple looked at 30 or 40 apartments south of Greenwich Village. "We were adamant about having as short a commute as possible," Ms. Peterson said.
For some young people, particularly those right out of undergraduate programs, a lack of credit or job history can result in being rejected by management companies, not to mention more stringent co-op boards. Sometimes a co-signer on the lease, usually a parent, is necessary.
For Mr. Gibbs and Ms. Peterson, however, the approval process was smoothed by letters from their employers verifying their income. "We heard horror stories, but for us it was really sort of fun," Ms. Peterson said. "But we had good salaries and cooperative brokers and had a good choice between apartments we really liked."
She conceded, though, that she was fortunate to have a boyfriend with whom she could share the rent on a one-bedroom apartment. "Most of my friends who have their own bedroom have to pay $700 or $800 a month," she added. "A colleague of mine pays $725 for a studio."
Tracy Hildebrand was also lucky. She didn't have a high-paying job; her sales position with a menswear company pays only "in the thirties." Nor did she have a live-in boyfriend to share the rent. Instead, last December, when she graduated, she went to Roommate Finders and quickly met two other women looking for a third to share a three-bedroom apartment at 72d Street and Second Avenue. The total rent: $2,100 a month, or $700 each -- about one week's gross pay -- which is about what most real estate brokers and financial planners cite as the typical rent a tenant pays.
(In the 80's, the amount was often higher, either about one and a half week's gross pay or one-third of a month's gross salary. By this yardstick, the salary needed to comfortably pay for an average one-bedroom apartment in New York, which, according to Ms. Packes, rents for about $2,000 a month, is about $100,000 a year, beyond the range of even the highest earners in their first jobs.)
Like Mr. Gibbs and Ms. Peterson, Ms. Hildebrand's company also paid for a five-day apartment-hunting trip. "I just immediately went to Roommate Finders because I knew I couldn't find anything on my own," she said.
She recalled her meetings with prospective roommates as "hysterical."
"There were a lot of unique individuals," she said "There was a whole range from completely bohemian to the anal-rententive, this-is-my-corner-that's-your-corner kind of person."
Ms. Hildebrand described her current roommates as a "perpetual student" and a museum employee thinking of going to law school. They are 28 and 24, respectively and "have both been in the city for a while," she said.
THOUGH she is at ease with her roommates, she foresees having her own one-bedroom apartment in Manhattan in about two years. She expects, however, to pay only $1,200 a month, a rent that may be unrealistic and that, at least on much of the Upper East Side, would probably not include a doorman.
Cheryl Braje, meanwhile, doesn't have a doorman in her tiny SoHo studio on Sullivan Street between Price and Houston Streets. Her rent, however, is a fraction of Ms. Hildebrand's. Ms. Braje splits $875 a month three ways, not much even for someone earning only $30,000 a year as a management trainee for a department store chain.
Ms. Braje, however, has just quit her job and intends to seek work in advertising. Originally, she said, a campus recruiter lured her to New York with talk about the store's location amid the bright lights of the big city. When she arrived in the city last February, though, she was sent not to the mid-Manhattan store but to a store in Stamford, Conn., and then transferred to Staten Island, and then later sent to Brooklyn. For a young single woman, these places paled even in comparison to her hometown in Ohio.
If her job was disappointing, her apartment search was worse. Like Ms. Hildebrand, she used Roommate Finders, but wound up living in February with a woman of indeterminate nationality who claimed to be an investment banker but who turned out to be a con artist who fleeced newcomers to New York, renting out -- without leases -- the same space to several women at the same time.
"I was completely naive to how people are up here -- she was running a big scam," she said. "I was going to sue her, but I didn't want to see her again. I gave her $1,350 and I lived for there on a pull-out couch for three weeks with an illegal alien in a studio divided with a sheet and every day she threatened to throw my stuff out."
"I didn't go back to the Roommate Exchange," she added.
MS. BRAJE'S next stop was Stamford, where her boyfriend helped bail her out financially. They stayed at a Day's Inn for three weeks, until they ran out of money. She then broke up with her boyfriend and stayed for two weeks at the Y.M.C.A. in Stamford.
Then she was transferred to Staten Island, where she found a room in a house for $125 a week. She lived there only a day, though. "I realized," she said, "that the woman who lived in the house was a hooker."
Her boyfriend returned again, but all he managed to do was wreck her rental car. "I remember walking up to my personnel manager in tears," she said. "And I as trying so hard to make a good impression."
By Easter, her parents arrived in the city to help her out; she was staying with family friends on the Upper East Side at this time. They said they were willing to pay up to $1,500 a month for an apartment on a month-to-month lease until she found a roommate and could extend the lease. Unfortunately, she couldn't find an apartment on a short-term basis. "We couldn't find anything that was for less than six months," she said. And taking an apartment by herself was simply too expensive.
"I thought that $30,000 was a lot of money -- it is back in Ohio," she said of her salary. "But it's nothing here."
After that, Ms. Braje moved into temporary housing for women at the Webster Apartments, on 34th Street and 10th Avenue, and paid $155 a week. "It was like a dorm really, and I stayed there for a month and a half," she said. "It was safe, but really unfriendly."
In June, however, almost five months after her arrival, she found her current apartment in SoHo. By chance and through some friends at work, she met someone who needed a roommate.
"I have really grown up a lot," she said. "I am a lot tougher now than I was in suburban Cincinnati. All my friends can't believe I am still here."
Reflecting further upon her experience, Cheryl said she had learned not to be so trusting and that sharing an apartment and having compatible roommates was crucial for anyone young and moving to New York for the first time.
"I would say come with a friend or have someone in mind that you want to room with," she said.
Ms. Braje also has learned what is perhaps the paramount lesson for anyone moving to, or even visiting, Manhattan.
"Make sure you have enough money," she said.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Specialized Buildings;
Filling Up Space With Like-Minded Tenants

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
LIKE many not-so-new and not-so-fancy Manhattan office buildings, 1040 Avenue of the Americas couldn't make a dent in its 25 percent vacancy rate. Its 39th Street location was not a great draw, and it had no particular amenities.
Then a couple years ago, the Winoker Realty brokers who manage the building started marketing it to textile companies. They stressed that the building was just one block from the garment district (albeit a very long one) and that by clustering in the building tenants could offer one-stop shopping for textile buyers. 
 "We persuaded tenants that they should be near the people they sell to," said Sidney Winoker, Winoker Realty's president.
The result: a once persistently vacant B-building with a mishmash of tenants is now a 95 percent-occupied building specializing in the textile industry and getting perfectly respectable rents in the low $20's per square foot.
Such success stories are being repeated a lot these days, as more landlords turn to industry specialization to distinguish their otherwise undistinguished buildings. They look enviously at the high rents and decent occupancy rates commanded by the Toy Center, at 200 Fifth Avenue at 23d Street, or by 579 and 589 Fifth Avenue, between 47th and 48th Streets, the latest buildings to be incorporated into the diamond district. And the landlords want equally profitable niches for their buildings.
Examples abound. The office space atop A.& S. Plaza on 33d Street and Avenue of the Americas, the old Gimbels building, has become the Children's Wear Center; 425 East 61st Street is a medical building, as is 30 East 40th Street; 305 East 63d Street is a decorative arts center.
And new industry buildings are being conceived constantly. Safra Bank just bought 546 Fifth Avenue, near 46th Street, and will market the space it does not use to other banks.
CBS, meanwhile, fully expects the 10 floors it will not use at 1697 Broadway, the 14-story office building attached to the Ed Sullivan theater at 53d Street that CBS bought for David Letterman's show, to go entirely to television production companies. Industry scuttlebutt has it that the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting is already negotiating for space.
"We haven't even finished renovating, yet so many people have called about space that we're already turning away those who want less than half a floor," said Edward Grebow, a CBS senior vice president.
The benefits to tenants of being among others in their industry are legion. They can hold joint open houses for customers and chip in for cooperative advertising campaigns. They can agree on the type of security system their industry requires. And smaller tenants can often hope for a spillover in any traffic that larger tenants generate. Someone visiting Hasbro at the Toy Center, for example, might well make a quick stop at some smaller toy company.
In fact, landlords of some specialized buildings play on those synergies, chipping in for the cost of cocktail parties or seminars for tenants' customers, or placing handheld lists of tenants in lobbies that visitors can carry with them as they browse from showroom to showroom.
The benefit to landlords, meanwhile, is double: higher rents and more tenants.
"IF you establish a critical mass of related companies in a building, their competitors feel they have to be there," said Robert L. Freedman, a vice chairman of Williams Real Estate, which has managed several clustered-industry buildings. "And that enables you to charge monopolistic prices."
Of course, that approach is not without risks, particularly in a recession.
"The problem with specialized buildings is that in bad times their fixed costs get too high for the tenants to support," said Josh N. Kuriloff, a director at Cushman & Wakefield.
Time was that 305 Seventh Avenue, near 27th Street, was a fully rented fur industry building. Then the fur industry "fell off the face of the earth," recalled Barry Gosin, president of Newmark Real Estate, the building's leasing agent. The building, half empty a couple years ago, is now a condominium for not-for-profit agencies.
Perhaps the worse difficulties have befallen the Decoration and Design building, at 979 Third Avenue, near 58th Street. Before the recession took its toll, this residential furniture building had a waiting list. James S. Meiskin, a senior managing director at Wm. A. White/Grubb & Ellis, recalls one tenant who renewed a lease there in 1987 for $45 a foot.
"I told them I could get them even better space down the street for $30, but they wouldn't budge," Mr. Meiskin said.
NO one is paying those rents today. The building has not only lost more than 15 percent of its tenants, but has had to slash rents for so many others that it could not meet its debt payments. It went bankrupt two months ago. The Chicago Merchandise Mart, which operates a huge, successful furniture and housewares selling area in Chicago, has been retained to try to lease the building up again.
Still, in this real estate market a lot of landlords are more willing to bet on their tenants' health than on their prospects for leasing space in buildings that don't offer like-minded tenants.
Sometimes they have no choice.
For example, the developers needed at least $35 a square foot in rent to cover the costs of the four floors of office space atop A.& S. Plaza. The problem was, no office tenant would pay that amount for that location. So they marketed the space, which has separate entrances at 100 West 33d Street, as a Children's Wear Center, wooing tenants like Kahn-Lucas-Lancaster, Doe Spun and Hush Puppies from the two older children's-wear buildings at 112 West 34th Street and 131 West 33d. Others followed. Today the building is three-quarters full, all with companies that specialize in children's wear.
The owners of 568-578 Broadway, near Prince Street, are seeking similar success with art galleries. The type of affordable storefront space coveted by art galleries is pretty hard to find in SoHo these days, yet plenty of SoHo buildings, including 568-578, are languishing half empty. The owners split the floors on one side of the building into small spaces, suitable for start-up galleries, and the other into large spaces, for established ones. And they advertised heavily in guides and art magazines.
Already, four of the building's 12 floors are occupied by art galleries.
And Winoker Realty, the building's leasing agent, has started a temporary leasing program in which galleries or individual artists who need space for a show can rent a gallery by the month.
"We get the advantage of the advertising they do, and our permanent tenants get the advantage of the added traffic," said Fred I. Adlman, Winoker's executive director.
Even well-occupied buildings are going the specialized route these days, in hopes of commanding higher rents.
Five years ago, 37 West 39th Street was full of tiny tenants paying low rents. Its owners redid the lobby, put in new elevators and created showroom space, which they marketed to accessory manufacturers. Today nine of the 36 tenants are in accessory- related businesses; whenever a new one signs up, the building takes an ad in Women's Wear Daily announcing yet another arrival.
THAT sort of high-profile trumpeting is almost essential to marketing a specialized building, in that it is the pull of like-minded companies far more than the pull of the building itself that draws new tenants. In fact, many landlords will offer cut-rate deals to kick-start a new specialty building.
Kahn-Lucas was one of the first tenants at the new Children's Wear Center. Mr. Kuriloff, Kahn-Lucas's broker, said he was able to negotiate a lot more free rent and a high landlord contribution toward customizing the space because of that.
"The landlord knew that small and medium-sized businesses will follow the leader because they want the benefit of the traffic the larger businesses will generate, particularly during market week," Mr. Kuriloff said.
Turns out that is exactly what happened, but Kahn-Lucas hedged its bets: it got a clause that allowed it to cancel its lease if the building did not reach a critical mass of industry tenants within a couple of years.
"Being in a magnificent building with low rent but no other industry members would be suicidal," Mr. Kuriloff said.

At the Decoration and Design building, 979 Third Avenue near 58th Street, 15 percent of the tenants had left and rents for many others had been slashed before bankruptcy two months ago. HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Comprehensive Land-Use Bill Faces a Tough Fight

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
THE autonomous control of land use by planning and zoning commissions in Connecticut's 169 towns may be in for some momentous changes in the next few years, but not without a fight.
A bill by the General Assembly's Task Force on the State Plan of Conservation and Development, designed to set up a comprehensive land-use policy by region, will be introduced in the 1994 legislative session, convening the first week of February. 
 It would require each region to adopt land-use regulations consistent with a state plan and each town to adopt regulations consistent with the regional and state plans. A version presented in the 1993 session passed three legislative committees but died in a tie vote of the Judiciary Committee.
"Regional land use is a skill that we must learn," said Mary Mushinsky, Democratic Representative from Wallingford and chairwoman of the 30-member task force. "Individual decisions by so many towns in a small state are more and more disjointed and harmful to other towns."
As examples she noted that a town wanting a shopping mall to increase its tax base will bring one in, duplicating one in the next town and sacrificing regional agricultural and recreational land. Or developers seeking cheaper land will create residential outposts to which highways must be built, followed by businesses, schools and municipal services, increasing random sprawl.
One of the task force members is Gerald B. Lucas, First Selectman of Killingworth, a 36-square-mile community with 4,980 residents. "I favor the idea on a lukewarm basis," he said. "Changes in a town's right to control its land flies in the face of the New Englander's God-given right.
"But when one looks at the demographics and economy of the state and the problems of the cities, it's obvious that more and more mandates are going to come down to the small town level. I'd rather be in front of the cart than behind it, and I think it has a chance of passing this year."
Monitoring of the towns would be overseen by 15 existing regional planning agencies, established by the state as advisory bodies in 1959 after Connecticut abolished its eight county governments. The agencies would have legal clout that they do not enjoy now, but a perceived infringement on their bailiwicks has made them wary of the plan.
"I don't feel it's time to throw out the concept," said Mary Ellen Kowalewski, executive director of the Capitol Region Council of Governments, Hartford's regional planning agency. "But I'm concerned about the lack of specifics."
Richard Carpenter, executive director of the Southwestern Regional Planning Agency, covering Fairfield County, called the plan "complex and cumbersome."
"I attended task force meetings, and a lot of the coordination they seek already exists through normal channels," he said. "This seems like an added layer to regional planning agencies, with authority coming from the top down."
Sentiments ranging from tepid to combative are widespread. The Connecticut Conference of Municipalities wants clearer definitions of costs and decision-making at the local level. The Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association in Stamford takes no position on the bill, but encourages study of regional issues.
"I would oppose any measure that would impose on municipalities any regional or state control over land," said Senator William Nickerson, a Greenwich Republican. "I believe municipalities are best able to determine use of their own land. A town like Greenwich could be destroyed by outside factors. Full-time professional zoning officials have been in place here for decades, unlike some rural communities."
Representative Jefferson B. Davis, a Pomfret Democrat, heads the Planning and Development Committee that supports the bill. He calls it "one of the most important issues facing the state."
"WHEN businesses think about expanding," he said, "city taxes push them into the suburbs, which pushes the suburbs into the exurbs and rural areas, creating more sprawl, more single-occupancy vehicles driving to work."
Support from the Home Builders' Association of Connecticut comes from its task force representative, Robert Fusari, a Middletown builder.
"The plan would simplify things and shorten approval time by allowing builders to deal with one agency," he said, "knowing what the rules are for all 169 towns rather than facing 169 sets of rules."
According to Robert D. Yaro, executive director of the Regional Plan Association in Manhattan, "there are at least 10 states that have adopted a regional land use plan, and more are in the process."
"In New England," he added, "only Connecticut and New Hampshire have none."
Apart from the environmental and esthetic considerations, "they save money," he said.
"In this economy it's particularly appropriate to curtail the costs of new schools, buses and police and fire stations by concentrating development where it already exists," Mr. Yaro said.
In New Jersey, where a plan was implemented last year, the state expects to save $5 billion over 20 years. Herbert Simmens, director of the Office of State Planning in Trenton, said "we set it up because open space and agricultural land were disappearing, highways were overly congested and housing was less affordable."
PERSUADING each of New Jersey's 527 municipalities and 612 school districts "has been time-consuming," he said, "but all 21 counties have participated voluntarily to a greater or lesser degree."
Among the incentives in the New Jersey plan is a process by which the plan functions as a one-stop clearing house for proposals by towns. Approved projects then get funds from appropriate state agencies.
This past summer Michael J. Cacace, a Stamford lawyer, assembled a coalition that supports the Connecticut task force's efforts and is helping to write new legislation for presentation in February.
The task force includes Terry Tondro, professor of law at the University of Connecticut ; Dwight Merriam of the Hartford law firm of Robinson & Cole; William Raveis, a realtor; Donald Strait, executive director of the Connecticut Fund for the Environment; the Connecticut Housing Coalition; the Connecticut Audubon Society and the Connecticut Institutes of Architects and Landscape Architects.
"We are examining the best modalities of existing plans," said Mr. Cacace.
"In order to preserve local control, municipalities will have to work together," he continued, "or services will be sited arbitrarily as they have been for years -- cellular phone antennae, solid and hazardous waste, group homes for the retarded, weigh stations. If towns help fashion the system now they will have more control in future."

HEADLINE: Elvis Discovered in a New Jersey Basement!

BYLINE: By JESSE HOLLAND

 BODY:
ROB LEVY, a piano dealer from Elizabeth who collects records, is no stranger to basements, attics and old record shops, where he has found all sorts of minor treasures. But what he found in a basement in New Jersey took his breath away: believed to be a one-of-a-kind 1957 Elvis Presley Christmas album, pressed in red vinyl as a keepsake by an RCA engineer.
"We've found what is probably the rarest record in the world in mint, pristine condition," Mr. Levy said. "The black vinyl 1957 Elvis Presley Christmas Album is one of the most collectible albums on the market today, and we have the only one in red vinyl." 
 But will the discovery catapult Mr. Levy and his two partners into a prominent place in the world of Elvis mythology? He, his partners and others say that this album should be a valuable collectible to record dealers and die-hard Presley fans. They hope it's worth as much as $75,000, although four record dealers asked to estimate the record's worth for this article suggested values that ranged from $2,000 to $10,000. The black vinyl version of the album is worth $500 to $1,500, the dealers said.
Mr. Levy and two friends who helped purchase the album, Freddie Nurman and Gene Van Severen, are still somewhat shaken by their good luck.
"Every record collector dreams of finding something like this," said Mr. Nurman, an unemployed real estate salesman. "The odds of finding something like this are similar to the odds of winning the lottery."
These three friends were brought together by their passion for record collecting. Mr. Levy and Mr. Nurman met at a collectors' show in Cranford, while Mr. Levy and Mr. Van Severen met when Mr. Levy took him a stack of records to be appraised. In the stack was the cover to the 1957 Elvis Christmas album.
"I told him if he had that record along with the case, he'd have something valuable," said Mr. Van Severen, who also works for the New Jersey Department of Vocational Rehabilitation. "I didn't know he was actually going to go out and find one."
 
RCA Has Master Copy
 Bernadette Moore, the archivist at RCA Records, which released Presley's records, said the red disk might be valuable to collectors.
"We at RCA don't put a value on things like that, because we have the master copies," Mrs. Moore said. "However, Elvis collectors would probably consider something like a red vinyl Elvis record valuable."
Mr. Nurman said he and his partners had already received an offer of $20,000.
"This is one of a kind," Mr. Van Severen said. "The only other completely unique Elvis record known of at this point is the record he made for his mother."
The three collectors said Elvis fans from as far away as Japan, Brazil and Argentina had inquired about the album. But the three men said they disagreed on whether they are going to sell it. Mr. Nurman wants to keep it. Mr. Levy wants to sell it. Mr. Van Severen can't decide. So for now, they are keeping the record in a climate-controlled vault at a bank they declined to name.
They were extremely lucky to find the album, Mr. Levy said. A friend told him about a retired employee of an RCA record-pressing plant in Rockaway that had since closed; the man was selling his possessions to raise money for a move to Florida. Mr. Levy said that after the man sold him his collection of 2,000 records, he asked Mr. Levy if he wanted to see something special.
"That's when he pulled out the Presley record," Mr. Levy said. "He told me that he worked at the plant out in Rockaway back in 1957, when the regular record was being pressed. He decided to make a souvenir for himself and pressed out a red vinyl one from the wax used for the classical albums."
Thinking it was a fake, Mr. Levy left it with its owner, but soon changed his mind.
"After I talked to some of my friends about it, they told me I was crazy not to go back to the old man," Mr. Levy said. "I then called him back and started to negotiate for the record."
Mr. Levy said that the former RCA employee, who asked him not to reveal his name, knew what he had. That's when Mr. Nurman and Mr. Van Severen got into the act, they said.
"Rob found it, Gene appraised it and I negotiated for it," Mr. Nurman said.
The collectors won't say what they paid for the record, although Mr. Nurman said "it was a considerable sum."
They said they have verified the authenticity of the album. "This red vinyl record contains speckling, which shows that it was pressed with the same machine that the black vinyl records were pressed with," Mr. Van Severen said. "The machine was not cleaned out in between pressings of the black vinyl records and the red vinyl, and pieces of black wax got into the red vinyl. That's one of the factors that convinced us that the record was authentic."
They have not yet allowed other record appraisers to look at the album, however. Mr. Van Severen, who runs a record appraisal business from his home, said there would be nothing with which to compare the record. The three friends have not played the entire album. But what they did hear was the final test of authenticity. After about 30 or 40 seconds of "Santa Claus Is Back in Town," they were convinced, they said, and the record went straight to the vault.
"Right now, we're just going to bask in the glory of this record," Mr. Levy said, smiling. "Maybe the King himself will come back and ask to buy it."
