HEADLINE: Worry Time for Wall Street?

BYLINE: By SUSAN ANTILLA

 BODY:
Is it finally time to jump ship? On Wall Street, where awe over the longevity of the bull market has been giving way in some quarters to disbelief, many are worried that the answer could be yes.
Every widely watched indicator of stock market value has been flirting with historical danger levels, whether it be the dividend yield (too low) or the price of stocks divided by earnings (too high). Privately held companies, sensing that the window of opportunity to sell shares to a very willing public might abruptly close, are filing their going-public documents as fast as their lawyers can review them. Or even sooner. 
 What's more, the small investor, frequently ridiculed as the player who always buys just as it's time to make a hasty retreat, has been jumping in with both feet, helping to send the Dow Jones industrial average to a record high of 3,663.83 on Aug. 26.
Last week, the jitters turned to shivers for some when the Dow fell 37.45 points on Monday, the steepest one-day drop since early April, and another 38.56 points on Tuesday. The market regained its balance Wednesday, and the Dow closed Friday at 3,543.11, down 70.14 points for the week. Still, the losses earlier in the week were a reminder that stocks had barely corrected since October 1990, when the Dow was just under 2,400 and the bull market began its latest climb.
The shaky political situation in Russia contributed to last week's investor unease. But the jumpiness had more to do with fundamentals: lackluster earnings reports and a still sputtering economic recovery. Indeed, worrywarts say the Dow would have to drop to 2,200 before stocks would sell at a valuation more typical of the last 20 years.
If that isn't reason enough to worry, next Friday is the first day of October, the month of choice for stock market crashes.
So, is a big selloff just around the corner, or is the market simply catching its breath before continuing its climb? Notwithstanding the warning signals and the growing worries, the experts remain as divided as ever about the market's next twist and turn.
The bears can't take their eyes off the flashing red lights.
"The fundamentals are so bearish they offset everything," said Norman Fosback, who publishes the Market Logic newsletter. "With the dividend yield under 3 percent, there is no question the market is on borrowed time."
But the bulls see a continuing appetite for stocks from investors both large and small, at least if interest rates remain low.
"What we're seeing from all the ticker tape is good solid trades, not just stocks being bid up by dealers or other people taking advantage of the little guy," said Laszlo Birinyi, an analyst in Greenwich, Conn. "If you look at the size of the upticks, you see 10,000- and 20,000-share trades, which means the institutions are stepping up."
According to another bull, William M. LeFevre of Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum, a New York securities firm, "There's one crash in a person's lifetime, and I've already seen mine," he said in reference to the October 1987 collapse.
But with stock prices so high, the market needn't crash for investors to lose sizable chunks of money. Portfolios can implode industry by industry or company by company, a slow-torture process that Justin Mamis, a technical analyst, contends has already begun -- and will continue. Mr. Mamis said the market is in the midst of a dangerous "top," a period in which companies with "important names" are falling apart while market indexes levitate deceptively near their highs.
In fact, while the widely watched general market indexes were hitting record highs this summer, clients of Mike Stolper, a consultant who matches money managers with wealthy investors, were fit to be tied over the state of their portfolios.
"I talk to some of my clients who are down 5 percent this year because of Merck, and you'd think someone had kidnapped their children," he said. "When people lose 5 percent while the market is at new highs, they have this sense that money is falling from the sky -- and they don't have a bucket."
That's the kind of market in which money managers like Eddie Brown of Brown Capital Management do best: a stock picker's market, in which adept players can profit no matter what the market's overall trend. But even Mr. Brown, who says he's "still positive" on the market, throws a big caveat into his bullish stance: if interest rates rise, all bets are off.
Low interest rates have been the hypnotic mantra of Wall Street's bulls, providing a justification since early 1991 for armies of analysts to say "buy" and for legions of investors to respond, "Where do I mail my check?" For once, brokers had no need to twist the arms of customers to see the wisdom of stocks over safe parking spots like certificates of deposit and money market accounts.
A sharp rise in rates -- to 6.5 percent or 7 percent on 5-year Treasury notes, trading late Friday at a yield of 4.79 percent -- would work like a sobering bucket of cold water on the hot market, Mr. Brown said.
How sobering would depend in large part on the reaction of the ubiquitous individual investor. The $64 million question on Wall Street now: What's that relatively new player going to do when the market suffers a pullback, or worse, a "meltdown"?
So critical is the answer that analysts like Steve Leuthold of the Leuthold Group in Minneapolis have taken to retooling their software, adding data about flows of money into mutual funds and levels of cash kept on hand by managers of those funds. It is those professionals who might have to quickly pay off investors should the public lose its cool.
But will they? Mr. LeFevre observed that small investors are both reluctant to change a new investment course and to take losses.
"It took them forever to get their money out of fixed-income parking places and into stocks," he said, "and now it's going to take forever for them to get it out of stocks."
Mr. Birinyi agreed, saying the data he tracks support the notion that small investors have made a long-term "secular" shift to stocks.
Bridget Macaskill, the president of Oppenheimer Capital Management, added that small investors have a good grasp of the risks of stocks, although they fall short of understanding the risks of some other investments, like Ginnie Mae funds.
Yet one popular Armageddon theory has it that the small investor will panic and inundate equity mutual funds with sell orders, resulting in a downward "cascading effect" on the market.
Given the market's traditional quirkiness, however, the very fact that everyone is focused on the weaknesses of funds probably means the impetus for a big correction, whenever it comes, will begin elsewhere.
Similarly, Wall Street's contrarians take heart whenever the crowd is in a cold sweat. It is at times when people are overly confident about markets that contrarians become most nervous about a selloff. Indeed, headlines -- like the one on this story -- that mention the word "worry" serve to comfort the bulls that the market is not in real danger.
What follows is a sampling of views from a half dozen veteran market watchers, representing bulls, bears and fence-sitters too.
 
 
 
SEEING BULLISH SIGNS EVERYWHERE
 LASZLO BIRINYI likes almost everything about the stock market right now, from bearish sentiment among investors and analysts (a good sign) to the fact that markets this year have rallied all around the world.
But the single most compelling reason to be bullish, according to Mr. Birinyi, who runs a financial consulting firm in Greenwich, Conn., is what he refers to as "positive money flow." What that means in non-Wall Streetese: on days when the overall market is weak, "investors take advantage of the weakness in stocks to buy stocks, which suggests they have faith in the future," he said.
Mr. Birinyi is also heartened to see that the individual investors who make trades of fewer than 100 shares each -- "odd-lotters" -- have undergone a sea change of enthusiasm over stocks. During the entire decade of the 1980's, there were only 18 trading days in which odd-lotters bought more shares than they sold.
So far in the 1990's, though, that trend has reversed. Odd-lot traders were net buyers on 10 trading days in 1990, followed by 95 trading days in 1991. By last year, the number had risen to 142, Mr. Birinyi said. "You're seeing a secular shift, where the individual has made a major change," he said. "These are not things that will be stopped by a couple of down days."
Asked about the bears' jitters over an historically low dividend yield on the S.& P. 500, Mr. Birinyi remained unflustered. "The dividend yield reached 3 percent in January 1992, so the red light has been on for some time," he said. Besides, he argued, the low yield is not so startling in periods during which inflation is as low as it is today.
 
 
UPBEAT, WITH A BUT

EDDIE C. BROWN of Baltimore's Brown Capital Management says he's positive on the stock market, but that almost doesn't matter considering his investment style.
Mr. Brown spends his time looking at individual stocks -- not the overall market. These days, he has his eye on some beaten-down growth stocks, particularly Home Depot, which fell from $46.625 on Aug. 16 to $37.75 on Friday. "We have not owned it before, because we thought it was too expensive," he said. "But we're beginning to warm up to it."
As for the overall market, much of Mr. Brown's bullishness rests on the assumption that interest rates will remain low; indeed, even his individual stock picks would be suspect if rates on five-year Treasury notes reached 6.5 percent to 7 percent.
But Mr. Brown is not particularly worried about the next 6 to 12 months. "Rates will creep up gradually as economic activity improves," he said. "But we don't expect a dramatic increase in rates or inflation."
He does say stock investors must begin to adjust their expectations. "The 17 to 18 percent compounded return of the last 10 years is not in the cards," he noted. "But you can stack up returns of 10 to 11 percent over the next 3-to-5 years."
"We're shopping," he added.
 
 
A BEAR'S ADVICE: GET HALF INTO CASH
 DURING the scariest of times for the stock market over the last 18 years, Norman Fosback has told investors to put as much as 50 percent of their money into "cash," or highly liquid money-market type instruments.
Mr. Fosback, whose Market Logic newsletter frequently outranks the competition in giving investors profitable advice, is saying to park half your money in cash now. "For us, that's quite bearish," he said.
Bothering him most of all about today's market is the dividend yield of the Standard & Poor's 500 index -- total dividends paid on the 500 stocks in that index divided by the value of the index. When dividend yields are high, as they were in August 1982 (at 6.69 percent), it frequently is a good time to buy stocks. But when they go below 3 percent, as they did in 1973 and just before the stock market crash of 1987, it frequently is a warning that it's time to exit the market.
The yield on the S.& P. 500 at Friday's close was 2.75 percent.
Dividend yield is by no means the only indicator Mr. Fosback watches, but it is one of the most reliable, he contends.
"Earnings can be massaged, but dividends show a corporation's willingness to pay cold hard cash out to shareholders," he explained.
But even the bearish Mr. Fosback admits that the market can charge on for some time at overvalued levels. The yield on the S.& P. 500 fell below 3 percent in January 1972, but the index rose another 16 percent after that before starting a 21-month bear market in October 1974.
 
 
 
THE PUBLIC IS GETTING SMARTER
 THE individual investor is bailing out of certificates of deposit and into stocks without the foggiest idea of the risk he or she is taking, right? Well, not quite, according to Bridget A. Macaskill, who spends a fair amount of her time on the road speaking to the investing public.
Ms. Macaskill, president of the Oppenheimer Management Corporation in New York, said investors who flock to her seminars don't need to be told that they're shifting into a less predictable investment. "They know the stock market is risky," she said.
Doomsayers are arguing that the small investors who are buying stock mutual funds in record numbers will be the first ones to pull the plug at the slightest sign of a market correction, sending stocks into a tailspin. But Ms. Macaskill said stock purchases may be the area where investors understand risks best of all.
The plunging of interest rates was actually a plus for investors' fortunes, said Ms. Macaskill, because it forced them to learn more about the benefits of asset allocation and a long-term strategy that includes stocks, which have tended to outperform other investments over time.
But investors' learning curves have further to go, she added. Now John Q. Public has to spend more time comparing one investment to another, and considering the effects of taxes and inflation.
 
 
HIS NUMBERS SAY 'BUY,' HIS GUT SAYS 'NO'
 TALK about a qualified opinion. Steve Leuthold, a Minneapolis analyst with a wide institutional following, told clients earlier this month that his proprietary "major trend" index surged in August, forcing him -- reluctantly -- to increase his allocation of stocks to 61 percent from last month's 33.5 percent.
But that's not what Mr. Leuthold's gut is telling him. "Because of the age of the bull market (1,058 days) and the high current valuation levels, the U.S. stock market comfort level here in the Leuthold Group is quite low," he wrote to his customers.
Still, the "discipline of the numbers" is usually more reliable than emotions, he added, so he's grinning, bearing it, and telling his customers to -- gulp -- buy.
The situation is uncomfortably familiar to Mr. Leuthold, who said his indicators turned from negative to positive in January 1987 -- another time that he thought, in his gut, that stocks had had it for the moment. But he told clients to buy nonetheless, guiding them to gains of 12 percent to 15 percent before his "major trend" index turned negative again in March 1987. In October, of course, the stock market crashed.
This time, he's figuring that investors can pick up as much as 10 percent by going into stocks now, but he expects that any rally will last less than six months. Even the stocks he's picking come from groups -- like oil and gold -- known to hold up better than others in down markets.
Mr. Leuthold concedes that it's certainly possible that stocks could move into what he calls "a new valuation era" in which such fundamental indicators as price-to-earnings ratios and dividend yields simply don't matter as much as they have historically. But he doubts that, saying, "I am a very edgy, reluctant bull."
 
 
PUTTING INVESTORS ON NOTICE: IT'S GETTING LATE IN THE GAME
DON'T be lulled by the stock market averages, advises Justin Mamis, technical analyst at Hancock Institutional Equity Services. He noted that beneath the averages are sick stocks that have dramatically hurt investors' performance. But, as investors increasingly convince themselves that every selloff is nothing more than a healthy correction in an interminable bull market, the bull market moves ever closer to an end, he said.
Mr. Mamis said the overall market is forming a "top" -- technical talk for the sometimes lengthy last-hurrah during which the averages meander near all-time highs before up markets turn down. "The ingredients of a top do things that eventually lull you," he said. A clue to spotting tops is that, in the end, investors interpret nearly every bad event as having a good side. "When corrections come, they say, 'Oh, that's nice -- it was overdue, and we needed that,' " Mr. Mamis said.
The small investor has particularly latched on to that "everything will be all right" way of thinking, Mr. Mamis said -- although the little guy isn't alone in being lulled by the top Mr. Mamis sees. "The public does not take losses," he said, referring to the small investor's tendency to hang on even after stocks have declined.
So he expects the small investor to stay in until it's too late. "Money magazine has told them it's a long bull market and don't worry about corrections," Mr. Mamis said.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Will Mayhem Maul Italy's Market?

BYLINE: By John Tagliabue

DATELINE: ROME

 BODY:
WITH all the turmoil, you would think Italy to have been a place to avoid. Yet investors did the opposite. From January of this year, even as criminal investigators jailed businessmen, politicians and mobsters, and as resignations crippled Consob, Italy's anemic stock market regulator, Milan's stock market index stubbornly climbed 42 percent, outpacing larger markets in Frankfurt, Paris and London.
Yet as summer turns to fall, the steam seems to be going out of Milan; trading has been sluggish since its August peak, and the Banca Commerciale Italiana's Comit index has fallen about 6 percent. 
 Have Italy's sins finally caught up with it? Probably not.
What fueled the enormous gains earlier this year appears to have had less to do with national turmoil than with the lure of low interest rates. Italian rates -- which were cut aggressively after Italy became the first European country to succumb to speculative pressure and pull out of Europe's Exchange Rate Mechanism a year ago -- devalued the lira, making Italian shares a bargain for big international investors like American pension funds, which thought they had room to invest in Italy. Moreover, low rates, plus an export surge fueled by the cheap lira, revived prospects for corporate profits despite a stubborn domestic recession.
Now, with little room for further rate cuts, and with corporate profits clouded by the recession in the rest of Europe, there is a fly in the minestrone.
Despite the lira's collapse against the mark and the dollar, Italy has endured little inflationary pressure. That is partly because, with the recession, imports have remained sluggish. Mainly, though, it has been the effect of a decision made last year to abolish Italy's wage indexation, a costly link between wages and consumer prices that desperate politicians convinced the labor unions to surrender. "Over the last 10 years, indexation was accounting for 50 percent of our inflationary thrust," said Mario Noiera, the chief economist at Euromobiliare S.I.M., a Milan brokerage firm.
Still, economists like Mr. Noiera say there is little room for rates to fall further. Meanwhile, analysts in Milan counsel taking refuge in anti-cyclical stocks, those chunks of the economy that usually thrive when everything else is hurting.
"There are food businesses like Parmalat and clothing companies like Benetton," said Massimo Gaggiotti, an analyst at Intereuropa S.I.M. in Milan. He said he also favors such telecommunications companies as Stet, Sip and Italcable, as well as such utilities as Italgas.
Services present a paradox, however. "The curious thing," Mr. Noiera said, "is that for the first time in Italy the recession has hit the service sector -- shops, retail distributors, consulting and advisory services."
In fact, while such big insurers as Generali and Alleanza continue to look good, banking in particular poses problems. Several large banks, including Banco di Sicilia and Banco di Napoli, are groaning under excess debt, and their owners in the Italian treasury, which still holds the bulk of Italy's banking business, are casting about for ways to help. Corporate turmoil, like the collapse this summer of Ferruzzi, the big industrial holding company, has also put pressure on the banks -- and more may be in store.
While Italy's market surge earlier this year was fueled mainly by heavy buying from abroad, a shift in retail investing, mainly by provincial banks seeking better returns for local investors against sagging bond rates, is currently preventing an all-out slide.
"They are providing the lag support, to prevent this slump from expanding to a major downward rush," Mr. Noiera said. "The question is whether the market has the steam to be bullish again. I think it lacks the steam, because that's linked to a perception of interest rates, and the outlook for corporate profits."
When industrials will revive depends largely upon corporate profitability. Fausto Galeotti, the director of research at Pasfin Securities in Milan, said the companies to bear in mind when that happens are, in descending order: the Fiat auto group, the tire maker Pirelli, Olivetti in electronics, and Montedison in chemicals.
The biggest downside of the market is Italy's brittle political situation. The cabinet of Prime Minister Carlo Azeglio Ciampi, a former central bank chief, was installed last April essentially to govern without politicians. But elections early next year could signal a return to politics as usual, and with unemployment posing a big threat, particularly in southern Italy, a return to loose fiscal policies could revive inflation.
Closely linked to this is the privatization of Italy's nationalized industries, which account for roughly half its economy. Sluggish movement toward this action has dismayed the market, but fresh plans to privatize the Banca Commerciale Italiana and Credito Italiano are encouraging.
By early winter, most large investors will probably have discounted uncertainties about Italy's Government, and if that coincides with increased corporate profitability, the market could bounce back.
Of course, there are risks that there will be more corporate trouble, similar to the collapse of Ferruzzi. Paradoxically, Ferruzzi appears to have had little net effect on the market. "The outlook for rates drove this market," Mr. Noiera said. "Ferruzzi's negative impact was overwhelmed by the macroeconomic picture."

HEADLINE: At Work;
Relief for Child-Care Workers

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble

 BODY:
AMONG small-business employees, child-care workers may have much to celebrate if President Clinton's health care proposal survives in anything like its current form. Barely a third of them now have health benefits, and though many are young and healthy, the work they do puts them at the mercy of the microbial free-for-all that is the immature immune system. Colds and flus are endemic, as are back problems from hefting and carting young children all day. Under the Clinton plan, workers would get benefits from their employers, who would probably qualify for an expense cap of from 3.5 percent to 7.9 percent of payroll. Self-employed family day-care providers would buy their own insurance but qualify for the 100 percent health insurance tax deduction. Making health care a fact of workers' lives would almost certainly improve quality by reducing turnover.
But child care is a peculiar economic institution. Technically, it is a small business, but one lacking many of the market options of other small businesses. "Over all, the change is going to be a good thing, but we have to pay attention to consequences for child care," said Barbara Reisman, executive director of the Child Care Action Campaign in New York. 
 Whatever form it takes -- center-based care and family day care dominate -- child care is a labor-intensive business in which salaries may represent as much as 80 percent of a total budget; an additional $8,000 to $10,000, say, to cover health premiums will not go quietly into the balance sheet. Expenses are typically covered by fees, supplemented occasionally by grants or donations. The usual ways of cutting costs or improving productivity -- investing in technology, streamlining inventory, etc. -- don't apply, and the creative ones, like staggering hours and teachers, put children in a topsy-turvy environment.
Passing costs on to consumers is problematic, because many of them are low- and middle-income parents with little financial flexibility. "If parents don't have the money, they can't move the cost forward," said Heidi Hartmann, director of the Institute for Women's Policy Research in Washington. The only other place for extra expenses to come from is the salaries of workers, who make from about $5 to $9 an hour.
The new system may prove especially difficult for in-home day-care providers, who account for nearly a quarter of child-care arrangements for children under 3. As self-employed workers, typically making less than $10,000 a year, they would be eligible to buy care from one of the regional alliances for about $1,800 for individuals and $4,200 for families. Without subsidies and cost-reduction formulas apparently envisioned by the Clinton Administration, the upfront cost would probably put the policies out of reach.
Whatever worries and imponderables there may be, the child-care community is optimistic about the new plan. Its emphasis on preventive care, for example, would probably benefit an occupation that draws from low-income groups whose access to health care is limited. "Prevention is something you don't pay for if you don't have money," said Linda Tarr-Whelan, head of the Center for Policy Alternatives in Washington. "It's incredibly important to that group."
CHILD-care advocates agree with President Clinton's appeal to the public to accept responsibility for part of the cost of their health care, but point out that child-care workers come to the reform table with a pre-existing condition. "We have a child-care delivery system that's breaking at the seams. It's not inefficient. No one's getting rich off it," said Marcy Whitebook, executive director of the Child Care Employee Project in Oakland. Calif. "The child-care work force is already doing more than its part by subsidizing the system of low wages." Ms. Whitebook said she was wowed by the passion for reform President Clinton revealed in his speech to Congress last week. The child-care system, she says, could use the same impassioned approach.
 
Adventures in Baby Sitting
 Among the clear winners this year of various Clinton Administration initiatives, intended and unintended, would seem to be full-time, in-home baby sitters, usually in cities like New York and Washington. First, the infamous $500,000-a-year Attorney General candidate episode force-marched many members of the cultural elite onto the Social Security straight and narrow and presumably benefitted those household workers who were not sacked by potential appointees eager to cover their tracks.
And now comes health care reform, which would treat employers of baby sitters and other domestic workers as small businesses, with the attendant responsibilities. That will entitle baby sitters to health benefits, at a cost to employers of anywhere from a few hundred dollars to well above $1,000 a year over the $200 to $400 weekly salary that many pay now. The plight of families with baby sitters -- about 3 percent of child-care users and often affluent -- generates little sympathy. Asked about the impact on in-home care, one child-care advocate sniffed, "Oh, you mean for the Zoe Bairds of the world?"
 
 
VOLUNTEERS IN SERVICE TO CHILDREN
 IF it's structured properly, say child-care advocates, President Clinton's new national service program could give the low-wage child-care industry a boost. The $1.5 billion measure creates a domestic version of the Peace Corps, allowing young people to do community service while being paid by the Government for college or job training.
The plan is modeled on volunteer projects already working in several cities. Typically, young people are placed in short-term assignments and circulate through participating organizations. If the assignments were longer term, volunteers could in effect become entry-level child-care workers. That would free up salary money for more experienced workers and widen the gap between entry- and higher-level salaries, a feature of the occupation that discourages long-term commitment. An added benefit, child-care experts say, is the potential to the health of the nation's children: "If you have young people working in a child-care facility who get good training," said Barbara Reisman, of the Child Care Action Campaign, "they learn good parenting skills."

HEADLINE: Business Diary/September 19 - 24

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Pining for 80's-Style Takeover Battles? They're Back 

Everything comes around. One might think that after the 80's crash-landed, giddy billion-dollar takeover battles were extinct. No, just taking a breather. No sooner had Viacom offered $8 billion for Paramount (a bit less now, since Viacom stock has fallen) than QVC, headed by Barry Diller, jumped in with a $9.5 billion bid. And the arbitragers were off and running, sending the stocks on merry rides. Mr. Diller, who once headed Paramount, has apparently long ached to buy the studio and combine it with QVC's cable business to create a multimedia empire. And now, as Mr. Diller is quoted as saying, "It's there, it's up for sale, and I can buy it." There may also be a personal goal for Mr. Diller, who is said to be seeking revenge against Martin Davis, now Paramount's head, and Mr. Diller's former boss. But it gets messy: though Paramount said it saw no need to respond to QVC, Viacom filed suit to try to keep QVC away.
 
Primerica, by Another Name
 
It's always the same. Big, bigger, biggest. While some people try to create multimedia giants, others have visions of financial supermarkets. And Sanford I. Weill, head of Primerica, is well on his way to a financial-services company second to none. Having recently bought the Shearson brokerage business, Primerica agreed last week to pay $4 billion for Travelers -- the rest of it, that is; Primerica already owns 27 percent of the insurer. The deal would create one of the nation's largest companies that links securities, insurance and consumer loans. And its name? Brokerages often have names that read like family trees: Pick three from among Barney, Hutton, Lehman, Lynch, Merrill, Shearson, Smith and string 'em together. No, Primerica, whose name was cooked up in 1987 by a "corporate identity specialist," would take on the more down-to-earth "Travelers."
 
A Men's Magazine's New Man
 
Esquire's hair is thinning. Ad pages are down, and its main rival, GQ, just passed it in circulation. What's the problem? Maybe nothing more than that it's a men's magazine in an age, in Gay Talese's words, "when being a male is almost held against you." Hearst, which owns Esquire, could see it that way -- or it could comb a few strands over the bald spot and then blame the editor. That seems to be what it did last week, removing Terry McDonell as editor in chief and taking the unusual step of going outside for a successor, picking Edward Kosner of New York magazine. "The clock just ran out on Terry," said Roger Black, Esquire's design director. If you can't make the magazine "hot" in two or three years, he said, "they look for someone else." Real men don't dawdle.
 
Anheuser-Busch, Lighter
 
The same day Bill Clinton gave voice to his dream of a healthier health care system, Anheuser-Busch, the world's largest brewer, said it would get a bit smaller. Any connection? No, the company insists, it does not expect any "sin tax" on alcohol to pay for health care. It has convinced the Administration, it said, that too many jobs would be lost. Perhaps. But this much is sure: beer drinkers are more and more inclined to reach for the cheaper six-pack, so Anheuser, like so many companies these days, is tightening its belt. It plans to cut salaried workers in the United States by 10 percent. As Anheuser-Busch Light, it hopes, it will be in fighting trim.
 
At Empire, an Official Mea Culpa
 
Empire Blue Cross has come clean. When evidence mounted earlier this year that the insurer had falsified records, the new managers ordered an internal inquiry. Last week Empire said the inquiry had shown that, yes, it was all true. Empire had shifted losses from ledger to ledger, overstating losses on high-risk policies so it could argue to New York State officials that it had been forced to take too many bad risks. Was it worth it? Empire was losing plenty as it was -- $250 million in 1991 and 1992. It didn't have to juggle the numbers to show hardship.
 
The F.C.C. Redraws the Maps
 
Forget those familiar state outlines. They never made sense anyway -- the nation's largest city jammed between New Jersey and Connecticut; San Francisco and Los Angeles, worlds apart yet sharing a state. No, it is the age of portable phones, of computer data speeding through the air. The shapes that matter now are "major trading areas." The F.C.C. created these last week -- 51 of them -- as it set terms for a multibillion-dollar auction of the airwaves. The F.C.C. has set aside far more of the spectrum than is now used by cellular phones, with new licenses to be auctioned in each zone. What does it all mean? All sorts of new contraptions for "wireless communications," and competition that should lead to lower prices for consumers. And what of the dying art of letter-writing? Don't ask.
 
Merck's Loss, Marion's Gain
 
All the health care uncertainty may be churning things up for drug makers, under attack for high prices. Richard J. Markham was seen as the heir apparent at Merck, but resigned suddenly in July, citing "personal reasons." But last week Marion Merrell Dow named Mr. Markham as its new president.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Paying a Bill for Mideast Peace
 
On the theory that a neglected Palestinian is an angry Palestinian, Secretary of State Warren Christopher promised a quick $250 million last week to help make Mideast peace a reality. And he called on the rest of the world to come up with more at a conference that could begin this week. About 60 percent of the money would go to public projects in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The need for rebuilding is so desperate, though, that the P.L.O. called for far more -- $2.5 billion now and $11.6 billion by 2000. But whatever the sum, money must be made available immediately, Mr. Christopher said, to curb the unemployment that "fuels extremism."
 
In Japan, Lawyers Are Coming
 
Hard as it may be to believe, Japan became an economic powerhouse with practically no lawyers. Well, it does have 14,000 of them, but in the United States that would barely be enough to thrash out a couple of good-sized corporate mergers. Why, in America there are 850,000 lawyers, all busy, busy, busy swapping their reams of legal prose. So how does Japan do it? For one thing, it has kept most American lawyers out. After all, if American lawyers are scarce, they can't do much, but if there are a lot of them, they'll be sure to keep one another busy. But now, under growing international pressure, Japan is about to lift many restrictions on foreign lawyers, even allowing foreign law firms to form partnerships with Japanese.
 
Beijing: Close, but No Olympics
 
 
China's economy has stepped firmly onto the world stage, and its star turn would have been to win the 2000 Olympics for Beijing. China waged a huge campaign to get that seal of approval from its fellow nations, but it was not to be. In a sense, it came down to this: whether the Olympics should look back or ahead. Looking back, China's human-rights record just could not be forgotten, while Australia had proven with the '56 Melbourne Games that it could put on the show. Sydney "presented no problems," one Olympic Committee member said. But looking ahead, China, with a fifth of the world's population, is opening up. It is the future. And if Beijing won, it could help push China toward more openness, more tolerance. In the end, picking Sydney, the committee could not ignore the past.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
The Vision: Health Security
 
That commotion you heard last week was one hell of an idea being born. At a celebration in the health care "war room" in the Old Executive Office Building after President Clinton's speech to Congress, Hillary Rodham Clinton stood on a chair and announced that it would now be called the "delivery room." Now it's time to bring up baby, to make good on the vow to provide health security for all, but keeping it simple enough to work.
 
And that other roar you heard was practically every citizen in this vast nation -- awakened to the giddy, scary realization that things were really likely to change -- pleading in unison, "What's in it for me?" People wanted to know which doctors they'd go to, what would be covered, how much they'd pay. Doctors wanted to know who'd be looking over their shoulders. Insurance companies wanted to know where they fit in. Medical students wanted to know whether their chosen careers were in disarray. And on and on. And of course the lobbyists moved out in force, trying to put their stamp on the final plan.
 
Russia Spooks the Market
 
The stock market is still high, but it's nervous. Traders, deeper in the jungle than they've ever been, are casting their eyes warily about, ready to sprint to safety if a lion appears -- or even if they think another trader sees a lion. Well, last week they saw a lion -- the political upheaval in Russia -- and they jumped, with the Dow industrials off 70 points at one point on Tuesday. As the crisis played out, though, traders decided that this lion, though fierce, would probably not eat them, and the Dow steadied to close down just 38 for the day. And the rest of the week the market just bobbed up and down a few points.
 
Gold prices surged, too, the day the Russian crisis erupted. Though it's a market axiom that investors seek havens for their money when times are shaky, it's never quite clear what good a bunch of gold bars are going to do someone if the world falls apart.
 
The Fed Won't Raise Rates
 
If anyone thought rock-bottom interest rates were a short-lived phenomenon, that the Federal Reserve could jump in any time to nudge them up again, the Fed put such ideas to rest last week, surprising many economists. In releasing a report of its Aug. 17 meeting, it said that since "economic growth did not seem particularly robust," it was no longer poised to raise rates at a moment's notice.

HEADLINE: Profile: Louis Loss;
For the Father of Securities Law, Yet Another Milestone

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
THEY came to a corner room of the library at Harvard Law School where Oliver Wendell Holmes's Civil War sword and humongous lunch pail were on display for an unusual book party. The scholars and lawyers and friends were here to celebrate Louis Loss's latest opus.
It is an 11-volume treatise on securities law, an update co-authored by the 79-year-old Professor Loss of the seminal single volume he wrote 42 years ago that founded an entire field of study: the law that governs Wall Street. But to many of those who gathered on Sept. 17, the celebration was as much of a life as it was of a law book. 
 For most of the second half of this century, Louis Loss has been known as the intellectual father of securities law.
Working virtually alone in the early 1950's, he was the first to put together all the laws, regulations and court decisions involving modern finance and systematically analyze them. He even coined the phrase "securities regulation" and made it the title of the first book on the subject, published in 1951.
Since then, his writings have had a profound impact on the law as judges and Government officials have turned to them in preparing thousands of opinions and regulations. His works have been cited more than 50 times by the Supreme Court and more than 1,000 times by other state and Federal judges.
He helped develop the initial theories that enabled the Securities and Exchange Commission to use the broadly worded anti-fraud provision of the Federal securities law to prosecute illegal insider trading, and he is proud of the fact that the Oxford English Dictionary (Second Edition) credits him for the word "tippee," referring to the person who receives an inside tip about a stock and then illegally trades on it.
Professor Loss has also consulted for many state legislatures and foreign governments about their own emerging laws, and trained generations of practitioners, academics and judges. Indeed, he has taught more people about securities law than any other person alive today. Among the thousands who have taken his course are four justices on the Supreme Court (Antonin Scalia, Anthony M. Kennedy, David Souter and Ruth Bader Ginsburg). A fifth, Harry A. Blackmun, maintains a warm friendship.
His most ambitious effort was a decade-long attempt through the 1970's to rewrite all the existing securities laws, regulations and court decisions into one coherent statute, a kind of Napoleonic Code for Wall Street. The effort failed when the new Reagan Administration gave it a lukewarm reception and many of the project's strongest supporters on Capitol Hill retired.
But the 700-page measure is now widely regarded as the most successful bill ever to fail in Congress. It is routinely cited by courts searching to interpret existing laws, and the Securities and Exchange Commission has turned many of its ideas into regulations.
Professor Loss says the need for Congress to simplify and update many laws is greater than ever. Some have not been touched for a half century, and others were grafted on the books piecemeal without looking at how they relate to other provisions.
"Patch, patch, patch," Mr. Loss said, describing what he views as the biggest problem in securities regulation today. "Each statute is a little different, with a curlicue here and a curlicue there. It means there are a great many questions that are litigated that ought not to be."
As an example, he added: "The Supreme Court has considered what is a security 10 times. That is remarkable. It is also wasteful."
Professor Loss's philosophy is not easy to articulate and, indeed, his failure to identify with a particular theory of the law has given him greater credibility with the courts and other scholars.
"When I began work with him on the treatise I asked him, 'What is your philosophy?' " recalled Joel Seligman, a professor at the University of Michigan who co-authored the study, called "Securities Regulation" (Little, Brown & Company). "He said, 'I don't have a good philosophy other than use good judgment.' Almost in the manner of Justice Lewis Powell, he takes the law section by section, and most generalizations about the law he views as naive. It is the fact that he does not have some grand theory that has made him so persuasive."
Yet in his many writings, Professor Loss has strongly supported the position that the way to insure integrity of the markets and reduce fraud and self-dealing is through mandatory and complete disclosure. While that view is now widely accepted, during the early years of the S.E.C. it was still subject to intense debate. Some critics argued that rather than require disclosure, the Government should try to evaluate the merits of stock offerings.
But Professor Loss was also quick to recognize that disclosure was not enough and that the Government must do more to protect investors from the unscrupulous.
Many of the ideas that he once fought to establish are now standard rule or law. For instance, the "shingle theory," which holds that a stock dealer who hangs out his shingle implies that he will deal with his customers fairly, is now taken for granted. But when it was developed in 1939 it was quite controversial; a lot of people in the securities industry thought that the Government had no business interfering in the marketplace and that the rule should be "let the investor beware."
Professor Loss has now slowed down somewhat, speaking more softly and taking greater efforts to get out of his chair, and he now needs a cane to walk even a short distance. As he grows older, he has begun to look more like the movie version of a Harvard Law scholar better known to most Americans, John Houseman as Professor Kingsfield.
AND although Professor Loss no longer teaches, he still finds himself involved in a number of significant cases. He has been retained, for instance, in a long-running dispute between Unocal and T. Boone Pickens's Mesa Petroleum. The issue: whether Mesa violated a Federal law against concealing large stock purchases when it bought Unocal stock through Jefferies & Company from Ivan F. Boesky and Irwin Jacobs during a takeover contest.
"People have paid a lot of money over the years to use my name," Professor Loss said. But there are times when his recognition has not always been helpful. A Federal appeals panel in New York once asked during a case whether it should believe his interpretation of a particular provision as an advocate or the contrary analysis he had previously written in a treatise. Ultimately, the judges adopted the view from his scholarly work.
Louis Loss was born in 1914, the son of immigrants from Minsk, in Russia, and he grew up in Lancaster, Pa. By the time he was 11, he decided to become a lawyer, he said, because a brother-in-law to whom he had grown close had been one.
As a teen-ager he hung around the county courthouse dreaming of being a trial lawyer. In 1934 he graduated from the University of Pennsylvania, majoring in pre-law. He attended Yale Law School during the depths of the Depression.
He went to the Securities and Exchange Commission in 1937, three years after it was founded. He was lured to Washington, he said, because of the excitement of the New Deal and because the big Wall Street firms were closed to Jews. (He views it a delicious irony that although he would have been denied a job at Sullivan & Cromwell, he is now the Harvard Law School professor emeritus who holds the chair funded by that law firm in the name of its founder, William Nelson Cromwell.)
Although he never rose above the rank of deputy general counsel, Mr. Loss exerted enormous authority at the tiny commission, particularly in the early 1950's, when the new chairman was Harry McDonald. Mr. McDonald got the job, according to news accounts at the time, because President Truman was a close friend and very much enjoyed it when Mr. McDonald would visit him and sing a song called "Wagon Wheels."
At about the same time, Mr. Loss began teaching securities law part time at Yale and at the George Washington University School of Law. At first, recalled his former colleague Milton Kroll, there were only about eight or nine students each year. Now, of course, the subject is almost as popular as constitutional law and contracts.
After leaving the commission, he wound up at Harvard. He later turned down a Kennedy Administration offer to become chairman of the S.E.C.
Professor Loss, who lives in Cambridge, with his wife, Bernice, the keeper of the room where the law school's artwork and artifacts are kept, says his new project will be a book he has tentatively called "Anecdotes of a Securities Lawyer." It will cover his years in the courts, lobbying for legislation, at the S.E.C., and at Harvard. But he confesses that his first love has been writing treatises.
"There are people at this faculty who scorn treatise writing and liken legal treatises to battleships -- prime, prestigious stuff in their time, but not really worth their keep in the contemporary world," he said. "They prefer to write about the sex lives of caterpillars. But what they don't realize is that these books have shaped the law. They have made a field of law that didn't exist before."
 
NOT A MANUAL, A RICH HISTORY

THE new 11-volume treatise co-authored by Louis Loss, "Securities Regulation," is encyclopedic in its treatment of the laws governing every aspect of American finance, from stocks and bonds to insider trading and mutual funds.
It is more than just a technical legal manual. It is a rich history that begins in 1285 when a law of Edward I authorized the licensing of brokers in London and works its way through the speculative frenzy of 18th-century Europe known as the South Sea Bubble, the origins of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the crash of 1987, the last 10 years of leveraged buyouts and takeover contests, and the emergence of mutual funds, options and futures, and index-based financial products.
Typical of its approach is its examination of what one might think a dry subject -- short-selling, the practice of betting that a stock will fall by selling borrowed shares and later buying them back at a lower price.
The chapter on the subject begins with a look at how the Dutch first banned short-selling 300 years ago and then taxed it. It looks at Napoleon's views on the practice in 1802 and then moves swiftly to the decision by Congress to ban short sales of gold during the closing days of the Civil War and then reverse itself after gold dollars rose in value.
It later explores 200 years of British laws on the subject and the state laws in the United States that led ultimately to the Federal regulations beginning in 1938.

HEADLINE: The Performance Scale: What It Means, How It Was Done

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
IN NEW YORK CITY, the traditional measure of a school's effectiveness has been how well its students perform on standardized reading and math tests. But this measure omits a factor that educators consider a major influence on a child's school performance: the social and economic differences among students' families.
The school performance scale seeks to give parents more information to evaluate the effectiveness of individual public elementary and intermediate schools, by adjusting scores on math and reading tests to eliminate socioeconomic variations. The scale is based on data provided by the Board of Education and on the work of Dr. Robert Berne, an associate dean at New York University's Wagner Graduate School of Public Service, who has been studying ways to judge New York City school performance for several years. Profiles of city's high schools were not available when the study was done. 
 The district superintendents who reviewed the new performance listings agreed that the schools that ranked high in their districts were, in general, more effective than the low-performing ones, even though they might not be the ones with the highest math or reading scores. Many of the superintendents, though, insisted that since each school was so singular, no statistical analysis could tell its entire story.
Indeed, the calculation includes assumptions that may not fit every school. Sometimes exceptional patterns -- a high concentration of gifted low-income students or of new immigrants with special problems -- may explain why a school scores significantly higher or lower than otherwise similar schools. The new scale should not be seen as the only tool for assessing the quality of public elementary and intermediate schools; many parents may still rely on traditional performance measures.
Educators and researchers have long known that the background of students -- the income, occupation and education of their parents, the parents' expectations for their children, the stability of a family -- has a strong bearing on academic achievement. A recent study of Scholastic Aptitude Test scores by the College Board showed that students from the poorest families, with incomes under $10,000, scored about 120 points lower than students from families with incomes over $70,000. The S.A.T. results are scored on a scale that runs from 200 to 800.
These differences are so well understood that researchers routinely make statistical adjustments to control for variations in student background when comparing schools. For example, in a study of public and parochial education ("Public and Private High Schools," Basic Books, 1987), Dr. James S. Coleman of the University of Chicago used the socioeconomic background of students to level the playing field when comparing the performance of public and parochial schools.
In the new performance scale, Board of Education data on family income were used as the indicator for the differences in student background, because of a strong relationship between income and other important factors, like family structure and parent education. For each school, the board reported the percentage of students above the eligibility limit for Federal education aid for the poor. In most cases, that is 130 percent of the Federal poverty level.
Using standard statistical techniques, the study identified a "predicted" reading score for the average school at each level of family income. Schools were then ranked by how much the actual test scores differed from the predicted values, and they were divided into five groups. Schools in the top categories performed better than predicted. Schools in the bottom categories performedbelow expectations. Schools in the middle performed as expected.
On the chart, each dot represents a school. The horizontal axis shows family income, the vertical axis shows test scores. The diagonal line shows the relationship between income and achievement -- how the typical school at each income level was predicted to perform on the tests. The difference between this line and a school's actual score is the measure of its performance.
The city's Board of Education has been working to develop a similar analysis of public-school performance. South Carolina also uses income as an important criterion in awarding $5,000 bonuses to high-achievement schools. It makes its awards after grouping schools by the poverty level of the students and the experience of its teachers -- factors beyond the control of a particular principal.
Dr. Berne of N.Y.U. said some educators and advocates for the poor worry that the statistical adjustments set lower standards for schools serving poor children -- in effect grading them on a curve. But he said that the performance measures test how well urban schools are able to overcome daily challenges. "Part of the notion of the American system of common schools is to overcome a strong relationship between a child's station in life and his ability," he said. "This measures how successful schools are at doing that. It should not be a substitute for high absolute standards."
But others object. Michael Meyers, the executive director of the New York Civil Rights Commission, called it a form of "educational snobbery."
"This sort of measure institutionalizes low expectations of low-income, low-status students," he said. "It doesn't set out a single standard of achievement for everybody. I think that all children can be held to a single standard of achievement."

HEADLINE: AT YOUR SERVICE;
Caveat Emptor, and Check Out These Booklets

 BODY:
New Yorkers, by nature, are wary of swindlers. But the dangers of being cheated aren't restricted to 14th Street three-card monte games. More often than not, the scam is going on close to home: in the supermarket, at the bank or on a credit card.
In an effort to combat such problems, the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs publishes reports on subjects from overpriced vitamins to corporate invasion of privacy. The reports are compiled by the department's advocacy division researchers, and are available from the communications division of the Department of Consumer Affairs, 42 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10004. HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Betting on Bonds of New Markets

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
THAT mutual fund investors are crazy for yield is an old story -- what is new is how far they will go to find it.
With yields on the bellwether 30-year Treasury issue hovering around 6 percent, investors are fleeing the United States in droves, to the emerging markets of South America, Eastern Europe and Africa. 
 The first of the dozen or so closed-end and mutual funds to invest in the debt of emerging markets began in mid-1991, but most came to market this year. Their red-hot returns -- plus yields of 7 percent to 11 percent -- are quite seductive, but analysts say investors should not be blind to the risks of investing in developing countries.
The rush to emerging markets debt began in 1989 when investors embraced the "Brady bonds," conceived by Nicholas F. Brady, then the Treasury Secretary, to resolve the Latin America debt mess created when Mexico and other countries defaulted on their American bank loans. Mr. Brady crafted a plan under which some loans were forgiven and new, more solid debt was issued.
After that, "the funds jumped on the Brady bond bandwagon," said Catherine Gillis, editor of Morningstar Closed-End Funds, a Chicago newsletter. The Eurobond market that existed then was too small and illiquid to support huge foreign investment; but the Brady bond market took off, and has ballooned to more than $140 billion.
The appeal of Brady bonds is simple: Most principal is guaranteed by zero-coupon bonds issued by the United States Treasury, and a few interest payments are guaranteed as well. And because the bonds are denominated in dollars, the currency risk -- the bane of overseas investments -- is eliminated. Moreover, the interest-rate risk is reduced because many coupons are pegged to short-term rather than long-term rates.
The biggest risk in emerging markets debt is the credit risk. Investors are paid a hefty premium for buying the debt of countries with questionable economic and political track records over the past hundred years. While Mexico's debt is on the verge of being upgraded and Chile's already has been, the biggest share of emerging markets debt is still rated below investment grade.
Because of the risk, Kenneth E. Gregory, who edits the No-Load Fund Analyst, a newsletter based in San Francisco, would fill no more than 5 percent of a diversified portfolio with emerging markets debt. He would do so by reducing existing positions in United States stocks, junk bonds and emerging markets equities.
Besides the tiny $600,000 Megy Income mutual fund, in Palm Beach, Fla., started in May 1991, among the first to venture into Latin America was the Latin American Dollar Income Fund, a closed-end fund started by Scudder, Stevens & Clark in July 1992. The fund lost 2.5 percent in the last quarter of 1992 because of ripples from the European currency crisis but rebounded sharply this year, gaining 25.5 percent through August.
The second generation of closed-ends -- Alliance World Dollar Government and Salomon Brothers' Emerging Markets Income -- came to market in October. Unlike the Scudder fund, which is limited to Latin America, these invest in emerging markets worldwide, including Nigeria, Poland and Morocco.
Because of their double-digit yields, the funds have been very popular. This has prompted a second round of offerings this spring and summer from Salomon and Alliance and one from Morgan Stanley; the Templeton Emerging Markets Fund is in the works.
Not to be outdone, mutual funds that invest in emerging markets debt worldwide are also sprouting up quickly. First to invest worldwide was the GT Global High Income Fund, started last October. The fund, which has $175 million in assets so far, gained more than 30 percent in the first eight months of the year, partly because of the price appreciation created by falling interest rates.
Close to two-thirds of the fund is invested in Latin America, with 23 percent in Europe, the Middle East and North Africa, mainly Morocco (11 percent). Another 6 percent is invested in the Philippines and Asia, with the balance in cash. The fund yields slightly more than 7 percent.
Two more funds followed in May: the $45 million Bear Stearns Emerging Markets Fund, the company's first mutual fund, and Fidelity Investments' $125 million New Markets Income Fund, the only no-load fund among the emerging markets debt group. Another no-load fund, from Dreyfus, should come to market shortly.
The Bear Stearns mutual fund is billed as the most conservative of its kind. The fund cannot use leverage; by contrast, GT can leverage up to 32 percent of its portfolio, although it has not done so yet.
Also, the Bear Stearns fund can own only bonds, of which at least 50 percent must be invested in Latin America. Today, 80 percent is invested there, with the balance in Asia and Africa. GT can invest up to 35 percent of its portfolio in stocks, although it has no money in stocks now and no plans to start, a company spokesman said. Fidelity can also own stocks.
Another way for a fund to reduce risk is to diversify. Look at how many issues a fund owns, and how geographically diverse it is. Evaluate interest-rate risk by looking at how much of the debt is tied to short-term rates.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;
Amid the Peep Shows, Discount Groceries

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
A new store has opened on Eighth Avenue at 43d Street, behind a bright orange front and huge spotlights. It is not a peep-show parlor or porno theater.
It is a discount food store, catering to families, although it gets its share of homeless people and residents of nearby single-room-occupancy hotels. 
 "It's a great location because there's lots of traffic -- tourists, commuters, late-shift workers and families from Ninth Avenue," said Janusz Sendowski, an owner of the store, Best Buy Foods. "And of course there are go-go girls, too, who eat lots of sweets for energy. We've already run out of Oreos."
Mr. Sendowski, who was born in Poland, and his Israeli-born partner, David Sarfati, started a fast-food restaurant on Fulton Street in lower Manhattan in 1982. When the economy began to falter, they went into the discount business, opening D.D.S., a department store on Eighth Avenue at 42d Street, as well as three food stores in the Bronx.
Neighborhood residents who have been shopping at the store in the month since it opened have noted that its prices are lower than those charged nearby. Among this week's best sellers are Adriatic jams, at $1.29 for a one-pound jar; a 6 1/2-ounce can of Bumble Bee tuna at 59 cents, and a 23-ounce bottle of Perrier for $1.29.
Although Best Buy Foods keeps long hours -- 6 A.M. to 2 A.M. -- security has not been a problem, Mr. Sarfati said. "The big lights and a permanent guard help." M. H.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WEST VILLAGE;
Desperately Seeking Savior: New Hope for Lion's Head

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
As mounting tax debts threaten to close the Lion's Head, its owners say they may have found a savior for the watering hole, long popular with authors, entertainers and politicians.
Since declaring bankruptcy in 1991, the Lion's Head has continued operating -- and running up more bills. To recoup $250,000 in sales taxes, state tax collectors have begun legal action that could lead to liquidation. 
 But Judith E. and John Wesley Joice, the couple who own the bar, say they are negotiating with a prospective buyer, though they would not give a name. They hope to have an offer in place by their next court appearance, next month.
"Closing is the easy way out, but it's pointless, because there's no chance of repaying debts," said Ms. Joice. "We took the more painful route to try to pay up."
The Lion's Head, at 59 Christopher Street at Sheridan Square, has had memorable moments in its 27 years. Covers from about 100 books, all written by Lion's Head patrons, decorate the walls.
At the bar's round table, legend has it, the writer Pete Hamill talked Robert F. Kennedy into running for the Senate. Norman Mailer made the bar an ad hoc headquarters when he ran for Mayor in 1969. Mayor Edward I. Koch often stopped for lunch, and so has David Dinkins.
Before stardom, Jessica Lange was a waitress, and Rod Steiger used to get his mail there. Lanford Wilson, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright, wrote a drama on waiters' order pads.
The Clancy brothers strummed guitars there. Bill Murray, Linda Ellerbee, William Hurt and Jackie Mason wined and dined. For young people on the way up, said Ms. Joice, "we used to buy dinners and beers so they could survive."
At times when The New York Post and The Daily News nearly folded, staff members gathered, "not knowing if it was for a wake or a celebration," she said.
The Lion's Head's fortunes first went downhill in 1985 "when a lot of village businesses started to go down with the phenomenal fear of AIDS," Ms. Joice said. Revenue revived a bit in 1986, she said, "then -- boom -- the stock crash in 1987, then the recession."
Ms. Joice, a former president of the Greenwich Village Chamber of Commerce, said that many small businesses "are in the same boat." B. L.

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
Suzuki's Sidekick: Useful, Thrifty and Entertaining

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
YOU don't hear much about Suzuki these days, but Japan's No. 6 automaker just keeps on truckin'.
In fact, American sales for 1992 were up 15 percent from the year before, and the company expects '93 results to be 12 percent better than that. And while the numbers are not huge -- 25,000 to 30,000 vehicles a year -- any double-digit increase in today's market is worth noting. 
 Notable, too, is Suzuki's worldwide effort, with sales of more than 833,000 cars and trucks in 150 countries. The 73-year-old company also has assembly plants and joint ventures in 25 of those countries. In fact, it may be its partnership with General Motors that obscures its presence in the United States.
Not everyone knows, for example, that Suzuki makes Geo Metros and Geo Trackers for G.M. or the ways in which they differ from Suzuki's own versions of those cars and little sport-utilities, the Swift, Samurai and Sidekick.
But then, too, tiny vehicles do keep a naturally low profile.
All the same, the Sidekick, introduced in October 1990, feels fairly tall when you motor down the highway. It rides on fat 15-inch tires, and its traction, low gearing and price also make it one of the least expensive ways to have four-wheel fun in the boondocks.
The Sidekick, which comes in two- and four-door versions and with two- and four-wheel drive, offers three levels of trim, JS, JX and JLX, and stickers range from $11,449 to $16,369. All two-door versions have canvas tops, while the four-door models have steel roofs, and there are few options.
The four-door Sidekick, sold only in America, accounts for about half of Suzuki's total sales here, and the tester was one of those, a $15,779 JLX painted polar white, with blackout trim and chrome molded wheels.
For '94, it has been gussied up with a new security alarm and a tilt steering column. But, as in the past, there was also a long list of standard equipment, including antilock brakes at the rear, power buttons for the windows, side mirrors and door locks, cruise control, reclining front buckets and a split rear seat.
The full-size spare rode on the rear in a locking hard case with "Sidekick" splashed across it. And behind the door, which swings from left to right, there was plenty of cargo room -- expandable to a more-than-plenty 45 cubic feet when the rear seat is folded down.
That seat, incidentally, is reasonably comfortable, although legroom is tight when the buckets are scooted back to accommodate tall occupants up front. One wonderful thing about the rear compartment is that the windows go all the way down, something rarely found in today's vehicles.
All Sidekicks have two-tone gray vinyl and cloth interiors, and the driver and front passenger are treated to most of the usual creature comforts. The sound system is excellent and is prewired for a compact-disk player.
There is no air bag. But, mercifully, there are none of those dangerous and troublesome mechanical seatbelts either. The four-spoke wheel is wrapped in vinyl, and the dash beyond includes a tachometer, fuel and temperature gauges and a speedometer that tops out at 90 -- faster than one probably wants to go in the rather tall and narrow Sidekick.
Buttons for the front windows are in the armrests, where they should be, and there is a one-push down function for the driver's window. Buttons for the rear windows are in the console, along with the shifter -- either standard or automatic -- and a lever to lock the vehicle into four-wheel drive.
There are overhead grab handles for all but the driver, and the dark gray vinyl dash has a large bar in front of the passenger, one that can be held with both hands should the off-roading get to be too exuberant. A small but deep tray also is molded into the top of the dash, and the glovebox is bigger than some in much larger vehicles.
The locking glove compartment is also cleverly designed to hold the hood release, an antitheft feature that other manufacturers might want to copy. The hood itself must be lifted manually and propped with a rod. But it reveals a neat engine compartment with the tiny powerplant mounted front-to-rear and affording what would appear to be easy maintenance.
The engine is aluminum, a 1.6-liter four with 16 valves and multipoint fuel injection. It produces 95 horsepower and a somewhat anemic 98 foot-pounds of torque, but then the vehicle weighs only 2,763 pounds, and performance is sufficient if not exactly robust.
The most expensive Sidekick couples the engine to a four-speed automatic transmission with a selector to choose "normal" or "power" modes for better economy or more acceleration. The tester, however, was of the five-speed persuasion, and the stick needed constant stirring to keep the little engine from stumbling.
Even so, the gearing is low, which means engine revs are high, and there is generally a fair amount of Sturm und Drang under the hood.
Otherwise, though, the Sidekick is quiet and well-behaved on the highway. The body, mounted on a frame in the old style of construction, is tight and seems possessed of fewer creaks than I have heard in the past.
The suspension also is tight and a bit firm. Combined with the big tires, it yields a jouncy ride but one that compares favorably with most other sport-utilities.
Like performance, fuel economy is sufficient if not spectacular. It ranges from a low with the four-door automatic of 22 miles per gallon, city, and 26, highway, to a high of 25 and 27 for a two-door with the stick.
Add the fact that a Sidekick's four-wheel drive is there when you need it and you have a vehicle that deserves to be . . . well, your friend and helper. The name is just right.

HEADLINE: Clinton Plan Will Restrict Health Care Choice

 BODY:
To the Editor:
President Clinton's claim in his speech to Congress that his proposed reform will broaden Americans' health care choices is deceptive. His plan would in effect obliterate private practice and other small-scale providers, leaving patients to choose from a menu offering only corporate care served up by insurance giants like Prudential and Aetna.
The President hopes to control costs through the rapid expansion of large, competing health maintenance organizations. But despite the Clinton assurances that other health insurance options will remain available, private practice cannot possibly coexist with a dominant H.M.O. sector. 
 Big health maintenance organizations skimp on doctors, employing about 1 physician for every 800 enrollees, often meaning long waits for hurried consultations. In contrast, for the country as a whole, the physician-to-population ratio is 1:400.
Hence, H.M.O. expansion would absorb many patients but few physicians. The result: a glut of doctors (mostly specialists) in private practice serving a shrinking pool of patients. Initially, doctors might increase fees to meet their overhead and maintain their incomes, but increasing fees would accelerate the movement of patients into health maintenance organizations.
The Princeton economist Uwe Reinhardt has noted that if half of Americans enrolled in health maintenance organizations with 1 doctor per 800 enrollees (and competitive pressures would drive health maintenance organizations to keep physician staffing to the minimum), each remaining private physician would serve an average of only 267 patients, too few to cover even office overhead.
At some point private practice would completely collapse, leaving tens of thousands of doctors scrambling. At the limit, if all Americans enrolled in health maintenance organizations, about 275,000 doctors, most of them specialists, would be stranded in a private practice sector devoid of patients. Competition for H.M.O. jobs would be fierce, the disruption of care massive.
The President's spin doctors portray his proposal as assuring a pluralistic health care system, with patients choosing the kind of care they want and doctors free of micro-management. But simple calculations belie this image. Instead, a few insurance giants would dictate care.
The Canadian alternative is far preferable. Everyone is covered, quality of care is high, patients can freely choose and change doctors, and physicians are free to choose from a variety of practice settings. Costs have been contained by streamlining bureaucracy (largely by evicting insurance companies from the system) and by a simple budgeting system, rather than the Rube Goldberg devices proposed by Mr. Clinton.
President Clinton's plan would sacrifice the health care of those who are now satisfied. It can't contain costs and hence won't extend coverage. But it will complete the corporate transformation of American medicine.
 
DAVID U. HIMMELSTEIN, M.D.
STEFFIE WOOLHANDLER, M.D.
Cambridge, Mass., Sept. 23, 1993
 
The writers, associate professor and assistant professor of medicine, respectively, at the Harvard Medical School, are co-directors of Harvard's Center for National Health Program Studies.
