SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 4; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1257 words

HEADLINE: The Health Plan;
Rising Expectations And Fear of the Bills Create an Opening

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT was only a wallet-size piece of red, white and blue plastic with two gold stars that President Clinton flashed to millions of Americans. But this "health security card" would be enough, he assured the public, to to safeguard Americans from a recurring nightmare: losing not only their health, but their ability to afford a cure.
Nearly 50 years after President Harry S. Truman proposed national health insurance, a consensus has finally emerged among Republicans, Democrats, labor and business groups that the nation needs to change the system. The desperation is so great that the same public that often says that Government cannot do anything right is now accepting the idea that Washington can be trusted to create a system that will control the most important, intimate and expensive aspects of American life. 
 The history of this country's quest for national health care has been one of missed opportunities. Mr. Clinton's plan is a patchwork of proposals that have been offered over the years, in one form or another, by other leaders. Yet by seizing the moment, and by framing the debate as a simple "Should Americans have health security or should they not?" while leaving the details to be fought over in Congress, Mr. Clinton has managed to create a new starting point.
Yes, party discipline has fractured, and yes, lobbyists and the general cacophony of Washington makes the fate of his proposal more problematic. Large-scale social engineering has long since lost its luster. But the bipartisan applause and the recent polls suggest that, a consensus has emerged where once there were only complaints.
The catalyst for change was not the plight of the uninsured. There have always been people too poor to afford medical care -- and often charity wards to care for them. This time it was the anxieties of the middle class, caught in a convergence of economic, social and technological forces. They feared losing their coverage in an age when even a broken bone, a pregnancy or a simple operation can be frighteningly expensive. They may mistrust Government, but they see no other way out.
"I don't think compassion is what drives this," said Uwe E. Reinhardt, a professor of political economy at Princeton University. "The middle class felt in the middle of the swamp named Uninsurance, and it is really that fear of losing insurance that the President is harvesting."
More and more people have friends or family who fall victim to "job lock" -- fear of changing jobs for fear of losing medical coverage.
"Baby boomers are moving out of the 'I'll never get sick and die' stages to a point where health care costs are of great personal concern," said Tom W. Smith, of the University of Chicago's National Opinion Research Center. "They're not old enough for Medicare and not poor enough for the poverty programs."
Only after decades of false starts is health care on the table. Immediately after World War II, most industrialized countries established universal coverage, and President Franklin D. Roosevelt toyed with the idea as part of his Social Security proposal. He backed off, though, for fear that opposition to it would sink the entire Social Security Act.
Truman, the first President to call for guaranteed medical care, complained in his memoirs of "all the fuss" over his doomed effort. "I usually find that those who are loudest in protesting against medical help by the Federal Government are those who do not need help," he wrote.
Even a Republican President, Richard M. Nixon, pushed for a program that closely resembles Mr. Clinton's. But neither Mr. Nixon, nor his health plan, survived Watergate.
As health care reform eluded the politicians, public expectations of medicine only grew. At the turn of the century, there was still a fatalistic approach: a person's health was in the hands of God or luck. A doctor could set a bone, prescribe a dicey tonic or recommend rest, but little more. Then the rush of scientific miracles -- vaccines, antibiotics, surgery with anesthesia, X-rays, chemotherapy -- raised people's hopes.
With the hope of cure came new bills. But Americans also became more comfortable with the idea that the Government, or big anonymous insurers, would pay.
"It's not just an economic argument, it's a technological one," said Senator Harris Wofford, a Pennsylvania Democrat whose election in 1991 demonstrated the salience of health care as a campaign issue. "With the incredible miracles of technology, a sense of possibility has arisen. For the first time in history, people believe in a radical form that life can be extended -- and the revolution of rising expectations is causing the cost increases."
The bills were becoming barriers to the miracles. Decades ago, a person who had a heart attack often simply rested, or died. Now treatment may start with a $1,500-a-day hospital room and a $1,000-a-dose anti-coagulant and even end with a $100,000 heart transplant.
As recently as the 1988 elections, the idea of national health insurance was little more than "Democratic window dressing," said David Blumenthal, chief of the health policy research and development unit of the Massachusetts General Hospital. Recalling his work on Michael S. Dukakis's Presidential campaign, he said, "We were jubilant if we could get the issue on the evening news. And we did only once, when Dukakis released his own health care plan."
A turning point was when Mr. Wofford, a hopeless underdog, defeated Dick Thornburgh, a former Attorney General. At the heart of Mr. Wofford's campaign was a potent television commercial in which he said: "If criminals have the right to a lawyer, I think working Americans should have the right to a doctor."
But while Mr. Wofford proved that this issue could turn a campaign around, Mr. Clinton still did not fully grasp the gravity of the issue. It was not he but Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska who championed the issue during the primaries; his plan was much more thought out than Mr. Clinton's hastily assembled proposal for managed competition.
Yet Mr. Clinton deserves credit for using his leadership to help catapult health care to the top of the national agenda; few believe it would have won much attention had President Bush been re-elected.
But what Mr. Clinton called the "magic moment" for introducing a bill comes with no magic formula for passing one. Under Mr. Clinton's plan, everyone would be guaranteed a generous basic package of coverage, negotiated separately in each state by alliances of consumers with insurance companies and medical groups.
While interest groups and Republicans, many of whom say the plan would lower the quality of care and put a new tax burden for businesses, do not want to be portrayed as obstructionists, opponents are battling the proposal at every turn.
As the lobbyists go into overdrive, the danger is that Mr. Clinton's plan, like those of the past, will fall victim to fear. Opponents raise the specter of medicine run with the efficiency of the Postal Service or the warmth of the I.R.S. "What's happened every time is that when we're just on the verge of a plan, people say to themselves, 'Maybe it could be worse,' " said Robert J. Blendon, an expert on public opinion and health policy at Harvard University.
But Mr. Clinton seems ready to fight fear with fear. Asked by Ted Koppel on "Nightline" about a poll showing people are worried that their future health costs won't be taken care of, the President was intentionally not reassuring. "They should worry," he said.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Every New President Gets a Rematch

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

 BODY:
"BRING them home!" Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia thundered on the Senate floor the other day, as he pondered aloud the mounting risks facing American troops hunting down warlords in Mogadishu. "I do not intend for the Senate just to roll over and play dead to this Administration!"
Well before a rocket-propelled grenade downed a U.S. Blackhawk missle in the Somali capital Saturday, killing three American soldiers, these words gave evidence of Congress's increasing restiveness over the Somalia mission in particular and and foreign affairs in general. 
 Lawmakers have taken the lead in recent months in pushing the Administration to suspend nuclear arms testing and to drop military aid for a losing war on cocaine in the Peruvian Andes. And they threaten the warming trend in relations with Mexico, with constant attacks on Mexican Government corruption and repression that could help defeat the North American Free Trade Agreement.
But it is in Somalia and Bosnia where the new Democratic President and the Democratic Congress are trying to define a new foreign policy while continuing the almost ritualistic struggle over which one should have the ultimate power to put American forces in harm's way.
While the Constitution granted Congress the power to declare war, it appointed the President Commander in Chief. It was left it up to the two branches to work out the details. That difficult process was played out again last week when Secretary of State Warren Christopher, Defense Secretary Les Aspin and National Security Adviser Anthony Lake traveled to Capitol Hill for feedback on a possible peacekeeping mission in Bosnia.
Like Congress, the Administration is deeply split on whether or not to send troops to Bosnia, and it's quite possible Mr. Clinton would welcome the cover that a reluctant Congress would provide. Still, the officials faced a barrage from Congressional leaders who took the opportunity to lay down markers and warn that Congressional authorization would be difficult to get should the Administration decide to send troops.
Representative Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana, chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee, told the officials they should win assurances from the warring parties that they will drop their heavy arms and ease the delivery of relief supplies -- difficult conditions in a war characterized by fluid battle lines and loose command controls. Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, publicly warned that they must come up with an exit strategy before even thinking about deploying troops.
 
Sparring Branches

 
 Congressional skepticism over new foreign interventions is likely to be on display again early this week when the House is expected to pass a resolution that will force the Administration to put limitations on its goals in Somalia or face the likelihood of a cutoff of funds. The Senate already approved the resolution by a 90-7 vote two weeks ago. President Bush won widespread Congressional support for dispatching troops on a humanitarian mission, but power brokers like Senators Byrd and Nunn are unhappy that the mission has changed from feeding to fighting.
Congress has argued with Presidents for more control over foreign policy ever since Thomas Jefferson, without legislative sanction, dispatched a naval squadron to the Mediterranean under secret orders to fight the Barbary pirates. With few exceptions, the legislative branch has lost this continuing turf fight.
But the balance shifted somewhat after Vietnam and Watergate. An emboldened Congress enacted the War Powers Act over President Nixon's veto, leading to a trend toward greater Congressional involvement in foreign policy. This led to the passage of economic sanctions on South Africa over President Reagan's objections. Congress curtailed and occasionally cut off military aid to the Nicaraguan contra guerrillas, setting the stage for the Iran-contra scandal, which underscored the willingness of senior Reagan Administration officials to circumvent the limits Congress had set on intervention in Central America.
For the most part, Congress deferred to President Bush on foreign affairs, although the Persian Gulf war resolution of 1991 was viewed as a victory for legislators demanding a tightening of Congressional controls over war powers after the unauthorized 1989 invasion of Panama.
Enter Bill Clinton. A foreign policy neophyte, he ran for President promising to concentrate on domestic policy. He sharply disagreed with Mr. Bush on China and Haitian immigration, but then reversed himself once elected and adopted stances similar to those of Mr. Bush.
The President's inexperience and indecisiveness gave Congressional foreign policy experts an opening. "When you have a President who is new in foreign affairs and a Secretary of State who is cautious," said Senator Paul Simon of Illinois, a ranking Democrat on the Foreign Relations Committee, "Congress fills the vacuum."
Mr. Simon suggested that Mr. Clinton could eclipse Congress as he gains experience and luster from presiding over international events like the recent signing of the peace agreement by the Israelis and Palestinians.
But leading lawmakers predict that the end of the cold war opens new opportunities for Congress to project its powers overseas no matter who is in the White House. With the threat of nuclear war reduced, constituents are demanding that their representatives address issues like trade, drugs and immigration.
"Increasingly all foreign policy issues are becoming domestic issues," said Representative Jim Leach of Iowa, a leading Republican on the Foreign Affairs Committee. "As a reflection of public input, Congress is demanding and playing a greater role."

HEADLINE: SEPTEMBER 19-25: Mandela Seeks Investment;
South Africa's Blacks Get Their First Share of Power, And Sanctions Promptly Fall

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER

 BODY:
Nelson Mandela and F.W. de Klerk began demobilizing their political forces last week, demonstrating their faith that South Africa's course of negotiated democracy is now all but irreversible.
First Mr. de Klerk assembled his docile Parliament to enact a law that will surrender some of the white Government's power to a multiparty council until the first universal elections next April. Mr. Mandela thereupon laid aside one of the last weapons of the liberation struggle. He urged his allies in the West to call off the remaining sanctions against trade and investment. The appeal at the United Nations was quickly heeded by states from New York to California and countries from Europe to New Zealand. 
 In coming weeks negotiators will fortify their consensus by adopting an interim Constitution, and by creating a peacekeeping force drawn from the police and anti-apartheid guerrillas. They will also try to consolidate their partnership of the center against the violent fringes on both sides. Only if these center-building measures succeed can Mr. Mandela expect the West to heed the other appeal he made in New York -- to help rejuvenate the economy by investing. BILL KELLER

HEADLINE: THE WORLD: VERBATIM;
A Call to Enlarge Democracy's Reach

 BODY:
EIGHT months into the Clinton Administration, debate continues to percolate in Washington about America's proper role in the post-Communist world. Top officials set out last week to define the Administration's vision, as President Clinton prepared to address the United Nations. On Tuesday, his national security adviser, Anthony Lake, offered his view of the nation's new foreign-policy goals. The speech, excerpted here, was delivered at Johns Hopkins University. 
 Throughout the cold war, we contained a global threat to market democracies; now we should seek to enlarge their reach. . . .
 First, we should strengthen the community of major market democracies -- including our own -- which constitutes the core from which enlargement is proceeding.
Second, we should help foster and consolidate new democracies and market economies, where possible, especially in states of special significance and opportunity.
Third, we must counter the aggression -- and support the liberalization -- of states hostile to democracy and markets.
Fourth, we need to pursue our humanitarian agenda not only by providing aid, but also by working to help democracy and market economics take root in regions of greatest humanitarian concern.
. . .
In this world of multiplying democracies . . . the rulers of backlash states face an unpleasant choice. They can seek to isolate their people from these liberating forces. If they do, however, they cut themselves off from the very forces that create wealth and social dynamism. Such states tend to rot from within, both economically and spiritually. But as they grow weaker, they also may become more desperate and dangerous.
Our policy toward such states . . . must seek to isolate them diplomatically, militarily, economically and technologically. It must stress intelligence, counterterrorism, and multilateral export controls. It also must apply global norms regarding weapons of mass destruction and ensure their enforcement.
. . .
 When the actions of such states directly threaten our people, our forces, or our vital interests, we clearly must be prepared to strike back decisively and unilaterally.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Malls Wrestle With the Blues

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM

 BODY:
THAT inalienable American right -- the freedom to shop -- has long been subject to the vagaries of Sunday blue laws. And though these barriers to consumerism have fallen in many states where churchgoing shares the day with trimming the hedges and driving to the mall, the battle between the soul and a sale is not over.
The debate is being rekindled in the mall country of northern New Jersey. On Election Day, voters in Bergen County will decide whether to overturn their 34-year-old ban on Sunday shopping. Although 10 of the state's 21 counties adopted blue laws in 1959, Bergen is the last to retain them. 
 Advocates of repeal -- the local newspaper, The Record, and a large shopping mall in Hackensack, Riverside Square -- say voters need and want that extra shopping day. The mall, which includes Bloomingdale's and Saks Fifth Avenue, says Sunday openings will help the economy.
Opponents include the Garden State Plaza shopping center in neighboring Paramus, the epicenter of North Jersey consumerism and home to three other large malls and many free-standing highway stores. They argue that the county's tranquillity is at stake.
But even if the county law is repealed, a separate and more stringent Paramus law remains, and borough officials have vowed never to lift it. The result would place the Paramus plaza, which is home to Macy's, Nordstrom's and Penney's, and the other malls and businesess at a disadvantage.
The county law is certainly an anachronism. Perhaps fewer than a dozen states retain some vestige of a prohibition that has its roots in a decree by the Roman Emperor Constantine. In 321 A.D., trying to calm the political turbulence between Christians and the pagan majority, he proclaimed a weekly celebration, a day of the Sun, which placated both camps.
After they arrived in Massachusetts, the Puritans etched their Sunday decrees on blue paper, marking the commonwealth as the Mount Sinai of such blue laws in the New World. As such, worldly pursuits -- with some exceptions -- have been off-limits since 1645.
 
The Din of Machines

 
 As the country grew, church and temperance groups fought periodically with civil authorities to preserve Sunday as a day of rest and contemplation. When they succeeded, they succeeded with a vengeance: repeat violators in 17th century Virginia were executed.
After the Civil War, as factories operated around the clock and society's needs and expectations changed, the call for a quiet Sunday was often drowned out by the industrial revolution. With economics rolling over the work prohibition, only the temperance movement apear to be holding the fort, with many states restricting the Sunday sale of alcoholic beverages to restaurants or hotel dining rooms.
David Laband, an economist at Salisbury State University in Maryland, traces the decline of the Sunday ban in his book "Blue Laws" (Lexington Books, 1987). "You're talking to an economist," Mr. Laband said. "Maybe the reason the churches worked to shut businesses was to limit competition."
But Mr. Laband found no drop-off in church attendance or in per-capita contributions when the blue laws were repealed or nonexistent. Nor did he find anti-Sabbath bias in votes by state legislatures to lift the bans. The laws began to evaporate when society began looking for ways to stretch the rules.
Riddled with exceptions and arbitrary provisions for enforcement, many blue laws have have been abolished. In 1970, 25 states had statewide blue laws; by 1984, 12 had repealed them.
North Dakota's experience is typical. Its blue laws listed 37 types of businesses that could be open and 44 categories of merchandise that could not be sold.
"You could buy a greeting card in a drug store, which was allowed to be open, but not a card store, which couldn't be open," said David Huey, an assistant attorney general in Bismarck. "It got to be complicated."
Consumers got fed up. In 1991, the Legislature discarded the old law, allowing shops to open after noon on Sundays.
"It's not uncharacteristic of our legal system," Mr. Huey said. "It comes from an erosion of the law, not a full frontal assault. Pretty soon you've got so many exceptions, it doesn't make any sense to have the law at all."
 
Closed Liquor Stores

 
 In New York, restaurants may serve alcohol, and beer is available in supermarkets after noon, but liquor stores must be closed. In Texas, until a few years ago, consumers could buy beer but not diapers, a can of beans but not a can opener, a hammer but not nails.
Massachusetts has its own quirks. "Apparel stores are closed, but it's O.K. to sell souvenirs," said Ken Gear, a spokesman for the Retail Association of Massachusetts. "We like to say, 'You can't buy a T-shirt unless it says Cape Cod on it.' " Mr. Gear's organization is seeking to repeal the blue laws, which have come under increasing fire for being arbitrarily enforced.
In New Jersey, the arguments are less about quirky legal provisions than about the peace envisioned by Constantine: Should a free market take precedence over a day of rest from the turbulence and frustration caused by traffic and angry motorists?
Routes 4 and 17, the county's shopping crossroads, are jammed all week and especially on Saturday. Opponents of repeal fear that a seventh day of shopping would make ordinary life unbearable and put an extra burden on municipal services in Paramus and elsewhere. Opponents insist that the suburban quality of life is at stake.
For Texans, who struggled for 25 years with what was known as the item law, a quality of life debate would have been a relief.
"It got confusing at the checkout counter." said Mickey Moore of the Texas Retailers Association. "You'd have a cart full of groceries, hardware, pots and pans. You could buy some of it, but not all of it. But the real fallacy in the law was, if you went to a retail store and said it was an emergency, then you could buy it."
The exceptions drove people nuts. Merchants were hauled off to jail. Customers wondered if they would also be subject to arrest. The blue laws, enacted in 1853 and amended numerous times, were finally repealed in 1985.
"No one in the retail community wanted people arrested in their store," Mr. Moore said. "You can understand that."

HEADLINE: An Open Mike, a Loudmouth Live, and Thou . . .

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
IT was the ultimate tribute to the power of talk radio: Bill Clinton was taking questions.
Last week, as part of the media blitz surrounding the President's health care proposal, the Clinton Administration held the first-ever White House briefing for hosts of the nation's radio call-in programs. Roughly 200 hosts showed up. 
 Time was when all a President had to do by way of news management was call in a brace of influential Washington columnists for a serious lunch a day or two before the press conference for everyone else. Those days are clearly gone. The briefing for radio hosts was a White House acknowledgement of a phenomenon that was much remarked upon during the 1992 campaign -- the rise of the "new" news media.
It was also, by most accounts, one of the rowdier question-and-answer sessions ever to take place at 1600 Pennsylvania Ave.
"We were like the nouveaux riches who don't know what salad fork to use," Barry Farber, the New York City radio host, said. "There was a lot of classless behavior."
David Gergen, the White House counselor, described Tuesday's briefing less delicately: "They were yelling and screaming at each other," he said.
One host loudly advised another to drop dead. Donna Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, had to scream for quiet. When Marshall McLuhan called radio a hot medium, he didn't know the half of it.
That the medium can also be a powerful -- though often unpredictable -- political force is something that few in Washington question these days. The consensus is that talk shows, either by galvanizing or simply giving vent to public frustrations, have helped doom several pieces of legislation, including the Congressional pay raise of 1989. More recently, they helped kill Zoe Baird's nomination as Attorney General and convinced many lawmakers to line up against the President's proposal to allow homosexuals in the military.
Whether talk shows can mobilize public opinion in support of a proposal like the President's health care plan, not just against it, is unclear. But the Administration apparently thought a little outreach to fans couldn't hurt. There are a lot of Americans listening; a recent poll by the Times Mirror Center for the People and the Press reported that 42 percent of all adults listen at least occasionally to talk radio programs, and 17 percent listen regularly.
"These people really have the time and the format where you can have a real exposition of different ideas," said Mr. Gergen. Besides, he said, "the President really loves radio."
Michael Harrison, the editor of Talkers, a magazine about talk radio, was one of those invited to the White House. (He has his own program on WNNZ in Springfield, Mass., and a nationally syndicated program on which -- in a sort of meta-talk-radio role -- he talks about what topics are hot on talk programs each week.) He agreed that Mr. Clinton had shown more affection for the format than most other national politicians. Unfortunately for the President, though, he said, the feeling is not reciprocated.
"The irony is," he said, "Bill Clinton is the most bashed person in the history of talk radio."
The Casey Kasem of talk radio, Mr. Harrison compiles a list each week of the ten most popular call-in topics; according to last week's survey, health care was No. 1 on the vox pop charts. (No. 2 was the media, and No. 3 was the economy, stupid.)
Mr. Harrison said he wasn't sure Mr. Clinton had swayed many hosts with his briefing, but said they had at least returned to their microphones with a few more facts. "If nothing else," he said, "it forced those people to focus on the issue for four hours." (Rush Limbaugh, the most talkative of all radio talk show hosts, did not attend, saying he couldn't work it into his schedule.)
Blanquita Cullum, a conservative talk show host on WLEE in Richmond, Va., called the briefing a clever piece of public relations. "The talk show hosts really love the idea that they were at the White House," she said. "We are now recognized." She had a complaint though: She was left hungry. "If we get more credibility," she said, "next time we'll get lunch."
The briefing was part of an air and print assault that included Presidential chats with the news magazines, an old-fashioned White House luncheon for Washington columnists and a seemingly endless series of network appearances by high-level officials.
On Thursday, a few dozen of the talk show hosts took up the President's invitation to broadcast from the White House lawn. Once again, the scene tended toward the chaotic. Wires snaked all over the grass and griping filled the air as hosts who are used to soundproof studios sat cheek-by-jowl at Government-issue tables, trying to connect with callers from back home. Administration officials roamed from table to table, answering questions that did not always center on health care. (One female talk show host, for example, flustered the White House communications director, Mark Gearan, by asking if he would care to continue their interview in her hot tub.)
It is, of course, too early to tell whether the Administration's multi-media strategy will work. If it does, expect the opinion jockeys to be invited back when the next major White House initiative is unveiled. And expect them to get a very nice lunch.

HEADLINE: 5 Families in Midwest Cheer Promise of Health Security

SERIES: The Clinton Prescription/First article of a series: The Impact on Families

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Sept. 24

 BODY:
For five families in the middle of America, President Clinton's promise of health care coverage "that can never be taken away" has hit home, addressing what is clearly a shared yearning.
In interviews this week and after the President's speech to Congress and the nation on Wednesday night, the families, including people who are insured and uninsured, employed and unemployed, healthy and sick, all said they welcomed the promise of secure health insurance for all. The New York Times first interviewed the families in May about their health and their needs. 
 The families welcomed the President's promises of Government-guaranteed care for all and the right to insurance even when they lose jobs. The elderly were especially pleased by his promise to preserve Medicare and, for the first time, to include prescription drugs in the program.
 
Fear About Paying More
 Some fear that under Mr. Clinton's proposals they might have to pay more from slim incomes for the insurance plans they already have. Some are skeptical -- about the President, about gridlock in Washington, about the financing of the plan and about the impact of the lobbyists representing doctors, drug companies and insurance companies. But to a person they are relieved that a President has finally taken on the health care tangle.
"I liked everything he said," said Debra O'Connor of Lisbon, Iowa, the single mother of three young boys. "I think it can work if everybody gives it a chance."
Ms. O'Connor said she took her job with an aerospace company not because she liked the work or the relatively low pay, but because she would pay only $7 a month for a comprehensive health plan. She expects to have to pay more if the Clinton plan succeeds, and so be it, she says -- at least her dread about the consequences for her children in the event of a pink slip, an ever-present threat in her industry, will be reduced.
Clifford McLaughlin of East Moline, Ill., has an even richer plan through Deere & Company. It suits him fine. But Deere does not cover his mother, his wife's mother or the McLaughlins' grown daughters, and they welcome the help the President would give to them.
An older couple, Bill and Gertrude Coen of Iowa City, are relieved that after all the questions that had been raised about preserving Medicare, it will survive and they can be relieved of their $2,000 annual bill for drugs.
But it is people like Leo and Elma Patten of Cedar Rapids, who are unemployed and largely uninsured, and Maria Weirather, who has been driven to poverty by bills for cancer surgery, who have the most to gain. "I'm not elated," Mrs. Patten said, "but at last I'm not discouraged."
 
The Pattens
Worry Over Access To Family Doctor
 Elma Patten brings out some big, meaty cookies, a stack of paper napkins to put under them, cups of coffee and takes her place at the dining room table. The mother of four grown daughters, Mrs. Patten, who is 58, looks fine.
"I had my one-year cancer physical in July, and I'm clean," she said. Her husband, Leo, 62, looks fine, too, although emphysema has cut his lung capacity to 40 percent of normal.
The Pattens, both unemployed because of their health -- she with no insurance, he partially insured -- feel heartened by Mr. Clinton's promise of secure coverage for everyone by 1997. It is something they desperately needed themselves in recent years. But as they watched the President on Wednesday night they worried that they could lose their access to the one person whom they credit for keeping them going: their family doctor, Jo Lynn Glanzer.
"She treats us so good," Mrs. Patten said. "She'll call and ask how we're doing."
The Pattens worked all their adult lives until their health forced them to stop. Mr. Patten says smoking -- he quit in 1975 -- and the foul air of the factories where he worked as a machinist brought on his emphysema.
He has Medicare because he has been disabled for more than two years, but because of his pre-existing condition he cannot get supplemental insurance to pay for doctors' and hospital charges that Medicare does not cover, or for any of his medicine. Mrs. Patten, a diabetic, cannot yet get any insurance that she can afford.
 
Huge Medical Expenses
 Working until a year ago, most recently marking prices on goods at a women's clothing store, she had insurance from employers that covered most of her huge medical expenses -- double bypass heart surgery, a mastectomy, a hysterectomy and two wrist operations for a repetitive motion injury related to her work.
Now, the Pattens' annual income is $23,460, entirely from the $1,374 Social Security disability check that Mr. Patten gets each month and $581 a month in disability compensation from his last employer.
They spend about $1,100 a year for medicine -- one expense they would largely avoid under the Clinton plan, which would extend prescription coverage to all. Dr. Glanzer now accepts Medicare's payment for Mr. Patten's visits and lets Mrs. Patten pay for hers in small installments. Mrs. Patten's disability will qualify her for Medicare next July, but she wonders what would give if she needed another operation before then.
Their one worry about Mr. Clinton's plan concerns Dr. Glanzer. She has joined a group of doctors who will compete to provide health care to businesses and their employees. In theory, under the structure the President has proposed, the Pattens should be able to choose that plan, or keep going to Dr. Glanzer under Medicare. But both the doctor and her patients feel uncertain about how the new system would really run, and they wonder whether things will work out as smoothly as promised.
"They will be better off with their medicine and their insurance," Dr. Glanzer said. "But in terms of whether they keep me as a physician, I don't know. You may get a choice, but maybe not the choice you want."
 
The O'Connors
Well Insured Now, But Vulnerable
 The President is relying on Debra O'Connor to help pay the medical bills of uninsured Americans. He would impose a $1 or 75 cent tax on the Merit 100's that she smokes at a rate of a pack a day. She pays $2.03 for her cigarettes now. "I would quit before I paid $2.75," she said. "Then they won't have any money."
While she is skeptical about the financing of the Clinton plan, its principal selling point -- guaranteed coverage regardless of job status or other factors -- has struck a deep chord. Although she is now well insured through her work, Ms. O'Connor knows how vulnerable she is to the layoffs that have been sweeping through American industry, and she worries about what could happen to her family.
Ms. O'Connor is a 30-year-old single mother of three boys, 5, 7 and 9 years of age. She lives with her parents in a farmhouse in Lisbon, Iowa, a village southeast of Cedar Rapids.
She considers herself lucky at the moment. The boys are in school. She no longer spends $120 a week for baby sitters, and everyone's health is stable for now.
She considers herself lucky with work, too. Two years ago she took a job at a Rockwell International plant in Coralville, near Lisbon. A few days ago Rockwell, a giant of the aerospace industry, announced a layoff of more than 100 workers at a nearby plant, but her own plant is humming.
There, she assembles ground radios for the armed services. She is paid $8.60 an hour, low for big industry. She works 54 hours a week and earns around $23,000 a year, but says the great attraction of Rockwell is the health plan the company worked out with the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers. She contributes just $7 a month to cover herself and the boys.
 
A Good Company Plan
 For now, at least, the company plan is better than the minimum that the Clinton proposals would require. Rockwell has enrolled most Cedar Rapids doctors in a preferred provider network, and keeps its own costs down by negotiating reduced fees with doctors and hospitals, something the Clinton plan wants to promote.
Ms. O'Connor pays $10 to visit any of the affiliated doctors, $25 to use the outpatient services of St. Luke's Hospital in Cedar Rapids, and $100 for any hospital stay. She also pays $3 per prescription for generic drugs and $10 for brand-name drugs.
To start school, her youngest child, Kyle, needed a measles, mumps and rubella immunization shot. "My doctor charged $65," she said. "I paid 10. Our insurance company paid $37. So he got only $47 for that shot."
Still, she is worried. As the President put it, she is one of the millions of workers who are "just a pink slip away" from losing her health insurance. With only two years' seniority at Rockwell, she would be among the first to go if business slumps.
"I want to keep that plan even if I'm not there," Ms. O'Connor said, and the Mr. Clinton assured her she could. Even if Rockwell begins charging her more for her health coverage, she said, "that's O.K. as long as I know I always have insurance."
 
The Weirathers
New Plan Gets A Wary Response

Maria Weirather, who lives in an Iowa City trailer with flimsy, sheet-metal walls, would welcome the changes proposed by the President, but she is skeptical about how soon they will materialize.
Her living room is also the master bedroom, with a foot-high double bed taking up the center. Ms. Weirather, 26 and divorced, sips a Dr. Pepper in an easy chair that has a broken leg. Her daughters, Andrea, who is 3 and entering a Head Start program soon, is asleep in the back, and Beverly, 5, is attending kindergarten.
Ms. Weirather (pronounced WY-rather), is stuck in this place, living entirely on food stamps, a welfare check of $426 a month and a $895-per-semester Federal Pell grant to go to the University of Iowa here part time, all because of disastrous bouts with her health and the medical system.
She had once been insured under the policy of her former husband. But last year, on her own without medical coverage, she had to have a second cancerous ovary removed. She owns nothing to speak of anymore, having sold her Dodge Spirit and a small piece of land to pay the hospital bills, and she still owes $500. After finishing a temporary job as a laboratory aide in May, she became eligible for Medicaid.
She said she welcomes Mr. Clinton's promise of nearly free care for herself, but she does not intend to wait to see the promise fulfilled. She has her own health insurance plan -- marriage in December to a man who hopes to follow others in his family into the Army. The Army provides family health care. She would complete college, having a little more than a year to go, and become a respiratory therapist.
"I'm not getting married for the financial aspect of it," Ms. Weirather said, "but it sure is a nice bonus."
She believes the health care system will take ages to fix. "The Government's going to have to put price controls on what doctors charge," she said. "That's going to be a big controversy. And the bigger companies are going to have to absorb some costs. I have a hard time visualizing it happening, even in five to 10 years."
 
The Coens
'Things Happen' To the Elderly
 William Coen, 79, the retired postmaster of Iowa City, and his wife Gertrude, 77, had been skittish about what the Government might do to their health care coverage, but they liked everything they heard from the President. "He said he'd keep Medicare," Mrs. Coen said. "He said we'd have long-term care and mental health -- all those things. You know, when you're older, things happen."
Things happening with the Coens' health are as routine as turns in the weather, and they speak of their setbacks as though they were no more disruptive. During the summer Mrs. Coen had a long bout with bronchial asthma, requiring three series of antibiotic treatments.
In October she faces surgery to remove a cataract, the latest in a succession of serious eye ailments. Mrs. Coen is not allowed to drive because of her vision, and when she watches television she sees two images, but she speaks of her medical problems and her husband's with a touch of humor.
"Last week his hearing went," she said. "He just got up and said, 'I can't hear anything.' He said, 'When you get your eyes fixed, I'll get my hearing fixed.' "
 
Involved With the Community
 What would trouble the Coens more than their ailments would be anything that interfered with their freedom to go on living in their split-level house, in an Iowa City neighborhood where nearly all the other homeowners are young enough to be their children.
They want to stay involved with the community. Mr. Coen is a member of a county task force on aging, serves meals and washes pots and pans at a center for the elderly and delivers meals to invalids at home.
He and his wife were relieved to hear the President promise them help with long-term care. But he wants to see the details. If the proposed nursing home program would cover only $30,000 of the cost of a one-year stay in a nursing home, he said, "then I don't think that's too great a come-on."
Mr. Clinton's proposal to cover prescription drugs through Medicare came as a relief, too. Last year prescriptions cost them almost $2,000.
He said there is "a fear that Medicare premiums are going to be raised quite high," but added that those costs, after the cuts in spending for drugs, might not make a big difference in their annual pension and investment income of about $40,000.
 
The McLaughlins
Providing Care For 3 Generations
 Whether Valerie and Clifford McLaughlin would have to pay more out-of-pocket themselves under the Clinton plan is not clear. But the fortunes of three generations of their kin who are not so well covered would certainly brighten.
The McLaughlins, who live in a two-story house in East Moline, each have mothers living alone who are anxious about the cost of health care. From previous marriages, both Mr. McLaughlin and his wife have a daughter with a child living on welfare and Medicaid. And the McLaughlins, both 41, have two more daughters of their own -- Carrie, 12, and Amber, 8.
Mr. McLaughlin's job at Deere as a $40,000-a-year press operator gives him one of the nation's most generous and comprehensive health plans, one that was negotiated by his union, the United Automobile Workers. Except for the wage increases he might otherwise have received, nothing is deducted from his pay for the insurance.
Mrs. McLaughlin takes out a statement they received from Deere's health maintenance organization listing the charges for the family's surgery, medicine and visits to doctors from last January to June. The total was $16,360. Most covered surgery and other treatment for Amber, who has acutely diseased eyes and may lose her vision. But it also covered psychiatric care that Carrie needed because of Amber's condition. The McLaughlins did not pay a dime.
The minimum company payment and standard benefits package that the President has proposed would be less generous. But the Clinton plan does not forbid higher company payments, and for now the extra benefits are secure.
 
Helping Young and Old
 Still, the McLaughlins wonder if such generous benefits will last. "I'm hoping it's not going to hurt us," Mrs. McLaughlin said. "But I like it helping my mom and his mom.
Mr. McLaughlin's mother has taken a job caring for invalids at home. But it pays only a little more than the minimum wage, Mr. McLaughlin said, and she lives in fear for her own health because she is uninsured.
Mrs. McLaughlin's mother is better off financially but in worse health. She is 63 and has Parkinson's disease, emphysema and a heart ailment. Mrs. McLaughlin said her mother often talks of retiring from her job as the chief deputy recorder of deeds for Rock Island County, Ill.
But she has been reluctant to give up a county insurance plan that pays 80 percent of her medical costs, including drugs. She would get Medicare at 65, which would cover most of her treatment costs, and under the President's plan, Medicare would also pay for her prescriptions.
The younger generations are no less trapped. Mr. McLaughlin's 20-year-old daughter is separated and living with her year-old daughter. Mrs. McLaughlin's 23-year-old daughter, whose son is 3, has just completed a state-financed training program to become a licensed practical nurse and has found a hospital job that pays about twice the minimum wage, enough to get her off welfare.
"But that's put her in a bad spot," Mrs. McLaughlin said. Insurance does not come with the job, so she is now exposed to the high cost of health care, one big headache that the Clinton plan hopes to cure.

HEADLINE: New York Casts for Solutions to Gaping Holes in Juror Net

BYLINE: By JAN HOFFMAN

 BODY:
The office in the courthouse at 60 Centre Street in Manhattan was overflowing recently with people who would really love to do their jury service -- but some other year, O.K.?
Down the street, Justice Joan B. Carey, the administrative judge of the criminal branch of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, was raging. "I have eight judges absolutely ready, ready, ready to go to trial," she fumed. "But there are no jurors. So I have eight judges looking at the ceiling." 
 Nationwide, a lack of jurors is delaying proceedings, clogging court systems that are already groaning from overload and squandering countless dollars and hours for lawyers, judges, assembled witnesses and court officers. Many states have been grappling with the problem; earlier this month, a committee in New York State began looking for solutions.
The composition of jury pools is also worrisome: black and Hispanic people as well as many professionals are dramatically underrepresented, leaving the public as well as many legal observers with the perception that the system may be unfair.
 
Committee to Suggest Changes
 New York State's two top judges, Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye and the Chief Administrative Judge, E. Leo Milonas, last week appointed a committee to suggest changes that would improve potential juror turnout, make jury panels more representative and make the experience for jurors less of a duty and more of a service. A report is due by Jan. 1.
New York is not the only state reviewing its jury system. Across the nation, many states have concluded that their jury systems do not work and have instituted a host of changes, like shortening the required service and reducing occupational exemptions, which have begun to alleviate jury crises.
As New York's two top judges acknowledged, blame for low turnout does not rest entirely on moribund civic spirit. While jurors who do end up deliberating a verdict tend to give the system high marks, the general experience has a reputation so awful that it drives away many prospective jurors.
For the princely sum of $15 a day, New York City jurors often spend hours waiting in crowded hallways, then are ushered into rooms with harsh lighting and bad ventilation and are offered seats on hard benches or chairs with the springs poking out. "You put people into those conditions for seven hours to deliberate over whether X killed somebody?" asked Justice Carey, whose own office has a broken wall clock.
To get potential jurors in the courthouse, most states use one or two lists. New York uses three: registered voters, licensed drivers, and the state's mailing list of taxpayers. Demographers estimate that such efforts should reach 85 to 90 percent of the state's potential jurors.
But the combination of New Yorkers' own evasive tactics and the state's crater-sized exemptions drastically cut the number of jurors who eventually appear. In a 12-month period ending in March, only one in six jurors summoned in New York County -- the borough of Manhattan -- which has one of the busiest state court systems in the country, showed up for service.
 
Forms Frequently Ignored
 Using the three lists, jury commissioners send preliminary questionnaires to establish minimum qualifications for service, from which the jury rolls are compiled. But in Manhattan and the Bronx, where the State Office of Court Administration says returns are among the lowest in the state, 50 to 60 percent are never completed, usually because they were sent to a wrong address or were tossed by the recipient into the next morning's garbage.
The questionnaires list 20 occupations that are automatically exempt from jury service, one of the largest set of exemptions in the country. Lawyers, police, firefighters and clergy can take a slide. So can podiatrists, physical therapists and embalmers. While 25 states have eliminated all occupational exemptions -- and 9 more have eliminated some exemptions -- a New York proposal to eliminate all exemptions has failed to pass in the Legislature.
 
Occupational Exemptions
 Jury reform advocates maintain that doing away with occupational exemptions would be the cheapest and easiest method to expand the jury rolls. "We've been trying like hell to get those lists repealed," said Norman Goodman, the New York County Clerk since 1969. "In New York City we have more doctors and lawyers than anywhere in the world, not to mention embalmers! Those exemptions take a big chunk out of our jury population."
Some can see reasons to exempt a few occupations. Police and firefighters got exemptions because they were already seen as serving the public; as a practical matter, defense lawyers would be disinclined to include them on juries. And prosecutors, Justice Carey speculated, would probably strike clergy from a panel: "Clergy have a built-in impediment," she said. "Most theologies urge them to forgive."
The overwhelming majority of jurors summoned ignore the first few notices or use up as many postponements as their county allows; each county can design its own regulations. New York County, one of the most accommodating counties, grants three deferments to a potential juror automatically. The fourth and fifth require the potential juror to show up with documentation. "Most people wait till they get their 'must serve' notices. And then it's like, 'O.K., maybe,' " said Florence B. Troia, the chief clerk of New York County's juror division. The annual postage for the waves of notices, cajolings and threats comes to about $250,000.
 
Annual Emergencies
 Since 1989, when the Legislature said jury service need be only one week every four years, many counties in New York have annually declared emergencies, so that jurors can be summoned for two weeks every two years.
Around the country, the shoulder-shrugging drives jurists wild. In recent years, a Tennessee judge ordered the arrest of 66 people who twice failed to show up for jury service and a Colorado judge even sent deputy sheriffs to a local mall to subpoena shoppers. Ignoring a jury summons is usually a misdemeanor, and jury commissioners, strapped for the resources to pursue scofflaws, are trying to impose fines. Mr. Goodman sent letters to 181 people, threatening them with a $250 fine, and earlier this month about 100 of them actually showed up in court to respond.
But states and local jurisdictions have also streamlined their procedures, making it both harder for jurors to duck out and easier for them to serve. Saving on postage and time, many commissioners send a qualification notice along with a summons for service. Most jurisdictions in New York State now allow jurors to phone ahead to determine whether their presence is needed on a given day; jurors in Queens and Staten Island can use the system and in Brooklyn the system is in place on holidays and sometimes in the summer.
 
'One Day, One Trial'
 Local courts scattered throughout at least 30 states have adopted a "one day, one trial" system that encourages more people to serve for a shorter time. Jurors are generally allowed only one postponement and almost no exemptions, but they only have to serve for one day. If they are not picked for a trial, they can leave. The average jury trial lasts about three days.
But almost none of these suggestions directly address one of the gravest concerns that the New York committee must take up: the underrepresentation of impoverished minorities on panels, mostly in counties outside New York City. The law requires that jury pools represent a fair cross-section of the community; it does not require that jurors be peers of defendants.
A 1992 study of two upstate judicial districts that included Albany County by the Capital District Black Bar Association found that minorities were underrepresented in jury pools. Members of minority groups, the study said, particularly those in poor neighborhoods, tended to be more transitory and so harder to locate to receive jury notices than other segments of the population, and less inclined to participate in civic activities.
 
Minority Participation
 To increase the participation of minorities, the study recommended that jurors' names also be taken from unemployment and utility lists. The Legislature this year passed a proposal that prospective jurors' names be taken from welfare rolls. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo vetoed the bill, citing reservations about privacy guarantees.
"Underrepresentation makes people think the system is unfair," said Justice Lewis L. Douglass of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, chairman of a state commission to develop strategies to make the legal system more equitable to minorities.
A racially and ethnically balanced pool and, subsequently, jury panel may indeed affect verdicts, he said. "People say that black and Hispanic jurors don't believe cops. That shouldn't surprise anyone: they have a different experience with the police, and they bring that skepticism to court." Justice Douglass believes that the qualification questionnaires should ask for racial identity.
But the judge said that even for people willing to appear, jury service has become synonymous with ordeal. "The court building is filthy and crowded," he said. "It doesn't look like a place where an important event is taking place."
 
'They're Not Evil'
 Jurors stand in hallways for hours, perplexed and angry, because no one bothers to tell them what is going on. "We insiders tend to treat jurors as a necessary evil," said Colleen McMahon of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, who chairs the New York Jury Project, the committee appointed by Judges Kaye and Milonas. "They're not evil. They're necessary."
And particular burdens fall on small businesses. Though many people indicate a willingness to serve, they cannot afford to do so: employers are not compelled to pay salaries while a worker is on jury duty. Suggestions to improve the lot of jurors include increasing the per diem from $15 to $40, the fee for Federal jurors. On-site child care has also been proposed.
And many judges favor reducing the peremptory challenges that lawyers can use to slice through a hefty pool, dismissing juror after juror without explanation. Civil jury selection often creates its own roadblocks: In New York neither judges nor judicial hearing officers preside over the lawyers' questioning, which can become unduly intrusive, long-winded and rancorous. And now, when lawyers cannot resolve a dispute during jury selection, they have to find a judge to get a ruling, which delays matters further.
Small wonder that the mood in the juror deferments' office the other day at 60 Centre Street was nothing short of adversarial. The clerks wanted those bodies, and those bodies sure didn't want to be there.
The line moved forward, and an older woman with tubes running from her nostrils to a portable oxygen tank stepped up to the desk.
The jury clerk looked her straight in the eye. "Do you have a doctor's note?" she said.

HEADLINE: Russian Says Soviet Atom Arsenal Was Larger Than West Estimated

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
A top Russian official says Moscow's nuclear arsenal peaked seven years ago at 45,000 warheads -- 12,000 more than generally believed and twice the number held by the United States at the time. The totalexceeded all estimates save those of the most hawkish analysts.
The official, Viktor N. Mikhailov, head of the Ministry of Atomic Energy, also says the Russian stockpile of highly enriched uranium is more than twice as large as commonly believed. Uranium in this form is a principal component of most nuclear weapons. 
 The Russian inventory of bomb-grade uranium is now said to be more than 1,200 metric tons. President Bush a year ago announced a multi-billion-dollar deal in which the United States would buy 500 metric tons of the Russian material, apparently thinking that this was most of Moscow's supply. The Clinton Administration is now considering whether to expand that purchase.
 
Scattered Disclosures
 The new comments being made by Mr. Mikhailov are scattered among recent interviews, conferences and public statements, some of which have appeared in the Russian press.
Surprised analysts say the remarks could rewrite parts of the cold war's history, with one suggesting that the West's blindness to the arsenal's size was an intelligence failure that might have had disastrous consequences.
"The large numbers lead you to worry that some of the planners may have had a first strike in mind -- using large numbers of weapons and having large numbers in reserve," said Bobby Ray Inman, a retired admiral and former head of the National Security Agency.
 
Alternative Explanation
 A more benign explanation, Mr. Inman said, was that the arsenal's vast size reflected a bureaucracy run amok and was unconnected to military strategy. "You just produce any number you can," he said in an interview.
Experts agree that the existence of a much larger uranium stockpile gives new urgency to tracking Russian bomb materials and guarding them against accident and theft amid political turmoil, a job the West is trying to aid.
Moreover, some warn that a large surplus of unregulated bomb-grade uranium might thwart new East-West arms accords or darken the estimates of military threats to the West if an unfriendly government came to power.
The sheer size of the enriched uranium stockpile illuminates the origins of a major part of Russia's current ecological crisis, revealing the vast pressures for the production of nuclear material that underlie the calamities of radioactive pollution and poisoning, which now haunt large parts of the former Soviet state.
The large stocks of newly disclosed Russian weapons and bomb material never violated an East-West arms accord, all of which set limits on large and verifiable objects like delivery systems rather than warheads. The logic was that a foe's missiles, bombers and submarines could be monitored by satellites, while nuclear arms and their constituents were too small and easily hidden to be checked for treaty compliance.
Nonetheless, analysts are surprised by the new numbers since the West spent so much time, money, material and even lives trying to track the most dangerous of all armaments.
"It's alarming that we have this discrepancy, but in some ways, it parallels the problems we had with assessing Iraq," said Fred C. Ikle, Under Secretary of Defense for Policy in the Reagan Administration.
"These things don't take that much space," he said. "It's conceivable that we could have missed them, as we did many other things in Russia, like the big fissures in their economy."
Mr. Ikle added: "Some of these things just ran wild, the military production. It was like the sorcerer's apprentice -- it just kept going. It happened occasionally on our side, too."
 
Caution Advised On Russian Report
 In the West, Mr. Mikhailov's disclosures are now being reported by the nuclear industry and private research groups. Although Mr. Mikhailov is a top Russian official, several analysts suggest that his numbers should be treated cautiously until independently confirmed.
"The quantity of weapons-grade uranium accumulated is very great," Mr. Mikhailov is quoted as saying in a coming industry report. He added that Moscow's stockpile is larger than the combined totals held by the United States, China, France and Britain.
Mr. Mikhailov's comments are to appear in the October issue of the Nukem Market Report, a monthly published by Nukem Inc., which is based in Stamford, Conn., and is one of the world's leading suppliers of nuclear fuel. The company, in partnership with Babcock & Wilcox, is one of several in the West that are vying to help the Russians dilute their bomb-grade uranium into reactor fuel.
Analysts believe that Moscow could be angling for new uranium sales in a bid to slow or reverse its slide into poverty. The American purchase of 500 metric tons of this material, whose contractual fine points are being worked out, is valued at up to $12 billion. A metric ton is 2,204.62 pounds.
Bomb-grade uranium, Mr. Mikhailov told the industry publication, "is extremely important" to Moscow as a source of "hard currency over an extended period of time."
During the cold war Washington's effort to gauge the strength of Moscow's nuclear hand was a guessing game laced with espionage, analytical work and considerable luck. In 1989 the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private group that monitors Russian nuclear affairs, published a summary of Washington's views in "Soviet Nuclear Weapons," a 443-page volume in its Nuclear Weapons Databook series.
The book's analysis of Federal estimates characterized three as credible and one as wildly inflated -- that of Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, who held that Moscow's arsenal peaked at 46,000 warheads. The research council's own estimate was 33,000 weapons, which was in line with many Washington views, apparently including those of the Central Intelligence Agency.
But in an update to its volume, published this month, the research council notes that Mr. Mikhailov has now said the arsenal crested in 1986 at 45,000 warheads, almost exactly as Mr. Weinberger had estimated. Mr. Mikhailov's remarks were originally made in private Washington briefings and, less precisely, in Russian press reports.
Surprisingly large, the 45,000 number rivals what Western analysts had previously thought to be the size of world's combined nuclear arsenals at their apex -- 50,000 weapons spread among the Soviet Union, the United States, France, Britain, China and Israel.
Western experts say they have no clear idea how the 12,000 added Russian weapons might have fit into Moscow's arsenal and military strategy, although some analysts believe that these arms may have been spares in deep storage.
 
Stockpile Down To 32,000 Weapons
 The research council reports that Moscow's actions after recent arms accords have now shrunk the total Russian stockpile to 32,000 weapons. But the spate of East-West agreements over the last few years have no provisions for the actual destruction of bomb material, which can be recycled for military or civilian purposes. The United States has 17,000 warheads, according to the Natural Resources Defense Council.
Lurking in and around the Russian arsenal, apparently, is a huge quantity of weapon material -- the newly described 1,200 metric tons of uranium that is highly enriched. That amount is enough to make 75,000 atomic bombs of the power that destroyed Hiroshima, or to energize a host of hydrogen bombs that would be even more deadly.
Natural uranium ore is made up of a mix of isotopes, or different forms of the same element. Less than 1 percent of ore is uranium 235, the isotope best suited to being split apart in a burst of energy. Uranium for most American nuclear power reactors is enriched to a level of about 3 percent uranium 235, while fuel for bombs is enriched by more than 90 percent in a process that is costly and time-consuming.
As the cold war ended, many Western experts suggested that the United States buy Russia's bomb-grade uranium as a way to gingerly disarm Moscow, to bolster the shaky Russian economy and to reduce the risks of nuclear accidents and theft.
 
Earlier Hints Of Larger Supply

On Aug. 31, 1992, President Bush announced the outlines of a deal to buy 500 metric tons of bomb-grade uranium from Moscow over 20 years. Private experts who once considered 500 metric tons to be the total inventory immediately started raising their estimates because it seemed unlikely that Moscow would sell its entire supply.
More recently, American intelligence is said to have estimated that Moscow's stockpile of bomb-grade uranium is 800 metric tons.
In the interview with the Nukem Market Report, Mr. Mikhailov put the minimum total stockpile, including what is currently in warheads, at more than 1,200 metric tons, or 1.5 to 1.7 times greater than the combined stores of all other countries. The 500 metric tons of the current sale, Mr. Mikhailov emphasized, "represents somewhere around 30 to 40 percent of all reserves that we possess."
The research council, in its 209-page update, gives many new details of the formerly secret factories that enrich the uranium, revealing a vast enterprise at four widely separated sites. Each site has many thousands of gas centrifuges, the most modern type of technology for making enriched uranium.
In the Nukem interview, Mr. Mikhailov was asked about the possibility of theft from this sprawling enterprise. He replied that bomb-grade uranium was stolen on one occasion, but gave no other substantive details about the incident. Repeated attempts to reach Mr. Mikhailov in Moscow were unsuccessful.
"In the old days we used to worry about external bandits and smugglers," he said. "Now we worry about internal smuggling activity. We have to strengthen the procedures for accounting and control."
He added, "Many people in Russia live on the edge of poverty, and there is a great temptation to steal in these plants."
Thomas L. Neff, a physicist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said in an interview that he thought Mr. Mikhailov might be exaggerating the amount of uranium, perhaps to appease the Russian military. But Mr. Ikle, the former Under Secretary of Defense, said the military was too close to the situation to be fooled.
 
Security and Theft As Main Problem
 William G. Sutcliffe, a senior physicist at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California who works in arms control, said all newly disclosed uranium was more dangerous as a security problem than a military threat.
"The important lesson from the cold war was that large numbers of weapons were not necessary," he said, adding that a smaller arsenal that could survive a pre-emptive strike was better.
But the existence of more bomb-grade uranium, he added, "magnifies the problem" of preventing theft. "It makes materials-accountability and physical control even more important."
Thomas B. Cochran, a senior scientist at the research council and a co-author of the update, said the new reports were a bad omen for arms control since they would unnerve Western military planners. He said East-West data exchanges were needed to reassure both sides about the feasibility of future arms cuts.
"The uncertainty in these numbers," he said, referring to the gap between the intelligence estimate of 800 metric tons and the Russian assertion of 1,200 tons, "is as big as our entire stockpile."
"You cannot expect to achieve deep reductions in nuclear weapons and material reserves with these huge uncertainties," he said.

HEADLINE: Unusual Joint Effort Is Seeking to Reduce Sulfur in Diesel Fuel

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Beginning Friday, pedestrians in New York and other congested cities may begin to breathe easier, as may motorists sandwiched between trucks in the Lincoln Tunnel, on the Long Island Expressway and on the nation's interstate highways.
The black soot pouring out of the exhaust pipes of the 2.5 million trucks, buses and many other diesel-fueled vehicles in the United States should begin to be substantially reduced. Within 60 days, diesel-fueled vehicles that use the roads and highways must begin to use fuel that contains 90 percent less sulfur -- no more than 0.05 percent sulfur, compared with the current standard of 0.5 percent. 
 The change is a result of an unusual five-year effort involving the Environmental Protection Agency and the oil and trucking industries, one of the most ambitious collaborations yet between industry and the E.P.A.
The effort began in 1988, when the oil industry and the manufacturers of diesel engines, under the threat of stiffer regulations, submitted a joint proposal for meeting new environmental standards with low-sulfur fuel and modifications to diesel engines.
In 1990 the Clean Air Act was amended accordingly, and the oil industry -- with the support of the trucking industry -- began a multibillion-dollar effort to gear up to produce the lower-sulfur fuel.
"It makes sense to do our part," said Thomas Donohue, the president of the American Trucking Association, a trade group in Washington.
He said truckers would pay about 3 cents to 4 cents a gallon more for the cleaner fuel. But he said they would pay less for the new engines, which will require less complicated technology to reduce pollution than those now in use. The manufacturers of diesel engines must meet the lower emission standards in 1994.
The E.P.A. has estimated that the savings from the new engines will be $60 to $325 per vehicle.
Although the new fuel is supposed to be available on Friday at gas stations, truck stops and fueling centers, some trucking companies have not been able to get enough of it.
After the trucking association demonstrated that shortages existed, the E.P.A. granted a 60-day grace period for the industry to phase in the cleaner diesel at fuel stops.
 
Inspections are Planned
 E.P.A. inspectors will soon begin testing to make sure the fuel distribution centers are using the new fuel, but during the grace period trucking companies can continue to use the older fuel if they can show that they made a good-faith effort to get supplies.
Richard Ackerman, a station chief for the E.P.A. in Washington, said the grace period was not a blanket moratorium; rather, each company would have to prove it could not get the fuel. Companies that fail to do so could be fined $25,000 a day plus any economic benefit they might get from using the cheaper high-sulfur fuel.
Responding to the concern of the truckers that their rigs would be stopped for spot checks of fuel tanks, Mr. Ackerman said that would not happen unless the agency got a tip that a particular trucking company was using high-sulfur fuel. "We're not going to stop trucks on the road," he said. "That's not in our plan."
 
Reduced Emissions
 The E.P.A. has estimated that under the new regulations, by 1995, the emissions of particulates, or soot, will be reduced by up to 38 percent, and sulfur dioxide, which causes acid rain and is formed when sulfur is released into the air, will decrease by up to 80 percent.
Particulates are small carbon particles that are not broken down in the air and can lodge in the lungs. The particulates have been considered a possible cause of cancer, and high levels can cause respiratory infections and attacks of asthma and bronchitis.
Because of those dangers, some environmentalists contend that not enough is being done in congested urban areas to cut emissions from buses. Yet they are encouraged by the effort to reduce sulfur in diesel fuel. Eric Goldstein, a lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council, a national environmental group based in New York, said the oil and trucking industries had a financial motive for cooperating to help reduce pollution in urban areas.
"There are many people who believe that the way to address the urban diesel problem is to switch to cleaner fuels like natural gas," Mr. Goldstein said.
High-sulfur varieties will still be available for about half the users of diesel fuel -- railroads, ships and vehicles used primarily on farms.
The E.P.A. has estimated that it will cost the oil industry from $380 million to $910 million by 1995, and up to $1.3 billion by 2010, to make the upgrades to meet the demand for the new low-sulfur fuel.
The National Petroleum Council, a Federal advisory committee to the United States Secretary of Energy, who appoints its members, said in a recent study that the oil industry would have to invest about $37 billion over the next decade to upgrade its refineries to meet Federal and state environmental requirements.
Charles Walz, the vice president of refining for Texaco, estimated that the company had spent about $175 million to upgrade its four refineries to produce the new fuel.
"We're in a painstaking transition process," he said, "You have to flush out the old material at refineries, distribution centers and finally at service stations."
 
Falling Prices
 The prices of diesel fuel and gasoline have been falling, as has the price of crude oil, in the face of plentiful supplies and weak demand.
Indeed, the spot market for the new diesel fuel has been weak, leading some industry executives to predict that eventually it will command a premium of only a cent or two a gallon over high-sulfur fuel.
Such predictions come as a relief to trucking firms and hundreds of thousands of independent truckers, because on Oct. 1, they will be hit not only with higher-priced fuel, but also with an added tax of 4.3 cents a gallon passed by Congress as part of the deficit-reduction package.
The National Petroleum Council study has estimated that gasoline, jet fuel, home heating oil and diesel fuel could cost an average of 6 cents more a gallon by 1995 as a result of the various Government standards.
