HEADLINE: Their Slice of the American Dream

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NORTH AMITYVILLE, L.I., Sept. 24

 BODY:
Every day for months, Yasmin Saunders took a few minutes out of her frenetic schedule to drive to a building site on a residential street just off the Southern State Parkway and watch the workers frame, hammer and paint the town house she had never dreamed she would own.
It had been such an arduous journey to this juncture in the life of Ms. Saunders, a 37-year-old single mother who had worked at two and sometimes three jobs at a time, that she was drawn to the site each day, not just to savor the achievement of buying a town house, but also to remind herself of how far she had come. 
 "The feeling is just overwhelming," declared Ms. Saunders, who has two teen-age sons. "I had never entertained the thought of buying a home. That certainly was not for me. A single mother? I'm supposed to struggle."
Next month, the first occupants will be moving into the new town houses on Schleigel Boulevard built by a nonprofit housing group for low- and moderate-income home buyers. In design, size and cost, the development resembles many other affordable-housing projects on Long Island and elsewhere. But the buyers of Amity Villas are different in one important respect: Many, like Ms. Saunders, are single working mothers.
Officials of the Long Island Housing Partnership, which developed Amity Villas, say no other project they have built on Long Island has attracted so many single mothers as first-time buyers. Of the 72 units built on a nine-acre tract in this working-class, racially mixed community, 47 were bought by unmarried women, 28 of them mothers.
The single mothers moving to Amity Villas are mostly women in their 20's and 30's -- secretaries, hospital aides and administrative assistants living as close as a mile from the development and as far as Brooklyn and the Bronx. They are women from a variety of backgrounds and cultures who shared a goal, but, with salaries of $20,000 to $35,000 a year, lacked the wherewithal to achieve it. For many of them, the notion of being tied down by a mortgage was less a burden than a badge of distinction.
"It's to get something better," said Petal Sampson, a 27-year-old native of Guyana who works as a membership secretary at the Harvard Club in Manhattan. She will soon be moving out of the one-bedroom apartment in East Flatbush she shares with her 6-year-old daughter, Nikeda, for a two-bedroom town house 35 miles east. "When I first mention it, people say, 'Why are you going so far?' But I knew I wanted to do it. I wanted to do it even more because I have a child."
 
An Untapped Market
 Sociologists and housing experts say that Amity Villas has inadvertently tapped into a large market of working single women, many with children, who want to own homes but traditionally have been blocked or discouraged from doing so because of limited incomes or their belief that they cannot get a mortgage. They say Amity Villas is a potential model for the type of housing that would give more single mothers the stable environments they seek for their families.
Experts in single parenthood say that the women buying in Amity Villas represent the majority of single mothers in this country: working women often holding more than one low-paying job and struggling to stay off government assistance. Sara McLanahan, a sociology professor at Princeton University who studies the effects of single parenthood on children, said that while the popular perception of a single mother is that of a woman on welfare, fewer than half of all single mothers are on welfare at any time in a given year.
"The typical single mother is not on welfare and is certainly not Murphy Brown," Ms. McLanahan said, referring to the affluent television character whose decision to have a child out of wedlock came under a heated attack by former Vice President Dan Quayle. "The typical single mother is near the poverty line but is working, and I think one of the most important things to help her raise her children is to give her stable housing."
In her statistical analyses, Ms. McLanahan has found that after a lack of money, the biggest problem faced by single-parent families is the failure to find permanent housing. "It's another form of instability, and the research I've done shows the majority of the moves for these families are involuntary. They get evicted, or they can't afford to stay," she said.
James Morgo, the president of the partnership, a five-year-old group that has built hundreds of houses on Long Island, primarily in Suffolk County, said that the development's location in an economically depressed area and its lower-than-average ceiling on household income -- $39,680 for a family of three or more -- contributed to the large numbers of single mothers who applied.
 
More Willing to Lend
 In addition, commercial banks, required by a 1989 Federal law to report on the numbers of mortgages they give to members of minorities and disadvantaged groups, have become more willing to extend loans to single and minority women, Mr. Morgo said.
The 72 identical town houses each cost more than $83,500 to build, but with subsidies of $25,000 per unit from the New York State Affordable Housing Corporation, the cost to the buyers was brought down to $58,500, Mr. Morgo said. Government subsidies through the Federal Home Loan Bank also helped to make the mortgages affordable. The would-be homeowners, selected in a lottery from among more than 300 applicants, were required to be first-time buyers with good credit records and the ability to pay about $6,000 in down payments and closing costs.
When an acquaintance gave Esther Scott a flier announcing the lottery, she jumped at the opportunity. Ms. Scott, a therapy aide for a state institution for the mentally ill who juggled a second job as a newspaper deliverer while caring for her two young children, recognized it as one of the few chances she would get to move out and up. In fact, the mortgage and taxes on the Amity Villas town houses were lower than the $700 a month she pays for a basement apartment off Sunrise Highway in North Amityville.
"I took out a consolidation loan and paid off all my credit cards and my car payments," said Ms. Scott, who lives with her 3-year-old son, Tristan, and 20-month-old daughter, Jaimie. "I knew I would get my mortgage."
She did. Ms. Scott's confidence was not unusual among the women who had applied for the homes. "I think they're all going to want to head the homeowners association," said Dolores Murphy, a project coordinator.
 
Overcoming Delays
 The project itself, however, was beset by delays. Although the lottery was held in 1990, the partnership did not break ground until last winter. Plaguing the startup was a major problem: Dozens of those who had won the lottery, married people as well as single, were being denied mortgages because of poor credit histories or inadequate income. In the end, the partnership offered units to all 300 original applicants, and about two hundred others added later, to find 72 qualified buyers.
Ms. Saunders, an administrative assistant for an export company in Woodbury, had her first mortgage application rejected. But a second bank said yes. "I got the letter. I was jumping up and down in the rain," she recalled with a laugh.
She is thrilled at the prospect of the move, and pleased at the chance the partnership has given her. But even so, Ms. Saunders is angry at the lack of options for a struggling mother like her, who at one point was working days as a secretary, nights as a saleswoman and weekends as a receptionist in a beauty salon.
"It's a degrading process," she said of obtaining a house by lottery. "It's like having to beg for it." Sitting in a diner near her office, she recalled something she had once heard Gov. Mario M. Cuomo say about the lack of housing for lower-income families.
"He said he thought it was a disgrace that your owning a home depends on whether your name is picked out of a hat," she said. "I agree with him, 100 percent."
With the opening of Amity Villas imminent, some of the single mothers wondered whether they could take advantage of their numbers, perhaps by pooling resources for child care. Mr. Morgo said that the partnership might seek community development funds to build a playground.
 
Protect That Credit
 For now, the prospective homeowners are obsessed with the mechanics of the move. To guard against last-minute reversals of mortgage approvals, they have been advised not to make big-ticket purchases until after they take possession of their 980-square-foot domains.
But no one can prevent them from dreaming. The other day, Ms. Scott was permitted a first glimpse inside her town house. As Tristan and Jaimie wrestled on the blue carpet, the 30-year-old mother glanced around, making decorating plans. Among the priorities: an L-shaped banquette in the eat-in kitchen.
"I like it," Ms. Scott said, glancing around the room, almost in a daze. "I can't wait to get in."

HEADLINE: Amid Turmoil, Holtzman Is Top Fund-Raiser

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

 BODY:
In a period when her integrity was under near-constant fire, Elizabeth Holtzman managed to raise more campaign contributions than her rivals for city comptroller, Assemblyman Alan G. Hevesi and Herman Badillo, campaign finance reports show.
Between Sept. 7 and last Monday, Ms. Holtzman received $266,100 in contributions while Mr. Hevesi received $229,494 and Mr. Badillo, $127,970, according to summaries of reports sent to the city's Campaign Finance Board yesterday. 
 Ms. Holtzman, the incumbent, and Mr. Hevesi will be in a runoff for the Democratic nomination on Tuesday.
Mr. Hevesi finished narrowly ahead of Ms. Holtzman in the Sept. 14 Democratic primary but failed to garner 40 percent of the vote, the minimum needed to avoid a runoff. Mr. Badillo, who will be on the November ballot as the Republican-Liberal candidate, finished third in the Democratic primary.
During the two weeks covered by the reports, Ms. Holtzman suffered a series of setbacks that severely eroded her once-formidable lead. In that time, the city released a critical report on a $450,000 campaign loan from 1992 and news organizations reported that the loan was the subject of a Federal bank-fraud inquiry.
 
Hevesi Gaining Faster
 Despite Ms. Holtzman's ability to raise money amid her travails, finance reports covering last Tuesday and Wednesday indicate that Mr. Hevesi may have gained momentum in the money-raising race. On those two days, Mr. Hevesi collected $44,250 in contributions to Ms. Holtzman's $27,750. And while Mr. Hevesi's contributions came from about 30 sources, Ms. Holtzman's came from 6 sources.
Among Mr. Hevesi's contributors last week were: John A. Zaccaro, husband of Geraldine A. Ferraro, $500; Vincent Tese, the State Commissioner for Economic Development, $2,500, and Lewis Rudin, the real-estate developer, $1,000. In addition, Mr. Hevesi received $5,000 from the Atlantic Bank of New York, $3,250 from the Sheet Metal Workers Local 28, and $3,250 from the New York State Laborers.
The bulk of Ms. Holtzman's contributions last week, $19,500, came from the Ratner family, including $6,500 from Bruce Ratner, who developed Metrotech Center in downtown Brooklyn, and $6,500 from one of Mr. Ratner's companies, First New York Partners.
Ms. Holtzman and Mr. Hevesi were scheduled to spend a full day on the stump today, focusing their efforts on black churches and on street fairs in Manhattan and Brooklyn.
Ms. Holtzman also picked up the measured support of former Mayor Edward I. Koch, who said in an interview yesterday that he plans to vote for Ms. Holtzman in Tuesday's runoff because he does not like Mr. Hevesi and feels Ms. Holtzman has been unfairly attacked for receiving the $450,000 bank loan, which he called a "lapse in judgment."
Mr. Koch said his support had not been solicited from Ms. Holtzman's camp. "I thought somebody has to stand up for this person," he said.
But Mr. Koch said he plans to vote for Mr. Badillo in November.

HEADLINE: NICARAGUA STRIKE UNITES OLD FOES

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Sept. 25

 BODY:
As he unstacked the paving blocks of a huge barricade that had stopped traffic along the Pan-American Highway, Oscar Mejia, a 29-year-old electrician, appeared satisfied with the four-day transportation strike he had joined.
The strike this week led the Government on Friday to ease an increase in fuel prices and repeal new vehicle taxes, but Mr. Mejia disagreed with the way some Government officials characterized the strikers. 
 "The Government says the barricades were put up by the Sandinistas," he said. "Some people here are Sandinistas, but I never was. Now we are all just poor people fighting together."
The strike, which blocked much of the traffic in the country, was the fourth serious episode of political turmoil in two months. In late July former Sandinista soldiers attacked the city of Esteli. Last month, there were two political kidnappings of some 80 officials, soldiers and politicians, including Vice President Virgilio Godoy Reyes.
 
A Blurred Ideological Line
 But more vividly than the earlier events, the transportation strike showed how poverty and anger have blurred the ideological line that divided Nicaragua through its civil war in the 1980's.
Many of the unions and workers who began the strike were traditionally allied with the leftist Sandinistas. But many of the people who came out of their homes to defend the barricade of paving stones and tree trunks said they had supported the contras, the United States-backed rightist rebels who had fought the Sandinistas. On this barricade, as on others, people said the former adversaries were finding common cause.
At the barricade, Ernesto Guzman, 28, told a story typical of many Nicaraguans.
As a teen-ager in 1978 he joined the Sandinista Front in the revolution that overthrew the dictator Anastasio Somoza Debayle. Then as a soldier in the Sandinista People's Army he fought the contras. Now, laid off from his job in a mattress factory, he said he was selling chewing gum and trinkets at the same Managua street corner as a former contra.
"The contras are victims of this Government too," he said.
 
Family Worse Off Than Before
 Two days into the strike, Marta Ceballos, 37, the wife of a cabdriver, came out to join Mr. Mejia, Mr. Guzman and the other people blocking traffic. She was given a spiked metal object the size of her fist to throw in front of the tires of vehicles that tried to pass the blockade.
Mrs. Ceballos said that throughout the 1980's she opposed the Sandinistas because of their socialist ideology. She said, "My mother raised me, and I raised my children, to believe that you had to rely on yourself".
She expected that the election of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro in 1990 would rebuild the country's economy. Instead, she said, her family is worse off than it has ever been.
"Chamorro is rich," she said. "The Sandinista leaders are rich. Those ministers in the Government are all rich. What do they care about us poor people?"
Last week a public opinion poll indicated that 50 percent of Nicaraguans surveyed thought life was better during the Somoza years.
Since Mrs. Chamorro took office, labor strife on the scale of this week's strike has typically involved the Sandinistas. But as the Sandinista Front has been weakened by internal divisions and its leaders have faced accusations of using their positions to enrich themselves, the front's power to bring people to the streets has diminished.
 
'This Isn't About Politics'
 After the barricades went up, the most prominent Sandinista leader, former President Daniel Ortega Saavedra, harshly criticized Mrs. Chamorro for policies he said were worsening poverty.
But the comments by people at the barricade on the Pan-American Highway suggested that Mr. Ortega and the rest of the Sandinista leadership may not have been leading the protesters so much as trying to catch up with them.
One former Sandinista militant, Santiago Vargas, said he now regreted the years he spent following Mr. Ortega. Mr. Vargas, an unemployed hospital worker, said he used to think he shared a vision of social justice and economic equality with the Sandinista leaders, but now he felt deserted by them.
Mrs. Ceballos, never a Sandinista supporter, said: "This isn't about politics. This is about poor people. If these children here had something to eat, or a decent school to go to, they'd be home eating breakfast and getting ready for school. I'd be home with my family. We are all here because we are desperate."

HEADLINE: NO AID IS PLEDGED FOR MIDEAST PLAN

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
Finance ministers and central bank presidents of the world's seven leading industrial democracies expressed support today for Russia and for Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied territories, but the officials pledged no new aid for either.
The ministers also reached no new plan to stimulate the sluggish world economy. American officials said this week that they were especially interested in increasing global economic growth through lower interest rates in Europe and Japan and possibly lower taxes in Japan. So the absence of any such deal was another sign that these periodic meetings play a dwindling role in international monetary policy. 
 "It was very successful in line with the approach that we're taking," a senior Treasury Department official said after the meeting. "These aren't meetings where one country negotiates the policy of another country's independent central bank. These are meetings where areas of mutual concern are explored."
 
Russian Progress Reported
 Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and Alan Greenspan, Chairman of the Federal Reserve, served as hosts to their counterparts from Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy and Japan. The ministers are here for the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
Toward the end of their meeting today, the finance ministers invited Finance Minister Boris G. Fyodorov of Russia to join them. Mr. Bentsen said Mr. Fyodorov had described Russia's recent payments on its overdue foreign debts and outlined a schedule for monthly payments through 1993.
He also said Mr. Fyodorov had found the Russian central bank to be more cooperative. Russia's Finance Ministry and central bank have been disagreeing for months about the Government loans being made to large, struggling factories. The central bank has encouraged such loans to prevent the failure of factories and the loss of jobs. But Finance Ministry officials and Western economists have attributed the loans to high inflation and the plunging value of the ruble.
 
World Bank to Aid Palestinians
 In a joint statement issued at the end of the meeting, the ministers said Mr. Fyodorov also discussed plans for more sales of state-owned enterprises to private investors. The statement endorsed President Boris N. Yeltsin's free-market policies and reaffirmed previous Western aid commitments without offering more money.
Referring to support to aid Palestinians in their transition to autonomy in the occupied territories, Mr. Bentsen said, "We talked about that today and agreed resources must flow to the region, private investment is critical and assistance must be coordinated effectively." He also said the World Bank would "play a central role."
Mr. Bentsen said details would be worked out next week at a conference that he and Secretary of State Warren Christopher are to convene to muster financial support for the peace plan.

HEADLINE: Gifts Help N.A.A.C.P. Focus on Economic Agenda

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
A few days before his death last January, Reginald F. Lewis, one of the country's wealthiest businessmen, dictated instructions to his wife from his hospital bed about giving favorite charities a share of his sizable fortune, including $2 million for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
The gift, and the creation of the Reginald F. Lewis Memorial Endowment, were announced at the annual N.A.A.C.P. convention in July and inspired an unexpected pledge of $1 million a few weeks later from Alphonse Fletcher Jr., a 27-year-old investor who regarded Mr. Lewis as a role model, adviser and friend. 
 The gifts are significant, said Dr. Benjamin F. Chavis Jr., the association's executive director, because they move the endowment toward its goal of raising $100 million to revitalize the 84-year-old N.A.A.C.P, the country's oldest civil rights organization.
The revitalization includes a newly aggressive focus on an economic agenda that has led the N.A.A.C.P. into clashes with aerospace contractors like Hughes and with the Denny's restaurant chain. On another front, the association wants to demonstrate that people like Mr. Fletcher from minority groups can and do achieve success as youthful entrepreneurs -- and help others follow that path.
 
'A New Generation'
 "The endowment will help the N.A.A.C.P. deliver on its promise to nurture a new generation of business leaders," said Dr. Chavis, outlining his plans during a joint interview with Mr. Fletcher, chief executive officer of Fletcher Capital Markets, at Mr. Fletcher's midtown business headquarters in Manhattan.
He said the endowment named after his longtime friend would not be limited to helping blacks but would also aid Asian-Americans, Hispanic people and American Indians.
Mr. Fletcher said his friendship with Mr. Lewis began with a telephone call of encouragement to him on a suit he had filed charging that racial bias affected his pay at Kidder Peabody, where he was then a manager of an investment group. Mr. Fletcher won an arbitration award of $1.26 million.
Over time, the two men met and also talked frequently. They shared a number of interests, one of them being Harvard. Mr. Lewis graduated from Harvard Law School and last year gave it $3 million. The law school named an international center for him -- the first building on campus named for a black man. Mr. Fletcher and two younger brothers graduated from Harvard College.
Like Mr. Lewis, who was chief executive of TLC Beatrice International Holdings, an international food conglomerate, Mr. Fletcher does not want the issue of race to dominate what he has accomplished or his performance to be measured exclusively as a black businessman.
 
'It Is All Too Little'
 In the notes dictated a few days before his death, Mr. Lewis said some progress clearly had been made in the civil rights cause. Nonetheless, he said, "It is all too little when we consider the day-to-day drama being inflicted upon many of our children who are of African or Hispanic descent and who are not yet fully included in the American dream.
"By working in this field in the future, I believe that I am working for all Americans because I truly believe that our society is highly vulnerable unless we join together in seeing this not as as a particular problem of any one ethnic group but as something that the nation must address as part of its own spirit of renewal."
Mr. Fletcher was with the Lewis family at the N.A.A.C.P. convention when the endowment was announced by Dr. Chavis. It was news that the family had kept to itself until then.
"As the announcement was made," Mr. Fletcher said, "I was sitting there thinking about what I could do to help others. I also believe challenging economic inequity is as important for the N.A.A.C.P. today as it was once to challenge segregation in restaurants and education. This was an appropriate way to honor Reginald Lewis. It all came together."

HEADLINE: Oil and Tourism Don't Mix, Inciting Amazon Battle

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: QUITO, Ecuador

 BODY:
Standing on a riverbank outside his Amazon tourist lodge, Pieter Jan Brouwer raised his rifle one day last year and shot out the tires, headlights and windshields of a dozen trucks and bulldozers that were dredging gravel for an American oil company road.
"I had the disaster of having the hotel full and 14 guests pounding on my door at 4 A.M. threatening to sue me," Mr. Brouwer recalled of the round-the-clock dredging operations by a subcontractor for Maxus Ecuador Inc., the oil company. "If you come to see the rain forest, to watch birds and to enjoy tranquillity, you can't imagine what it is like to wake up and see dump trucks and bulldozers." 
 Mr. Brouwer, a Dutch businessman who operates the Amazon Jungle Resort Village, may not exactly be Ecuador's environmental Minuteman, but his gunshots warn of a looming collision between two radically different views of Ecuador's Amazon.
Oil companies depict the area as a pool of underground wealth, two billion barrels of oil that could lift this nation out of chronic poverty. Organizers of "nature tourism" argue that the Amazon, one of the world's richest biological regions, should be preserved as it is for tourists, scientists and the region's 100,000 Indian inhabitants.
 
Conflicts Are Common
 Conflicts between preservation and development are common in the eight-nation Amazon region, but Ecuador's circumstances have thrown the debate into fast forward. With about one-third of this Colorado-size nation covered by Amazon rain forest, oil drillers and tourist operators increasingly say the area is too small for both industries.
On the scale of economic value, oil, Ecuador's largest export, currently outweighs tourism, Ecuador's fourth largest source of foreign exchange.
"Ecuadoreans need oil for development," Francisco Costa Coloma, Ecuador's Energy and Mines Minister, said in a recent interview here. According to Unicef, 79 percent of Ecuador's population is considered poor and 39 percent of the children under the age of 5 suffer from malnutrition.
Mr. Costa noted that this country of 11 million people relied on oil sales for half its export earnings and for 62 percent of its Government budget.
A map in his office shows that the country's 45,000-square-mile Amazon region is already largely carpeted by oil company exploration and production blocks. With most of Ecuador's proven reserves in the Amazon, the Government plans to put up for bids in January six more Amazon blocks, totaling 5,000 square miles.
In December Ecuador dropped out of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries after the cartel tried to impose a production quota that was 23 percent below the country's projected output for 1993.
During 25 years of oil production in Ecuador's Amazon region, oil companies traditionally ran roughshod over the land rights and health concerns of the region's Indians and peasant settlers.
"Hundreds of oil wells generate more than 4.3 million gallons of toxic wastes every day, virtually all of which are spilled or discharged into the environment without treatment, contaminating countless streams and rivers," Judith Kimerling, an environmental lawyer, wrote in 1990 in "Amazon Crude," a book that has become the "Silent Spring" of Ecuador's increasingly aggressive environmental movement.
 
Water Tests Conducted
 In October, the Institute for Economic and Social Rights, a nonprofit group based in New York, is to release results of drinking water tests conducted last spring in Amazon areas where a consortium set up by Petroecuador, Ecuador's state-owned oil company, and Texaco produced oil from 1967 to 1990.
Testing eight sources of drinking water for polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, substances that cause cancer in humans, researchers found levels ranging from 2 to 500 times the maximum level accepted by the United States Environmental Protection Agency. Sarah Zaidi, a coordinator of the project, said that these high levels of hydrocarbons were byproducts of oil production.
In the battle to force oil companies to adopt cleaner practices, Amazon Indians are discovering a powerful ally in Ecuador's mushrooming nature tourism business. Only four hours by air from Miami, Ecuador expects to attract 30,000 American and European tourists to its Amazon region this year.
Amazon tourism has doubled over the last five years, giving influential business people in Quito an economic interest in preserving the jungle.
Last month, Ecuador's President, Sixto Duran Ballen, visited a Petroecuador oil exploration site in a park wetlands adjacent to Imuya Camp, a forest lodge operated by Metropolitan Touring, Ecuador's largest tourism operator. In addition to offering jungle walks in "remote, untouched forest," Imuya Camp takes tourists in canoes to paddle through forest lagoons, watching for freshwater dolphins, black caimans, monkeys and the bright plumage of parrots, macaws and toucans.
 
Hotel Owner Sues
 After the visit the President banned further oil exploration by Petroecuador in the area of the camp. But he upheld drilling in two other sections of the park, the Cuyabeno Wildlife Reserve.
After the President's daughter, Alicia, visited the Amazon Jungle Resort Village at the head of an official investigating team, Maxus agreed to move its gravel-dredging operation half a mile downriver. Before the move, a jeepload of workers for the American company's Brazilian subcontractor, Andrade Gutierrez, attacked one of the hotel employees, breaking his hand. The construction workers also warned Mr. Brouwer and another hotel director that "a price was offered" for their heads in a nearby town, Shushufindi, Mr. Brouwer said.
This month the hotel's owner, Mariana Almeida, filed a $4 million damage suit against Maxus in a court here alleging that bookings at the lodge had dropped by 70 percent and that a British bank canceled a $2 million loan because of the dredging operations
A Maxus official said in an interview that Mrs. Almeida had opened her hotel two years ago on a part of the Aguarico River where oil companies had traditionally dredged for gravel.
"Tourism and mining are not compatible, and, unfortunately, she located her hotel near a mine," said Boris P. Abad, manager of government affairs and environmental control for the American company.
 
Wider Conflicts Predicted
 With Amazon tourism growing by 12 percent a year, operators say, the disputes with oil companies are going to increase. . "Nature tourists don't want to see helicopters, pipelines and oil rigs," said Pedro Proano, a spokesman for the Ecuadorean Eco-Tourism Association, a newly formed group that represents 35 operators.
Mr. Proano is leading a fight to keep oil exploration out of the Cuyabeno Reserve. In an increasingly common alliance here, his company, Transturi, hires Cofan Indians to serve as forest guides. Last year a group of Cofan detained about 25 Petroecuador surveyors and escorted them out of the reserve. After President Duran Ballen authorized drilling at one Cuyabeno site, Zabalo, this month, Cofan Indians burned a Petroecuador heliport and placed obstacles on the landing pad, according to Accion Ecologica, a private environmental group here.
Last spring Quechua Indians in Capirona, a community with a fledgling business in nature tours, confronted workers for an American seismic company, who were protected by Ecuadorian Army soldiers. After a tense standoff, the Indians prevailed, forcing the oil workers and soldiers to leave.
With their budgets largely financed by oil revenue, Ecuador's armed forces traditionally side with oil workers. The country's air force maintains a monopoly on all scheduled commercial flights into the Amazon, a prerogative that allows it to limit tourism.
One of South America's last state-run airlines, Transportes Aereos Militares Ecuatorianos, known by the Spanish acronym TAME, does not accept individual reservations and changes schedules without notice. Travel agencies generally refuse to deal with the airline.
To fill the jungle lodges, big nature tour operators charter planes. The smaller ones bribe TAME personnel at Quito's airport to guarantee seats.
"The Government sees eco-tourism as something positive," Mr. Proano, the spokesman for the tourism alliance, said. "But oil is the No. 1 priority."

HEADLINE: IRAN TALKS OF BID FOR NEW ALLIANCES

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 25

 BODY:
Facing political isolation and a wave of diplomatic pressure over its denunciation of the Israeli-Palestinian accord, Iran proclaimed this week that it was seeking a strategic alliance with China and India.
"One of Iran's most natural partners is India, and given our situation with the United States and some Western countries, China is another suitable partner," the Iranian President, Hashemi Rafsanjani, said in an interview published in The Hindustan Times, an Indian daily. "We have tested their honesty. If we work together we can have the last word on international issues." 
 Although Iran may emerge one day as an import market for nuclear technology and textiles from Asia, analysts said Teheran's overtures seemed to be a bargaining chip for normalizing relations with the West.
 
Distrust from China
 China's view of Iran's Islamic fundamentalist politics appears to be one of distrust. And India is among the countries that have been pressing the Iranian Government to endorse peace efforts in the Middle East.
During an official visit to Teheran this week, India's Prime Minister, Narasimha Rao, emphasized "the great specter of change in the world" in a meeting with Mr. Rafsanjani, the newspaper Salam reported.
High-ranking French and British Foreign Ministry officials also arrived here this week to solicit Iranian support for the Israeli-Palestinian peace accord, which Mr. Rafsajani bitterly condemned last week.
Japan's warning to Iran was especially blunt, diplomats said.
"It is in the interest of the Iranian state to endorse the Israeli-Palestinian accord," diplomats quoted Japan's Deputy Foreign Minister, Hiroshi Fukuda, as telling his Iranian counterpart last Sunday. "Rejection will be a sign that Teheran is not worthy of trust."
 
Diplomatic Isolation
 Mr. Fukuda warned Teheran that it faced increasing diplomatic isolation because of its stance on the agreement.
The Japanese envoy reminded Teheran that Tokyo had opposed the Clinton Administration's policy of containment for Iran earlier this year.
But in its official remarks, Teheran has said repeatedly that the peace pact had only increased its incentive to part ways with Europe and Japan.
Hussein Sheikholislam, a senior Iranian diplomat, traveled to Damascus, Syria, last weekend to meet with militant Palestinian groups. In a meeting with Ahmed Jabril, Secretary General of The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, he pledged "Iran's comprehensive support for the Palestinian cause," The Teheran Times reported.
"In response to the compromise of Arabs with Israel and the backing of the accord by Europe and Japan," the state-run Hamshahri newspaper said in an editorial on Tuesday, "the most rational counterattack is to build a strategic alliance between Iran, India, China and even Kazakhstan."
 
A Skeptical Reaction
 Though the editorial was interpreted as promoting a nuclear alliance, political analysts and business people reacted skeptically.
"The Iranian economy cannot suddenly change course from a Western-dependent economy," said Reza Dadmanesh, a real estate developer. "Every year, $1 billion worth of Iranian carpets are exported to Western Europe. There is practically no market for them in India. Mr. Rafsanjani apparently employs some very unqualified advisers."
Analysts say one motivation for denouncing the Israeli-Palestinian peace accord was to bring together competing blocs in the Iranian leadership. Agreement on one policy could pave the way for "bargaining on issues that divide them," said an economics professor at Teheran University who spoke on condition of anonymity.
In the interview with the Hindustan Times, President Rafsanjani said wide-ranging relations with the United States might be possible if Washington relinquished its "imperialistic attitude."
In a letter written in July that was excerpted in the state-run press, an unidentified Iranian lawmaker suggested that "much of Iran's existing disagreements with the West would be eliminated" if relations with Washington were restored and that "economic development plans will get a boost."
The letter was reportedly widely read in official circles.
"Better to solve our disputes with the U.S." now that Iran "has the time and opportunity to choose," the author said.

HEADLINE: Few Raves Greet Plan By Whitman

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
It was to have been the jolt that awakened a tax-weary electorate and bolstered her campaign for governor, but four days after Christine Todd Whitman delivered her bold promise to cut taxes by 30 percent, the plan's impact seems to have been dissipated in a campaign of Democratic scorn and largely unfavorable editorial responses.
Several Republican state senators and Assembly members, who would presumably be responsible for enacting the plan -- cutting taxes by $1.2 billion over three years -- expressed dismay that after revealing her long-awaited plan on Tuesday, the Whitman campaign seemed to let the subject drop. The plan faced a carefully orchestrated Democratic campaign to deflect attention from Gov. Jim Florio's own vulnerability on the tax issue. 
 The Republicans said they were not troubled by Governor Florio's focus on the lack of detail in the program. But they said they wished that Mrs. Whitman had continued to emphasize the plan, instead of resuming normal campaign visits to a wide variety of voter groups.
"I am not in charge of her campaign, but I would certainly have asked for a more vigorous follow-up," said Rodney P. Frelinghuysen, a Republican lawmaker from Morristown who heads the Assembly Appropriations Committee.
 
Not the Hot Topic
 "To be perfectly honest, I don't think it has turned out to be the first thing people are talking about," said John W. Hartmann, a Republican Assemblyman from Lawrence Township who won his first term two years ago amid anger over Governor Florio's $2.8 billion tax increase.
Mrs. Whitman spent Wednesday, the day after announcing her plan, receiving a union endorsement and touring communities in Hudson County. On Thursday her speech advancing the plan before the Mercer County Chamber of Commerce was overshadowed by news coverage of Mrs. Whitman's statement that she might limit state aid to wealthy school districts to meet court-mandated increases in aid to poor districts.
Also on Thursday, former Gov. Brendan T. Byrne gleefully recalled that Mrs. Whitman's plan was released 16 years to the day after Mr. Byrne's 1977 re-election opponent, Raymond H. Bateman, shot himself in the foot by promising to end the state income tax that Mr. Byrne had helped establish. Many television programs and newspapers emphasized the wry parallel between Mr. Byrne's campaign and Mr. Florio's.
 
Critical Editorials
 On Friday, with the Democratic criticism of her plan unabated and as the state's papers weighed in with critical editorials, Mrs. Whitman visited a high school. It was not until Friday afternoon that her campaign announced that she would meet, on Monday, with small-business owners who would endorse her tax program.
Mrs. Whitman's spokesman, Carl Golden, said on Friday that it was too soon to say that the tax-cut plan had failed to generate much excitement.
"One thing it has done is it has succeeded in focusing the campaign debate where it ought to be focused," he said. "The Governor has tried to avoid engaging us in the debate over taxes and the economy, and we are hearing from people who call that they are delighted that the campaign between the two candidates is about what concerns them most."
In the days after Mrs. Whitman's announcement, many of the state's newspapers published editorials expressing various degrees of disappointment in Mrs. Whitman's plan.
 
Economic Menu Questioned
 "What happened?" The Atlantic City Press asked Mrs. Whitman in an editorial on Friday. "You were supposed to unveil the meat and potatoes of your campaign. Instead, it looks like dessert."
On the other hand, The Home News of New Brunswick and some other newspapers supported the Whitman program.
Mr. Golden said the Whitman campaign was not dismayed by the largely unfavorable editorials in local papers about Mrs. Whitman's economic centerpiece.
"I think we sort of expected it," he said. "There was no question that there would be criticism coming our way, because you can't win everybody over with a program that is as innovative as this, and as massive as this."

HEADLINE: Plan Helps Panhandlers With Vouchers, Not Quarters

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 23

 BODY:
"Junior" spends most of his days sitting near the sidewalk on York Street here, holding his baseball cap out and asking passersby for change. "How you doing? You got some coins?" he asks.
But now, mixed in with the dollar bills, quarters and dimes, he is getting 25-cent vouchers he can redeem for food, personal items, even bus fare. "I like the idea," said the unemployed panhandler, who would give only his nickname. "I'm happy when someone gives me a voucher because I can go over to Wawa and get me some food." 
 The vouchers are distributed by New Haven Cares, a nonprofit group created to reduce panhandling in downtown New Haven and to help the community support street people without supporting their alcohol or drug habits.
The idea emerged in 1992 when members of the Downtown Christian Ministries approached Yale University about supporting a voucher program modeled after one in Berkeley, Calif., which has sold about 240,000 25-cent vouchers in two years.
Matthew Lieberman, a third-year law student at Yale and the son of United States Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, led the effort, gathering the support of church and community leaders, merchants, Yale University officials and the New Haven police. The vouchers were first distributed early in September.
 
Food, but No Alcohol
 "People in New Haven do care about homeless people and about panhandlers," Matthew Lieberman said. "The overwhelming support of this program shows that. But getting all these groups together -- who knew we had a panhandling problem but were often at odds over what to do about it -- was exciting."
More than 45 New Haven merchants are participating in the program. About 35 sell vouchers and 15 redeem them, allowing street people to pick up a hot cup of soup, a pint of orange juice or a bottle of baby formula. Cigarettes and alcohol cannot be bought with the vouchers.
"We can't get the vouchers in fast enough, they're selling so quickly," said Richard Hibbard, the manager of Store 24, a convenience store on Broadway. "People are buying them at $3 and $4 a clip and giving them to panhandlers."
Lisa Lubasch, a Yale junior from Jericho, L.I., went into the Wawa food market on York Street to get a quart of milk and bought some vouchers, which she passed out on her way down the street. "You can't walk down the street without having someone come up to you asking for money and that can be intimidating," she said. "I like the idea of a voucher so much better. You know at least they'll be getting food."
 
Encouraging Generosity
 Mr. Lieberman says he thinks the vouchers will make people more generous. "The sum total of giving is going to increase a lot," he said, "because people know the vouchers will be used to meet a need."
Harry W. Berkowitz, the president of the Yale Co-op, a major department store for Yale students, applauded the effort. "I think it's a wonderful thing that Matt and his group, who are up to their eyeballs in studies at law school, have the time, the drive and inclination to become involved in the community's needs," he said. "This community needs to do more to solve its own problems. We have to reduce the intimidation, reduce the feeling of unsafeness. This is one step in that direction."
Mr. Lieberman and two fellow law students, George Miller and Don Moorehead, act as a kind of central bank. Merchants who sell vouchers pass on the money to the law students, who reimburse merchants who have redeemed vouchers. Most stores act as either selling or redeeming sites, although some convenience stores and restaurants do both. Those who sell vouchers do not make any profit on them.
Signs are up in the windows of all the cooperating stores, and Yale law students also spend time walking the streets telling indigent people about the program.
 
'America Cares' Program
 Besides New Haven Cares, there are voucher distribution programs in Chicago, Seattle, Portland, Ore., San Francisco, Berkeley and Santa Cruz, Calif., Boulder, Colo., Chicago, and Edmonton, Alberta. Senator Jeff Bingaman, a Democrat from New Mexico, has proposed legislation to create an America Cares voucher system that would provide start-up money in more than 60 cities. Mr. Lieberman's father, a Democrat from Connnecticut, is a co-sponsor of the bill, which is in the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee.
New Haven corporations are starting to sign on, buying up hundreds of vouchers to be given to the city's non-panhandling homeless at soup kitchens and social service agencies.
Mr. Lieberman, a lifelong New Haven resident, said he wanted to address the problem of panhandling ever since he was 13 and his parents let him take the bus alone into downtown New Haven. While there a panhandler asked him for money and he gave him three dollars.
When he got home he told his mother, Elizabeth Haas, a psychiatric social worker. She told him that many of the panhandlers spent their money on liquor and wound up at the front door of the mental health center.
"I became one of those people who never gave to panhandlers," he said. "I didn't want to contribute to a drinking problem and yet I never liked just walking by and not helping. This is a way to get people to help and to interact."

HEADLINE: Urban Cowboys Shouldn't Rule the Range

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Higher Grazing Fees Have Ranchers Running Scared" (Sept. 12), on the rangeland reforms proposed by Secretary of the Interior Bruce Babbitt, points out that the "proposals would make it easier to terminate leases to ranchers who abuse the land." That may sound reasonable, but far more frightening is that the proposals would provide new, undefined reasons that a Federal employee could decide a rancher should lose his lease. "Shortening grazing seasons, curtailing use of pesticides," even micro managing from Washington to the extent of saying where salt can be placed, are part of this document that is obviously authored by people who know virtually nothing about resource management in the West or the diverse systems requiring local knowledge and input that abound. 
 Claiming improved environmental care, Mr. Babbitt threatens short-term leases instead of the stabilizing 10-year renewable preferential leases now owned by ranchers as part of their capital investment. Environmental care comes from people who are in long-term business dependent on a healthy environment. It does not come from short-term, questionable tenure.
It is an economic reality that most ranchers will quit or be bankrupted by the raise in fees alone. The rest of the uncalled-for "reform" will make it easy for the Government to remove the rest from the land. Congress must be called upon to stop this abuse of agencies' perceived regulatory powers.
 
PEGGY MONZINGO
Benson, Ariz., Sept. 17

HEADLINE: When in Rome . . .

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While it may be encouraging that some companies are beginning to appreciate multilingual managers ("When a Deal Can Turn on a Turn of a Phrase," Sept. 12), I consider the more typical case to be that of a company that will send an English-speaking executive to another country without any preparation whatsoever. Several years ago I informally briefed a woman acquaintance, a high-level sales manager being sent by her multinational pharmaceutical company to Japan for the first time. Although well educated, she knew absolutely nothing about Japanese society or mores -- and neither she nor her company felt it worth her time to read even one general book on Japanese society before going off to participate in million-dollar transactions. Similarly, I recall a seatmate on a plane, a banker going off to Canada, who assumed Canada was no more than an extension of the United States. 
 I wondered then, and I wonder now: Who runs these Fortune 500 companies so stupidly? Why are they so deaf to our message that good manners, if not good business, requires that you know something about your hosts?
 
B. MEREDITH BURKE, Ph.D.
Cupertino, Calif., Sept. 15
 
The author has been a consultant to the United Nations Development Program, the World Bank and the United States Agency for International Development.

HEADLINE: SEPTEMBER 19-25: Donors' Conference;
Clinton Looks for Help To Finance Mideast Peace

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO

 BODY:
As the Israeli-Palestinian accord progressed last week -- with the Israeli Parliament ratifying it over less-than-expected right-wing opposition -- President Clinton designated himself as the global fund-raiser for Middle East peace. He has sent out invitations to more than two dozen leaders of the world's richest countries, asking them to send their representatives to Washington this week to pledge enough money to make the Palestinians' experiment with autonomy work.
The United States last week promised $250 million over the next two years -- less than half of what the World Bank estimates the Palestinians will need during that period and a fraction of the $5.1 billion in annual American aid for Israel and Egypt. Those two countries made their peace in the 1970's at Camp David; their American assistance has been linked by an unchanging formula ever since. 
This time, however, the United States cannot afford to secure a peace by agreeing to bankroll it as the Carter Administration did. And Israel and Egypt have won assurances that their coffers will not be less full as a result of the Israeli-Palestinian agreement. ELAINE SCIOLINO

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;
Building the Cardboard City of Tomorrow

BYLINE: By EMILY M. BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
In a crowded room on the ground floor of the New School, a team of urban planners is building an elaborate cardboard city meant to help create a consensus about new construction around Lincoln Center.
The model, with scale photographs of the real facades attached to cardboard buildings, reconstructs the character of the neighborhood -- from 59th to 70th Street and from Amsterdam Avenue to Central Park West -- in vivid detail. A thin camera lens "walks" through the model, projecting views of the area onto a screen. 
 "You will be able to come in and we can show you what it looks like from your window," said Michael Kwartler, the director of the Environmental Simulation Center at the New School.
For each of six sites considered prime for new development, there will be three different renditions of buildings -- one built under current zoning laws, one under a new proposal by the City Planning Department and one under a counter-proposal by neighborhood groups including Community Board 7 and Landmark West!
The zoning in the Lincoln Center area has come under review because of a 545-foot building under construction on the block between 67th and 68th Streets and Broadway and Columbus Avenues.
The building, which is being developed by Millennium Partners and Lincoln Square Partners, will include 10 movie theaters, a post office and an eight-story health club, in addition to condominiums intended primarily to cater to foreign businessmen.
What has attracted attention is that everything about the building, which inspired complaints from nearby residents and a lawsuit, is allowed under the zoning for the Special Lincoln Square District. The district was created in 1969 to foster the area's development.
As a result, the Planning Department acknowledged the need for new guidelines, which it presented in June.
The community board and Landmark West! would like to see stricter zoning than the city has proposed. They advocate height limits on new buildings and guidelines for facades to conform to neighboring buildings. In addition, they want planners to consider the impact each new development would have on an already-crowded area.
Landmark West! originally commissioned the detailed physical model and raised the money to finance it.
"I hope this alleviates some of the confusion in the community, because it is meant as an educational tool," said Arlene Simon, president of Landmark West!
"But I would also like to be able to have the Department of City Planning understand what the actual impact of these buildings is."
Mr. Kwartler of the New School said he is trying to convince the owners of the development sites in question to participate in the project, and the owners of the Mayflower Hotel site have already agreed. The Planning Department is also contributing designs, and plans to use the model in the public review process. EMILY M. BERNSTEIN

CORRECTION-DATE: October 10, 1993, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption on Sept. 26 about the construction of a cardboard model of the area around Lincoln Center misidentified one model maker. He was Joseph Keating, not Nicole Comp.
