HEADLINE: The Fuhrer's Movie Maker

BYLINE: By John Simon; John Simon is the theater critic of New York magazine and the film critic of National Review.

 BODY:

LENI RIEFENSTAHL
A Memoir.
By Leni Riefenstahl.
Illustrated. 669 pp. New York:
St. Martin's Press. $35. 
 LET'S get the hoary questions out of the way. Was Leni Riefenstahl Hitler's lover? No. Was she a Nazi? In the strict sense, no; otherwise, the Americans, the French and, finally, the Germans would not have eventually cleared her. Was she an asset to the Nazi cause? Yes. What she also is, certainly, is one of the supreme artists of the cinema, the greatest woman film maker ever. And her 669-page autobiography, "Leni Riefenstahl: A Memoir," does not contain a single unspellbinding page. Some books are merely so exciting that you can't put them down. This one is so exciting that you often must put it down, lest you overdose on thrills.
Riefenstahl tells her story in a clean, well-lighted prose, interrupted by occasional purple passages, with here and there an intensely personal touch to remind us that this is a memoir, not just a set of memos. (The uncredited translation is fluent and generally satisfactory, but does not avoid some common errors.) How truthful is it? How does one assess the veracity of any memoir? Behind Hitler's well-guarded doors, or in the remote hills of the Sudan, whose corroborating voice can we expect? Save for the flourishes with which an elderly autobiographer (this Aug. 22 she turned 91) may bedeck some of her choice memories, this strikes me as a credible account of an extraordinary life out of which three or four more than sufficiently eventful ones could be fashioned. It's something like a 90-year hurdle race. The book must, in the main, be true; it is far too weird for fiction.
Still, says the captious reader of this review, wasn't she a screenwriter, too? Couldn't this be a scenario posing as a memoir? As a screenwriter, Riefenstahl was more Manichaean; hers was a passionately black-and-white world shot in bold blacks and whites -- a vision of extremes at one with the deep romanticism of 19th-century German culture. In this memoir, there are colors and shades; the skies are troublingly changeable; the characters more lifelike than movieish. I defy the most skeptical, even hostile, reader to emerge from a reading unaffected.
Part of the way Riefenstahl works on a reader's sympathies is by casting herself as both the master of her fate and its victim, a woman who knew what she wanted, had seemingly insurmountable obstacles thrown in her path and overcame them. Her first impediment was her father. Born into a middle-class Berlin family in 1902, a scrawny baby who improved with age, young Leni excelled at sports, studied painting, dreamed of becoming an actress, then a dancer. But Papa considered performing a one-way avenue to hell. Under strict supervision -- she was not allowed to date or even to go to the movies alone until she was 21 -- she had to become a bit devious. It was a lesson that served her throughout her life. If Papa threatened to beat you and lock you in your room, plead your case with Mutti. If Italian customs inspectors were officious, wire Il Duce. Goebbels stood in your way? Go to Hitler for support. If Hitler said no . . . but we'll come to that.
While taking dancing lessons on the sly, Leni turned down the occasional movie offer so as not to blow her cover. But doing so hurt as much as her father's beatings or watching him browbeat her mother; the girl vowed to become and remain independent.
NOTHING daunted her. Seemingly too old at 23 to start ballet, she nevertheless worked hard enough to succeed at it; she also won second prize in a beauty contest, setting another lifelong pattern. She's not ashamed, later, when her beloved film "The Blue Light" takes only a second in an international contest, or when she comes in second in a major ski race. And some of her greatest loves rejected her for other women. Well before Avis, our second-prize winner only tries harder.
And succeeds, or at least gets to meet the right people. Before she was 25, she tells us, Ferruccio Busoni composed a piece for her and predicted success as a dancer; the playwright Karl Vollmoeller tried to seduce her and prophesied failure without a sugar daddy. Otto Froitzheim, a German tennis ace, stared at her in the locker room and later, with a power play, netted her virginity. Men generally fell at her feet, she says. Are we to believe all this? The evidence is not unpersuasive. The great Mary Wigman, who taught only the best, put the final polish on Leni's dancing. She appeared in Max Reinhardt's Deutsches Theater and danced triumphantly in a huge Prague theater where only Pavlova had preceded her.
The fuel she drove on was obsession. Admirable or misguided, it subsumed all her strivings: as a dancer, as an actress, as a mountaineer and skier. And later as . . . but we'll come to that, too.
Obsession rescued her when a cracked kneecap threatened to end her dancing career. Waiting in the Berlin subway for a train to take her to a doctor, she spotted a poster: " 'Mountain of Destiny' -- a film about the Dolomites by Dr. Arnold Fanck." Instead of the physician, she saw the movie; enthralled, she set about becoming an actress. Luis Trenker, the leading mountain-movie star, patronizingly discouraged her. On her way to one of her periodic stays in the hospital for the ill health that plagued her throughout her life, she sent pictures and a letter to Fanck. Soon he was at her bedside with "The Holy Mountain," a script dedicated to her.
So the mountain had come to Mohammed. Presently Fanck was directing her in the film, with Luis Trenker as her co-star, and also showering her with unwelcome love letters, poems and gifts. When he discovered her in the arms of Trenker (a once-only fling), there was a terrible fight and Fanck tried to kill himself. But when he was recalled by UFA, the premier German company producing the movie, it was Riefenstahl who finished the film for him with great success. Trenker, all along, seethed with professional jealousy. Eventually, he would betray her.
As Riefenstahl tells it, jealousy and its handmaiden, betrayal, stalked her all her life, often at the hands of a spurned lover. Hans Schneeberger, for one, Fanck's cameraman and the man who taught her how to ski, had an intense affair with her and subsequently turned on her, first as a lover, later even as a friend.
By the time Leni met Hans, in the mid-1920's, she had become a strikingly handsome young woman, exuding strength, purposefulness, health (whether or not she actually had it) and a certain haughtiness. She could be both peremptory and charming. Alas, she was a workaholic and a perfectionist, both qualities that were roadblocks to romance. When not toiling unholy hours for days on end (one of the causes of her health problems), she was consumed by her latest project.
Such a person has no time for love affairs. Or, if so, only with co-workers. And she had a few, with cameramen, mountain guides, soundmen. Still, not for nothing was her fondest ambition (unrealized, like so many others) to play Kleist's Penthesilea, the virginal Amazon queen who dies for love. One of her greatest realized roles was the mountain girl in a film she persuaded the eminent G. W. Pabst to direct with Fanck, "The White Hell of Piz Palu," wherein she had to climb barefoot. Dancing gave her the feet for it; her character, the courage. Silent cinema did not go in for doubles; one did one's own perilous stunt work. At this point another leitmotif of her life appears: the hairbreadth escape.
It was in "White Hell" that, buried in the snow a long time, Riefenstahl developed the severe bladder problems that she could never quite shake. But here, too, Pabst discovered that she was a director at heart. When he told her to look to the left in a shot, she looked to the right, thinking in terms of the viewfinder, into which Fanck had repeatedly let her peer.
THE next director she impressed was Josef von Sternberg, who wanted to take her to Hollywood along with Marlene Dietrich and make her as big a star. Though tempted, she was still in love with Schneeberger, who had left her for another woman, and she refused. Meanwhile Fanck had taught her how to edit film, and it was she who, when the French found "White Hell" too long, successfully cut it down.
Her own favorite among her movies, "The Blue Light," was next. She oversaw the entire production from the beginning, and the story of its conception and execution is pure Riefenstahl. She got the distinguished Hungarian writer Bela Balazs to help her with the screenplay. For shooting "night" scenes outdoors in daylight, she prodded Agfa to develop a new film stock, and upon founding her own film company, turned to directing because it was cheaper than hiring someone else. For the same reason, she starred in the film as Junta, the mountain girl who climbs to the heights -- alone -- but dies of the impurity of the rest of the world. The master of fate becomes the victim of forces beyond her control. It is, for Riefenstahl, a familiar motif.
A book could easily be written about the filming of "S O S Iceberg," a German-American co-production shot in Greenland, where obstacles multiplied in glorious profusion: cracking ice floes, dangerous flights between icebergs with a flying ace, recalcitrant polar bears imported from the Berlin Zoo, starved Eskimo dogs that ate anything made of fur or leather; everything from ingrown toenails to more attacks of her now-chronic cystitis. But Riefenstahl, master of fate, surmounted them all. She had discovered the miracle of Greenland: "We see differently there, we feel differently," she writes. The "ballast of superfluous, unproductive things . . . seemed to vanish in the ocean."
If a yearning for extremes is part of the fascist spirit, then Riefenstahl was ripe for fascism. But suffice it to say here that this high-striving woman was eager to get away from the ordinary, the messiness of the mundane. Hence the urge to lose herself in solo dance, to scale or ski the highest mountains, to immerse herself in romantic-idealistic movies, to embrace the austerities of Greenland. Magnitude, altitude, solitude -- whatever removes you from the multitude.
Hearing Hitler address a crowd in 1932, she wrote him soliciting a meeting; she was fascinated by a man who could raise expectations to such orgasmic heights. The instant she heard his voice, she tells us, "I had an almost apocalyptic vision that I was never able to forget. It seemed as if the earth's surface were spreading out in front of me, like a hemisphere that suddenly splits apart in the middle, spewing out an enormous jet of water, so powerful that it touched the sky and shook the earth. I felt quite paralyzed."
It turned out the Fuhrer was a fan of hers, admired her as an artist and flattered her as a person. She soon became aware of what she saw as the split in his personality: showy rouser of primitive public yearnings, modest private person and, either way, endowed with a charisma as undefinable as Greenland's.
Though he once or twice made the merest hint of a pass at Riefenstahl, Hitler respected her lack of response; mostly he needed someone to talk to. Actually, talk at; never during their friendship did he show the slightest interest in her personal life. If self-obsession was what they both excelled at, she again came in second. Riefenstahl was never seriously attracted to strong, famous men, i.e., father figures; the many crude attempts by the notorious womanizer Goebbels to seduce her especially repelled her. Several such scenes in the book combine low farce with Grand Guignol. Rebuffed, Goebbels became her dogged enemy, strewing her path not with roses but with monkey wrenches.
As Minister of Propaganda he could make life difficult for her, even though the movie she agreed to make -- reluctantly, as she tells it -- was ordered by Hitler, who gave her complete artistic freedom. The masterpiece that resulted was "Triumph of the Will" (first shown in 1935). Hitler himself "knew little or nothing about art." Albert Speer, the architect of the Nuremberg party rally that she was to film, built her an elevator on a flagpole. (When Goebbels threatened interference, she went right to Hitler.)
Riefenstahl's training as a dancer and painter served her well, as she turned a Nazi rally into a picturesque and balletic spectacle. Her sound cinematic instincts let her come up with a variety of shots never before used in documentaries, such as those made by cameramen on roller skates. Most ingenious were the stratagems by which she kept Goebbels's henchmen out of her hair, and the Minister's hands out of her pants.
Even more remarkable is the account of her next masterwork, "Olympia" (1938), a two-part film about the 1936 Berlin Summer Olympics. The technical difficulties to be overcome, given the primitive state of film and the peskiness of both sports officials and Goebbels's bloodhounds, make for breathless reading. Commissioned by the German Olympic Committee, the film was intended as a documentary; but, once again, Riefenstahl was interested primarily in art. The main financing came from UFA -- which wanted to add a love story! -- and none of it from the Nazi Party. Otherwise, Goebbels would have exercised stifling control.
THERE were other projects, notably attempts to fulfill the recurring dream of making "Penthesilea," for which she became an expert horsewoman. This time the enterprise foundered for lack of money. Meanwhile Hitler and his favorite director continued their intermittent conversations, with God and the Messiah among their topics. Whenever she alluded to his racist policies, she says, he simply cut her off. Later, during the war, Hitler confided his wish to yield the reins to others after the victory; he himself wanted to make movies with Riefenstahl, a prospect too shuddery for her to contemplate.
Her concern apparently was less political, or even ethical, than professional: she feared Hitler would be a nuisance. Riefenstahl protests that throughout most of the Hitler period she was a political ignoramus. Despite her sophistication and exposure to the world, she does seem to have spent her life a bit out of touch. When Mick Jagger, at the height of his fame in the 1970's, wished her to take his picture, she had to ask, "Who is Mick Jagger?"
But arriving in the United States in November 1938 to front-page news of Kristallnacht, she must have found it hard to dismiss the reports as American propaganda, as she says she did. Whether she lied to herself then and whether she is still doing so, one can't know. Certainly her moral compass set her a peculiar course.
On the other hand, her personal relationships, if we can trust her tale, seem to have been admirable. She was clearly devoted to Peter Jacob, an army officer whom she met on a train and who helped film some of her movies. Passionate but unfaithful, he was the only man she ever married. She also adored her mother, and the way these two women helped each other makes for one of the loveliest strands of this memoir.
Riefenstahl condemns herself for her failure to intervene to save her brother, who was assigned to a punishment battalion for making unflattering comments about the war. Fighting on the eastern front, he was blown to bits by a Russian grenade. Her remorse over his death is, in fact, more convincing than any expressed shame at submitting to the Fuhrer's demands.
To Hitler's delight, "Olympia" became a worldwide hit in 1938, winning (for once) first prize in Venice. Audiences in France, Belgium, Norway and the United States, among other countries, applauded not only the film but also Hitler's brief appearances in it. (She doesn't say if anyone booed.)
Like many Germans, Riefenstahl says, she began by believing Hitler could pull Germany out of its terrible economic woes in the 1930's. Though she says she had read "Mein Kampf" by 1932, she either missed or chose to ignore its racist message. Certainly she did not foresee its tragic consequences. She tells us she lost her faith in Hitler well before war's end. When in 1942 she returned from a trip to Italy and saw Jews forced to wear the yellow star, she was, she says, "indignant and ashamed." That year, at her last meeting with Hitler, she wanted to confront him, she confesses, but "held my tongue."
For most of the war years she worked on a movie version of "Tiefland," Eugen d'Albert's opera, but without the music. It gave her a chance to play a dancer, though had she known that it would take two decades to complete -- what with war, illness and the confiscation of her rushes, which lasted 10 years -- she might never have undertaken it.
After Germany fell, there commenced a series of unending misfortunes for her. The United States authorities investigated and denazified her promptly, but she did not follow American advice to avoid her mountain home in Austria's French zone. The French had her in and out of prisons, for a while even in an insane asylum, and treated her very roughly. She was to find out later that, having got hold of her films, various French groups fought for their possession and wanted their maker safely out of the way. Yet eventually the French, too, denazified her, only to expose her to endless troubles with her fellow Germans. They, finally, also cleared her, although libels against her were to embroil Riefenstahl in much grinding litigation, costly in time, money and energy, even though she says she won 50 libel cases.
After the war she was reunited happily with her refugee friends from the United States. She and Manfred George, the German Jewish journalist who became the editor of the newspaper Aufbau in New York, enjoyed a Berlin Film Festival together in 1965. And at the 1959 Venice Festival, which paid tribute to both of them, she and von Sternberg again rejoiced in each other's company. She quotes from letters to support her belief that her Jewish friends forgave her.
The greatest damage to her name in the postwar years was the publication in 1947 of the supposed diary of Eva Braun, which, though subsequently proved a hoax, accused her of a lurid affair with Hitler and eliminated forever her chances as a feature-film maker. The perpetrator was Luis Trenker, her erstwhile co-star, one-hour lover and virulent professional rival.
SHE was at least able to shoot some sports documentaries. Yet her most cherished project, "The Red Devils," an international ski film for which she was assured the collaboration of Vittorio De Sica and the celebrated scenarist Cesare Zavattini, collapsed because of an attack on her in Vienna's Communist newspaper, Der Abend, that, she says, scared the Austrian Government out of subsidizing it. During the 1950's and 60's, when Riefenstahl was persona non grata even in the United States, where her films were nonetheless taught and admired in university film schools, her marriage to Peter Jacob unraveled, in part from attrition caused by the poverty in which he, she and her mother lived.
If the famous spider whose repeated efforts to rebuild its web inspired Robert Bruce to chase the English out of Scotland had met with as many frustrations as Riefenstahl, it would surely have given up. After two attempts at making a film in Africa failed, and just as she was about to drop the Africa project altogether, one of her guardian angels (she believes in them) led her to a newspaper picture of the Nubas, a Sudanese tribe she fell in love with.
Scraping together what money she could, she traveled back to Africa, where she exhibited enormous skills in winning over various tribes, including the warrior Masai, as well as high and low government officials. But her happiest times were among the Nubas, whom she visited five times and who, in effect, adopted her. These adventures, during which she and Horst Kettner, her young assistant, made films and took photographs (many of them lost in thefts and accidents, or through the ineptitude of her German photo lab), could in themselves make a spectacular mini- or maxi-series. Two collections of her pictures brought her renewed prominence -- and criticism -- in the 1970's. Eventually, as she eloquently reports, the Nubas were ruined by the encroachments of tourism and the seduction of money. She never explains what part her own work played in the process.
At 72, shaving 20 years from her age, she enrolled in scuba-diving school and, with Horst's aid, passed the grueling test. To her photography books about the Nubas, she was now able to add a volume of underwater photographs.
A noted French writer has called Leni Riefenstahl "the Plato and Michelangelo of the Leica," and her films assure her an enduring place in cinematic history. That she put her art to the use of evil is an issue she never seriously addresses here. But can the self-deceptions of an obsessed esthete wipe out the fact of her greatness as an artist? A leading British film historian, John Grierson, publicly kissed her foot and paid her expenses in one of her libel suits. In the United States, frequent showings of her films, including a retrospective at the Telluride Festival in Colorado in 1974, did much to rehabilitate her as a genius. If there were still attacks accusing her not only of gleeful collaboration with the Nazis but also, among other things, of not influencing the course of cinema, the last charge, at least, is otiose. Successes generate demonstrable imitations; masterpieces subtly alter perception and create influences less easy to trace.
As for the life, perhaps we should look to the character with whom Riefenstahl most closely identifies herself: Junta, the mountain girl in "The Blue Light," who was willing to die for her aspirations. Riefenstahl, too, was ready to sacrifice all in pursuit of her obsessions. In the process she may have compromised her humanity. But her artistic integrity, never.
 
 
 
AT LUNCH WITH ADOLF HITLER
 In the last week of August 1933, I was invited to a luncheon at the Reich Chancellery. . . . After the meal, when the company broke up into small groups, Bruckner came over to me and said, "The Fuhrer would like to speak to you," and I was led to an adjacent room. There was no one else there except a servant . . . serving coffee, tea and mineral water. A short time later Hitler came in and greeted me, apparently in high good humor. His very first question however put me in a quandary.
"I invited you here today in order to find out how far you've got with your preparations for the film on the party rally, and whether you're getting enough support from the Ministry of Propaganda." I stared at him in amazement -- what was he talking about? Surprised at my reaction, he said: "Didn't the Propaganda Ministry inform you that I want you to make a film about the party rally in Nuremberg?" I shook my head and Hitler was clearly perplexed. "You know nothing about it?" he asked. . . . He summoned Bruckner and angrily asked him, ". . . Why wasn't Fraulein Riefenstahl informed?" As he spoke he clenched his fists, glaring with anger. . . .
I myself was by now very agitated, and I interrupted Hitler. "My Fuhrer, I cannot accept this -- I have never seen a party rally, I know nothing about what goes on there, and I have no experience in making documentaries. It would be better if such films were made by party members who know the material and are happy to be given such assignments." I talked to Hitler almost beseechingly, and slowly he relaxed and calmed down.
Looking at me, he said, "Fraulein Riefenstahl, don't let me down."
 From "Leni Riefenstahl: A Memoir."
 
 
 
'WHY AM I GUILTY?'
 Leni Riefenstahl was angered by the many European reviews that characterized her memoir as a protracted defense of her involvement with the Nazi inner circle. "Writing the truth is not a defense, it is what happened," she said in a recent telephone interview from her home on Lake Starnberg, outside Munich. "To defend myself is not necessary." Rather, she explained, she published the book to save herself the trouble of repeatedly detailing her life to journalists.
"People can read the book and not bother me," she said. "Those who are not prejudiced will be satisfied with my book. Others will never be happy with what I say; they will always believe the old stories." She hopes that by setting the record straight she will be free to devote herself to her art. The 91-year-old director recently returned from making an undersea documentary film in the Maldives.
Miss Riefenstahl feels that the decades of criticism she endured for making "Triumph of the Will" were wholly unjustified. "In 1934, all the diplomats of Europe had met with Hitler and recognized Germany," she noted. "Why am I guilty for making a film that year that was not propaganda? I have always spoken the truth, and I have made no compromises, not even to Hitler."
Despite her contention that "Triumph" in no way glorified Hitler's cause, she didn't hesitate when asked whether she would have agreed to make the film if she had had any foreknowledge of his atrocities. "I would never have done it," she insisted. "I would not even have made 'Olympia.' "
She refuses to grant permission for "Triumph" to be screened in Germany today, even in schools and universities. "The film has a strong effect," she explained. "If young people see it, maybe they will get too enthusiastic about it in the wrong way and not understand the difference between art and history."
She said that there have been no reports of neo-Nazi groups using her films, and that she does not consider today's extreme nationalism to be a serious movement. "I don't think it is a real threat," she said. "It is a minority -- young, stupid people."
Miss Riefenstahl attributed her own failure to recognize the sinister nature of Hitler's rhetoric to her apolitical nature, and observed that an ambivalence toward politics was typical of German artists at the time. Even when she arrived in New York just days after Kristallnacht in 1938, she had no inkling of the Nazis' genocidal intentions. "Journalists came to the boat and asked me what I thought about Kristallnacht, and I told them that it couldn't be true, because in the American newspapers on the ship I had read so many lies about Germany," she recalled. "When months later I came back to Germany, I went to an adjutant of Hitler's and he told me what had happened, and at that moment I was nearly sick."
 TOBIN HARSHAW

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Westport Company Drops Curtain

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
STATE financial support, long delayed by red tape, was held up yet again and so the Fairfield County Stage Company of Westport announced last week that it was going out of business.
Actually it was not quite that simple. "I'm not going to blame it all on the state," said the company's artistic director, Burry Fredrik. "We were behind the eight ball from the beginning." 
 The beginning to which Ms. Fredrik referred was the move in 1990 of the Boston Post Road Stage Company, as it was then called, from the Mill Hill School in Fairfield to the Westport Playhouse. That was a mark of growth and a chance to play in a real theater with its own history -- and to get rid of the institutional image the company had from its opening in 1984 in the Grasmere School in Fairfield. "We were bursting at the seams and we tired of being in school buildings. And people couldn't find it," said the company's managing director, Marilyn Hersey.
Upward mobility apparently signaled the company's downfall. "It was a wonderful move, except in hindsight," said Ms. Hersey. "When people could find us, they didn't come. And we struggled ever since."
The cost of the move from Fairfield to Westport was $100,000. "We applied for and won bonding money from the Department of Economic Development in the amount of $60,000," Ms. Hersey recalled. "The Attorney General's office congratulated us upon winning it and we counted on it." What the company did not count on was the labyrinthine process, the misunderstandings, "back and forth through so many channels," Ms. Hersey said. "Would we have gone into the Playhouse without the promise of that money?" Ms. Hersey asked.
For three seasons the company expected to have the money in its operating budget but did not: "so we were always behind," Ms. Hersey said. And there were other setbacks, not just bureaucratic. "In January, the heating system broke down. And we were just hanging on. We weren't building audiences. The economy didn't help," she added.
Echoing Ms. Fredrik, Ms. Hersey went on: "I won't blame the theater folding on the state of Connecticut but it was the straw that broke us. We'd probably be opening if we had it." Ms. Hersey mentioned that a $75,000 grant from another source was contingent upon getting the state money. "And whatever potential we had for further fund raising," she added.
"Curiously," Ms. Hersey pointed out, "we had a stronger following in Fairfield. With 100 seats we played 88 to 89 percent capacity over a season." The Westport theater had 190 seats, a reconfiguration for the winter (designed by Ms. Fredrik) that was restored to the 707-seat capacity for summer stock. "But we were lucky if we sold 50 percent of the seats in Westport," Ms. Hersey added. "I don't think people in Westport really want a winter theater."
 
'One Hot Show, Hands Down'
 If the audience in Westport was a shrinking one, it was also quite conservative. The Fairfield County Stage Company, which has been known for an enterprising repertory, had but "one hot show, hands down, the best attended," Ms. Hersey said. That was "A Christmas Carol." A campy spoof of 1940's B movies (Charles Busch's "Lady in Question") was the worst attended. "People were put off by drag and by Nazi characters in Bavaria, even as cartoons," Ms. Hersey said. In the first season Christopher Durang's scathing look at the Roman Catholic Church ("Sister Mary Ignatius Explains It All for You") drew "enormous amounts of hate mail."
"Westport audiences are offended more easily than Fairfield audiences" and Ms. Hersey wondered why: "It's only four miles away."
"We disappointed Westport and Westport disappointed us," Ms. Fredrik added. "If people want to see a show, they get there. Aren't there enough who care to support good effort? Maybe they thought we weren't good enough. I don't know. We just didn't sell enough tickets."

HEADLINE: Baseball Without Me

BYLINE: By Fay Vincent; Fay Vincent was baseball commissioner from 1989 to 1992. He is working on a book about those years.

 BODY:
It has been a year since I resigned under duress as commissioner of baseball. On the field, the game thrives -- as it always has. This September, there have been good pennant races in all four divisions. Attendance is soaring.
But off the field, the landscape is not so verdant. Owners are fighting owners; owners are fighting the players' union; the union is fighting everything. And all the while, there is no commissioner. Too many of those who steward the game still don't understand that they hold baseball in trust for the public and that baseball deserves better. 
 To be sure, many baseball clubs face a fiscal reckoning. They are not generating a decent return on investment, and the grim new deals that will sharply reduce television revenue will only increase pressure on the bottom line. It's true that no owner in recent times has lost money when it came time to sell a club, but that kind of economic madness must end someday: remember the tulip craze.
Yet for most of us the business of baseball is like the sun: we can't look at it too long without having to turn away.
Money is not the point. I leave that to the game's ample supply of accountants, marketing experts and tax wizards to analyze. My concern for baseball is that the business people who run it seem to be treating it as nothing more than a business. It isn't. The owners have talked all summer of establishing a partnership with the players as part of the current labor negotiations -- something I urged throughout my tenure. So far, we have been given little more than talk.
Was the union consulted before a television deal was struck with the networks? No. What about plans to realign the leagues? Not until the union objected. Why would the union accept management "wisdom" on economic matters, given the owners' failures over the years on this front? The fact is, the union will want a vote on major issues -- and is entitled to one. Some owners' idea of a partnership, I suspect, is one in which they're the senior partners.
For its part, the union must stop seeing everything as a matter of confrontation and must also realize that the players have a greater obligation to the game than showing up at the ballpark. It is a disgrace, for example, that Steve Howe is still pitching for the Yankees even though I banished him after his seventh violation of baseball's drug policies. Howe was reinstated by an arbitrator because the union -- misguidedly, I believe -- challenged my ruling. I can understand his desire to stay in the game and earn his million-dollar salary. But could not the union consider more than just his interests?
Yes, I very much understand that unions operate for the benefit of their members. That is a good thing. But if there is ever to be a strategic alliance between owners and players, the union will have to widen its vision of what policies serve the institution and not just the individual. Stubbornness and the status quo are not the exclusive franchises of management.
If baseball does not get its act together, Congress may try to "help." And that will be bad for almost everyone. In the long run, baseball deserves its immunity from the antitrust laws. But frustrated by the myopic conduct of owners, Congress is closer now to repealing that immunity than it has been in years. The best way for owners to show Congress they can clean up their act is to reinstate a strong, independent commissioner. They've had 384 days in which to do so.
I have been told many times that peace and prosperity in baseball were about as likely as seeing the Prime Minister of Israel and the leader of the P.L.O. shake hands. Could we all not hope for another miracle? Remember the '51 Giants!

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Viewpoints;
A Cartel More Durable Than Diamonds

BYLINE: By STEFAN KANFER; Stefan Kanfer is a journalist and author. His latest book, "The Last Empire," is a history of the De Beers company (Farrar, Straus & Giroux).

 BODY:
IN the pantheon of great advertising slogans, few have enjoyed more lasting power than "A diamond is forever." It is the signature line of De Beers, the huge South African cartel that controls 90 percent of the world's diamond supply.
On closer inspection, though, few slogans make less sense. A diamond is no more "forever" than a garnet, a ruby or the piece of rose quartz you picked up on the beach. A diamond may be the hardest natural substance on earth, yet if hit with a hammer it will shatter into worthless shards. 
 No, "forever" may better describe De Beers than its product. Ever since Cecil Rhodes created the cartel in 1887, no matter what the hammer blows of circumstance -- wars, financial crises, racial strife, hostile governments -- De Beers has managed to outlast or circumvent them all.
Late in World War II, for example, President Franklin D. Roosevelt demanded from De Beers 6.5 million carats of industrial diamonds for aircraft factories. De Beers largely refused, despite threats of Justice Department investigations. It knew, as Time magazine said in 1945, that Justice had "no more chance of denting the cartel than of cleaving a diamond with a butter knife."
How does De Beers do it? For one, it's a mammoth enterprise, with profits of $373 million in the first half of 1993 alone. But it's much more than that. While even the Coca-Cola Company must go head-to-head with Pepsi, De Beers has no real competition. It controls its product, a finite resource, much as OPEC controls oil. But, better than OPEC, De Beers has no dissension. It has been strictly ruled by its own royal family, the Oppenheimers, since the 1920's.
Nor does the company sit idle in this exalted position. For decades, it has spent millions to promote the romance of diamonds, turning into an article of faith the sentiments of Marilyn Monroe in "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes." ("Square-cut or pear-shape/These rocks don't lose their shape/ Diamonds are a girl's best friend!")
The marketing pays off well. In the 1940's, fewer than 5 percent of Japanese fiancees had diamond engagement rings. Now, after a relentless ad campaign by De Beers, 8 out of 10 brides wear sparklers on their way to the altar. And in the United States and Europe, the company is rapidly invading a market much richer than newlyweds -- couples married 10 years or more.
As it whips up desire for diamonds, though, De Beers cagily manipulates supply. Diamonds are not unduly rare in nature; besides the well-known mines in South Africa, there are rich deposits in countries to its north, as well as in Siberia and Australia. But diamonds show up in stores only when De Beers wants. Waiting out the current recession, the cartel has been holding back millions of excess carats, storing them in company vaults. Similarly, during the Depression, De Beers actually ran out of space to keep unwanted diamonds, even stuffing the stones in butter churns.
If time is of no consequence to De Beers, neither is politics. Take the former Soviet Union. All the years it was denouncing capitalism in general and South Africa in particular, it was dealing Siberian diamonds under the table -- to De Beers.
Or take the emerging black nations. They could hardly have been expected to trade with an apartheid state. So they dealt their unpolished jewels to companies licensed in Switzerland and Luxembourg. It was not their fault that the diamonds were then quietly channeled -- to De Beers.
Or take South Africa. After the elections next April, the country will empower its first black government. Dire forecasts are being made: civil strife, nationalization, white flight.
But the smart money remains on De Beers. For when Nelson Mandela was released from jail, one of the first white industrialists he wanted to see was Harry Oppenheimer, the top executive of De Beers. As Mr. Mandela knows, diamonds are sometimes, but De Beers just might be forever.

HEADLINE: Supporting Dinkins, Clinton Worries About Role of Race

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
President Clinton, his voice ringing in revival tones, told a packed fund-raiser last night that Mayor David N. Dinkins deserved re-election on his record, but was facing a tough campaign partly because "too many of us are still too unwilling to vote for people who are different than we are."
With such an overt reference to Mr. Dinkins's status as New York City's first black Mayor, the President unleashed perhaps the most explosive electoral weapon at the Mayor's command, and one that Mr. Dinkins has seldom, if ever, invoked in such strong terms. 
 "This is not as simple as overt racism," Mr. Clinton told 1,000 people at a $1,000-a-plate dinner at the New York Sheraton, speaking extemporaneously and choosing his words with apparent care as the crowd burst into cheers and ovations. "That is not anything I would charge to anybody who doesn't vote for David Dinkins or Bill Clinton or anybody else. It's not that simple. It's this deep-seated reluctance we have, against all our better judgment, to reach out across these lines."
At that, a voice in the crowd shouted out, "Tell 'em, Bubba!"
As he began this portion of his speech, flanked on the dais by such celebrated Democratic orators as Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who had spoken earlier, and the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Mr. Clinton said, "I'm going to get in a lot of trouble."
But he said that on the flight from Washington with the Mayor on Air Force One, he had begun to wonder why Mr. Dinkins, having endured tough fiscal times, hired more police and seen crime decline, should face a competitive race against Rudolph W. Giuliani in a city like New York, where registered Democrats outnumber Republicans by more than 5 to 1. He said part of the reason is "he doesn't give enough speeches like he gave here tonight," referring to the Mayor's own unusually emphatic broadside against Mr. Giuliani as a supporter of Republican policies that he says have hurt the city. He also called the Mayor a humble man in a society "that values self-promotion."
Then he went on to raise the race question, saying several times that he did not mean to suggest overt racism. Instead, he said: "It is this inability to take that sort of leap of faith, to believe that people who look different than we are really are more like us than some people who look just like us but don't share our values and our interests."
Black supporters of the Mayor have tried occasionally to voice such concerns, and have often faced stiff criticism. For a white Southern-born President to raise them was an altogether different order of political tactics, though mayoral aides insisted that the passage was unplanned.
Indeed, the tone of Mr. Clinton's speech was in marked contrast to the photo opportunities and other carefully scripted events in a day that began with the President giving the Mayor a lift on Air Force One from Washington, where Mr. Dinkins had gone Saturday night just for a morning meeting at the White House and airborne face time with his Commander in Chief.
 
Sticking to Clinton
 From the White House lawn to the Future Diner in Fresh Meadows, Queens (where the President conducted one of his trademark Oprah-esque seminars on health care, with Mr. Dinkins nodding solemnly in a front-row booth) to a private fund-raiser for big donors at the home of a whiskey magnate to the dinner, the Mayor stuck to the President like wallpaper sticks to the wall. Beaming broadly, he introduced him in Queens as "our fearless leader."
At the fund-raiser, Mr. Clinton said of his help for the Mayor, "This is a big deal to me," noting that he himself could never have been elected without broad interracial support. "This is a big deal, folks. This is not just New York, this is L.A., this is rural South. This is every place we are being tested. We are going through a time of profound change and we right now don't have the sense of personal security to make the changes we need to make."
He continued: "We need more confidence in our selves, and confidence that we can meet all these challenges that are out there and confidence that the 21st century will also be an American century. And in order to do it, we have to get our act together, so we can feel good about the people we elect."
Citing the treaty-signing ceremony between the Palestine Liberation Organization and Israel, Mr. Clinton said: "Think about what it means for the future of the Middle East if we can keep it going. And then ask yourself, this man, who has a good record, who has a good plan, who has a good heart, has earned the right to your vote, and you ought to make sure he gets it and is returned to City Hall."
The Mayor wrapped Mr. Clinton in a bear hug and told the crowd, "For me, it does not get better than this."
In an interview later at the Carnegie Delicatessen, where he had repaired with aides for a bowl of chicken soup, the Mayor said he had had no idea that Mr. Clinton would make such comments. He had been moved, the Mayor said, but "in retrospect, I'm not surprised, given the man."
He added: "I think this: that one has to take his words in the total context of what he was saying, and get the nuances and subtleties that are there."
Noting that the President had explicitly said he was not talking about racism, Mr. Dinkins said that some would undoubtedly try to twist Mr. Clinton's words. "The point I would make is if others of us would attempt to make those subtle distinctions, we would not be able to. Given his stature, and the respect and esteem in which he's held, I think he's able to."
Mr. Dinkins's campaign manager, Bill Lynch, insisted of the remarks: "The President just went off and did that. There was no discussion. It was not the prepared text I saw. I think he formed a bond with the Mayor."
This election is likely to be decided by a range of local concerns and anxieties, like crime, the economy and race, which no Presidential visit can easily allay, and Mr. Clinton cannot deliver much in the way of tangible government aid. On the other hand, the contest figures to be close enough that a day of stumping and money-raising with the President qualifies -- in the spirit of the diner -- as chicken soup: It can't hurt, and it might help.
The President's remarks themselves may carry some risk, simply because of the sensitivity of the topic.
Ken Frydman, a Giuliani spokesman, said the campaign would have no comment on the President's remarks. Earlier, Richard Bryers, a another Giuliani spokesman,, measured his words in assessing the visit.
 
'Politics as Usual'
 "It's good that the President has come into town to see the problems of New York and meet with the people of New York, because New York needs all the help it can get," he said. "But this is politics as usual and we offer a different approach to government that goes beyond partisan politics."
In his 1989 race against Mr. Dinkins, Mr. Giuliani himself relied on the fund-raising power of George Bush, who came to town and managed to embarrass him a bit by mangling the pronunciation of his name. Mr. Clinton missed no chance to let the Mayor bask in his reflected glow, at the end of a week in which the President introduced his proposed health-care changes and was riding a crest of publicity much more favorable than the daily crises that dogged him a few months ago.
For the Mayor, it was a day to reap the rewards he hoped for early in his term when he sought to play host to the 1992 Democratic Convention, despite the early skepticism of some party leaders, including Mr. Clinton, that the Democrats had no business coming to a place that was such a symbol of urban problems.
It was also a day calculated to fulfill the Mayor's passion for ceremony.
 
Lots to Talk About
 "I think it's the only way to travel," Mr. Dinkins said in an interview between events, noting that the two had talked both politics and government on the trip. "It was a most rewarding, refreshing time. He's terrific. He's certainly knowledgeable."

HEADLINE: Mayoral Agenda: A periodic report on post-election issues facing the winner. -- 1. The Budget;
New York City Candidates Agree: Reduce Spending but Hold Details

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
When the winner of New York City's mayoral race takes the oath of office on Jan. 1, he will face an immediate challenge: preventing a budget crisis.
That is the consensus among experts on the city's fiscal affairs, who say that without major changes, there will be shortfalls of at least $2 billion a year in the next three budgets. 
 Mayor David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani, his Republican-Liberal challenger, agree that bold innovations will be needed. Both are committed, in principle, to balancing the budget in the long term by cutting back the city's rapidly growing spending to match its recession-ravaged revenues.
But neither Mr. Dinkins nor Mr. Giuliani has shown much willingness, in the heat of the mayoral race, to discuss precisely how he would scale back city government -- which services to curtail, which jobs to eliminate and which agencies to put out of business.
The Mayor, pressed hard by members of the State Financial Control Board, which monitors the city budget, committed himself last May to a significant shrinking of the size of local government and to fundamental changes in how the city does business.
He appointed a panel of three former government officials to recommend ways to trim $2 billion a year from the city's $31 billion annual budget. The panel's reporting date: Dec. 1, a month after the election.
Mr. Giuliani has also promised sharp cuts, but in his public remarks and in a 40-page position paper has not specified which city services he would sacrifice or from which agencies he would eliminate jobs.
It will not be easy for either candidate to cut such a huge chunk from the budget, particularly after four years in which Mr. Dinkins has drastically reduced the number of workers in several agencies. His cuts have meant fewer pickups from wire trash baskets on city streets, reduced maintenance in the parks and, until recently, shorter hours in public libraries. A vivid measure of the challenge is that $2 billion represents the combined budgets of the departments of Health, Aging, Cultural Affairs, Sanitation, Parks and Fire.
Mr. Giuliani released his own fiscal plan last month. He proposed eliminating more than 30,000 city jobs, a reduction of about 15 percent from the current 211,140. That would leave the work force with about 180,000, or the level of 1983, before the boom of the mid-1980's that fueled a huge increase in the size of city government under the Koch administration.
Mr. Giuliani promised to increase productivity by demanding changes in work rules from municipal unions, and he said he would contract out to private companies some city services, including several of the 11 municipal hospitals.
 
Takeovers, but Few Details
 Mr. Giuliani also called for the state to take over some city agencies, including the departments of Mental Health and Consumer Affairs, which he says duplicate the work of state agencies. And he proposed phasing out four city taxes, including the commercial rent tax and the unincorporated business tax.
He said at first that he would exempt some departments from budget cuts, including Parks, Fire and Police, and agencies which, in his words, involved children.
He recently modified his position, saying he would not exempt any agencies, but would simply try to avoid further job cuts in departments that have already been hit hardest. It is not clear what Mr. Giuliani, who has campaigned as a strong anticrime candidate, would do about the Police Department, which has grown more than any other city agency under Mr. Dinkins.
"As a realistic campaign document, this is about as specific as anybody has ever gotten," Mr. Giuliani said.
But many fiscal experts, including some who praised the scale of Mr. Giuliani's proposals and his willingness to experiment with ideas like incentive pay and privatization, criticized his plan for lacking details.
Many questioned, too, whether his proposed tax cuts and job cuts would, in effect, offset one another, with few long-term savings. But Mr. Giuliani insisted that he could simultaneously cut taxes, reduce jobs and achieve long-term balance.
The mayor will actually confront two budget crises in January, one short-term and the other long-term.
 
Budget to Unbalance Soon
 The budget for the current fiscal year, which began in July, is likely to come unbalanced after Election Day on Nov. 2, virtually all experts say. That will cause whoever is mayor to scramble to find as much as several hundred million dollars in savings or reductions to offset some questionable anticipated revenues in the current budget, which was proposed by Mr. Dinkins in May and passed by the City Council in June.
But the far greater challenge, the fiscal experts say, is in the city's long-term budget problems. The administration will be forced to heavily reduce the size of the city government.
"The situation is horrible, and the next mayor will face horribleness," said Alair A. Townsend, a former deputy mayor and budget director. "It won't be fun, unless you have a high taste for drama and change."
Since the long, deep recession began in the city in 1989, slow increases in tax revenues have not kept up with sharp increases in spending. Indeed, the rise in spending for welfare and Medicaid was caused in large part by the recession itself. Even when the city finally emerges from the recession, economists predict that growth will be slow until the end of the decade, and the gap between spending and revenues will remain.
 
In Line With Economy
 The experts contend that the city must either increase taxes or reduce spending to achieve what they call structural balance, in which the size of local government reaches a stable long-term balance with the size of the local economy on which it rests. Neither the politicians nor the economists favor tax increases, however -- the politicians fear the wrath of voters, and the economists fear higher taxes would inhibit a recovery.
Mr. Dinkins has struggled each year to balance the budget. He raised taxes in his first two years, and then cut jobs sharply in his third year. He has often used short-term strategies, like non-recurring revenues.
"They have continually compromised the future in the effort to balance the budget in a given year," said Allen J. Proctor, executive director of the State Financial Control Board. "What they have backed off from is making the balancing of each year's budget contribute to long-term structural balance."
In his standard stump speech, Mr. Dinkins often takes credit for balancing the budget four years in a row. But critics note the law that requires him to keep the budget balanced or lose authority over the city's finances to the State Financial Control Board.
 
Giving Dinkins Credit
 Some fiscal experts give Mr. Dinkins considerable credit, because he has faced the worst recession in New York since the Depression.
Still, fundamental problems persist. Most experts said that the Mayor began to make major strides two years ago against the structural imbalance. He pledged to eliminate more than 20,000 jobs and vowed to grant no new raises to city workers unless they were financed through productivity measures.
But the Mayor did not meet his goals, the experts say. Raymond D. Horton, the president of the Citizens Budget Commission, said he "just backed down, in the face of the political obstacles and the service consequences of doing it."
One disappointment, Mr. Horton and other fiscal monitors say, was the Mayor's revision of his goals on job cuts. About 14,000 jobs are gone from the peak of 225,300 in November 1990, but most of the reductions took place by November 1991.
 
Cuts Called Not Enough
 The net reduction in city jobs since Mr. Dinkins took office in January 1990 is about 10,000 jobs, or about 5 percent. But the Mayor and his senior aides often note that they trimmed the overall work force while greatly expanding the Police Department and adding many new teachers.
Mr. Dinkins has promised to cut 8,000 more jobs by 1996. But Mr. Horton and many others say greater reductions are needed.
Another disappointment, most experts say, was the 39-month contract settlement last January with 19 municipal unions. The contract called for a total raise of 8.25 percent, which the fiscal experts applauded as modest. But it did not include any efficiency measures. Separate negotiations were to produce six work-rule changes by last June, but the talks are bogged down, city officials say.
"The city and the unions have not been able to produce the savings to pay for the contracts," said Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, who endorsed Mr. Dinkins last spring and who announced recently that he planned to step down.
 
Need for Incentives
 Norman Steisel, the First Deputy Mayor, said the critics did not understand that it takes time to change work rules, even in private industry, and that incentives must be offered to gain labor's assent. "You can't do it through confrontation," he said.
He also said that Mr. Dinkins had done much to re-organize government. Mr. Steisel cited a thorough revision of the Probation Department, the consolidation of a half-dozen economic development agencies, experiments in managed care for Medicaid patients and the creation of new city primary-care health clinics.
Mr. Steisel added that the state failed to keep a major promise: a takeover of the crushing local costs of Medicaid, more than $2.3 billion a year. That proposal remains mired in the State Legislature.
Mr. Dinkins has left the tough budget plans for the future to his panel -- Donald D. Kummerfeld, a former Deputy Mayor and Budget Director; William H. Gray 3d, the former Congressman from Pennsylvania who was chairman of the House Budget Committee; and Dall W. Forsythe, former state Budget Director.
He insists that the panel's reporting date, Dec. 1, was not dictated by a desire to avoid scrutiny before the election. He said their report would be part of the city's four-year financial plan, which is due in January.
"I'm not hiding anything," the Mayor said in an interview. "But there is no compulsion to tell people when we have not completed the analysis yet. It would be irresponsible."
Mr. Giuliani has argued that the Mayor was just trying to avoid addressing potentially unpopular ideas before the election. "There doesn't seem to be any attempt to say to the public what they are going to do over the next four years," he said in an interview.
Mr. Dinkins has shown a similar disdain for Mr. Giuliani's fiscal proposals, often arguing that Mr. Giuliani's numbers do not add up. If Mr. Giuliani were to cut more than 30,000 jobs by attrition, and also exempted many agencies, then he would have to gut essential services like meals for the elderly, the Mayor argues.
In response, Mr. Giuliani said he would try to avoid job cuts in the Parks and Fire departments, but that few agencies would be exempt. He acknowledged that the job cuts he proposed "can't be done without pain."
Mr. Horton of the Citizens Budget Commission, who for years has advocated many of the ideas now proposed by Mr. Giuliani, praised him for promising "that he would take a pretty big bite of the apple."
"The problem is that there was not enough detail," Mr. Horton said.
Which, some acknowledge, should come as no surprise. Said Mr. Rohatyn: "In an election year, it's unreasonable to expect either candidate to put down the ultimate in pain that he expects to impose on the citizens of the city over the next four years."
 
 
 
FISCAL POLICY: People With Influence
For Mayor David N. Dinkins
 
Norman Steisel, First Deputy Mayor
Former Sanitation Commissioner under Mayor Edward I. Koch and former Deputy Budget Director under Mayor Abraham Beame. Known as an astute budget strategist who can be blunt and less than diplomatic with colleagues.
 
Carol O'Cleireacain, Budget Director
Served as Mayor David N. Dinkins's Finance Commissioner for the last four years. Took over as Budget Director last month, when Philip R. Michael resigned under pressure after a city investigative report found he had shown favoritism to a company seeking a $150 million contract to collect parking fines.
 
For Rudolph W. Giuliani
 
Richard Schwartz, Deputy Campaign Manager
A Democrat who served as a Deputy Commissioner in the city's Parks Department under Mayor Edward I. Koch. Serves as Mr. Giuliani's top adviser on city policy matters.
 
Stephen Kagann, Director of Research for the Giuliani campaign
An economist who worked for City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman before joining Mr. Giuliani's campaign.
 
Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission
He is not a formal campaign adviser to Mr. Giuliani and has not endorsed the Republican-Liberal candidate. But his ideas on fiscal affairs and the budget have influenced Mr. Giuliani significantly.
 
 
 
AT A GLANCE
The Candidate's Budget Plans

 
Major elements of what the candidates have done or proposed to deal with the city's continuing budget problems.
 
Mayor David N. Dinkins
 
Has cut 14,000 city jobs from a peak of 225,000 in November 1991. Has pledged to eliminate another 4,000 jobs by June 1996.
Has appointed a three-member panel of former government officials, which is to report back by Dec. 1 with recommendations on how to cut more than $2 billion a year from the city budget.
Wants the state to take over city's share of the cost of Medicaid.
 
Rudolph W. Giuliani
 
Has proposed cutting more than 30,000 city jobs over four years, bringing the total number of city-financed unded jobs to about 180,000.
Would contract out some city services to private businesses or nonprofit groups, including as many as 4 of the 11 city acute-care hospitals.
Has called for the state to take over some city agencies, including the Departments of Mental Health and Consumer Affairs. Also wants the state to take over city's share of Medicaid costs.
Has proposed phasing out and then eliminating four city taxes: the unincorporated business tax, the commercial rent tax, the surcharge on the personal income tax and the hotel occupancy tax.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN;
Coffee and Clinton: A Hard Sell on the Health Plan

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

 BODY:
Framed by boxes of breakfast cereal and refrigerated pies, President Clinton took a seat at the counter of a Queens diner yesterday and, like a neighborhood insurance agent trying to sign up his friends, listened to the customers' woes and tried to convince them that the one-size-fits-all Clinton health plan would meet their needs.
"What's your deductible?" the President asked Mark Fish, a diner in a booth a few feet from Mr. Clinton's counter stool. 
 "It's $1,000, spread out over two years," said Mr. Fish, who added that his family policy cost $8,500 a year.
The President pointed to a woman down the counter, who minutes earlier had said she was paying $12,747 a year for her and her son's health insurance coverage, "Your problem is similar to hers," he said, "since you are both self-employed and you both have family coverage for one child."
 
'Would Make a Big Difference'
 Then, like an insurance agent moving in for the sell, the President told them both about his plan: "Let me tell you, now, I've hesitated to say this in the past, but I think I can say roughly that a family package which would be the same price starting out for everybody, whether they were self-employed or not, would be about at least $4,000 cheaper than you're paying.
"In addition to that," added the salesman-in-chief, sensing he was about to close a deal, "if you're self-employed, today, as you know, your policy is only 25 percent deductible. Under our plan it would be 100 percent deductible for both you and your wife, which would make a big difference."
The other diners, sipping coffee and munching on rolls, all nodded in assent, but then the President was preaching to the converted. The 50 or so local residents packed into booths and along the counter of the Future Diner, on 190th Street off Utopia Parkway in Fresh Meadows, in Queens, had all been selected by the White House because they had written the President or his wife, Hillary, and urged health care measures to deal with their particular needs.
Mr. Clinton, in New York to attend a fund-raising event for Mayor David N. Dinkins last night and address the United Nations today, heard stories that had him and other participants teary eyed. Minutes after he left the diner, one woman, who had told the President of her troubles getting insurance as a kidney transplant patient, had a seizure and had to be rushed away by ambulance. She was released after treatment at Long Island Jewish Medical Center, officials there said.
The woman, Mary Jane Van Wick, had just told Mr. Clinton that she had no medical coverage other than Medicare, that she needed up to $1,000 a month in drugs to prevent rejection of her new kidney and that she had had to retire early to keep her Medicare eligibility. If she went back to work, she said, insurers would not cover her pre-existing illness, "so I have to stay at a poverty level with no insurance and keep my fingers crossed."
Mr. Clinton turned to the other people in the diner, and the bank of cameras packed in behind them, and said: "Now, there are literally tens of thousands, maybe more, people like Mary Jane in this country who can get health care only if they're on public assistance. Just think about that. This will also be fixed if you have universal coverage that moves from employment to unemployment to employment again, and which includes families as well as individual workers."
 
'Help People Like Me'
 Jean Townsend, who worked 20 years at Kennedy International Airport, read to the President her letter, which explained that as a result of the slowdown in the airline industry her working hours were reduced to part time and that as a result she lost her health insurance.
"Please help people like me get low-cost health care," Mrs. Townsend said. "I raised four children and have worked hard all my life. I don't want charity but I should be able to see a doctor when I am sick."
Mr. Clinton told her: "Under our plan, even part-time workers would be covered. But we would split the difference, so that if you're a part-time worker, your employer and the employee would have the responsibility of only paying a pro-rata share of what the premium would be. And the Government would pick up the rest as they do for unemployed people."
This approach, Mr. Clinton said, "would remove the incentive to hire part-time workers solely to avoid the health care costs."
Susan Berardo told the President of having suffered from metastatic breast cancer and requiring a bone marrow transplant. When she asked her insurer to pay, she said, the insurer said it did not cover that procedure. She said she was advised by her hospital to sue her insurer, which she did, settling out of court.
"I personally do not think that anyone fighting for their life should have to fight their health care system," Mrs. Berardo said.
Mr. Clinton used her case to highlight one of the bigger, but lesser known, problems with the current system: insurance policies cover certain illnesses, but they do not promise to pay for every procedure to cure them.
Under the current system, Mr. Clinton said, any insurer can say, "Well, if we think something is experimental, we don't have to let you do it." Under his plan, the President said, there would be less incentive for insurance companies to do that, because costs would be spread out in larger insurance pools.
As much as the people in the Future Diner seemed sold on the President's prescription, it almost sounded too good to be true. It was left to one unidentified customer to ask the question that seemed on the minds of many there, and in Congress, who are dubious about Mr. Clinton's assertion that health costs can be lowered and his plan financed largely by eliminating waste and stimulating competition.
Almost mocking Mr. Clinton's numbers, the woman said: "So once the hospitals see that they're getting covered by everybody, they're going to say, 'Oh, great, let's reduce costs because we're making enough profit?'
"I mean, will they? I've lived in this country 42 years, and I don't see things come down."

HEADLINE: United Nations Is Finding Its Plate Increasingly Full but Its Cupboard Is Bare

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 26

 BODY:
The lights are going out early at the United Nations as this year's General Assembly gets under way.
Despite having 80,000 peacekeepers in the field and despite the brave predictions of a United Nations renaissance in the post-cold-war world, the organization is on the brink of bankruptcy and is torn by self-doubt. 
 To save money on overtime costs, the United Nations is requiring heads of state and foreign ministers to end their speeches promptly at 6 P.M. because many services are shut down at that hour. Each delegation is restricted to just two copies of official documents.
Only a $194 million peacekeeping payment by Japan last week enabled the United Nations to meet this month's payroll. But budget officials, frantically juggling funds between accounts to meet their most pressing bills, do not know where they will get money for paychecks for the next three months, until next year's contributions start coming in.
 
Members Won't Pay
 Despite ritualistic pledges of support for the ideals and goals of the United Nations Charter, member governments are reluctant to pay its bills.
Whatever pledges of support President Clinton might offer in his speech to the General Assembly on Monday, the fact remains that the United States will owe the United Nations $1 billion in peacekeeping and regular budget dues by the end of this month. That is half the total owed to the United Nations.
The penny-pinching reflects a deeper malaise. The international climate may seem more favorable to global governance than at any time in the past half century, but the United Nations is not yet looking like the world authority it hopes to be. In Bosnia, Somalia, Angola and other places, it seems in danger of falling down on the job.
Disillusionment has been building all summer. Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali has warned repeatedly that the organization is being asked to take on more than it can handle.
"Our renaissance remains in question," he said in a recent interview. "Demands made upon the United Nations are not being matched by resources to do the job."
Complaints about chaotic, ineffective and corrupt management abound. In June, Madeleine K. Albright, the United States representative, accused the United Nations of sending "ill-equipped and often unprepared troops" into peacekeeping missions and attacked its "Byzantine and drawn-out budgetary decision-making process." Last week she said that if the United Nations had been charged with containing Communism, the Berlin wall would still be standing.
Gen. John M. Shalikashvili, nominated as the next Chairman of the Joint Chiefs, last week criticized the United Nations' efforts in Somalia, telling the Senate Armed Services Committee that "this operation does not have a clear articulation of its political and economic goals."
But as problems continue in peacekeeping operations and the money runs low, accusations of corruption and inefficiency are again swirling around the organization's top-heavy bureaucracy, which cannot even publish an up-to-date telephone directory.
After complaints from the United States and other countries, the United Nations is investigating accusations of corruption and embezzlement involving the $3.4 billion it is spending on peacekeeping this year. The accusations include charges that lucrative transport contracts were awarded unfairly and complaints of missing vehicles and supplies.
 
Peacekeepers Accused
 In Bosnia and Herzegovina, peacekeepers have been accused of selling fuel and food on the black market and of running prostitution rings. Last year, the commander of a Ukrainian battalion there was sent home after being presented with a white Mercedes by local Serbian leaders.
In a report on the United Nations bureaucracy issued before he stepped down as the United Nations' top management official earlier this year, former United States Attorney General Dick Thornburgh acknowledged that "duplication is widespread, coordination is often minimal, bureaucratic battles aimed at monopolizing a particular subject are rife and organizational objectives are sometimes in conflict."
Shortly after taking over as Secretary General last year, Mr. Boutros-Ghali slashed the number of departments and seemed ready to make staff cuts. But a rebellion within the ranks forced him to back down.
Most important of all, the United Nations finds itself being criticized for some of its peacekeeping operations, traditionally the most visible and successful of its activities.
After notable successes in Central America, Namibia and most recently Cambodia, the United Nations has failed to prevent Bosnia, a member state, from being dismembered by force, despite innumerable Security Council resolutions calling for the reversal of "ethnic cleansing" and return of conquered lands.
In Somalia, controversy surrounds the United Nations' efforts to impose order on Mogadishu as casualties mount and the national contingents of peacekeepers bicker. Meanwhile, its success in ending starvation and restoring a semblance of normality to the rest of the country goes largely unnoticed. Elsewhere in Africa, an ill-conceived Angolan peace plan has collapsed into renewed civil war.
But it is not only in the political field that the United Nations is having difficulty living up to opportunities created by the end of the cold war.
The organization is now caring for 14 million refugees and delivering huge amounts of aid to those left destitute by famine or conflict. And a new department to coordinate its mushrooming relief activities has been created.
But a Scandinavian-led attempt to streamline the economic and social side was blocked by the developing countries last summer. And the General Assembly is likely to see equally strong third world resistance to the Clinton Administration's plan for a new human rights high commissioner, for fear the investigations would infringe on governments' sovereignty.
 
Dual Crises
 For Mr. Boutros-Ghali, the organization is in the grip of two simultaneous and self-reinforcing crises, one financial and the other military.
Lack of money constrains the United Nations ability to take on new responsibilities, especially in peacekeeping. As a result, he says, he is quite happy to see NATO take control of any force sent to carry out a peace plan in Bosnia. "We don't have the personnel or expertise to manage another 50,000 troops," he said recently.
The military crisis he defines as the unwillingness of public opinion to let the United Nations use military might to enforce peace and reverse aggression under the provisions of its Charter.
Member countries have also given the Secretary General little support in his efforts to strengthen peacemaking by giving the United Nations the kind of permanent enforcement ability the Charter foresees.
In "Agenda for Peace," the blueprint for United Nations reform that he issued last year, the Secretary General suggested creating heavily armed "peace enforcement units" and he asked members to assign armed forces for Security Council missions and to give the United Nations the means to command such forces by activating a Military Staff Committee. One result would have been to equip the United Nations with a kind of standby army.
But his suggestions have fallen on deaf ears.
The Clinton Administration is no exception. As a candidate, Mr. Clinton appeared to support giving the United Nations a "rapid deployment force," which could be called up from units of national armed forces earmarked and trained in advance.
Its duties, he suggested, could include "standing guard at the borders of countries threatened by aggression, preventing mass violence against civilian populations, providing humanitarian relief and combating terrorism."
Now under pressure from a skeptical Congress and doubters within its ranks, the Administration appears to be backing away from its original commitment. A draft Presidential directive that would have committed the United States to provide troops for peacekeeping operations under foreign commanders is still being revised as the Administration seeks to place limits and conditions on its commitment to multilateralism.
As he surveys his dominion, the 71-year-old Secretary General seems at once besieged and combative.
 
Hard Cash, on Time
 A third of the way through his five-year mandate, his talk these days is incessantly of money and the need for members to back the organization they say they believe in with hard cash, on time.
"Money, money, money -- that is the prerequisite for the United Nations playing the role it could play after the Cold War," he said.
Despite all the criticism and setbacks, he says that he is still determined to turn the United Nations sometimes creaking machinery into "the instrument for dealing with all the world's post-cold-war problems, the problems of ethnic conflict, of the environment, of poverty and development."
But to do this, he stressed, he needs "the support of member governments." And sometimes, he adds, "they seem reluctant."
