HEADLINE: North Korea Won't Budge on Nuclear Stance

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 26

 BODY:
Six months after Washington broke decades of cold-war silence with North Korea and opened talks, American, Japanese and South Korean officials say there is no evidence that the reclusive Government is backing away from its nuclear weapons project or that it will allow international inspectors into its most secret installations.
No one knows if the Government in Pyongyang has been able to use the time to further its bomb development, or whether such efforts have slowed under international pressure and a lack of technology. American negotiators insist that the talks have not been a failure, largely because they dissuaded North Korea from pulling out of the international treaty limiting the spread of nuclear weapons. 
 But in the last week, Asian leaders have suggested that the situation is once again veering toward confrontation. In the last six months, international inspectors have gotten no closer to two secret sites near Yongbyon that may reveal how much bomb-grade plutonium North Korea has, and no one knows how close the North is to producing weapons.
 
Sanctions Are Predicted
 South Korea's President, Kim Young Sam, told a Japanese newspaper that now he thought North Korea had enough material to make three bombs. "If the nuclear dispute remains unsettled, international sanctions against North Korea will be unavoidable," he said.
Japan's Prime Minister, Morihiro Hosokawa, told American reporters on Friday that North Korea's development of a missile that could hit virtually anywhere in the Japanese archipelago was "a threat to our country."
"When a missile is launched in North Korea, it will reach Japan in eight minutes," Mr. Hosokawa said, explaining why building a new anti-missile defense capability "is a matter of great interest to us." The United States has proposed joint work on such a defensive shield, although it would take years to build.
Curiously, after months of refraining from comment, the North Koreans themselves tacitly confirmed on Friday that they test-fired the new missile, the Rodong 1, over the Sea of Japan three months ago. In a statement carried by the state-controlled North Korean News Agency, a Foreign Ministry spokesman accused Japan of starting a campaign against his country in response to "a normal missile drill."
 
An Issue of Sovereignty
 "It is only too natural for us to increase our defense capabilities when the enemies' moves to isolate and stifle our Republic are intensifying, and Japan herself is joining force with them," the spokesman said. He said the missile test was "entirely a matter pertaining to our sovereignty."
Frustrated by the impasse on inspections and concerned that North Korea might be using the time to finish its weapons project, the International Atomic Energy Agency said Friday that it would refer the issue to its governing board on Monday. The decision was widely interpreted as a signal that the agency is once again thinking about recommending sanctions.
A third round of talks between North Korea and the United States, which was supposed to have taken place this month, was indefinitely suspended a week ago after American officials said North Korea had made no progress on steps agreed upon in July. Among them was the renewal of discussions with South Korea on beginning mutual inspections of each other's nuclear sites, a step that was accepted in principle more than two years ago.
The Clinton Administration seems likely to face a particularly vexing question in the next several weeks: whether to continue negotiations or to resume the movement in United Nations toward economic sanctions against North Korea, which were halted to give the talks with the United States a chance.
 
Incentives From the U.S.
 The talks themselves were a change: For decades Washington refused to deal directly with North Korea, saying the Government of Kim Il Sung, now 81, was simply trying to drive a wedge between the United States and its ally South Korea. That policy was reversed after an announcement on March 15 that the North was preparing to exit the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.
The Clinton Administration's strategy has since been to engage North Korea in a dialogue that would end the country's isolation, dangling incentives of investment and aid if it reversed course on its nuclear weapons project. Failing that, the talks are a way of showing the world -- especially China -- that every reasonable effort at quiet persuasion has been exhausted in case sanctions are necessary.
"I don't think anyone really wants to go the U.N. because the North would react so strongly," one Japanese official familiar with the talks said.
American negotiators say the North Korean Government, already reported to be under pressure from food shortages and an industrial base that is literally running out of oil, seems to be facing difficult choices of its own.
"If they give the project up, they feel they have no card," said one official familiar with the talks. "If they hold on, they face total pressure, and a Security Council action."
Moreover, support for Pyongyang has been fading fast, confronting North Korea with the possibility that it is about to lose its last Asian ally, China.
But critics of Washington's approach say North Korea has gained time, both to work on developing its first operable weapons and to test the Rodong 1, which the Central Intelligence Agency suspects will soon be sold to Iran.
Some experts argue that the North Korean Government sees nuclear weapons as an insurance policy for an orderly transfer of power to Mr. Kim's son, 51-year old son, Kim Jong Il. None of the major powers surrounding North Korea would like to see such weapons under uncertain control during a struggle for leadership.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Set To Propose Health Plans

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
In the fourth major policy statement in a week, Mayor David N. Dinkins plans to announce a series of health-care initiatives today that range from expanding the number of neighborhood health centers to providing scholarships to medical students who agree to serve patients with AIDS after graduation.
Mr. Dinkins's health proposals are the latest in a series of policy statements intended to seize the attention of the public in an election season in which the Mayor has been plagued by bad news. The health proposals are also intended to counter the claims of Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal mayoral candidate, that the Dinkins administration is without leadership on a number of fronts. Mr. Giuliani has faulted the Mayor in recent weeks for the city's management of public hospitals, some of which he said should be privatized. 
 In a speech scheduled for this afternoon at the Elmhurst Hospital Community Center in Queens, Mr. Dinkins will announce plans to increase the number of Communicare family health centers from the current 13 to 50 within four years. He will also announce the construction of a new Emergency Medical Services Center, expected to be completed by 1997, and the purchase of 200 new ambulances in the next four years.
Both Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Giuliani have been offering major policy statements and proposals in the last few weeks, but Mr. Dinkins has been especially prolific. Last Monday, the Mayor unveiled a series of proposals aimed at curbing crime. The next day, he delivered an address on ways to stimulate the city's economy. On Thursday, he offered several proposals on improving the city's schools.
As in the other policy speeches, many of the initiatives Mr. Dinkins plans to announce are either enhancements of proposals announced earlier or ideas that have been presented in previous speeches. For example, his plan to create a network of clinical health services was included in an earlier proposal for the consolidation of the city's clinical health services under the Health and Hospitals Corporation.
Cesar A. Perales, Deputy Mayor for Health and Human Services, defended the presentation of the report, saying that it offered a substantive look at the Mayor's overall vision for health care in New York.
"It's part of a strategy to lay out the Mayor's plan for the next four years," Mr. Perales said. "Obviously we are in an election, and the people want to know what the candidates are offering for the future."
Cristyne Lategano, a spokeswoman for Mr. Giuliani, said the Mayor has "presided over more hospitals losing their accreditation and more that face the risk of losing their accreditation than any other Mayor." She added that the proposals offered by the Mayor "can only be seen as a joke."
On the scholarship program for medical students, Mr. Perales said that the plan would involve about $7 million in Federal money and that a year of service would be required for every year a medical student received a scholarship.
In other proposals, Mr. Dinkins plans to announce the establishment of a $60 million venture capital fund that would provide money for companies to develop advanced medical technologies. The fund would be registered as a small business investment corporation and financed with $10 million in city funds, $10 million from corporations and $40 million from the Federal Small Business Administration.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Media Business
Paramount's board meets this morning to consider rival takeover bids, and one executive close to the company said senior officials seemed ready to begin discussions with QVC. Any talks with that rival bidder depend on whether Paramount's legal advisers conclude that by taking that course, the board would be within its legal obligations to Viacom, its initial suitor. [Page D1.]
Steven Hoffenberg still has publishing ambitions despite the failure of his attempts to take over The New York Post. He says his latest effort, a paper aimed at women called Her New York, will reach newsstands on Friday. William Glaberson: Press. [D6.] 
 Advertising may be down at Time Inc.'s magazines, but circulation and earnings are up. [D6.]
Language barriers have never stopped MTV as it moved from continent to continent. Now a Spanish offshoot, MTV Latino, will seek to overcome regional language differences as it aims at viewers in 20 countries, each with a distinct musical tradition. [D6.]
KPMG Peat Marwick is telling potential clients to go west, as well as east, north and south. In its first ad campaign, the accounting and consulting firm is selling its global business expertise. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]
 Nielsen will not provide overnight television ratings until the confusion is resolved involving cable television retransmissions of programming from the broadcast networks. [D6.]
 
International

Western investors' enthusiasm for Poland may cool and new commitments may be delayed following the success of former Communists in recent elections. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Farm Subsidies Still Threaten GATT Talks

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26

 BODY:
After seven years of negotiations, world trade talks are falling apart this autumn, which could hurt the world economy, damage confidence in the financial markets and provoke a crisis in the European Community.
President Clinton and leaders of the world's other large industrial democracies contended in Tokyo in July that the talks were back on track, after their trade ministers agreed to lower tariffs on many manufactured goods. But with less than three months until President Clinton's special negotiating authority effectively expires, the talks have slowed to a crawl because of renewed squabbling over farm subsidies. 
 France is trying to undo a deal to limit the subsidies. The French say the deal, reached in November by the Bush Administration and the European Community, may hurt French grain farmers. Administration officials refuse to renegotiate the deal, while Congressional Democrats and Republicans agree that the deal is doomed if the United States budges.
The French are trying to keep sections of the November deal that helped them, and renegotiate the rest. "We order bouillabaisse, and they're trying to serve it without the seafood," said Carol L. Brookins, an agriculture consultant here, referring to the French seafood stew.
Sir Leon Brittan, the European Community's top trade official, will try to resolve the farm subsidy dispute in talks here on Monday with Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative. But trade officials are pessimistic.
"It's very difficult to conclude there is going to be an immediate conclusion," said Peter Sutherland, the Director General of the secretariat of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. GATT, a body of 116 nations, sets rules for international commerce.
To be sure, a crisis can sometimes break a deadlock in trade talks. Prime Minister Edouard Balladur of France took a less confrontational stand than usual today when he told members of Parliament, "We don't want a crisis, either in Europe or in international trade."
But a senior Administration official and a European official said this weekend that Mr. Kantor and Sir Leon were likely to emerge with optimistic words but little change.
The current round of world trade talks, which began in Uruguay on Sept. 20, 1986, is aimed at lowering tariffs and at applying GATT's free-trade rules to agriculture and to services like insurance and shipping. A deadline of Dec. 15 has been accepted by all member governments for completion of the Uruguay Round.
The rapid deterioration in the talks has grabbed headlines across Asia and Europe but not in the United States, where the public and politicians remain preoccupied with another trade issue, the North American Free Trade Agreement. Yet the consensus of economists is that the world trade talks are much more important than the North American pact in stimulating growth in the global economy and halting an international slide into protectionism.
Ross Perot has warned repeatedly that factories employing six million Americans could move to Mexico if the North American accord is approved by Congress this fall. Mr. Sutherland one-upped Mr. Perot during appearances here and in New York on Thursday and Friday, saying repeatedly that seven million American jobs in export industries would be at risk unless a global trade deal is quickly concluded.
Gene M. Grossman, a professor of economics and international affairs at Princeton University, said, "The GATT is much more important to the U.S. because we don't trade that much with Mexico and because our existing barriers with Mexico aren't that high."
 
Political View Differs
 But politicians take a different view, reflecting public worries about the more easily understood consequence of possible American job losses to low-wage Mexican workers. "The issue in Nafta is how we see ourselves as a country; whether we want to do business abroad," said Senator John C. Danforth of Missouri, the ranking Republican on the Commerce Committee. "My own view is the Uruguay Round is not a matter of that great importance."
But the fate of the world trade talks has become increasingly intertwined with the North American Free Trade Agreement. One fear expressed by Mr. Sutherland and other international trade officials is that the Clinton Administration may try to persuade members of Congress to vote for the North American pact in exchange for avoiding concessions in the world trade talks that would expose companies in their districts to more international competition. Such deals could jeopardize the talks by limiting the flexibility of negotiators.
It is unclear what will happen in the world trade talks if the Dec. 15 deadline passes without a deal. Several previous deadlines have been missed, and the special Presidential authority for trade negotiations has been extended three times, in 1988, 1991 and this year. Yet more members of Congress have been urging that potentially trade-restricting legislation be attached to any further renewals, a step that could hurt trade relations with American allies.
 
France's Move to Renegotiate
 The current crisis in the world trade talks reflects a renewed effort by France to renegotiate part of the Blair House agreement on farm subsidies, named for the White House's guest quarters where the accord was concluded in November.
Blair House really involved two agreements. In the first, the European Community effectively froze subsidized soybean production at current levels while the Bush Administration withdrew a threat to impose 200 percent tariffs on European white wines. In the other, the United States and Europe agreed that the final Uruguay Round text should require countries to reduce their tonnage of subsidized grain exports by 21 percent.
The soybean agreement imposed little if any reduction on Europe's soybean production. But the Europeans had offered only an 18 percent cut in subsidized grain exports. So the 21 percent cut in the Blair House grain deal represented a concession.
France and other European Community nations endorsed the soybean deal last spring. But France is now trying to cancel the concession on subsidized grain.
French officials contend that they are not breaking an agreement because the common American-European position on subsidized grain exports does not become final until the Uruguay Round is completed.
The French demands have threatened a crisis in the European Community, whose rules clearly assign responsibility for trade negotiations to Sir Leon and the rest of the community's executive commission. Yet Paris has, in effect, refused to accept the results of these negotiations.
 
Compromises Possible
 International trade officials have been looking at a few possible compromises, like a deal on agricultural tariffs and quotas, which the Blair House pact did not address. The senior Administration official, who insisted on anonymity, said today that the United States might accept lower tariffs on processed foods, which would help European farm exporters as well as some American farmers.
European officials privately accuse the Clinton Administration of retreating from past American stands. For instance, Administration officials have called for changes in the so-called Dunkel draft, a proposed final Uruguay Round text set forth in December 1991 by Arthur Dunkel, who was Mr. Sutherland's predecessor as Director General of GATT. The Bush Administration never officially accepted the Dunkel draft, but did not criticize it.
In an interview Friday, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown rejected equating French efforts to change Blair House to the American move to revise the Dunkel draft. "On Blair House there was a concurrence, consensus," he said. "Folks sat around and negotiated something, and completed those negotiations. The Dunkel text was a text written by a person, that was then laid on the table. So they're not comparable."

HEADLINE: New York City Considers Exporting Trash

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
For the first time, New York City is looking to ship some of its household garbage to other states.
With the city's only landfill, Fresh Kills on Staten Island, filling up, and with plans to build incinerators and expand recycling moving slowly, sanitation officials are considering exporting some of the 14,000 tons of garbage produced each day by households and institutions. 
 The city hopes to take advantage of an unexpected decline in fees at out-of-state landfills and incinerators, officials say. Emily Lloyd, the Sanitation Commissioner, said in an interview that the city has learned "anecdotally" of a possible surplus capacity for trash at incinerators and landfills around the country.
But the city's search for places to send its trash will run against another trend, a growing fear of imported trash in communities around the country, and the threat of national legislation that would let states close their borders to trash.
 
Landfill Fees Falling
 The phenomenon that the city is trying to capitalize on is that tipping fees charged by landfills per cubic yard of trash have declined recently, some industry experts say, although the reasons for and likely duration of the trend are not completely clear.
James E. Kundell, a landfill expert and professor of environmental policy at the University of Georgia's Vinson Institute of Government, said that landfills are "going through a transition period" because of changes in Federal regulations. Many will be forced to close, he said, and the result has been the equivalent of a going-out-of-business sale as operators try to fill their landfills before closing them.
Some newly established private landfills have opened bidding wars, he said. Meanwhile, the volume of trash from households and businesses has fallen because of the recession, a slowdown in industrial activity and the growth of recycling.
An abstrusely worded two-sentence notice scheduled to appear next week in the city's official publication, the City Record, invites trash haulers and the operators of landfills and incinerators to an informational meeting on Oct. 19. Although the purpose is for the private companies to give the city information, not the other way around, Ms. Lloyd said that she hopes to solicit bids formally by the end of the year.
"We want to have a well-informed discussion of what the options are," said Ms. Lloyd in an interview on Friday. Trash could be shipped by train anywhere in the continental United States, she said.
New York City is looking for alternatives to disposing of its waste as Fresh Kills nears capacity and officials continue to have problems building incinerators and increasing recycling. Since 1960, the city has closed 11 landfills and 7 incinerators.
 
Would It Be Economical?
 An important issue is whether shipping garbage elsewhere would be economical. New York City pays between $15 and $20 to bury a cubic yard of trash at Fresh Kills, and until December 1988 it charged $18.50 to any business that wanted to dump there. But then it decided that beyond the cash outlay, the space itself had value, because it is irreplaceable, and it raised the fee for private haulers to $40, which drove nearly all of them to private landfills.
If the Sanitation Department has options to ship its trash outside the five boroughs, it would have to consider whether the increased operating costs are worth it to save capacity at Fresh Kills.
In the short term, the Sanitation Department faces a logistical problem beginning in the second half of 1995, when it plans to close a marine transfer station at Hunts Point in the Bronx for a three- to five-year rebuilding project. Each day, Bronx homes and institutions generate about 1,700 tons of trash, which is now loaded onto barges at Hunts Point and shipped to Staten Island.
Without the transfer station, the city could send garbage trucks to transfer stations in Queens and Manhattan. But from the Bronx, the only borough on the mainland and the only one with adequate freight rail service, it could also export the waste over land.
 
Minefield of Opposition
 In discussing a change in how trash is handled, officials are tiptoeing through a minefield laid by two sides: unionized city workers and private haulers. Both sides fear any effort that would upset the current system, in which private haulers take commercial trash and city workers take everything else. But Ms. Lloyd said that if there were any job losses at Fresh Kills or in the medium-sized navy of barges that the city maintains to move garbage around, they would be through attrition.
A major question for the city is whether it can depend on outside landfills over the long term. As Ms. Lloyd put it, "we cannot become too dependent on the kindness of strangers." The city will look for long-term contracts, she said, meaning 15 or 20 years at least, but Congress could pass a law that would allow states to annul such contracts.
Local governments and environmentalists already have an informal veto on trash imports in many cases, said Edward W. Repa, the director of technical and research programs at the National Solid Wastes Management Association, a trade association in Washington.
Mr. Repa said that it was not unusual for cities to export their household trash.
"Usually when you do those contracts," he said, "You do them in areas where they have the backing of the local community."
 
Community Backing Crucial
 Ms. Lloyd said the support of the community getting the trash would be a precondition of any contract. Some communities find that the taxes and jobs generated by operating landfills make importing trash desirable.
Environmentalists in New York might also object, although Eric Goldtstein, a spokesman for the Natural Resources Defense Council, said that "it's probably a sound interim step as New York makes the transition to primarily relying on recycling and waste reduction."
"If it's done strategically, with willing recipients, it could make short-term sense," he said. "But it's certainly not the ultimate answer."

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Seeing Today's Dreams Against Political Reality

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
"WHEN people say dreams don't come true, tell them about Rudy."
Rudy who? That advertising slogan is promoting a new film, not a candidate for mayor. But the advertisement conjures up nostalgic Horatio Alger-type images of a young man who succeeded against the odds -- images that often seem to represent the underpinnings of Rudolph W. Giuliani's mayoral campaign. For many New Yorkers, today's dreams seem to be less about what could be than about what might have been. 
 "Make it like it was," an anxious elderly woman once pleaded as she accosted Edward I. Koch on a Brooklyn boardwalk. Mr. Koch reassured her as best he could. But he later acknowledged privately that "it" never was as good as the woman remembered. Only that so much, for many people, seems to have gotten worse. Or, so different.
Belying rosy recollections, the proportion of poor elderly people is smaller today than a generation or two ago as a consequence of Social Security and, later, of tying benefit levels to the cost of living.
"The time is coming," New York City's Welfare Department declared hopefully in 1940, "when medical service will be regarded as a public utility which should be available to everyone regardless of his financial position." President Clinton's health care proposals (not coincidentally, he lobbied for them yesterday in a virtuoso performance at the Future diner in Queens) may finally deliver on that promise.
Still, factors like the recession, broader eligibility rules for public assistance, and deep-seated poverty that costs money to cure have conspired to make for a poorer city than the one Mr. Giuliani left for Long Island when he was 7 years old (and was stoically raised as a Yankee fan, an even greater burden in Brooklyn when the team was winning pennants).
Last month, the number of New Yorkers receiving public assistance reached the highest level since the Depression. More New Yorkers are receiving food stamps -- more than 1.3 million -- than ever before. And the number collecting public assistance (1,096,669) and Supplemental Security Income (324,909) last month was higher than in any year since 1936 when the comparable total was an average of only 7,448 more.
Last spring, when Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan evoked the seemingly simple New York of 1943, when two-parent families were not the exception and when a mere 44 people were killed by gunfire, David N. Dinkins irately reminded the Senator that 50 years ago was not the good old days for everybody. Blacks were still relegated to the back of buses in America and even a diligent young black man, like Mr. Dinkins, harbored no hope of becoming Mayor of New York.
Crime, by many measures, is also worse than when Mr. Giuliani left. Reports of some crimes have registered a statistical decrease and the city's police force is growing again. But the proliferation of guns and crack and the seeming decriminalization -- by police policy or by public acquiescence -- of whole categories of antisocial behavior may have rendered some of society's gains against crime illusory. That was one largely untold story buried in the state report on the Crown Heights violence.
During this year's mayoral campaign, overtime pay has been authorized "to immediately deploy as many police officers as possible in high-visibility assignments to ensure that the public is aware that their 'Safe Streets, Safe City' tax dollars have been put to good use."
On the eve of today's Mollen Commission hearings into police corruption, though, the police whistle-blower David Durk complains that cynicism is the worst corruption hazard -- cynicism fostered by a policy to maximize "visible presence" coupled with what he says have been unwritten orders to minimize arrests that would take officers away from their assigned posts.
The Dinkins campaign has accused Mr. Giuliani of "manipulating nostalgia." But, besides being different today, some aspects of life in the city are indisputably worse. Neither Mr. Dinkins nor Mr. Giuliani has demonstrated concern as effectively as Mr. Clinton did yesterday in a forum that was stunning in its simplicity. Ordinary people aired their average problems and a public official responded with compassion and in detail. Mr. Dinkins has tried to respond, but his agenda has been by curtailed by the recession. Mr. Giuliani is just generating a detailed agenda of his own.
Measured by demographics, Mr. Dinkins, who is black, represents the city's future as the proportion of non-Hispanic white people declines. Measured by political experience, Mr. Giuliani, who has never held elective office, is more emblematic of change. His challenge is still to prove that, this time, the change will be for the better.
"Coming in with a clean slate has the advantage over the incumbent of the absence of status quo," says Felix G. Rohatyn, the retiring (but not shy) chairman of the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation. "But in order to be credible, you have to show you have the people and the sophistication, and that you can pursue your ideas in the context of political reality and history."
Dreams came true for "Rudy" in the film version, which is based on a true story. Defying predictions, he finally achieves his goal of playing for Notre Dame -- even if only for two plays in the season's final game. He sacks the Georgia Tech quarterback. Today, he sells real estate in South Bend. In other words, dreams alone -- either of what was, what might have been or what might be -- are not enough.

HEADLINE: Ford Sets Its Sights on a 'World Car'

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENK, Belgium

 BODY:
With their sleek contours and high-tech features, the cars rolling off the production line at the Ford plant here would never be mistaken for a Model T.
Yet they represent the most ambitious effort so far by the American auto industry to accomplish what Japanese auto makers -- and Volkswagen with the Beetle -- have done in the decades since the Ford Motor Company's Model T epitomized mass production: design a car that can be built and sold in pretty much the same form all over the world. 
 It is an expensive and risky effort for Ford, both in Europe and in the United States, where despite improving sales, the industry's overall performance remains lackluster. Ford has spent $6 billion developing the car, which is already on sale in Europe and parts of Asia as the Ford Mondeo and will be introduced in America next summer as the Ford Contour and the Mercury Mystique.
 
 
Savings of 25 Percent
 The investment is one of the biggest new-car investments ever. But Ford said it saved 25 percent over the more traditional way of developing new cars separately for the North American and European markets.
Just as important, by going for a single global design, Ford was able to justify spending on new technology and features, like better suspension and handling, that would make the car more competitive, company executives said.
"We could afford to invest far more in a product which would have sales in excess of 700,000 units globally than to invest in a product with a 300,000-unit potential in a single market," said William H. Fike, the president of Ford of Europe, referring to the annual sales targets for the new car.
So far, the car has received glowing reviews from the European automotive press, and sales are relatively strong in key Ford markets like Britain and Spain, despite a severe industrywide slump.
 
 
'Very Economical'
 "I like everything about the car," said Yolanda Rehuaz, a 23-year-old student from Madrid who recently purchased a Mondeo. "It is very economical, comfortable and smooth."
The program's ultimate success, however, will not be known until the car goes on sale in America, where it will replace the Ford Tempo and Mercury Topaz compacts, but with a higher sticker price, probably starting in the range of $16,000 to $17,000.
The program has already had to compromise some of its initial aims, most notably by restyling the body of the North American version to satisfy consumer tastes that are different from those in Europe, where the primary design and engineering work was done.
But Ford executives said that even if the European version looks somewhat different from the American version, the program had proved the validity of their "world car" approach. The basic design and all the major systems and components -- the engine, the transmission, the suspension, the body frame, the electronic systems, even the seats -- were identical, they said. So is the tooling at the plant here, 60 miles northeast of Brussels, and at the Ford plant near Kansas City, Mo., where production will begin next spring.
 "Mondeo is a single world car in all of the ways that count," Mr. Fike said in a speech to an industry group last month.
For years, the Japanese have designed cars like the Toyota Camry and the Honda Accord, which have been produced and sold in nearly identical form in different parts of the world, relying on high quality as well as engineering and manufacturing innovations to sidestep variations in local tastes. They have increasingly used their worldwide manufacturing systems to help absorb upward and downward variations in demand from different regions.
But even the Japanese have recognized limits to the strategy. As automobile marketing has become even more competitive in recent years, Honda, Toyota and Nissan have been moving more toward customizing models for local tastes. Honda, for example, is reportedly considering differing versions of the Accord for Europe, North America and Japan.
"The direction is much more towards specialized and dedicated production to serve the needs of particular markets," said Karl E. Ludvigsen, a former Ford executive who is now a consultant in London.
Mr. Ludvigsen said Ford's strategy was not fundamentally flawed. He said the auto maker should have recognized, however, that the car's styling would have to be adapted to suit local tastes. Ford changed the North American version of the car only after market-testing the design. Consumers found the Ford Contour to be too conservatively styled and too small in some ways -- for example, in the trunk.
The auto maker had always planned for the Mercury Mystique version in the United States to be slightly different in exterior and interior styling from the Mondeo version in Europe, according to Rex Greenslade, a Ford spokesman. After the market-testing, though, the Ford Contour version was changed as well to make it slightly longer and sleeker.
"The idea of doing the core engineering of key platform components in one place is perfectly sound," Mr. Ludvigsen said. "But you need to accept from the beginning that the interiors and exteriors will have to be different in different markets."
In the beginning, there were doubts within Ford as to whether a global program would work at all. Ford had an embarrassing failure more than a decade ago when engineering teams from the United States and Europe were unable to settle on a unified approach for the Ford Escort and went their own ways, delivering cars with little more in common than a few parts.
 
 
Final Say
 The biggest problem with the Escort debacle, Ford said, was that neither the North American nor the European team had final say over the design. This time, Europe, with its expertise designing sporty-looking small cars, was given the lead role. Units in the United States were used in areas where they had greater expertise: in V-6 engines, automatic transmissions and air-conditioners, for example.
"Culturally, we recognized the concern and said that we were going to respect the principle that there could only be one lead engineering activity," said John A. Oldfield, Ford of Europe's vice president for product development.
Not only were the lines of responsibility made clear, but the corporation's top management, starting with the chief executive, Harold A. Poling, put its weight behind eradicating the old turf-protecting attitudes that had inhibited the 1981 Escort program.
"There were very clear signals from the top that the management team really wanted this to happen," said Mr. Oldfield, who as the executive in day-to-day charge of the program frequently shuttled to Ford's headquarters near Detroit to brief Mr. Poling and his lieutenants.
Mr. Oldfield said that Ford had also worked hard for several years previously to change its culture by throwing out its old discipline-oriented organizational structure -- engineering, production and marketing -- and creating product-oriented organizations that encouraged teamwork.
"If you look at the tough times the industry has been through, and the amount of restructuring necessary at Ford and among all the manufacturers, and at the Japanese threat we face in all markets, you can see that simply continuing to do business in the old ways was not good enough," Mr. Oldfield said.
The program was slowed by the need to develop common approaches in the United States and Europe to a host of issues -- getting information properly from engineers and designers to the manufacturing divisions, for example.
When the design work was finished last year, the company had to insure that it would not squander the savings from the global design work on manufacturing or quality problems -- and that it would be able to replicate in Kansas City next year the efficient manufacturing process it was seeking to develop for the European plant here in Genk.
Two years before production began here, Ford moved a "launch team" to the site. The team, comprising designers, manufacturing experts and suppliers, was given the job of making sure the manufacturing went smoothly, and given the authority to do the job quickly.
Instead of the normal 20 to 30 days it might have taken to get an engineering change made on a typical program, the launch team made the changes on the spot. During production planning, for example, engineers on the team determined that the interior door trim needed only three clips to hold it to the door frame instead of the six called for by the design. Making the change normally would have entailed a review process taking weeks or months; the team made the change in one day. Mr. Oldfield said 50 percent of all problems were dealt with within three days, and most of the rest soon after.
 
 
Quality Problems
 One of the goals was to avoid the quality problems that often accompany a new production program -- and that had severely plagued previous Ford of Europe programs, like the redesign of the Escort. The launch team's goal for the Mondeo was to have no more quality problems than there were at the end of the program it replaced in Europe.
Measured by quality audits in the factory, as well as customer returns, Ford met its goal, Mr. Oldfield said. After three months, more than 95 percent of Mondeo owners said they were completely or very satisfied with the car, compared with an average of about 85 percent for Ford over all, Mr. Oldfield said.
Members of the launch team have been moving to Kansas City to try to replicate the process there.

HEADLINE: Accord Is Near on a Mental Health Bill

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Negotiators for the Legislature and the Cuomo administration said today that they were near agreement on a mental health bill that would close five state psychiatric hospitals and earmark between $153 million and $180 million in new spending for community care over the next five years. An additional $30 million would be spent on programs for the homeless, with most of the money going to treatment for alcoholics and drug abusers who are mentally ill.
The negotiators have been working quietly since early July, when the Governor threatened to veto a mental health bill passed by the Legislature. That bill would direct money to community mental health programs each time a bed was closed in one of the state's 22 psychiatric hospitals. According to estimates, it would route between $208 million and $245 million to community care over five years. 
 Mr. Cuomo says he supports the continuing shift of the state's mental health system from its underused and expensive hospitals to community programs like group homes and day treatment centers. He concedes that the state has not funneled enough money to such programs.
 
Political Pressure
 But he originally objected to the plan to earmark future revenues for mental health, saying it would tie his hands in the budget-making process. As political pressure for a bill mounted, Mr. Cuomo said he could accept a compromise if the bill met three conditions. He said it would have to require the closing of psychiatric hospitals, allocate money specifically to programs for the homeless and include an escape mechanism in case the state's economy deteriorates.
Negotiators for the Governor, the Democratic-majority Assembly and the Republican-controlled Senate said today that they were close to agreement on each of those conditions. "We are a hair away from getting it done," said Senator Nicholas A. Spano, a Yonkers Republican who is the mental health committee chairman.
Karen Carpenter Palumbo, assistant secretary to the Governor for human services, agreed. "Progress continues to be very positive," she said. "I'm generally optimistic that we are going to reach an agreement."
 
'Just a Matter of Time'
 The chairman of the Assembly mental health committee, Steven Sanders, a Manhattan Democrat, said: "I believe we've passed the point of no return. I think this is now on a one-way track toward completion and it's just a matter of time."
The negotiators compromised recently on the amount of additional money to be spent. The bill would set aside $210 million over five years, with $30 million for homelessness programs. Of the remaining $180 million, at least 85 percent, or $153 million, would be spent on community programs. Up to 15 percent could be spent to improve staffing ratios at psychiatric hospitals.
New York currently spends $995 million in state tax dollars on mental health, with $594 million of that amount spent on community care, Ms. Palumbo said.
The schedule for closing psychiatric hospitals would begin with the Gowanda Psychiatric Center in southwestern New York, which has few patients remaining and would close almost immediately after the bill was signed. The Harlem Valley center in Dutchess County would close in February and the Central Islip center on Long Island would close in October 1995.
The timetable for closing the other two hospitals -- Willard in the Finger Lakes region and Kings Park on Long Island -- is still being negotiated. Legislators from those districts want the bill to promise that another use will be found for the hospitals, such as a prison or substance-abuse treatment center. The hospitals are major employers in their areas.
 
A Sticking Point
 The other remaining sticking point involves Mr. Cuomo's request for a so-called escape clause. In fact, Mr. Cuomo and the lawmakers concede that he already has the power to withhold scheduled spending if his fiscal analysts determine that the money is needed to keep the budget in balance.
But largely for political purposes, Mr. Cuomo wants the bill to make that point explicitly so that the Legislature is on record as acknowledging that the commitment to spend money on mental health can be revoked.
Some lawmakers have trouble with this, saying it sends a signal to the public that the state is making a promise that it expects to break.
Progress in the negotiations has been slow, largely because the Legislature has not set a date for returning to Albany for a special session. Without such a deadline, there is little pressure to reach a final agreement.
The Legislature is expected to reconvene sometime before the end of the year to deal with issues it did not address in its six-month regular session, including hospital financing, workers' compensation, storage of low-level radioactive waste and election of an interim attorney general to succeed Robert Abrams, who has announced his resignation. Mr. Cuomo has proposed an Oct. 19 date for the session to begin, but Senate Republican leaders have said they prefer to wait until after the Nov. 2 election.

HEADLINE: Machine Tool Orders Fall

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Orders for American-made machine tools, considered a barometer of future industrial activity, fell 22 percent in August from the month before, the fourth consecutive monthly decline, a trade group said yesterday.
The Association for Manufacturing Technology said August orders totaled $177.5 million, down from $228.3 million in July. Orders came to $313.7 million in June, $315.8 million in May and $348.3 million in April. 
 August orders, however, improved 11 percent from $160.3 million in August 1992.
"August was the first month this year without unusually high auto-related orders," Albert W. Moore, president of the association, based in McLean, Va., said in a statement.
"Despite this, August orders are ahead of the same month a year ago, and year-to-date orders are one-third higher than 1992 levels," he said.
From January to August, machine tool orders were up 33 percent, to $2.17 billion, from $1.63 billion in the corresponding period last year.
Shipments in August were up 4 percent, to $220.6 million, from $212.8 million in July. Shipments increased 29 percent from $171.5 million in August 1992, and year-to-date shipments gained 34 percent, to $2.03 billion, from $1.51 billion.
Export orders for machine tools fell 58 percent in August, to $15.9 million, from $37.8 million in July. But export shipments more than doubled in August, to $27.6 million, from $12.3 million in July.
The backlog of machine tool orders in August stood at $1.47 billion, down from $1.51 billion in July. The year-ago backlog was $1.46 billion.
The monthly report, which covers shipments and orders for metal cutting and metal forming machine tools, represents a relatively small industry, and the monthly figures can fluctuate widely.
Nevertheless, orders for machine tools provide some insight into future industrial health, because the tools are needed to manufacture a broad range of products from dishwashers to aircraft engines.

HEADLINE: Communist Gains May Cool Investment in Poland

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW, Sept. 26

 BODY:
For companies experienced in emerging markets, Poland, with its 40 million people and a centrist Government, has proved a fertile field in the last four years. But with the success of former Communists in the elections Sept. 19, Western investor enthusiasm may cool and new commitments may be delayed, at least in the immediate future, investment bankers and company officials say.
"In the short term it will be wait and see, and if the business climate changes dramatically you'll see people reassess the risk," said John Simpson, a director of Wasserstein Perella & Company, the New York investment firm that was involved in purchases in Poland by the Gerber Products Company and the International Paper Company. 
 Three days before the election, Owens-Illinois Inc., the glass manufacturer, signed an agreement with the Polish Government to buy Poland's largest glass producer, Jaroslaw. The conclusion of the deal, the first investment by Owens-Illinois in Eastern Europe, is contingent on the American company's raising $25 million for improvements at the Jaroslaw factory, according to a John Hoff, an Owens-Illinois spokesman.
Asked if the election results would affect the borrowing, Mr. Hoff said, "We'll have to see."
Some companies are not concerned about the change in Parliament. Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. announced plans last month to invest 20 million ($30 million) to build a candy factory in western Poland. The company said the "consistent economic policies and substantial growth prospects in confectionary, particularly chocolate," had driven the decision to locate in Poland rather than elsewhere in Eastern Europe. And the election had not changed that view, said Chris Milburn, the company's director of communications in London.
Another estimated $1 billion has been committed by American companies for investment in Poland, including $500 million announced last month by Pepsico Inc. for its snack, beverage and restaurant businesses. Poland's largest foreign investor is Fiat S.p.A., the big Italian auto maker. Such large and experienced investors, who came to Poland before the 1989 collapse of the Communists, were unlikely to be affected by the latest change, analysts said.
The successor party to the Communists, the Democratic Left Alliance, which gained 20 percent of the vote, quickly made soothing noises about how it wants foreign investment in Poland to continue. About $2 billion has already been invested since 1989 in Poland by foreign companies.
The Alliance has been conducting talks recently with other political parties, particularly the Polish Peasants Party, which was allied with the Communist regime, in efforts to form a government. The most likely outcome appeared to be a leftist coalition between the Alliance and the Peasants Party, which favors heavy subsidies to farmers.
The most prominent and wealthiest Polish businessman, Zbigniew Niemczycki, the chairman of the Curtis Companies, a conglomerate of electronics, construction, aviation and health care concerns, seemed to set a cautionary tone Wednesday when he said in an interview that he was delaying a major new investment until the new government made clear its economic plans.
With election promises to raise pensions, and enormous pressure to satisfy other social demands, a new government might find it necessary to increase business taxes and customs duties and give greater protections to Polish workers, business executives said.
"We'd like to have more time to see whether the new government will increase taxes," Mr. Niemczycki said. "If they deliver what they promise in social services, they will have to get the money from some place. One of the choices could be to increase taxes, which would be a killer for the economy and bad for unemployment."
Construction on a planned $25 million industrial park in Warsaw, scheduled to start early next spring, would be postponed until midyear, he said.
Foreign investors familiar with the last three years of privatization said they believed the new government would slow the process. While the Alliance provided the crucial votes for passage of the privatization plan in Parliament this year, party leaders have said they want privatization of state companies to be done more selectively.
New people are sure to be placed at the head of the Privatization Ministry, and several investors say they are anxious to see and assess the new faces. More worker participation would probably be encouraged -- either by giving workers more say in whether a deal should be completed or allotting more shares to them.
Changes at the ministry were bound to affect purchases of state companies. "Our acquisition of a state enterprise will be affected," said Ian Murray, a director of Kouri Capital Group in New York. "The message is if nothing else changes, privatization will slow. As an investor that's bothersome. But as a small investment firm, we can stand the wait longer. We'll just wait if we have to."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rally Is Over, an Economist Says

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond has been trading above 6 percent for seven days now, and to David C. Munro, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics, it looks as if the rally is over. But Mr. Munro is not expecting any sharp jump in long-term interest rates to follow.
He does not arrive at this conclusion from a concern about inflation. Nor does he expect that the economy is about to break out of its sluggish path. 
 For the next year, he expects the economy, after adjustment for inflation, to grow at around 2.75 percent, no great shakes by any standard except the 1.3 percent pace in the first half of this year.
On inflation, he is even a little more optimistic than some forecasters, thinking that it can fall toward 2.5 percent, below the 2.9 percent annual rate of increase in the Consumer Price Index during the first eight months of the year.
So why does he think the rally at the long end of the bond market is over? One reason is that yields have fallen so far already, touching 25-year lows of 5.86 percent on the 30-year bond and 5.22 percent on the 10-year note before they slipped into their current trading range two weeks ago.
The other reason is that Mr. Munro believes long-term real interest rates, which are interest rates minus inflation or expected inflation, have now reached the 2 percent to 3 percent level that he says are the historical norm.
The real inflation rate, he said, "is a benchmark to which you should expect interest rates to gravitate to." And once they get there, he adds, they will stop falling.
For Mr. Munro, the real interest rate is around 2 percent for the 10-year note and around 3 percent for longer issues, like the 30-year bond. With inflation so far this year at about 3 percent, that equals a 5 percent to 5.25 percent level for the 10-year note and a 6 percent level for the 30-year bond.
"We are there, and we ought not to expect to move beyond this," he said.
But his view of the impact of real interest rates also means that long-term interest rates should not move much higher, because they would still gravitate back to the 6 percent level on the 30-year bond and 5.25 percent level on the 10-year note.
 
 
Accord on Rates
 It is not known yet what the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided at its meeting last week, but the minutes from the previous meeting in August resolved one question: the Fed has switched back to a neutral stance on short-term interest rates from its previous bias, set in May. That was a bias toward raising the Fed's short-term interest-rate target, which has been 3 percent for just over a year.
Going into last week's meeting, all the debate centered on whether the Fed would switch back to a neutral stand. Well, it was a moot point: they had already made the move.
Reading the signals from the Clinton Administration, it is also clearer that the President's economic policy makers are pleased with the Federal Reserve and its chairman, Alan Greenspan, although various governors of the central bank have indicated recently that they have no intention of cutting the Fed's short-term interest-rate target in an effort to stimulate the sluggish economy. That means that despite a weak economy, the Administration is not pressing for lower interest rates.
"We're pretty much in agreement," Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said when asked about the Fed's interest-rate policy in an interview last week. "He feels and I feel that the economic underpinnings are good," Mr. Bentsen said, referring to Mr. Greenspan.
Mr. Bentsen added that the economy "is not coming out as fast as we want, but we still think that the second half will get to 2 to 3 percent."
 
 
Hospital Ratings
 The Standard & Poor's Corporation, the credit rating agency, says it does not think that the Clinton Administration's health care plan will lead to widespread downgradings of the ratings of nonprofit hospitals around the country.
The S.& P. analysis reached this conclusion because the Clinton plan "adopts and accelerates health care trends that have been developing since the mid-1980's," and these factors have already been incorporated into credit ratings.
But this does not mean the plan would have no impact. What it probably would do, S.& P. said in the report to be released today, is broaden the gap between the nonprofit hospitals with top credit ratings and those at the bottom of the ratings ladder. The report said the trend "has been occurring since the mid-1980's and has resulted in increased numbers of credits at both ends of the rating spectrum."
The $67 billion of hospital debt now rated by S.& P. is dominated by issues with single-A ratings. But in 1992, the number of double-A rated issues and the number of speculative or junk issues both increased to 7 percent of the total, from 6 percent the year before.
The report said that one overlooked but critical point was the impact of cost cutting and, if they are employed, revenue caps on the bonds sold by nonprofit hospitals. Over time, the report said, the reduction in revenue would impair credit quality by lowering the ratio of total revenue to the interest owed by a hospital on its existing bonds.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Beyond the Tinkering at Time Inc.

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
On the theory that if it ain't broke, you don't fix it, Time Inc.'s overhaul of its management structure last week has raised an inevitable question about the health of its magazines.
The company's moves were quick and, in some ways, drastic: it shuffled executives, gave more financial responsibility to individual magazines and returned to a more traditional advertising sales structure. One goal was to reverse declines in ad sales at its seven core magazines. 
 Indeed, the number of advertising pages at each of those magazines, all based in New York, has fallen during the first eight months of 1993, compared with the corresponding period last year, according to the Publishers Information Bureau. The magazines are Sports Illustrated, with a 16.6 percent decline; Life, 14.5 percent; Time, 11.9 percent; Money, 7.2 percent; People, 5.1 percent; Fortune, 3 percent, and Entertainment Weekly, 1.5 percent.
The declines compare with an overall 1.2 percent increase in advertising pages at the 180 magazines tracked by the bureau.
 
Increases in Circulation
 Circulation, however, is another story. With the exception of Life, each of the core Time Inc. magazines showed circulation gains for the first six months of 1993, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations. And at Life, the circulation cutback was intentional, as part of a broad overhaul to make the magazine's operations more efficient.
As Time Inc. officials are quick to point out, advertising accounts for only a third of the company's more than $3 billion in annual revenue. The remainder is split almost evenly between circulation of its 32 magazines and its book operations.
Another sign of health is the bottom line. The company reported a 19.3 percent increase in earnings for the first half of 1993, compared with the year-earlier period, and has announced a goal of continued double-digit growth.
Although Time Inc. officials generally decline to give information about specific magazines, executives within the company, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said that Time, Fortune, People, Money and Sports Illustrated were all making money. Executives said Entertainment Weekly, which began in 1990, has not yet broken into the black but is on track, while Life, which had been struggling for years, seems to be back on its feet.
 
A Leaner Life
 Don Logan, president and chief operating officer of Time Inc., called this a transition year for Life, which was redesigned in February. Costs were cut by trimming the size of the magazine, reducing staff, slashing ad rates and lowering circulation to 1.5 million from 1.7 million. "On an operating basis, month to month, Life is certainly profitable," Mr. Logan said.
But visible as the New York-based magazines are, they represent only a small part of the company. Many of its other magazines, so-called niche publications that are aimed at specific audiences, have generally fared better in the advertising recession.
In 1985, Time Inc. acquired the Southern Progress Corporation and its magazines, including Southern Living and Southern Accents, two profitable publications. Cooking Light, started in 1987 amid the trend toward healthier cooking, has also been a success.
Other successful start-ups and purchases include Parenting, acquired in 1990, and Martha Stewart Living, started in 1991. It is too early to gauge the performance of Vibe, a hip-hop magazine that started last year.
Still, questions remain about why the core magazines have fared so badly in advertising.
In the case of Time magazine, part of the problem could be the continuing struggle of news weeklies to define themselves in the 1990's. Over all, however, Time Inc. seems to have more fundamental problems.
Many media directors at advertising agencies say the company became out of touch with the needs of advertisers by starting an ad sales structure in 1991 that took power from individual publishers and placed it in the hands of regional managers. The policy was reversed in last week's restructuring.
"It was an error of judgment," Emily Swartzentruber, senior vice president and New York media director at J. Walter Thompson, said of the regional structure. "And if it had gone on much longer it would have begun to seriously erode equities."
Reginald K. Brack Jr., chairman and chief executive of Time Inc., stressed that a main point of the reorganization was to put publishers more directly in touch with the advertising community. Each publisher will be responsible for at least one ad account, including sales calls.
The restructuring, however, may not be enough to fix the problem, said Gene DeWitt, president of DeWitt Media, an independent magazine consulting firm. He said the difficulties went beyond the regional setup and that "something in their sales mix isn't working."
"What I sense missing is an entrepreneurial focus, drive and energy that any successful sales organization needs," he said.
David Lehmkuhl, president of David Lehmkuhl Media, a magazine consulting firm, said that Time Inc. management and its sales force "are pretty much out of touch with what's going on in the media planning and buying community."
"I think all of those books are out of touch both in editorial and sales," he said. "Media planners who are 23 and 24 see them as an old man's read."
Mr. Logan, Time Inc.'s president, said many of its publications were not geared to younger readers, citing Fortune and Money. "They are just not young magazines," he said, although he noted how publications like People continued to have a strong following among younger readers.
"It's just a very complex environment out there still," he said. "But we feel very confident about the future."

HEADLINE: 2 Autumn Festivals in Europe

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW, Sept. 26

 BODY:
Both the Warsaw Autumn, which ended its 36th installment on Saturday night, and Paris's 22d Autumn Festival, which got under way last week and continues until December, were intended to open their cities to the best the world had to offer. Both remain at full strength, attracting audiences from far beyond their local borders. Yet both festivals are facing a new order, forced by circumstances to reconsider their roles.
In the late 1950's and 60's, the Warsaw Autumn provided Poland and the entire Soviet bloc with its only comprehensive look at contemporary classical music. But it has had to readjust as the shock of the new wore off and the modernist passions of its founders were diluted by today's musical eclecticism. 
 "The first performance in Poland of Webern's Op. 10 "Orchesterstucke' was encored, the whole piece," the composer Witold Lutoslawski recalled in an interview on Friday. "There was tremendous enthusiasm for everything. That can't sustain itself for decades. Now the halls aren't always filled, but we can't complain: it's still a major event."
 
Nostalgia for Dissent
 The fall of Communism only underscored that sense of youthful loss. Throughout Eastern Europe intellectuals feel nostalgic for their days as dissidents, when culture had a passionate purpose that transcended mere esthetic pleasure or even moral elevation.
"It was a place of confrontation," recalled Antoni Wit, who is the music director of the Polish Radio National Symphony in Katowice. "In 10 days you could hear what had happened in music all over the world in the last year."
Today, the Warsaw Autumn is just one music festival among many, East and West, and hardly the richest. But it remains one of the best: open, engaged and full of judiciously chosen scores and remarkably accomplished performances.
At the Autumn Festival in Paris, the change has been personal, not political. Founded in 1972 by Michel Guy, it reflected his passion for American avant-garde performing arts, so much so that it was for a time perceived (stigmatized, in some quarters) as an American agent. With the fading of the extraordinary outburst of performing-arts creativity in New York after the 1970's, however, the Autumn Festival became what Guy had always conceived it as being: a window on the whole world of the performing arts, including the third world, and to some extent a showcase for the best in experimental activity in France.
 
One Man's Taste
 The Autumn Festival was always a reflection of the subjective tastes of Guy, who took a three-year sabbatical from the festival in the mid-70's to be French Minister of Culture. "I openly acknowledge my enthusiasms, my prejudices, my friendships, even my stubbornness," he once wrote. "Let no one imagine that the Festival d'Automne could exist without passion!" But Guy died in 1990, and the question is how well the festival can carry on without him.
The festival was founded by Guy and his old friend Georges Pompidou in what the festival's current general director, Alain Crombecque, called a "princely act," bypassing normal bureaucratic channels. Pompidou was the President of France at that time, and Guy once said that the Pompidou Center was the "concrete result" of their effort to revitalize contemporary arts in Paris, his festival being the "active result."
"This activity emerged from the silent vacuum reigning over the capital in the 70's," Guy continued. Except for New Wave film and a few playwrights, he added, "there was no audience in Paris for new creations, no money and no vitality." Mr. Crombecque agreed with that assessment. "Paris had been a little provincial," he said. "They wanted to open it up to the world."
Their success has been spectacular, so much so, said Josephine Markowits, the festival's longtime music director, that when she regards the current competition all over the city, she is "proud or depressed, depending on the day."
 
Resonance in Brooklyn
 Much of what the Autumn Festival presented has always been anticipated or echoed by the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Harvey Lichtenstein, the academy's president, openly recognized the Paris festival as a "formidable influence" on his decision to start his own fall Next Wave Festival. Paris has staged far more events than Brooklyn, and the reason is money. This year, the Paris budget is more than $3 million, with $1.3 million from the state and the rest from the city, sponsors and the box office.
The Autumn Festival opened this year with Robert Wilson's French-language version of his and Darryl Pinckney's monologue based on Virginia Woolf's "Orlando," starring Isabelle Huppert and seen already this spring in Lausanne, Switzerland. That recalled one longtime festival tradition, its support of American artists in general and Mr. Wilson in particular.
Also on the first-week docket was a charming if trivial hourlong music-theater piece by Mauricio Kagel, the Argentine-born, German-based vanguard composer. He wrote the music in 1977, but this version, staged by Werner Herzog and offering a sequence of acts recalling a small-town traveling circus of yesteryear, was new in Germany last year. That suggested the festival's more recent history: increasing reliance on European artists and on European co-productions.
 
Built-In Continuity
 Fortunately, continuity was always built into this compact organization. The festival's founding president, Janine Alexandre-Debray, is still on board. So are the two women who have long done the bulk of the work of lining up festival presentations: Marie Collin, for theater and dance, and Miss Markowits for music. Mr. Crombecque, the new general director, worked for Guy off and on for years and was brought by him to run the Avignon Festival in the 1980's.
Still, for a festival in which Guy himself put so much weight on personal taste, one has to worry. On the other hand, this year's festival, planned without him, offers a feast of interesting possibilities in the coming months. On the schedule are John Cage's gigantic "103" for orchestra on Tuesday night, Steve Reich's "Cave," yet another Goldoni play from Giorgio Strehler and his Piccolo Teatro of Milan, Peter Sellars's English-language version of Aeschylus' "Persians," dance from Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker, Lucinda Childs and Bill T. Jones, and much more from European artists less well known to Americans.
Events at the Paris festival, in theaters all over the city, attract a trendily youthful audience but also, for the openings especially, a predictably well-coiffed Parisian crowd. The audiences for the Warsaw Autumn are likewise handsome and even elegant, and also young, given the festival's policy of providing free tickets for students.
 
Getting Around the Budget
 The Warsaw audiences do not look well heeled, however, which reflects the still-shaky economic circumstances of this festival and its public. The subsidies have not declined, but their value in hard currency has. According to Olgierd Pisarenko, who as head of the festival's repertory committee counts as its artistic director, the official budget, provided by the Government, is still only slightly more than $300,000. That is supplemented, however, by various in-kind arrangements (hotel rooms, air tickets, etc.) and foreign-government grants.
Phyllis Bryn-Julson, the American soprano who was here for two concerts, said her fee was paid in German marks, and Mr. Pisarenko added that the appearance of the Schoenberg Ensemble of Amsterdam was underwritten by the Dutch. "They've been very generous with my stay," Ms. Bryn-Julson said. "And it's so cheap. I can't ever eat more than $4 worth on the menu."
Budget limitations generally preclude inviting Western orchestras and opera companies, as happened during the Communist past. But the level of performances, with Polish ensembles and artists supplemented by visiting chamber groups and soloists, is impressive.
Mr. Wit's Katowice orchestra revealed itself as one of the best in Europe with its performances of Messiaen's "Eclairs sur l'Au-Dela" and a Polish program that ended with two scores by the chart-topping Henryk Mikolaj Gorecki. The Wilanow String Quartet accompanied Ms. Bryn-Julson handsomely, the National Philharmonic played well for Lutoslawski and the 18-year-old Aleksandra Krzanowska revealed a real pianistic talent as well as a sweet theatrical flair in her late-night recital on Friday at the Chopin Music Academy.
 
The Big Three
 Young Polish composers seem as eclectically diffuse now as the rest of the world. But the Warsaw Autumn still offers innovative programming, including a clutch of Chinese composers and a mini-retrospective of Cage and his New York School. And Poland still has its big three: Krzysztof Penderecki, who conducted the opening concert on Sept. 17, ending with two of his works; Mr. Lutoslawski, whose recent, finely wrought Fourth Symphony ended the festival's closing concert on Saturday, and Mr. Gorecki. He had four works in the festival's final days, including the hushed and compelling Concerto-Cantata, with Carol Wincenc of New York as its impeccable flute soloist.
Still, an aura of apprehension hangs over the festival, a sense of drift that parallels fears for the future of the Autumn Festival in Paris. Everyone agrees that Warsaw had an enormous impact on Eastern bloc music and on the developing new Polish school of composers. And while no one knows quite why the Polish Communists permitted all this musical freedom, some now miss the excitement of staging a festival under the constant threat of repression.
"We can only guess, but I would think the authorities realized that music was not very important as a means of public propaganda," Mr. Lutoslawski said. "They censored literature, film, theater, television, but not music. They were proud of the festival. They could show other countries, especially Russia, that they could present things like that."
Now the thrill of battling a common enemy is gone. "Maybe the festival hasn't changed, but its role has changed," said Mr. Wit of the Katowice orchestra. "It has lost its political aspect, and now people don't wait for it all year long."
