HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
America's Dream on a Slide Into the Third World

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

The Endangered American Dream
How to Stop the United States From Becoming a Third-World Country and How to Win the Geo-Economic Struggle for Industrial Supremacy
By Edward N. Luttwak
365 pages. Simon & Schuster. $24.
Much will seem familiar about Edward N. Luttwak's cumbersomely subtitled but important economic jeremiad, "The Endangered American Dream." 
 Scarcely another book is required to tell us that the American economy is declining relative to other first-world industrial powers; that the country increasingly lacks patient capital investment and a highly skilled work force; that its middle class is shrinking while the gap between the super-rich and the poor grows apace; that one of the causes of these problems has been the economic growth of Japan, not so much through its people's superior diligence, but more because of unfair trade practices; that America must now fight back by paying off its huge debts, revamping its deteriorating public-school system and adopting an industrial policy of its own to contend with those of Europe and Japan. All this has been written before in recent books too numerous to list.
Indeed, Mr. Luttwak has said much of it himself. A director at the Center for Strategic and International Studies of Washington and the author of half a dozen previous books, among them "The Pentagon and the Art of War" and "Strategy: The Logic of War and Peace," he has repeatedly testified before Congress.
What is new here is the detail he supplies to illustrate his points: details ranging from a description of urban crime as "America's permanent intifadah," to a survey of the sort of product-liability suits that increasingly impede American commerce, to a review of the ill-defined ethnic and racial categories to which teachers in the San Diego Unified School District must now be sensitive. (For instance, as he quotes the official directive, a Hmong is "a person having origins in any of the original peoples of Laos or Cambodia and are of the Hmong culture or origin.")
And what is newly compelling in this book is Mr. Luttwak's thesis that whereas the nations of the world once competed geopolitically, with the end of the Cold War they now compete geo-economically, a point he first developed publicly in the pre-Gulf war hearings of the United States Senate. In this view, it is no longer by territory that countries measure their strength, but by industrial productivity. Using that measure, he sees the United States as fated to become a third-world economy by the third decade of the next millennium, or a nation of low-wage, assembly-line workers or poorly paid hamburger-flippers.
What is to be done? (as he titles his chapter of proposed solutions). For one thing, he insists, the public educational system must be overhauled by giving extra Federal pay to teachers who can pass uniform, nationwide, written qualification exams, by rewarding students with Federal diplomas for tested educational achievement and by strengthening vocational training and work-study programs.
For another thing, he writes, the country should promote capital investment by doing away with what he characterizes as productivity-inhibiting social security and corporate taxes, and introducing value-added taxes, which, he says, cut down on consumption and encourage savings. Finally, America should renounce its mindless faith in free-market ideology (as damaging, he believes, as Marxist-Leninist dogma) and adopt an industrial-policy apparatus to compete with the Ministry of International Trade and Industry in Japan and comparable bureaucracies elsewhere in the world.
After all, if Japan isn't proof enough that industrial policy works, then the nation can look to "the very 'Japanese' semiconductor policy pursued by the very same Reagan administration that issued long perorations on the evils of industrial policy," or to the United States Advanced Battery Consortium, or, most recently, to America's "flat panel" consortium for computer display screens. These, he argues, are some of the most dramatic proofs that industrial policy is viable for this country.
None of these arguments are likely to sweep opponents of Mr. Luttwak's views off their feet. The organization of his book is somewhat haphazard, his arguments frequently lurching uneasily from broad generalization to near-obsessive detail. While his views are often trenchant, they sometimes become mired in pages of mind-numbing statistics. Nor is his non numerical prose always winning, tainted as it sometimes is by overly harsh ridicule of the proponents of multiculturalism or by the crude sense of humor apparent in his suggestion that in the hypothetical event of a wave of capital-rich Swiss immigration, "Americans would be content enough with their rising wages to tolerate a fair amount of noisy yodeling."
More seriously, Mr. Luttwak does not trouble to rebut the theoretical basis of a belief in international free trade. He merely waves it away with an unfavorable example or two. In any case, as his argument turns out, his point is not really that free-market ideology is false, but rather that, like unilateral nuclear disarmament, it may not be entirely practical in a world that embraces the opposite view.
Finally, what he argues most effectively is that as long as the nations of the world wage geo-economic warfare, Americans must be willing to arm themselves appropriately, just as they did when geopolitics was the game. As he concludes: "The choice that remains for the United States is between the successful negotiation of a sweeping geo-economic disarmament, and the waging of the geo-economic struggle in full force. The looming presence of expansionist international corporations, activist bureaucracies, and economically ambitious governments -- none of which is to be found on Main Street, USA, or in economics textbooks -- requires that the choice be made and acted upon. Not to choose is to lose."

HEADLINE: PULSE;
Savings Associations and Commercial Banks

 BODY:
After peaking in 1988, the number of commercial banks in the region has plummeted, in large part reflecting the effects of the recession. The trend in New York has been driven by mergers like the one between Chemical Bank and Manufacturers Hanover, and by moves by many large New York City-based banks to merge their upstate subsidiaries into the parent banks. In Connecticut, the FDIC closed 10 institutions in 1992 alone; only one of the state's banks was closed in the 1980s. In New Jersey, a slow down in commercial real estate and construction took a toll on commercial banks, but they resumed profitable operations in 1992, after three years of setbacks. The thrift industry in all three states has also contracted, afflicted by the same troubles that beset many of the country's savings and loan associations.

HEADLINE: Nafta and the Environment

 BODY:
Environmentalists, accustomed to unified struggles against common enemies like air pollution and Ronald Reagan, have fallen to fighting among themselves over the North American Free Trade Agreement. Grass-roots organizations like Friends of the Earth say it will create a polluters' paradise in Mexico and degrade America. Mainstream groups like the National Wildlife Federation say it all but guarantees a cleaner hemisphere.
Nafta's critics are even more jittery now that a Federal appeals court has ruled that the White House can forward the agreement to Congress without an environmental impact statement. A careful reading of Nafta should ease their worries. 
 No previous trade agreement tackles as many pollution issues as Nafta does. The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade -- the basic document governing international commerce -- doesn't even mention the word "environment." Nafta, by contrast, includes numerous environmental protections; a side agreement makes them even stronger. Mexico is more likely to become a cleaner nation with Nafta than without.
Critics raise three complaints, all overstated.
Nafta Undermines Laws. Critics say the agreement threatens global environmental treaties as well as stiff U.S. laws that, they fear, could be challenged by either Canada or Mexico as unfair barriers to free trade. But Nafta explicitly protects the international pact prohibiting illegal trade in wildlife, the Basel Convention against shipment of hazardous waste, and the Montreal Protocol phasing out production of ozone-destroying chemicals.
Nafta also protects the right of each country to set any standards it wants as long as they seek a "legitimate" environmental objective, are based on scientific data and apply to foreign and domestic products alike. Given this language, it seems highly unlikely that Mexico could, for example, successfully challenge a U.S. decision to prevent the import of fruits sprayed with pesticides banned by U.S. law.
Nafta Won't Clean the Border. The boundary between Mexico and the U.S. is undeniably a cesspool. "Dirty" U.S. industries like petrochemicals have flocked to the border zone because, under Mexican law, the goods they manufacture can be shipped back to the U.S. duty-free.
Nafta addresses the border problem in two ways. First, the side agreement promises $8 billion for water and sewage treatment, although the money has yet to be appropriated. More important, all of Mexico will become a duty-free zone under Nafta, thus removing any incentive to concentrate industry on the border.
Nafta Will Ruin Mexico. Although Mexico has strong environmental laws, it rarely enforces them. Thus, critics say, America's dirtiest industries -- tempted not only by Mexico's lower wages but by its regulatory indifference -- will now infest every nook and cranny of Mexico, adding greatly to Mexico's existing pollution overload.
However, Nafta explicitly bars all three parties to the agreement from creating "pollution havens" by waiving or ignoring environmental laws for the purpose of seeking investment. The trick is to insure that this pledge is honored. To that end, the side agreement sets up a three-nation mechanism, the Commission on Environmental Cooperation. Any country (or private group like the Sierra Club), believing that a nation is not enforcing its laws, can complain. If the commission finds a pattern of violations, it can impose fines of up to $20 million on the offending country and, if that doesn't work, invoke trade sanctions.
The procedure is cumbersome and it is hardly foolproof. But at least it would bring to bear international pressures that do not now exist and would give Mexico an incentive to obey laws that it routinely ignores.
Nafta will not turn Mexico, Canada or the U.S. into a preindustrial paradise. It simply seeks to protect the environment against the economic explosion that Nafta is supposed to let loose. Those who claim otherwise haven't done their reading.

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Fifth Person

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Within a few years, health insurance will be universal and irrevocable; that's a given.
Reality #1: The four out of five Americans who are presently covered will have to pay for the fifth person's insurance: that is logically inescapable. Four must pay for five. 
 Let us not be misled by phrases like "employer mandates"; that means only that the cost of a payroll will rise and be paid by the consumer. In the same way, "government subsidies" to small business, and to the unemployed, mean that the cost of insurance will be paid by the taxpayer. The consumer and the taxpayer are the same person.
The huge new benefit -- the social justice of changing charity to an entitlement -- will have a price. President Clinton would have us believe that the cost of insuring the fifth person will be made up by eliminating paperwork, by rejiggering present Federal programs for the elderly and poor, and by extracting $365 a year from the pack-a-day smoker. (About time the poor paid their fair share.) That cost concealment is a fraud that betrays the promise of health insurance reform.
Reality #2: Republicans huddling in secret conclave have decided not to be out-compassioned by anybody. The party line is to embrace the President's goals, to remember Nixon's plan and declare health to be "above politics," and to suggest that minor differences in the details of approaches will be ironed out in Congressional hearings. That concealment of principled opposition is also a fraud; we should not be fearful of constructively opposing the wrong means to a good end.
Reality #3: The Clinton plan imposes price controls. Its chokepoint on a free economy is the insurance premium: Put that in Washington's hands, and the Feds dictate everything from the price of bypasses to the price of aspirin. Most people like the idea of price controls until they are faced with the shortages and black markets and rationing -- and wage controls -- that always follow.
Clinton's proposed price control dares to be aboveboard on new drugs. By putting researchers on notice that a supreme court of health will determine the price of newly developed medicines, the Clintons have chosen to inhibit private investment in potential cures for AIDS, brain diseases, cancer or the common cold. If there is no big profit payoff, there will be no corporate roll of the dice; that's capitalism. The last thing reform should do is reduce the current investment in new drugs that may curtail expensive hospital stays.
Reality #4: Buyers' cooperatives usually contribute to competition, realizing savings by buying in bulk; but the Clinton co-ops -- called "alliances" -- are to be state monopolies, not subject to competition from other co-ops. Government-directed monopolies are inherently bureaucratic, and no government operation is purified by failure; the person who loaded the wrong speech into Mr. Clinton's teleprompter was not fired for incompetence. To claim that the cost of the fifth person's coverage will come out of "bureaucratic savings" or paperwork reduction is to hypnotize yourself.
Reality #5: Notwithstanding the previous realities, the Clintons have touched the nation's guilty conscience: The poor should not have to choose between food and medicine. "Pre-existing condition" are dirty words. Emergency-room care is wasteful. Forms can be standardized. Malpractice threats that trigger expensive tests and doctors' insurance costs should be curbed.
Reality #6: The heat is on conservatives not to merely tinker with a statist plan, but to come up with one that protects individual choice. Senator John Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, has a voucher-based plan on the table whose costs are more readily accountable and where the quality of today's care is less diluted.
Who will espouse the alternative that emerges? Dr. Bernadine Healy left liberal Senator Jay Rockefeller an expostulating wreck on yesterday's ABC Brinkley show; before any of us decide on health care, we should be educated by a formal two-hour televised debate between Dr. Healy and Hillary Rodham Clinton.
Remember: Nothing is for nothing. The generous four will pay to cover the fifth person with higher taxes, higher prices and higher premiums. Let's not also pay in our personal freedom by lurching toward a command economy.

HEADLINE: Accord Is Near on a Mental Health Bill

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Negotiators for the Legislature and the Cuomo administration said today that they were near agreement on a mental health bill that would close five state psychiatric hospitals and earmark between $153 million and $180 million in new spending for community care over the next five years. An additional $30 million would be spent on programs for the homeless, with most of the money going to treatment for alcoholics and drug abusers who are mentally ill.
The negotiators have been working quietly since early July, when the Governor threatened to veto a mental health bill passed by the Legislature. That bill would direct money to community mental health programs each time a bed was closed in one of the state's 22 psychiatric hospitals. According to estimates, it would route between $208 million and $245 million to community care over five years. 
 Mr. Cuomo says he supports the continuing shift of the state's mental health system from its underused and expensive hospitals to community programs like group homes and day treatment centers. He concedes that the state has not funneled enough money to such programs.
 
Political Pressure
 But he originally objected to the plan to earmark future revenues for mental health, saying it would tie his hands in the budget-making process. As political pressure for a bill mounted, Mr. Cuomo said he could accept a compromise if the bill met three conditions. He said it would have to require the closing of psychiatric hospitals, allocate money specifically to programs for the homeless and include an escape mechanism in case the state's economy deteriorates.
Negotiators for the Governor, the Democratic-majority Assembly and the Republican-controlled Senate said today that they were close to agreement on each of those conditions. "We are a hair away from getting it done," said Senator Nicholas A. Spano, a Yonkers Republican who is the mental health committee chairman.
Karen Carpenter Palumbo, assistant secretary to the Governor for human services, agreed. "Progress continues to be very positive," she said. "I'm generally optimistic that we are going to reach an agreement."
 
'Just a Matter of Time'
 The chairman of the Assembly mental health committee, Steven Sanders, a Manhattan Democrat, said: "I believe we've passed the point of no return. I think this is now on a one-way track toward completion and it's just a matter of time."
The negotiators compromised recently on the amount of additional money to be spent. The bill would set aside $210 million over five years, with $30 million for homelessness programs. Of the remaining $180 million, at least 85 percent, or $153 million, would be spent on community programs. Up to 15 percent could be spent to improve staffing ratios at psychiatric hospitals.
New York currently spends $995 million in state tax dollars on mental health, with $594 million of that amount spent on community care, Ms. Palumbo said.
The schedule for closing psychiatric hospitals would begin with the Gowanda Psychiatric Center in southwestern New York, which has few patients remaining and would close almost immediately after the bill was signed. The Harlem Valley center in Dutchess County would close in February and the Central Islip center on Long Island would close in October 1995.
The timetable for closing the other two hospitals -- Willard in the Finger Lakes region and Kings Park on Long Island -- is still being negotiated. Legislators from those districts want the bill to promise that another use will be found for the hospitals, such as a prison or substance-abuse treatment center. The hospitals are major employers in their areas.
 
A Sticking Point
 The other remaining sticking point involves Mr. Cuomo's request for a so-called escape clause. In fact, Mr. Cuomo and the lawmakers concede that he already has the power to withhold scheduled spending if his fiscal analysts determine that the money is needed to keep the budget in balance.
But largely for political purposes, Mr. Cuomo wants the bill to make that point explicitly so that the Legislature is on record as acknowledging that the commitment to spend money on mental health can be revoked.
Some lawmakers have trouble with this, saying it sends a signal to the public that the state is making a promise that it expects to break.
Progress in the negotiations has been slow, largely because the Legislature has not set a date for returning to Albany for a special session. Without such a deadline, there is little pressure to reach a final agreement.
The Legislature is expected to reconvene sometime before the end of the year to deal with issues it did not address in its six-month regular session, including hospital financing, workers' compensation, storage of low-level radioactive waste and election of an interim attorney general to succeed Robert Abrams, who has announced his resignation. Mr. Cuomo has proposed an Oct. 19 date for the session to begin, but Senate Republican leaders have said they prefer to wait until after the Nov. 2 election.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 2, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about a New York State mental-health bill referred incorrectly to the position of state legislators on Long Island who are concerned about the proposed closing of Kings Park Psychiatric Center. They want assurances from the state that local planning officials will have a significant voice in determining the future use of the site, rather than wanting another state use, like a prison or a substance-abuse center.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A flurry in the chemical industry confirms analysts' suspicions.

BYLINE: By Kathryn Jones

 BODY:
THE rapid-fire succession of spinoffs, acquisitions or restructurings last week in the chemical industry reinforced what many Wall Street analysts had already concluded: Chemicals are having another bad year, and will probably endure several more before the business pulls out of a prolonged slump.
Texaco Inc. kicked off the flurry by disclosing plans to sell its Texaco Chemical Company to Jon M. Huntsman, a chemical entrepreneur from Utah, and the Australian billionaire Kerry Packer, for $1.06 billion. Then the American Cyanamid Company and the Ethyl Corporation each announced that they planned to spin off their chemical businesses to shareholders. And E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said it would lay off 4,500 employees in its domestic chemicals business. 
 The announcements barely moved the chemical stocks as a group, indicating the pessimistic attitude about the outlook for the depressed industry.
"There's disillusionment about the industry's prospects," said George J. Krug, an industry analyst at Oppenheimer & Company. "It will be a number of years before we see any significant recovery, and then there will be a lot of competition from new players. It's going to be a long, hard battle."
The reshuffling of assets, which has been taking place gradually during the four- to five-year industry downturn, probably spurted last week as a result of uncanny timing, analysts said. But they said the activity also represented a trend they saw continuing during the next year to 18 months as companies shed operations in depressed industries like chemicals, focused on core businesses and tried to enhance shareholder value.
"We'll see ongoing rifle-shooting at businesses that will be divested and pruned over the next year," said Robert S. Reitzes, a chemical industry analyst with C. J. Lawrence Inc.
Speculation has persisted about when or whether Du Pont would split off from its Conoco petroleum subsidiary, which is largely independent of its chemical business. And some analysts also said it would make sense for some diversified energy companies, like the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, to spin off their chemical businesses.
But analysts cautioned investors about takeover plays in the chemical industry. The opportunities, and the stocks that analysts recommend, are in companies that are either highly specialized, diversified or have already revamped.
"I would suggest that investors look at the stronger companies that are likely to survive, rather than speculate on who is a takeover candidate," said Leonard Bogner, a chemical industry analyst with Prudential Securities. "Companies that have gotten this far probably see the light at the end of the tunnel."
The chemical industry, like metals and forest products, is tied to the ups and down of business cycles. Traditionally, the industry has cycled up and down every 7 to 10 years. Analysts and industry executives said the current cycle will be longer than expected because of the slow economy in the United States and depressed economies abroad.
Mr. Huntsman said in a telephone interview that the current slump had been difficult to predict and was "one of the worst down rides" he had seen in the chemical industry. His strategy is to keep the chemical companies he acquires privately held. "The chemical industry does not lend itself to having companies go public," he said. "The cycles are just too vicious."
Analysts said Mr. Huntsman's investment could be a gold mine for him if the industry finally moves to boom from bust. But as Mr. Krug of Oppenheimer put it, "I hope he lives that long."

HEADLINE: THE U.N. ASSEMBLY;
In Clinton's Words: U.N. Become Engaged in Every World Conflict

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 27

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's address to the United Nations today:
I have made nonproliferation one of our nation's highest priorities. We intend to weave it more deeply into the fabric of all of our relationships with the world's nations and institutions. We seek to build a world of increasing pressure for nonproliferation, but increasingly open trade and technology for those states that live by accepted international rules. Today, let me describe several new policies that our Government will pursue to stem proliferation. 
 We will pursue new steps to control the materials for nuclear weapons. Growing global stockpiles of plutonium and highly enriched uranium are raising the danger of nuclear terrorism for all nations. We will press for an international agreement that would ban production of these materials for weapons forever.
As we reduce our nuclear stockpiles, the United States has also begun negotiations toward a comprehensive ban on nuclear testing. This summer I declared that to facilitate these negotiations our nation would suspend our testing if all other nuclear states would do the same. Today in the face of disturbing signs, I renew my call on the nuclear states to abide by that moratorium as we negotiate to stop nuclear testing for all time.
 
Controlling Biological Weapons
 I am also proposing new efforts to fight the proliferation of biological and chemical weapons. Today only a handful of nations has ratified the chemical weapons convention. I call on all nations, including my own, to ratify this accord quickly so that it may enter into force by January 13th, 1995.
We will also seek to strengthen the Biological Weapons Convention by making every nation's biological activities and facilities open to more international scrutiny. I am proposing as well new steps to thwart the proliferation of ballistic missiles. Recently, working with Russia, Argentina, Hungary and South Africa, we have made significant progress toward that goal. Now we will seek to strengthen the principles of the Missile Technology Control Regime by transforming it from an agreement on technology transfer among just 23 nations to a set of rules that can command universal adherence.
We will also reform our own system of export controls in the United States to reflect the realities of the post-cold-war world. Where we seek to enlist the support of our former adversaries in the battle against proliferation at the same time that we stop deadly technologies from falling into the wrong hands, we will work with our partners to remove outdated controls that unfairly burden legitimate commerce and unduly restrain growth and opportunity all over the world.
As we work to keep the world's most destructive weapons out of conflicts, we must also strengthen the international community's ability to address those conflicts themselves. For, as we all now know so painfully, the end of the cold war did not bring us to the millennium of peace. Indeed, it simply removed the lid from many cauldrons of ethnic, religious and territorial animosity. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	The United Nations simply cannot become engaged in every one of the world's conflicts. If the American people are to say yes to U.N. peacekeeping, the United Nations must know when to say no. The United Nations must also have the technical means to run a modern world-class peacekeeping operation. We support the creation of a genuine U.N. peacekeeping headquarters with a planning staff, with access to timely intelligence, with a logistics unit that can be deployed on a moment's notice, and a modern operations center with global communications.
And the U.N.'s operations must not only be adequately funded but also fairly funded. Within the next few weeks, the United States will be current in our peacekeeping bill. I have worked hard with the Congress to get this done. I believe the United States should lead the way in being timely in its payments and I will work to continue to see that we pay our bills in full. But I am also committed to work with the United Nations to reduce our nation's assessment for these missions. The assessment system has not been changed since 1973, and everyone in our country knows that our percentage of the world's economic pie is not as great as it was then. Therefore, I believe our rate should be reduced to reflect the rise of other nations that can now bear more of the financial burden. That will make it easier for me as President to make sure we pay in a timely and full fashion. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	As we dream new dreams in this age when miracles now seem possible, let us focus on the lives of those people, and especially on the children who will inherit this world. Let us work with a new urgency and imagine what kind of world we could create for them over the coming generation. Let us work with new energy to protect the world's people from torture and repression. As Secretary of State Christopher stressed at the recent Vienna conference, human rights are not something conditional, bounded by culture, but rather something universal granted by God. This general assembly should create at long last a high commissioner for human rights. I hope you will do it soon and with vigor and energy and conviction.
Let us also work far more ambitiously to fulfill our obligations as custodians of this planet not only to improve the quality of life for our citizens and the quality of our air and water and the earth itself, but also because the roots of conflict are so often entangled with the roots of environmental neglect and the calamities of famine and disease.
During the course of our campaign in the United States last year Vice President Gore and I promised the American people major changes in our nation's policy toward the global environment. Those were promises to keep, and today the United States is doing so.
Today we are working with other nations to build on the promising work of the U.N.'s Commission of Sustainable Development. We are working to make sure that all nations meet their commitments under the Global Climate convention. We are seeking to complete negotiations on an accord to prevent the world's deserts from further expansion. And we seek to strengthen the World Health Organization's efforts to combat the plague of AIDS, which is not only killing millions, but also exhausting the resources of nations that can least afford it. And let us make a new commitment to the world's children.
It is tragic enough that one and a half million children died as a result of wars over the past decade. But it is far more unforgivable that during that same period, 40 million children died from diseases completely preventable with simple vaccines or medicines. Every day -- this day, as we meet here -- over 30,000 of the world's children will die of malnutrition and disease.
Our Unicef director, Jim Grant, has reminded me that each of those children had a name and a nationality, a family, a personality, and a potential. We are compelled to do better by the world's children. Just as our own nation has launched new reforms to ensure that every child has adequate health care, we must do more to get basic vaccines and other treatments for curable diseases to children all over the world. It's the best investment we'll ever make. We can find new ways to ensure that every child grows up with clean, drinkable water, that most precious commodity of life itself. And the U.N. can work even harder to ensure that each child has at least a full primary education, and I mean that opportunity for girls as well as boys.
And to ensure a healthier and more abundant world, we simply must slow the world's explosive growth in population. We cannot afford to see the human race double by the middle of the next century. Our nation has at last renewed its commitment to work with the United Nations to expand the availability of the world's family planning education and services.

HEADLINE: U.S. and Peru at Odds Over Death of Airman

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Sept. 24

 BODY:
The attack on a United States military transport plane by two Peruvian jet fighters in April 1992, in which an American airman was killed, has come back to haunt the Government of President Alberto K. Fujimori and strain relations with the United States.
A foreign aid appropriations bill passed by the Senate on Thursday included an amendment prohibiting the United States from disbursing $100 million in aid planned for the Peruvian Government in the 1994 fiscal year, until Peru settles damage claims with the family of Sgt. Joseph Beard. 
 Sergeant Beard was sucked out of the American C-130 military transport at 20,000 feet off the northern coast of Peru when strafing by Peruvian fighters blew a hole in the fuselage on April 24, 1992. His body has never been found.
The amendment, sponsored by Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, has the support of some Democratic senators, and seems to reflect a desire by some in Congress to use foreign aid to Peru to improve the Fujimori Government's record on human rights and respect for international codes of conduct.
"The desire is not to be punitive with Peru, but there hasn't been any movement on compensating the Beard family for months," a member of Senator Helms's staff said in a telephone interview. "This is a very sensitive issue in the Congress because the death of a United States serviceman is involved, and responsible nations, when this kind of thing happens, do what they can to compensate the families."
The amendment also instructs the United States to urge international lending organizations to withhold loans to Peru until a settlement on the Beard issue is reached.
The case presents thorny issues for Mr. Fujimori and Peru. The Beard family is seeking payment of about $900,000, which an Air Force analysis calculated would be the present value of the sergeant's earning power over his expected lifetime. Peru is offering to pay between $100,000 and $150,000.
In a country with so much poverty, a deep recession and average monthly wages of about $60, a payment of almost $1 million to the family would unleash criticism. There is also fear that if Mr. Fujimori agreed to such a payment, it would cause deep resentment in the armed forces, which still assert that they were justified in shooting at the plane.
Mr. Fujimori repeated the Government's claim that Peru was not responsible for the incident, and that the shooting was provoked by the pilots of the American plane, who refused to communicate with the Peruvian pilots or obey their signals to land. Peru says its pilots feared that the large transport was carrying drugs.
Yet, if the Helms amendment is approved over the next few days by a House-Senate conference committee, Mr. Fujimori will have little choice if Peru is to get the much-needed aid.
Members of Senator Helms's office said Washington attorneys hired by Peru were working hard, and could succeeed, in getting the amendment struck from the bill in a conference committee. But one staff member added that if Peru's lawyers were successful, "You can be sure Senator Helms will put this provision on every bill possible in the future, ad infinitum, until Peru settles with Mrs. Beard."
Peruvian officials say the cooling of tensions between Peru and the United States is important for Mr. Fujimori, since he will attend the United Nations General Assembly to present his case for seizing almost dictatorial powers on April 5, 1992. He shut down the Congress and the courts in an effort to combat corruption and the leftist guerrilla group called the Shining Path.
Though strongly supported by Peruvians, he became almost an international pariah and has been struggling since then to convince Western nations that his actions were his only recourse to prevent the Shining Path from toppling the Government.
In the wake of what is called the Fujimori coup, the United States stopped all but relief aid. When less than three weeks later the Peruvian jets strafed the American C-130, it only added to the acrimony.

HEADLINE: Israel and P.L.O. Have 'a Lot to Do' in Little Time

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Sept. 27

 BODY:
Two weeks after the handshake that stunned the world, Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization are only just beginning to put together the political machinery needed to transform Palestinian self-rule in Israeli-occupied territories from a principle on paper into a reality.
Given the emotional power of the White House signing ceremony on Sept. 13 and the handshake between Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel and Yasir Arafat, chairman of the P.L.O., the subsequent lack of visible movement has caused a letdown among some people on both sides. It is almost as though they had got all dressed up, only to discover they had no place to go. 
 In fact, a period of suspended animation was built into the agreement.
It will not go into effect until Oct. 13, a month after the signing. Then, the two sides will begin negotiating the critical details of their coexistence and the transfer of authority from Israel to the Palestinians, starting in the Gaza Strip and Jericho, on the West Bank.
 
Dec. 13 Deadline Set
 Those negotiations are supposed to last two months, tops -- in other words until no later than Dec. 13, when not only are Israeli troops supposed to begin withdrawing from Gaza and Jericho but also the Israeli military government is to transfer power to Palestinians elsewhere in the West Bank in education and culture, social welfare, health, taxation and tourism.
What is dawning on both sides is the realization that, as one Israeli official put it, "we have a lot to do and not much time to do it in."
And even if the timetables are met, it does not necessarily mean that all authority will shift suddenly from Israel to Palestinians.
"I would not expect any miraculous overnight change," said Hanan Ashrawi, spokeswoman for the Palestinian delegation to the formal Middle East talks. "They're not just going to hand over the keys. I think there will be a period of transition."
 
Site Is Uncertain
 It is not even clear where the negotiations on the details will be held.
Mr. Rabin told his Cabinet on Sunday that he wanted the Gaza-Jericho plan to be negotiated in one of two Egyptian towns in Sinai: El Arish on the Mediterranean or Taba on the Gulf of Aqaba. Both are near the Israeli border, and both were in Israeli hands, as was all of Sinai, from the 1967 war until the 1980's, when Egypt regained control under its 1979 peace treaty with Israel.
At the same time, talks would continue in Washington on less immediate issues -- though no less important ones -- like preparations for the election of a Palestinian council that will supervise the self-rule throughout Gaza and the West Bank. Those elections are to be held no later than next July 13.
Israel and Palestinian officials say specific sites have yet to be decided.
According to Mrs. Ashrawi, the two sides have had quiet contacts since the White House ceremony -- "but nothing official," she added, and nothing that had produced solid agreements.
Two Israeli publications reported in recent days that Israel was preparing to meet a central P.L.O. demand by freeing most of the roughly 11,000 Palestinians held for offenses stemming from the six-year-old anti-Israel uprising. Only some 2,000 prisoners judged to be the most dangerous would still be held, transferred from jails in the occupied territories to prisons inside Israel, The Jerusalem Report magazine said.
On this issue as well, Government spokesmen say no decision has been reached, although they do not reject the idea of a possible prisoner release.
For the rest of the many issues that the negotiators face, nothing is any more clear than it was two weeks ago. Here are a few prominent examples:
*What is Jericho -- the town of 10 square miles, or a much broader district of 146 square miles as defined by Jordanian law before 1967? A compromise seems likely, Palestinians say, perhaps one that gives them control of refugee camps near Jericho but not strategic mountains to the west or the Allenby Bridge to Jordan, to the east.
*How big a police force, and how heavily armed, should the Palestinians have in the territories? Israel's Police Minister, Moshe Shahal, says a 10,000-member force sounds right, but the Palestinians are talking about 20,000 or 30,000. At the start, Mrs. Ashrawi says, there will probably be only "a few thousand."
*How close will economic links be between the territories and far wealthier Israel? Palestinian and Israeli economists say solid ties are necessary to keep Gaza and the West Bank from collapsing, but they add that nationalist considerations may come into play. Mrs. Ashrawi also suggests that may be so, saying the Palestinians do not want to become an appendage to Israel and prefer "to look east and not west."
*When will Mr. Arafat move from Tunis to Gaza or Jericho? A widely circulating rumor is that Mr. Arafat wants to arrive in Jericho by Jan. 1. That raises questions about how he will be protected from Israeli and Palestinian extremists who want him dead.
Whatever happens, it is clear that both sides recognize that they need each other. One sign is an attempt suddenly by senior Israeli officials to portray the once-reviled P.L.O. as a partner that keeps its word. They have pointed out that since The Handshake, any anti-Israel violence has been carried out not by P.L.O. loyalists but the militant Islamic group Hamas.

HEADLINE: THE U.N. ASSEMBLY;
Clinton, at U.N., Lists Stiff Terms For Sending U.S. Force to Bosnia

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 27

 BODY:
President Clinton today laid down a long list of American conditions for sending peacekeeping troops to Bosnia and called on the United Nations to be much more selective about where it sends such troops in the future, saying the United States could not afford to go on subsidizing open-ended missions.
In his first address to the United Nations General Assembly, which has just begun its annual fall session, Mr. Clinton also proposed a worldwide treaty that would ban production of fissile materials for nuclear weapons. But the thrust of his remarks was an appeal to overhaul the peacekeeping machinery of the United Nations and to define more clearly its mission in the post-cold-war world. [Excerpts, page A16.] 
Mr. Clinton made only scant reference to Bosnia in the speech, but at a news conference later he spelled out the terms for American troops' participation in a peacekeeping force there. The President's lengthy list of conditions is likely to fuel questions about whether his Administration will ever actually commit the 25,000 troops it has earmarked for peacekeeping in the Balkans.
Mr. Clinton assured the United Nations that the United States would pay its long overdue $400 million bill for peacekeeping operations and another $400 million in unpaid dues. That money is about to be approved by Congress.
But the President, mindful of Congressional concern about rising United Nations costs, emphasized that the United States would no longer continue supporting peacekeeping operations if the world body did not become more discriminating in the jobs it undertakes and did not lower American dues to reflect the United States' diminished economic status relative to Germany, Japan and other industrial states.
The United States, as a permanent member of the Security Council, has a veto over peacekeeping operations, and it has given its blessing to the 17 such missions now going on. In effect, Mr. Clinton's comments were a warning that the United States would increasingly weigh fiscal considerations among others in deciding whether to support a new operation. This would presumably go some way toward meeting Congressional concerns.
When asked at his news conference about his terms for peacekeeping in Bosnia, Mr. Clinton said:
"I would want a clear understanding what the command and control was. I would want the NATO commander in charge of the operation. I would want a clear timetable for the first review and ultimately for the right to terminate American involvement. I would want a clear political strategy along with a military strategy. After all, there will be more than soldiers involved in this. And I would want a clear expression of support from the United States Congress. Now, there are 20 other operational things I would want, but those are the big policy issues."
The President added that he would also want to know "exactly what our financial responsibilities were."
"We have to know how we are going to fund it," he said, "and then we would have to know that others were going to do their part as well."
Mr. Clinton suggested that such tough criteria should also be adopted by the United Nations.
"The United Nations simply cannot become engaged in every one of the world's conflicts," he said. "If the American people are to say yes to U.N. peacekeeping, the United Nations must know when to say no."
 
U.N. 'Not a Magic Wand'
 After Mr. Clinton's speech, the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, did not sound pleased.
"It must be understood that there will be failures as well as successes," he said at a news conference. "The U.N. is not a magic wand. The problems before us cannot be solved quickly. Staying power is crucial. If the forces of chaos and confusion conclude that the U.N. is short of breath, they will prevail simply by waiting for the world to turn its attention elsewhere."
Mr. Clinton also said he was "committed to work with the U.N." to reduce the United States' share of its budget.
"The assessment system has not been changed since 1973," he said. "And everyone in our country knows that our percentage of the world's economic pie is not as great as it was then. Therefore, I believe our rates should be reduced to reflect the rise of other nations that can now bear more of the financial burden. That will make it easier for me as President to make sure we pay in a timely and full fashion."
America currently pays a 30.4 percent share of the United Nations budget and wants to go down to 25 percent.
 
Speech's Delivery Subdued
 Mr. Clinton's speech seemed to capture his ambivalent impulses on foreign policy. It began with soaring language about Washington's commitment to continued world leadership and ended with a discussion of overdue bills and a warning that the will of the United Nations had begun to outpace the United States wallet.
For anyone who watched Mr. Clinton deliver his speech on health care before a joint session of Congress last Wednesday, today's address from the marble podium of the United Nations sounded flat, with a subdued delivery, few memorable phrases and only one interruption for applause in 45 minutes. Mr. Clinton was clearly much more animated talking about health care at a Queens diner on Sunday than he was today talking to heads of state, foreign ministers and United Nations ambassadors about arms control.
"Domestic renewal is an overdue tonic," Mr. Clinton said. "But isolationism and protectionism are still poison. We must inspire our people to look beyond their immediate fears toward a broader horizon."
"I know many people ask whether the United States plans to retreat or remain active in the world, and if active, to what end," he continued. "Many people are asking that in our own country as well. Let me answer that question as clearly and plainly as I can. The United States plans to remain engaged and to lead."
The major new proposals in the President's speech revolved around what needed to be done to enlarge the family of free-market democracies and protect them from three major post-cold-war threats: weapons proliferation, regional ethnic conflicts and environmental degradation.
 
The Treaty Clinton Wants
 "We will pursue new steps to control the materials for nuclear weapons," Mr. Clinton said. "Growing global stockpiles of plutonium and highly enriched uranium are raising the danger of nuclear terrorism for all nations. We will press for an international agreement that would ban production of these materials for weapons forever."
Aides said that the President envisions a treaty that prohibits the production of highly enriched uranium or plutonium for nuclear explosives purposes outside of international safeguards.
In addition, Mr. Clinton said, "as we reduce our nuclear stockpiles, the United States has also begun negotiations toward a comprehensive ban on nuclear testing."
"This summer I declared that to facilitate these negotiations, our nation would suspend our testing if all other nuclear states would do the same."
Then, in what Presidential aides said was a clear warning to China, which intelligence reports suggest is preparing a nuclear test, Mr. Clinton added, "Today, in the face of disturbing signs, I renew my call on the nuclear states to abide by that moratorium as we negotiate to stop nuclear testing for all time."
 
U.N. Overhaul Is Asked
 To confront the threat of regional conflicts, Mr. Clinton called for an overhaul of the United Nations, including the establishment of a command and control center at the United Nations to keep track of its 80,000 peacekeeping troops now spread out in 17 operations on four continents and a general rethinking of the United Nations' peacekeeping role.
"In recent weeks in the Security Council," he said, "our nation has begun asking harder questions about proposals for new peacekeeping missions. Is there a real threat to international peace? Does the proposed mission have clear objectives? Can an exit point be identified for those who will be asked to participate? How much will the mission cost? From now on, the United Nations should address these and other hard questions for every proposed mission before we vote and before the mission begins."
At a news conference after his private talks with Japan's new Prime Minister, Morihiro Hosokawa, Mr. Clinton was asked to be more specific about what United Nations operations he would oppose.
"I wouldn't say that any of the peacekeeping operations here are ill-founded," Mr. Clinton said. "But there are limits to how many things we can do. There are going to be a lot of chaotic situations. We had another development in Georgia today. And we may or may not be able to see the U.N. go into every one of these circumstances. That's the only point I wanted to make.
"In Somalia, I think we did go in with our eyes open. I think we did essentially what we meant to do. I just think we may have underestimated the difficulty of setting in motion a political transition."
On reforming the United Nations, Mr. Clinton said he fully endorsed efforts by Mr. Boutros-Ghali to reduce the organization's bureaucracy.
"Now we must all do even more to root out waste," the President said. "Before this General Assembly is over, let us establish a strong mandate for an Office of Inspector General so that it can attain a reputation for toughness, for integrity, for effectiveness. Let us build new confidence among our people that the United Nations is changing with the needs of our times."

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN;
Job Losses in Health Plan Are Denied

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27

 BODY:
Recognizing that in this day and age the econometric study is mightier than the sword, the Clinton Administration has begun fighting back against reports concluding that its health care plan will cause huge job losses.
One study, largely financed by companies that do not provide health insurance for their employees, asserts that requiring employers to pay for health coverage would wipe out 3.1 million jobs. Another study, sponsored by the National Federation of Independent Business, a small-business lobbying group, estimates that such costs would put 12.7 million jobs at risk and cause one million layoffs. 
 Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said in an interview that the studies were "incorrect," adding, "They're based on questionable assumptions and they didn't factor in our subsidies for small business."
Gene Sperling, an assistant to the President for economic policy, called the studies "bogus" and "inaccurate."
 
Research Called Sloppy
 And in a letter to the study estimating 3.1 million lost jobs, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers, sounded like the economics professor she used to be as she chided the authors for what she viewed as sloppy research. She said, for example, that the study ignored how the plan would hold down health costs for companies large and small, enabling them to expand.
These officials also said the studies overlooked how President Clinton's plan might create hundreds of thousands of new jobs in certain areas by, for example, expanding home-based health care.
"There are some things in the plan we think will increase employment," Ms. Tyson said in an interview. "There are some factors that will reduce employment, and there are things that would change the composition of employment. When we weigh all these things, we believe the net effect on the total of jobs will be small."
 
'Dr. Kevorkian Prescription'
 Republicans have seized on the studies as Exhibit No. 1 to oppose that part of Mr. Clinton's plan to require all businesses to pay part of the cost of insurance for their employees.
"We're likely to lose 3.1 million jobs because of this plan," said Representative Dick Armey of Texas, chairman of the House Republican Conference. "The plan is really a Dr. Kevorkian prescription for the jobs of American working men and women."
As so often happens when Government proposes a new burden on employers, business lobbyists are howling -- not that the mandate will eat into their profits (that wins little sympathy), but that it will force them to lay off their workers.
Small-business opponents of the plan requiring employers to buy health coverage make a straightforward economics argument: it would increase the cost of labor. And when labor becomes more expensive, employers are not able to afford as much of it. The result: layoffs and fewer new hirings, especially among low-wage workers.
"From what I'm hearing from businesses, my anecdotal instincts tell me that the estimate of three million job losses is a low number," said Richard Berman, executive director of the Employment Policies Institute, a business-backed research organization that sponsored the study estimating 3.1 million jobs would be lost. "There are over 700,000 restaurants in the U.S.; if each restaurant cuts back one job on average, that gives you almost 25 percent of the total."
 
Small-Business Subsidies
 The Administration's biggest complaint with the studies is that they ignore the subsidies to help small businesses afford insurance premiums. When two professors from Baruch College, June and Dave O'Neill, did the study for the Employment Policies Institute, they estimated that small, low-wage companies like restaurants and retailers that do not now offer insurance would have to spend more than $4,000 per worker in health care premiums for many low-wage workers, equal to more than 30 percent of their wages.
Administration officials note that the President's plan would place a ceiling on what businesses pay. Under the plan, many small businesses with low-wage workers would receive Federal subsidies, so they would pay no more than 3.5 percent of their payrolls.
"For a worker earning the minimum wage of $4.25 an hour, our cap would cost just 15 cents an hour more," Secretary Reich said. "That shouldn't cause much in the way of layoffs."
Ms. O'Neill and Wilbur Steger, an author of the study estimating a loss of one million jobs, conceded that the figures they used differed from those in the plan announced by the President. But they said they made the best estimates they could with the information available.
The two economists contended that the Clinton plan would cause far greater job losses among small businesses than the Administration predicts. They said the Administration would have problems finding money to pay for the tens of billions of dollars in subsidies planned for small businesses.
In early versions of the Clinton plan, before the subsidies were added, Administration officials estimated that the requirement that employers buy health coverage might cause small businesses to lay off 200,000 to 700,000 workers. But with the subsidies, one official estimated it would cost about 150,000 jobs at small businesses that do not now provide health insurance.
"That represents one month's worth of job creation," one Administration economist said. "Isn't that worth it when what we gain in return is health security for all Americans and an end to spiraling health care costs?"

SECTION: Section D; Page 26; Column 1; Style Desk; Fashion Page

LENGTH: 1024 words

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By Amy M. Spindler

 BODY:

Squeezing Models' Fees
Picking on models is like shooting fish in a barrel. Few want to drum up sympathy for people who are beautiful, are fodder for gossip columnists, travel to exotic places and can earn $10,000 a day until they retire to marry rock stars. 
 Of course, $10,000 a day is outrageous. Absurd.
Until someone pays it. Then it is the fair market price.
Now, American designers are trying to tinker with that market. Women's Wear Daily, the trade newspaper, reported last week on secret meetings on model pay scales held by the Seventh on Sixth Corporation, the group formed to organize a showing of New York collections in Bryant Park from Oct. 31 to Nov. 6. The meetings were attended by Fern Mallis, executive director of the Council of Fashion Designers of America, as well as by modeling agency representatives and designers like Calvin Klein, Donna Karan, Isaac Mizrahi and Nicole Miller.
The designers, complaining that models are the single biggest cost they incur in staging runway extravaganzas, want to force agencies to cut fees from $750 an hour to $250.
"It's not a restraint-of-trade issue," Ms. Mallis said. "We're working closely with attorneys. Seventh on Sixth is an organization for this purpose."
Ms. Mallis said costs for all runway-show services, from electricity to tent design, are negotiated. The difference is that with models, fees are based on a combination of the client's ability to pay and the status of the model. So the designers most affected by model costs aren't the young upstarts, who often barter clothes for fees, but the big names.
Some in the design industry say there are plenty more pertinent issues for Seventh on Sixth to take on.
"It takes you an hour to cross Sixth Avenue now," said Bud Konheim, president of Nicole Miller. "Imagine crossing by Bryant Park with 2,000 cars trying to make a show on time."
Mr. Konheim said of the show organizers: "Everything they're doing is great, but they're trying to handle too many things. As far as I'm concerned you pay models what they ask or you don't use them. If a model asks us for $10,000, we have to pass because we can't afford it."
Bethann Hardison, a former model and owner of the Bethann Management Company, said: "There are young women you represent that work for $150 an hour and some that are $750 an hour. It goes the gamut. Runway costs don't begin and end with the cost of models. You can have a show and do it all kinds of ways."
Ms. Karan said in Women's Wear Daily: "I have a problem giving young people that kind of money. It's immoral."
Some people feel the same way about paying $2,000 for a dress. What do they do about it? They don't buy it.
There is something unsettling about an industry trying to save money through monopoly tactics.
Why should some models get $10,000 for a day's work? Because in a free market economy they sometimes can. Just as some designers get $2,000 for a dress because they can.
 
Hollywood Deconstruction
 Designers can only dream about models who illustrate their vision as convincingly as the leading lady of the new film by Tim Burton, who also directed "Batman Returns." Sally, the female lead of the new film, "Nightmare Before Christmas," is so deconstructed that her hands and legs detach with the yank of a thread. Her dress is the rough-sewn patchwork sort that has been appearing regularly on runways, a trapezoid of tweed here, a swatch of stripe there.
Three years in the making, "Nightmare Before Christmas" is an elaborate stop-action animation movie, and the beguiling Sally is a 15-inch painted puppet molded from latex.
"Tim Burton, let's face it, he's into stitches," said Kelly Asbury, an assistant art director who worked on the Sally character. "You saw it on Catwoman in 'Batman Returns.' Sally was a rag doll-slash-cadaver, and the stitching goes along with that. She sews her own clothes, and she's made her wardrobe from scraps of cloth. The idea was, since she's scraps of flesh, why not make her clothes from scraps?"
"Maybe Sally will help that deconstruction movement go forward," Mr. Asbury said. "She's actually the epitome of grunge, because she's made of nothing but scrap inside and out."
 
African Silhouette
 The Nigerian-born Lola Faturoti doesn't have just her name on the label of her clothes in Charivari. Outlined like a thrown shadow is her elegant silhouette. "I wanted it to be clear that this is an African woman who designed this line," she said.
Like another rising African star, Lamine Kouyate, Ms. Faturoti has strong memories of childhood: "My granny designed for the village, and she would make me pick out panels of fabric to stitch together to add to something she was making. As a kid, I hated doing it, but it gave me a real knowledge of fabric." Her collection in Charivari is a mix of muted, dour shades, and fabrics shiny enough to draw a magpie.
Ms. Faturoti is a Charivari saleswoman being nurtured, like Marc Jacobs once was, by the store while she sews clothes in her apartment. A regular customer, Holly Solomon, is giving her gallery to Ms. Faturoti for her first runway show, on Oct. 28.
 
Pinning Down Punk
 Gianni Versace is putting his stamp on the return of punk, right down to the safety pins, which he's designed with his signature Medusa's head.
"There is plenty that is classic Versace, very safe and very nice," he said, calling from Milan, where he is preparing the collection for its show next Sunday. "But there will be little punk details. When it's punk, it's very colorful punk, never black like it used to be when kids started it in London." In honor of the subtle touches, Mr. Versace's sister and muse, Donatella, will give a punk party after the show. The invitation calls for black leather, which is experiencing its own revival.
"Punk was a revolution when it started," Mr. Versace said. "Today, you can't talk of revolution. You talk of attitude. This is a mixture between royalty and punk everyone can wear, like a black pullover with a Medusa pin, very designer."
He added: "This is a fresh summer punk. Nothing to do with old punk."

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

The Media Business
CBS conceded defeat in its struggle to win payment from cable TV systems that carry the signals of its broadcast stations. Cable carriers have turned down three ideas from the network for new channels. [Page D1.]

 International
When Spain was booming in the 1980's, Kuwait plowed $5 billion in investment into the country. Now Spain's boom has turned to bust, and the Kuwaiti investment has become the object of countless lawsuits over how the money disappeared. [D1.]

Maurizio Gucci agreed to surrender to Investcorp his remaining share in the Italian fashion company his grandfather founded. Investcorp is an investment bank based in Bahrain. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Bahrain Group Wins Battle With Gucci for Full Control

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, Sept. 27

 BODY:
Maurizio Gucci, renowned through the world for loafers and lawsuits, agreed today to surrender his remaining share in the fashion goods company his grandfather founded to an investment bank that has sought full control of the company.
The announcement, in a joint statement by Mr. Gucci and Investcorp, a Bahrain-based merchant bank, ends a drawn-out feud for control of Gucci, whose horse-bit shoe buckles and double-G logo provided the original paradigm for designer labels. For Italians, depressed by a web of political and business scandals, the surrender of Gucci appeared to signal the loss of one of the nation's crown jewels. 
 Mr. Gucci and Investcorp said they had reached a "friendly and amicable solution" for the bank to acquire Mr. Gucci's 50 percent share in the business. But the pact brought to an end a tangled legal drama, with suits and countersuits, charges of mismanagement and breach of trust that wore down Gucci executives and brought repeated pressures on the company's financial state.
Neither Mr. Gucci nor Investcorp, which is owned by investors throughout the Arab world, would say how much money would change hands. The Financial Times reported that Investcorp paid $170 million, about what it paid in 1988 and 1989 for an initial 50 percent stake in Gucci, but the figure could not be confirmed.
Gucci, with headquarters in Milan, Italy, was founded in Florence in 1922 by Maurizio Gucci's grandfather, Guccio Gucci. It sells apparel, leather goods and accessories that it manufactures in its own workshops or under licensing and marketing agreements.
In recent months, with the recession biting into sales of the company's luxury items, and legal struggles crimping its management, the bloom has been off Gucci's rose. To stanch the losses, Mr. Gucci brought in fresh faces, like Dawn Mello, the former president and driving fashion force at Bergdorf Goodman in New York. The company also set up a new design team around Richard Lambertson, a New Yorker and formerly an assistant to Geoffrey Beene. At a news conference this summer, Gucci announced it had trimmed its net loss in 1992 to the equivalent of $17 million, from $25 million a year earlier.
Analysts who took a closer look at the agreement today concluded that the Guccis had behaved like many other Italian family-owned concerns. The efforts to clean up the business came after decades of dithering, complicated by refusals to take the company public, and bitter Gucci family quarreling that included a 1988 Milan court conviction of Maurizio Gucci for attempted tax fraud.
In the end, Investcorp, which also owns stakes in Chaumet of Paris and Saks Fifth Avenue, lost patience with Mr. Gucci. In July, it filed suits in New York State Supreme Court charging that Mr. Gucci violated shareholder agreements by running the business as though he alone owned it, and by pledging his own shares in collateral for millions of dollars in personal loans.
Besides the suits with Investcorp, Mr. Gucci has been entangled in legal proceedings with Gucci America, the United States unit, which accounts for roughly half the group's business.
Today's announcement said Mr. Gucci would surrender all management and supervisory functions within the group, though he would be retained as a "senior adviser" to Investcorp's chairman and chief executive, Nemir Kirdar, a former Chase Manhattan banker. That move may have sweetened the pill financially for Mr. Gucci by providing annual consultancy fees.
The announcement also said that legal disputes between Gucci America and the Gucci group in Italy "will also be resolved promptly."
Investcorp said it planned to inject fresh capital into Gucci and to reorganize the group into a "cohesive worldwide organization."
In August, cash flow problems related to the legal battles forced Gucci to delay by up to a week pay to its 800 Italian employees.

HEADLINE: Administration Plans New Export Initiative

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27

 BODY:
President Clinton is about to introduce an aggressive national export policy aimed at using 19 Federal agencies to help manufacturers compete in foreign markets, Administration officials said today.
The new policy calls for a quick lifting of controls on some high-technology exports, the opening of Federal export assistance offices and more overseas lobbying by the President and Cabinet officials on behalf of American companies. 
 The policy calls for a redirection of Federal export credits toward manufacturers, but not until the 1995 fiscal year. Ronald H. Brown, Commerce Secretary, said that the money for industry would not necessarily come from Agriculture Department export programs. But he acknowledged, "About 80 percent of our export promotion dollars have been spent on agricultural products, which represent 10 percent of our exports."
Shifting export finance money to manufacturing would require Congressional approval, something that has stymied past efforts by legislators from industrial states. Large sums of export assistance money, mostly for American farm products, could be freed up if a world trade agreement is reached this year.
And if the White House gives its assent in the next two days, the export policy will also include the creation of a new lending program to help American exporters with low-interest, long-term loans.
President Clinton is scheduled to announce the plan, dubbed the National Export Strategy, at a White House ceremony on Wednesday.
The plan will especially benefit small-business owners and Californians, two groups in which the Administration wants to rebuild political support. Small businesses have led criticisms of the President's health plan, while Mr. Clinton's public approval ratings have plunged in California as the economy there remains more sluggish than that of the nation.
California companies account for 40 percent of all requests to the Commerce Department for permission to export computers and other high-technology products that may have military applications. They have been among the leaders in an corporate lobbying effort this summer for a relaxation of export controls.
To help small and medium-sized businesses, the Administration also plans to set up at least four export assistance offices outside Washington, most likely in state capitals, and hopes to expand to as many as 60 offices within a year. The Commerce Department, the Export-Import Bank of the United States and the Small Business Administration will provide information and process applications for export financing at the offices, which will be intended to help businesses without staffs in Washington.
Large corporations currently account for two-thirds of American exports. With the export initiative, Mr. Brown said, "this Administration has demonstrated beyond any doubt that it will stand shoulder to shoulder with American business."
The President alluded to one element of the plan in his speech at the United Nations today, when he indicated that the United States would eliminate many controls on American high-technology exports to former Eastern bloc countries.
An interagency committee has recommended that as part of the National Export Strategy, the White House should create a new lending program at the Ex-Im Bank that would provide long-term, low-interest loans to American exporters, matching similar programs overseas. But the recommendation was not unanimous, and the White House has not yet made a decision, said Kenneth Brody, the president of the Ex-Im Bank, which is a Federal agency.
 
Controversy on Financing
 The lending program is a contentious issue because several Administrations have sought to limit similar programs abroad, contending that they amount to government subsidies that distort international markets. Mr. Brody said this afternoon that by creating such a program in the United States, the Clinton Administration would have more influence in seeking international limits on such lending.
The Bush Administration negotiated a 24-nation pact two years ago that set broad limits on subsidized export finance programs. Mr. Brody and Mr. Brown said that the new American program, if instituted, would comply with the pact.
Most loans by the Export-Import Bank are now made at market interest rates with short maturities.
With the exception of the possible lending program, much of the initiative represents a continuation and expansion of Bush Administration efforts. For example, the number of export shipments subject to Commerce Department controls has already fallen by three-quarters in the last seven years, as a succession of Commerce Secretaries have decided that many exports no longer pose a national security risk with the end of the cold war.
But many American companies and trade experts have contended for years that the United States is less effective than its trading rivals in promoting exports, costing American jobs in the process. Mr. Brody said that the National Export Strategy was too broad to be considered a continuation of the Bush Administration's less coordinated efforts.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Make New Gains

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Treasury prices shot higher yesterday and yields fell as traders and investors seemed to focus on the positive story for the bond market: continued slow growth and low inflation.
The mood swing was enough to push the yield on the 30-year bond below 6 percent again, just four trading days after selling had pushed the yield up to 6.12 percent. 
 But just as the selloff last Tuesday was not enough to convince analysts to declare an end to the bond rally that pushed yields to 25-year lows, yesterday's buying was not enough to make anyone conclude that the market was back on track.
 
Long Bond Yielding 5.94%
 "For the whole first half of the year, and through Sept. 15, we have has a market with interest rates trending down," said John Costas, managing director for government trading and sales at the First Boston Corporation. "Now it is a trendless market. And you will have these ebbs and flows." Sept. 15 was the day after the bond market was jolted by an unexpected three-tenths of a percent increase in the Consumer Price Index for August.
The price of the 30-year bond was up 18/32 point as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 5.94 percent, from 6.03 percent on Friday. The yield on the 10-year note dropped to 5.28 percent from 5.38 percent, and the yield on the two-year note fell to 3.78 percent from 3.88 percent.
The yield on the 30-year bond is now within easy striking distance of the 25-year closing low of 5.86 percent that it touched on Sept. 8. A rise of just 15/32 point in the price of the bond would bring the yield back to that low. That is less than the price jumped yesterday.
The yields of Treasury notes are also now near their recent lows. The 25-year low of 5.22 percent on the 10-year note was reached on Sept. 8. And the recent low on the two-year note, of 3.69 percent, was hit on Sept. 3.
But Mr. Costas thinks that once these levels are neared, the market will sell off again, while investors wait for the September employment report, due on Oct. 8, and the September consumer inflation data, due on Oct. 15. Those reports will indicate whether the low-inflation, slow-growth pattern that propelled the rally is still a good bet.
The positive mood yesterday was, in part, a result of a report on Friday that the Federal Reserve had shifted in its August policy-making meeting to a neutral stand on short-term interest rates from its bias toward raising short-term rates that it established in May. The shift was disclosed in minutes, released on Friday, of the August meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee.
The shift especially helped short-term Treasury notes, as it removed any lingering concern that the Fed might move soon to raise short-term interest rates. It also signaled that the Fed was comfortable again with the inflation outlook. The Fed's short-term interest rate target of 3 percent has been unchanged for more than a year.
The policy shift also seemed to help the weekly Treasury auction of three-and six-month bills. The average discount rate of 2.90 percent for the three-month bill and 3.02 percent for the six-month bill were both the lowest since the May 10 auction.
But while this policy shift could help shorter maturities, it was a little more difficult for some analysts to explain why prices were up so much in the long end of the market. "I am a little surprised that the long end of the market took such a leap today," said Elliott Platt, director of economic research at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
 
Speculation About Brazil
 Some traders attributed the rally to speculation that Brazil was buying 30-year bonds to turn them into zero-coupon bonds to be used as collateral in a debt deal with commercial banks. But the Finance Minister of Brazil, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, said in Washington that the country would not be buying these bonds in the secondary market but would get them in a special private deal from the United States Treasury.
Mr. Costas of First Boston noted that the Brazilians, if they were buying the bonds in the secondary market, would be unlikely to say so publicly, effectively raising the price they would have to pay.
Further buttressing the long bond was a decline in the Commodity Research Bureau index of commodities, a barometer of inflationary pressures. It fell as much as two points during the day.
Still, at least one forecaster, Mr. Platt of Donaldson, Lufkin, was unwilling to conclude that inflation has been tamed. He is predicting that when the report is released on Friday, the index of leading economic indicators for August will spike nine-tenths of a percent, the largest monthly increase since December. This kind of jump could prompt selling because the buying today seemed to be based on an assumption that the economy is still moving sluggishly ahead and inflation is sticking around 3 percent.
Following are the results from the Treasury auction yesterday of three-month and six-month bills:
