HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
A Road to Pure Water Paved With Anxieties

BYLINE: By George Judson

DATELINE: MARGARETVILLE, N.Y.

 BODY:
LEONARD UTTER has a fat scrapbook of photographs to remind him of his hometown and of the way life used to be. But lately he doesn't need the pictures. With drought lowering reservoirs throughout the Catskills, all he has to do is drive to the end of his road and walk through the woods and look down on the flat, dry bottom of the upper Pepacton Reservoir.
There he can see the foundations of houses that once made up Arena, the village where Utters lived for generations until New York City came and destroyed the community to build the reservoir. Some images never fade. He and his wife, Betty, still see the smoke billowing out of the valley of the East Branch of the Delaware River in 1953, as Arena's bulldozed homes were burned. 
 "I'm very bitter," Mr. Utter said. "The land under the reservoir was the very best land, the bottom land. When the Pepacton was filled, and then the Cannondale, they cut the heart right out of Delaware County."
New York City is much on the minds of people in the Catskills these days as it moves to adopt new regulations to protect the water that drains into its reservoirs. The regulations also will affect large areas east of the Hudson, but it is here that the memories are strongest, the anxieties greatest, the opposition loudest.
It is here, in a sparsely populated mountain region where New York shades into Appalachia, that people can imagine what is inconceivable in the settled suburbs of Westchester: that the city, in its pursuit of pure water, could break their tenuous grip on the land.
"A lot of those people were never seen again," Mr. Utter said of Arena's residents. "The older people, undoubtedly, suffered the worst. Sure they were compensated for their homes, but they had no reason to move. They didn't want to move. A lot of them didn't live too much longer."
This time, New York City is not seeking to displace anyone. To avoid a Federal order to build a filtration plant costing billions, it needs to insure that people within its vast watersheds do not pollute the source of the drinking water for nine million people in the city and neighboring communities.
Sewage treatment plants and septic systems must work properly. Manure and fertilizer can't wash off farms into rivers. When it rains, parking lots shouldn't flush their debris into streams.
No one here is opposed to clean water. "It's our water first," said Michael Finberg, who owns the bowling alley on Route 28 in tiny Arkville. "We drink it. We wash in it."
But it requires almost an act of imagination, in addition to a three-hour drive, to go from the city to the source of its water and to understand how the people here live. David Taylor invited the city's Environmental Commissioner, Albert F. Appleton, to his dairy farm to show him what one rule would mean.
The rule called for farm fields to end 200 feet from the nearest stream. On hillside farms like the Taylors's, brooks run down many fields. Mr. Appleton could see what removing 400-foot swaths would do to a farm, and his department threw out its farm rules and began working with farmers on a new approach.
"They thought we were shoveling our manure directly into streams, but most farmers today are pretty good environmentalists," Mr. Taylor said.
Mr. Appleton is generally considered sympathetic, for someone from the city. But people worry that the New Yorkers he answers to, the budget officials and the Brooklyn politicians and the world-famous man on the street, don't know or care what a sewage treatment plant could cost a village like Fleischmanns, a village of 351 whose Main Street hangs over the Bushkill.
The city says it will help pay for what needs to be done. In Delaware County, where 47,000 people are spread over 1,460 square miles (imagine Manhattan if it had only 800 people), the city said it would pay for improvements to the plant in nearby Hobart, but not the extra $20,000 a year needed to operate the plant. What is $20,000 to the city? What is it to a village of 400?
"That got across the county in half a day," Mr. Taylor said.
Nearly 30 percent of the county receives some form of public assistance. Property taxes can be high. Residents doubt that the profligate city understands how thinly they are stretched, how small a margin keeps them on their land.
Mr. Finberg is the designated optimist for Middletown, which includes Margaretville and Fleischmanns. He leads a committee drafting a plan for the town, with the city's financial help, to protect both its water and its economic life.
He says the city and the watershed towns must work together. It may help that he is not a native, that he never saw the lost villages. He finds it hard to believe that one community, today, could destroy another.
"Fleischmanns is right there on the stream," he said. "What are we going to do, shut Fleischmanns down? That's ridiculous."

HEADLINE: Bonds Help to Lift Stocks; Dow Rises 24.59

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
After a trading week in which the Dow Jones industrial average suffered its worst loss in more than seven months, stocks were pushed higher yesterday by a sharp increase in bond prices.
The Dow closed at 3,567.70, up 24.59, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index closed at 461.80, up 4.17. For the third day in a row, the Nasdaq composite index hit a record high, closing at 759.95, up 5.30. 
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange eased to 244.9 million shares, from 248.3 million shares on Friday. Advancing stocks topped decliners, 13 to 7.
Analysts said that the surge in stock prices followed the rise in the price of bonds and the corresponding fall in bond yields. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond dropped yesterday to 5.94 percent from 6.03 percent Friday. These advances came, moreover, despite the uncertainty over the political battle in Russia between President Boris N. Yeltsin and Parliament.
"The catalyst was the announcement by the Federal Reserve that it was pursuing a neutral monetary policy," said John H. Shaughnessy, senior vice president of Advest, Inc. "There had been a fear that the Fed might tighten up."
Mr. Shaughnessy said that "if short-term rates stay at around 3 percent, it will be positive for equities," adding, "So the market breathed a sigh of relief yesterday."
Oil stocks enjoyed one of the day's strongest rallies, after reports that OPEC had agreed to an oil production ceiling in the fourth quarter of 24.5 million barrels a day. The members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are currently producing at a level of 24.7 million barrels a day.
Among the big oil companies showing gains were Chevron, up 2 1/8, to 93 1/4; Amoco, up 1, to 55; Royal Dutch Petroleum, up 1 3/8, to 100 1/4, and British Petroleum, up 1 1/2, to 57 5/8.
Many stocks in other groups that benefit from low-interest rates also advanced yesterday. For example, prices of regional banking companies increased, including Shawmut, up 1, to 26; Signet, up1/4, to 33 1/2; Keycorp, up 1/2, to 38 1/8, and PNC, up 7/8, to 30 1/2.
Similarly, some of the multiline insurance companies were higher. Among them were American International Group, which rose 2 1/4, to 99 1/2, and Cigna, up 1, to 64 1/4.
Another gainer was Motorola, which closed at 102 1/2, up 3. In conjunction with two other companies, the big semiconductor manufacturer announced a new product and a new development system
But the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company moved against the tide, falling 1 to 26 3/4. The supermarket chain's earnings for its fiscal second quarter dropped to 15 cents a share from 20 cents a share in the period a year ago -- and below the median analyst forecast of 25 cents a share.
Also declining were the Mead Corporation and Alco Standard after Merrill Lynch downgraded its investment rating on the two companies. Mead dropped 1/2, to 42 1/8, while Alco Standard fell 3, to 43 1/4.

HEADLINE: Missing Millions -- Kuwait's Bad Bet -- A special report.;
Big Wallets and Little Supervision

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MADRID

 BODY:
During the late 1980's, when Spain was booming, Kuwait came shopping for corporations and investments, got a little carried away and plowed $5 billion into paper, chemical and fertilizer companies, as well as two leaning office towers whose bizarre silhouette dominates the Madrid skyline.
But now Spain's boom has turned to bust, the Kuwaiti corporate flagship here is in receivership, many of its businesses have closed, more than 20,000 jobs have been lost and the office towers are not even completed much less occupied. As for the investment, it has become the object of countless lawsuits disputing how the money disappeared. 
 Kuwaiti authorities contend that between $500 million and $1 billion was stolen, and the balance of the $5 billion squandered through egregious mismanagement, in what amounts to Europe's biggest financial scandal since the collapse of Robert Maxwell's media empire in 1991.
Much fog still surrounds what has become known in Spain as the KIO scandal (pronounced KEY-oh), after the Kuwait Investment Office.
At the center of the scandal is a sprawling Spanish conglomerate called Grupo Torras managed by a maverick Spanish financier with a dubious record named Javier De la Rosa. Over a six-year period, from 1986 to 1992, the London-based KIO put about $5 billion of Kuwait's oil wealth into building Torras.
Now, Grupo Torras has filed for protection from its creditors and is being run by court-appointed administrators. Its main holdings -- the largest Spanish chemical group, Ercros, the biggest paper producer, Torras-Papel, and the real estate group Prima -- lie in ruins.
A lawsuit filed on April 14 in London by the law firm of Baker & McKenzie, America's largest, on behalf of the new Kuwaiti management of Grupo Torras, was made available to The New York Times. The suit contends that through the use of various shell companies, fictitious loans, fraud and embezzlement, the former Torras management conspired to steal at least $500 million between May 1988 and May 1992.
The main targets of the suit are the former chairman of KIO, Sheik Fahad Mohammed al-Sabah, who is a cousin of the Emir of Kuwait and is now living in the Bahamas; Fouad Khaled Jaffar, the former general manager of the investment office, who is in London, and Mr. De La Rosa, a director of Torras and the mastermind of its investments.
"There is enormous anger here at this scandal and a feeling that money was just stolen," said Abdallah al-Nobari, an opposition leader of the Kuwaiti Parliament. "It seems that some members of the Kuwaiti royal family just helped themselves in a financial grab equivalent to Saddam Hussein's invasion."
 
The Damage
Unfinished Towers Become a Symbol
 The havoc wreaked on the Spanish economy is enormous. From his 11th-floor office at the Economy Ministry, where he oversees foreign transactions, Fernando Eguidazu looks out on the two immense, unfinished office towers hovering over the Paseo de la Castellana, the Park Avenue of Madrid. Named "the gateway of Europe," and conceived as showpieces of Spain's boom, the towers now stand as symbols of the Spanish bust.
"Even if the towers were rebuilt," Mr. Eguidazu said, with a moroseness that has become uniform in Spain as the economy has dived, "what the hell would you do with them?"
In a city full of shuttered restaurants and "For Rent" signs on office blocks, there is no ready answer. But for the Kuwaiti officials and their lawyers seeking to discover just what became of their multibillion-dollar Spanish investments, the fate of the $283 million towers is a mere detail in a mind-boggling disaster.
What these officials want is justice and, if possible, a few billion dollars back.
Unlike the Kuwait Investment Office's previous conservative investments in blue-chip companies like Daimler-Benz of Germany, its Spanish operation was restlessly aggressive. Starting as a troubled paper company, Torras quickly grew into one of Spain's largest industrial conglomerates and an active player in the country's surging stock market. At the same time, KIO made heavy investments in British Petroleum in London that have now placed the organization at the center of a separate tax-fraud scandal.
 
Plaintiff's Version
 Two opposing versions of Kuwait's Spanish debacle exist. The first -- whose essence is that Kuwait was heavily defrauded over several years in a Spanish scam coordinated between KIO in London and Mr. De La Rosa in Spain -- is outlined in the London lawsuit.
"We intend to follow the London suit with other suits in Spain," said Sara Blazquez, a spokeswoman for the new Kuwaiti management of Grupo Torras. "Our best estimate is that about $950 million was simply stolen and is in the pocket of somebody. The balance of the $5 billion investment was lost through colossal mismanagement. Kuwait was robbed by its people at the KIO working with Mr. De La Rosa."
 
Defendant's View
Kuwaiti Politics Gets the Blame
 That account of events is vigorously contested by the 45-year-old Mr. De la Rosa, who left Torras in May 1992 to resume his financial activities in the Barcelona area.
Sitting on a salmon-colored sofa in his luxurious Madrid apartment, Mr. De la Rosa insisted between meditative puffs on a soggy Havana clutched in his tremulous hand that he was an innocent victim in a political plot.
He said that opposition figures in Kuwait, bolstered by their electoral gains last year, grew determined to attack the Kuwaiti royal family by implicating them in the Spanish disaster. Chief among their targets were the former KIO chairman, Sheik Fahad, and the Finance Minister during the gulf war, Sheik Ali al-Khalifa al-Sabah, who then oversaw KIO's activities. The two men, who are first cousins, are members of the royal family.
"I am just one way for these people to attack the Emir and his cousins," Mr. De la Rosa declared.
 
Making $40 Million
 He added that he had acted throughout on instructions from KIO in London and had done nothing illegal. His personal profits from his dealings with the Kuwaitis amounted to $40 million over six years -- "not bad, I agree," -- earned legitimately, he insisted, through commissions paid to his personal investment group, Quail Espana, for investment advice to Grupo Torras.
Mr. De la Rosa's case has gained some support in Spain. Three attempts by lawyers hired by Kuwait to bring criminal charges for embezzlement, falsification of accounts and other crimes against the Spanish financier and the former London-based management of KIO have been rejected by a Barcelona judge. An appeal is pending.
 
Official View
Madrid Says, 'We Told You So'
 An investigation into the Kuwaiti disaster by the Spanish Government has also disclosed no irregularities, although stock exchange authorities are still investigating.
Almost all the Kuwaiti investments in Spain were made through two Amsterdam-registered companies, Koolmes Holdings B.V. and Kokmeeuw Holdings B.V., owned by the Kuwait Investment Office through other companies registered in the Dutch Antilles. Because the Netherlands, like Spain, is a member of the European Community, there were no restrictions on investments by these two Dutch companies.
"Opposition politicians here have tried to blame the Socialist Government for the fiasco," said Mr. Eguidazu, the Economy Ministry official, "but there was no official means to control these investments. Moreover, the Spanish Government warned the Kuwait Investment Office early on that Mr. De la Rosa was not reliable. The KIO replied that how they invested was up to them and nothing to do with the Spanish Government. So when the Kuwaitis claimed they were cheated, we had every reason to say, 'We told you so.' "
Certainly, Mr. De la Rosa's record was not without blemishes. In 1986, a Catalan bank, Banco Garriga Nogues, which he had propelled into a heady expansion in agricultural projects, collapsed with bad loans of $800 million. Mr. De la Rosa's apparently reckless management was widely criticized.
None of this appeared to matter to the Kuwaitis, and particularly to the former chairman of KIO, Sheik Fahad, when they started to invest heavily in Spain in 1986.
 
Good Old Days
The Boom Country Of the 1980's
 The country, newly admitted to the European Community, was starting to boom, attracting much American investment, and the charming, garrulous Mr. De la Rosa had won the confidence of the Kuwaitis.
According to Finance Ministry records, Kuwait poured at least $2.5 billion into Spain between 1986 and 1988. With this money, and some borrowings, a struggling paper company called Torras Hostench was converted by 1988 into the publicly traded Grupo Torras, with holdings in chemicals, fertilizer, real estate, food and paper. The group was the largest in Spain not owned either by the Government or a bank.
Its holdings, with the exception of the Ebro food group, were, however, dubious.
"Chemicals, fertilizer and paper were all sectors that were not very competitive," Mr. Eguidazu said. But as the Spanish economy boomed, and stock prices climbed, few people paid much attention. Mr. De la Rosa estimates that Kuwait took about $1.5 billion in profits from its Spanish investments between 1986 and 1989.
But, from the outset, it appeared that Grupo Torras was managed more to produce quick financial gains than to become an industrially viable company.
 
Intermediaries
Numerous Links To Tax Havens
 Koolmes and Kokmeeuw, the Dutch companies controlled by KIO, were just 2 of about 200 companies registered in tax havens like Jersey, Gibraltar, the Cayman Islands, Switzerland and the Isle of Man that became heavily involved in Grupo Torras's frenetic web of transactions. The sheer number and inaccessibility of these companies, and the fact that many have since closed, have made investigations difficult.
More often than not, when a transaction occurred, one of these companies would be an intermediary, generally reaping a big profit that lawyers for Kuwait now contend ultimately went to the private accounts of Sheik Fahad, Mr. De la Rosa, Fouad Jaffar and their associates.
For example, in 1987, a Swiss-registered company called GSM Securities bought 119,498 shares of the Ebro food group on the open market for $9.8 million. A few weeks later, after rumors of Kuwaiti interest in Ebro had driven the share price up, these shares were sold to Torras for $19 million. The $9.2 million spread was personal profit for the former management of KIO, Kuwait's lawyers say.
Other operations were bolder. The London lawsuit gives a detailed account of complex dealings in 1989 under which, the suit states, Mr. De la Rosa and a former director of Grupo Torras's London subsidiary Torras Hostench London Ltd., Walid Edmond Moukarzel, arranged two "loans" for a total of $105 million to a Jersey-based company, Oakthorn Ltd, for marketing services that Oakthorn was in fact incapable of performing.
The money disappeared and was, the lawsuit contends, pocketed by the former management of KIO and Grupo Torras.
One supposed loan for $50 million, was arranged this way: According to the lawsuit in London, on June 12, 1990, the peseta equivalent of $50 million was transferred from Grupo Torras's account at the Sumitomo Bank, Barcelona, to the Barclays bank account in London of its subsidiary Torras Hostench. From there, on the same day, it was transferred to an Oakthorn account at the St. Helier, Jersey, branch of the Royal Bank of Scotland.
 
Spending Is Challenged
 To justify the loan, a Jersey-based accountant named Michael Russell, who was a director of Oakthorn and is a defendant in the London lawsuit, drew up an agreement on July 9, 1990, with Mr. Moukarzel of Torras Hostench London.
This stated that Oakthorn -- in fact a shell company -- had received the money to help it find potential clients to buy some Grupo Torras assets.
The loan was later extended and finally written off in Grupo Torras's accounts. There is no evidence, the plaintiff's lawyers say, that Oakthorn ever performed any of the services it was supposed to.
"There is a pattern of payments and loans from Grupo Torras to shell companies that were never capable of performing the services for which they were allegedly receiving the money," Ms. Blazquez, the spokeswoman for the new Kuwaiti management of Grupo Torras, said. "In all cases, these funds disappeared."
 
The Unraveling
Economy Sours, And Then a War
 By 1990, the rot had set in. The Spanish economy's long boom was beginning to turn to bust. The chemical, paper and real estate industries were particularly hard hit. Grupo Torras, which had been taken private in December 1989, began to crumble. Then, with the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August 1990, an all-out plundering of the Spanish group appears to have begun.
Certainly, the group's accounts appear to have veered totally out of control.
Kuwaiti money continued to pour into Spain -- close to $2 billion was invested after 1990 -- but quickly disappeared. Jim Roberts, a spokesman for KPMG Peat Marwick, KIO's auditors in London, said that "from 1990 we were unable to sign off on an audit because we were in a total quandary as to the state of KIO's rapidly disintegrating Spanish investments."
Some Torras money, it seems, went to buy political support around the world for Kuwait. "During the gulf war, I am aware of the transfer of about $300 million that was made from the Torras Group in order to make political payments to gain support for the war effort," Mr. De la Rosa said. "But again, I was merely acting on instructions from London."
Not until June 2 of this year, six months after filing for receivership, was Grupo Torras able to sift through the wreckage and send a balance sheet for 1991 and 1992 to the Spanish securities regulators.
The balance sheet showed net losses of $1.6 billion for the two-year period; a plunge in reserves from $1.1 billion in 1990 to a negative $80 million in 1992; a bad-debt provision of $433 million for loans made to shell companies like Oakthorn in 1991 and 1992; and debts of more than $1.5 billion, mainly to KIO, which has had to reimburse international banks that lent to Grupo Torras.
 
Seeking Causes
Few Controls Over Big Sums
 For many who have studied the case closely, the disaster appears attributable essentially to gross mismanagement and corruption. Only after Sheik Fahad was replaced in February 1992 as chairman of KIO by Ali Rashid al-Bader, and Mr. De la Rosa departed three months later, did Kuwait begin a serious attempt to track its huge investments.
"The extraordinary thing in all this is the absence of controls," said Mr. Eguidazu, the Finance Ministry offical. "A dozen Kuwaitis were managing over $70 billion in London with virtually no control. In the end, the people of Kuwait were robbed. In Spain, their money was used chiefly to produce commissions and profits for a few insiders."
Any resolution of the scandal appears a long way off. A final judgment in the London civil suit is probably a year away. Spanish lawyers are still struggling to get judicial approval for their criminal suits.
Mr. De la Rosa has responded with several suits of his own, contending libel and defamation. Investigations by the Kuwaiti Parliament and attorney general are also being pursued.
Anger, both in Kuwait and Spain, is running high. "The Government must take action to bring people to justice," said Mr. Nobari, the Kuwaiti opposition member of Parliament. "What took place was a robbery of the citizens of Kuwait."
As for Mr. De la Rosa, his latest project is a large Disney-style theme park in the Barcelona area, being developed by a company called Gran Peninsula. His minority partner this time is Anheuser-Busch, the gaint American brewer that makes Budweiser beer; Anheuser has a 20 percent stake in Gran Peninsula.
Asked if the company had any qualms about this association, a spokesman for Anheuser-Busch in the United States, Fred Jacob, said he could not comment on Mr. De la Rosa's record.
Mr. De la Rosa, whose left eye is given to a disarming twitch, would say only:
"Look, what happened with KIO was a disaster and a pity. But I have always done my best and tried to give good advice. I am confident the theme park will be a success."
 
KUWAIT'S SPANISH MISADVENTURE
 The sequence of events that bled $5 billion from Kuwait through bungled investments in Spain.
 
1986
A TOEHOLD
The Kuwait Investment Office buys control of Torras Hostench, a troubled Spanish paper maker.
 
1987-1988
A BUYING SPREE
Torras Hostench goes on a buying spree, eventually gaining control of Ebro, a food group, and Ercros, a chemical group formerly called Explosives Rio Tinto, among others.
PAYING FOR IT ALL
A rights issue in June 1987 raises $500 millilon, and the group goes public as Grupo Torras in June 1988, but an attempt to raise capital in December fails. So far, KIO has poured in about $2.5 billion.
 
1989-1990
THE TROUBLE STARTS
KIO takes Grupo Torras in December as a prelude to selling some assets. But Spain's economic boom evaporates and Torras's debts mount.
A GULF WAR CASUALTY
Iraq annexes Kuwait in August 1990, destroying confidence in Grupo Torras. KIO begins pumping in a further $1.8 billion to shore it up.
 
1991-1992
LOSSES AND OUSTERS
Grupo Torras loses $1.6 billion, including more than $400 million in apparent "loans" to shell companies. The chairman of KIO, Sheik Fahad Mohammed al-Sabah, is removed in February 1992; Javier DE la Rosa, the Spanish financier behind grupo Torras's growth, leaves in May.
 
Dec. 1992
$5 BILLION GONE
Grupo Torras files for protection from creditors. Kuwait acknowledges its $5 billion Spanish investment has vanished.
 
1993
SIFTING THE DEBRIS IN THE COURTS
A criminal action is filed in Spain against former Torras management. A judge rejects it, but the order is appealed. The new Kuwait management of Grupo Torras sues the former management in London in May, seeking recovery of over $500 million. The Kuwaiti Parliament's Finance Committee finds eveidence of corruption and gross mismanagement in KIO's handling of Kuwait's Spanish investments and calls for legal action against former managers.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up a Bit Against Yen And Falls in Other Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced slightly against the Japanese yen and fell against most European currencies in light trading yesterday. Traders were awaiting the results of President Clinton's meeting with Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa of Japan and watching the political situation in Russia.
"The market is consolidating and digesting its recent move, awaiting further news," said David Durst, assistant vice president at Credit Lyonnais in New York. 
 The move he referred to was the dollar's rise against the German mark last week after Boris N. Yeltsin seized power in Russia. Investors fear the German economy could suffer if upheaval in Russia means the country can't repay its debts to Germany.
Traders were also awaiting the outcome of President Clinton's meeting with Mr. Hosokawa in New York. It stretched beyond the end of the trading day yesterday.
Jack Griffin, a vice president at Fuji Bank Ltd. in New York, said traders were anxious to see the United States reaction to Japanese efforts to reduce the trade imbalance.
The yen's rise in recent months was partly because of a perception that the United States was encouraging a strong yen to shrink its trade deficit. A strong yen makes Japanese exports more expensive and imports there cheaper.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 106.27 yen, up 0.22 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, it fell to 105.90 yen, from 106.05 on Friday. In New York, the dollar finished at 106.20 yen, up from 106.00 on Friday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.5123, from $1.5035 late Friday. In New York, the pound was trading at $1.5135, more expensive than $1.5082 on Friday.
Other dollar rates in New York, compared with Friday, were: 1.6290 German marks, down from 1.6395; 1.4220 Swiss francs, down from 1.4285; 5.6730 French francs, down from 5.7108; 1,575.00 Italian lire, down from 1,583.00, and 1.3259 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3196.
Other dollar rates in Europe, compared with Friday, were: 1.6305 German marks, down from 1.6475; 1.4250 Swiss francs, down from 1.4365; 5.6862 French francs, down from 5.7450; 1.8305 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8505; 1,577.50 Italian lire, down from 1,593.50, and 1.3240 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3193.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Prices Down Sharply As Worries on Russia Ease

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold prices fell sharply yesterday on signs of a calming in the Russian political situation and a lack of inflation signals. Other precious metals also declined.
On other commodity markets, crude oil futures rose, and the coffee, grain and livestock markets all declined. 
 Gold for October delivery on the Commodity Exchange in New York fell $3.70, to $353.80 an ounce; September silver dropped 7.1 cents, to $4.045 an ounce.
Precious metals prices have been volatile since last Tuesday, when President Boris N. Yeltsin dissolved the Russian Parliament. Gold finished yesterday at exactly the price it settled at on the previous Monday, before the Russian turmoil began.
"The Russian premium is slowly but surely going out of the metals," said James Steel, metals analyst with Refco Inc. in New York.
He said gold was resuming its long-running affair with one of the market's traditional influences, the inflation outlook. Investors tend to buy gold as a defense against rising prices, but the inflation rates in major industrialized nations remain low.
Crude oil futures ended moderately higher after giving up most of the strong gains posted early in the session on news that OPEC had set an overall production cap.
Ministers of the 12-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said they would limit oil production to 24.5 million barrels a day over the next three months. That would hold output to current levels.
Light crude for November delivery finished 16 cents higher at $17.73 a barrel.
December coffee futures tumbled 3.6 cents, to 77.50 cents, a pound on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in reaction to the United States' announcement that it was withdrawing from the International Coffee Organization, a group that major coffee producing and consuming countries established in the 1960's to stabilize coffee prices by imposing export quotas.
Soybean futures prices fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade, leading grain prices lower as harvest pressure came to bear.
Livestock and meat futures fell on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, reflecting slackening demand for beef and expectations for large numbers of slaughter-ready animals in the weeks ahead.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Mexican truck manufacturer could be a nifty Nafta play.

BYLINE: By Adam Bryant

 BODY:
ADVICE for buying Mexican stocks to play the North American Free Trade Agreement is developing a familiar ring: If you can't handle the risk that the accord will not be approved, which is certain to spark a drop based on emotion rather underlying economics, steer clear. But if you're a long-term investor, then Mexico presents some decent bets.
Stocks often mentioned in the same breath include Telefonos de Mexico, the phone company, and Cementos Mexicanos, the large cement maker. Of course, many others have realized that such stocks have a bright future, considering the need for infrastructure to support Mexico's expanding economy, and have already bid those stocks up. 
 A lesser-known Mexican company among American investors is Consorcio G Grupo Dina, the country's biggest truck and bus manufacturer. Its American depository shares started trading on the New York Stock Exchange in the spring, and investors are trading but a fraction of Dina's stock daily compared with the action surrounding Telmex. American depository shares of foreign companies like Dina are receipts for foreign companies' stock that are held in the United States and trade on American exchanges. In Dina's case, one A.D.R. is equivalent to four shares of the stock.
Dina analysts give the company the same rather rosy billing as many of the Mexican stocks trading on the Big Board. Regardless of the free trade accord, they expect Mexico's economy to grow quickly, making the stocks and their relatively low multiples attractive. "The Mexican story is built on structural reforms," Lawrence Krohn, chief Latin economist at Lehman Brothers, said. "And all that will be intact if Nafta fails."
Some industry analysts see an opportunity in Dina (pronouned DEE-na), whose A.D.R.'s traded within a narrow range around $16 from April through August, only to climb quickly through August to their high of $21.875. With growing doubts over the fate of the free trade agreement, they have settled somewhat, closing at $19.125 yesterday, unchanged.
The case for Dina includes the fact that the country's expanding economy will create a need to move more goods and workers, and that there are few alternatives to the road. Dina's truck sales could jump by 16 percent in 1994, and bus sales are expected to grow 10 percent, Steven J. Colbert, an analyst for Prudential Securities, said.
Replacement demand is also working in Dina's favor. The average age of Mexico's truck fleet is about 12 years, compared with roughly 8 years in the United States. Dina's double-digit operating margins far exceed those of other publicly held truck manufacturers, like American companies Navistar International and Paccar.
The Mexican Government is also pitching in. With trade barriers expected to fall -- quickly with the free trade deal, slowly without it -- Mexican truckers will likely feel the need to upgrade their equipment to compete against counterparts in the United States and Canada. The Government also said it would help Dina's truck division by providing up to $250 million to help smaller truck companies get low-rate loans.
The stock is trading at 8.9 times the 1994 earnings estimate -- roughly equal to the Mexican market index, and far below the 14 times that the 500 largest American companies are expected to fetch next year. Dina is expected to remain attractive as it expands with Mexico's economy, which grew at a real annual rate of 3.5 percent from 1989 through 1992. Over the same period, Dina's revenues grew by 27.3 percent annually.
All this opportunity in the Mexican truck market has not been lost on competitors, and Dina will be fighting for market share increasingly with the likes of Mercedes-Benz and Volvo. If the free trade measure is ratified, the current 20 percent tariff that Mexico imposes on European and other foreign heavy-duty trucks would also begin to fall.
But Mr. Colbert believes Dina will stave off many of these new threats to its market share of close to 40 percent because of its brand name, breadth of products and dealer network.

HEADLINE: Existing-Home Sales Drop

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27

 BODY:
Sales of previously owned homes slipped 1.3 percent in August, the first decline in five months despite the lowest mortgage rates on record, a real estate trade group said today.
Sales fell in both the Midwest and South but posted gains in the Northeast and West. Still, the National Association of Realtors report showed sales remaining brisk by historical standards and well above the pace a year earlier. 
 The group said sales totaled 3.81 million at a seasonally adjusted annual rate, down from 3.86 million in July. July's revised advance of 4.9 percent was slower than the initial estimate of 5.4 percent.
The decline in August was the first since sales fell in each month of the January-March quarter, when severe winter weather curbed buying. But sales rebounded in April and had risen each month since.
Despite the August pause, the association noted that sales were still 14.1 percent above those of a year ago. It predicted sales would total 3.675 million this year, up from 3.52 million in 1992 and 3.22 million in 1991, when the housing industry emerged from recession.
The median price of a previously owned home edged up six-tenths of 1 percent from July, to $109,200, and 4 percent from August 1992. The median price means half of the homes cost more and half cost less.
Regionally, sales shot up 9.1 percent in the Northeast, to an annual rate of 600,000. Sales rose 1.2 percent in the West, to an 820,000 rate, despite the poor economy in California. But they dropped 8.6 percent in the Midwest, to a 960,000 rate. They also fell in the South, down 2.1 percent, to a rate of 1.42 million.

HEADLINE: Stop Subsidizing the Arms Race

BYLINE: By Jeff Bingaman; Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico, is a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
At the United Nations yesterday, President Clinton called on the world to halt nuclear testing and ban the production of fuels for nuclear weapons. But while the Administration is saying that attacking the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction is an urgent priority, the Senate has sent a different signal by approving subsidies for arms exports. The House has rejected this approach and a conference committee can soon put the matter to rest.
A provision of the 1994 Defense Department Authorization Act, passed Sept. 14, provides $1 billion in loan guarantees for the export of weapons to NATO members, Australia, Japan, South Korea and Israel. 
 At a time when Yasir Arafat and Yitzhak Rabin are shaking hands, such subsidies for foreign arms sales are a mistake. They may encourage other countries to promote the proliferation of weapons and destabilize developing countries.
Instead of encouraging defense manufacturers to try to adapt to the post-cold-war world and to restructure our defense-oriented industrial base, Congress is using taxpayers' dollars to subsidize companies that are willing to put off the inevitable.
Supporters of the provision say there are no proliferation concerns, that only our close allies are covered under the program. Wrong. When we subsidize sales to our allies, and other countries subsidize sales to their own allies, weapons proliferate exponentially: the close allies of Russia and China include North Korea and Syria.
It would be a mistake to believe that more sales to our allies will not contribute to increased arms sales around the world. The U.S. controls the world market for arms sales and other arms-exporting countries will follow our lead. They face the same challenges we do to preserve jobs and maintain declining defense industries.
The new U.S. export guarantee would lead to increased subsidies by foreign governments to defense industries in their countries to keep sales competitive, and would put increased pressure on those governments to sell where the market is largest: the Middle East and the third world.
Arms exports do not help conversion. The impact of defense downsizing will be felt for years, and Congress and the Administration will be under pressure from companies, workers and communities to do something to prevent the inevitable transition.
If Congress gives in to pressure to maintain the status quo, the U.S. will lose an opportunity to help move defense companies into sustainable commercial development.
Besides, we will lose an opportunity to help move Russia and the other Soviet successor states away from defense economies and into commercial development when they see that the U.S. considers arms exports a form of defense conversion.
And we will misuse scarce Federal dollars in trying to hold on to a rapidly declining world market for arms -- dollars that could be used to support conversion, work-force training and community development. Or even to reduce the Federal budget.
Wisely, Congress has established a $1.6 billion conversion program to help companies adjust. The Administration has pledged to spend $20 billion in conversion over the next five years for technology and manufacturing programs, worker training and economic development programs.
A robust conversion program and increased Federal support for commercial exports -- even an export loan-guarantee program for defense companies seeking to develop markets for civilian goods -- makes sense. What makes no sense is the prospect that arms proliferation will detour developing countries worldwide, especially when old adversaries in the Middle East are finally on the uphill path to peace.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
So Where's the Catch?

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
First, take the three foreign affairs speeches made in the past week by President Clinton, his national security adviser and his U.N. delegate. Then squeeze them good and hard to get rid of the inevitable pulp of jargon, pieties and diplomatic roundabouts.
What is left is the juice of some important policies, and an unusual question.
1. When military action is needed, the U.S. will ask the U.N. for help and permission -- when it is in American best interests to do so. 
 Otherwise, the U.S. will rely on regional alliances like NATO or on pickup groups united by common interests in the crisis of the moment, or go it alone. American forces will not be committed to a permanent U.N. standing reserve, despite past hints. And now the U.S. will ask questions about getting out before it gets in.
All fine, and pretty much what the U.N. was created to be -- a place where nations could work together in a crisis when they wished without surrendering the right to self-defense or collective action outside the U.N. when they didn't wish.
The Clinton U.N. policy is the result of some rethinking, encouraged by a political pounding that convinced the policy makers that the American public would not stand for U.N. commitments in any crisis beyond the one at hand -- if that.
That does leave a problem. American journalists and politicians will have to give up talking of Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali as if he were plotting to command U.S. troops in a mad charge from U.N. headquarters to the sea and across. He is simply an experienced diplomat who suffers from having ideas of his own -- which member nations can accept or reject.
2. The U.S., now the U.N.'s champion deadbeat, will pay its $1 billion in past dues and peacekeeping assessments. Now American Presidents can lecture the U.N. without embarrassment.
Repayment should not immediately be loaded with conditions about dues reductions and "reinventing" the U.N. That would be like walking into a bank and saying you will pay back the automobile loan provided you get a better deal and six vice presidents are fired.
3. The U.S. will work for a treaty to end world production of highly enriched uranium and reprocessed plutonium, used for nuclear bombs.
Now, the question: Where is the catch? There must be one lurking in this interesting thinking. But I can't put my finger on it; very upsetting.
The speeches of Mr. Clinton, his national security adviser, Anthony Lake, and the U.N. representative, Madeleine Albright, are connected to realities -- and strengthened by a healthy dollop of idealistic optimism about expanding democracy.
Sorry, no catch found. But what is missing is a strong track record on handling crises. "Solving" Bosnia was impossible, certainly not without the commitment of U.S. combat troops. Even in fierce American hawks, the thought turned their brown eyes blue.
But the Administration never told us exactly what it would do in Bosnia. It still hasn't. How long would U.S. troops serve there as peacekeepers? And why 25,000, almost half the total?
On Somalia too the President does not give us the answer to the question he says he will always demand of the U.N.: How do we get the hell out of here? Will Americans agree to keeping troops in both places?
So we have to hold judgment on how the Clintonians will handle new foreign crises. The way things are, we won't have to wait long.
As for treaties, they are lovely, when observed. But only wishfulness is behind the hope that China, North Korea, Iran and Iraq will obey nuclear treaties unless their current leaders are good and gone.
And how about a look in our own mirror? Nuclear weapons have been a death threat since Hiroshima. But death reality -- in a dozen wars since Hiroshima -- has come from the tanks, bombs, short-range missiles and long-range guns on sale in the arms bazaar. China and the former Soviet republics are big death salesmen, but right up there with them is the West, including the U.S.
Maybe one day an American President will say, Enough -- from now on we supply arms only to friends in peril and will use economic power against countries that keep the death bazaar open.
Could Bill Clinton be that President some day? After all, it is the one true universal health plan.

HEADLINE: Global Warming's Doomsday Nowhere in Sight

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Scientists Confront Renewed Backlash on Global Warming" (Science Times, Sept. 14) well documents the absence of any scientific consensus on the existence of enhanced greenhouse warming, on the magnitude of any future temperature increase, and on whether any such climate change would be harmful or beneficial. It is important to emphasize this uncertainty in order to counteract unsupported claims that "all scientists agree." 
 Such claims are being used to justify economically harmful policies to limit energy use by imposing special taxes or other restrictions. In his 1992 best seller, "Earth in the Balance," then-Senator Al Gore wrote that 98 percent of all experts agreed with his cataclysmic view of future global warming. As your article shows, this is clearly not the case.
Your article requires some elaboration. Climatologists no longer believe carbon dioxide, the most important man-made greenhouse gas, stays in the atmosphere "for centuries"; better data have reduced this "lifetime" to about 40 years. This means policy steps can be safely delayed pending better evidence.
At last year's Earth Summit in Rio, politicians were led to believe that carbon dioxide concentrations would double by as early as 2025. You report a revised date of 2100, an estimate more in line with the shorter lifetime. In fact, carbon dioxide may never double, partly because of the limited availability of fossil fuels.
You also report that today's greenhouse gas concentration has already moved halfway toward a doubling over the pre-industrial value. According to the "best" computer models, one would expect global temperatures to be increasing at the rate of 0.5 degree Fahrenheit per decade, an easily detectable amount. The best available data, however, taken with globe-circling satellite instruments since 1979, show no increase at all.
As observations and theory diverge more strongly with each passing year, it becomes more certain there is something very wrong with the computer models that have been used to scare the world public and their governments into considering drastic, hasty actions.
 
S. FRED SINGER
Director, Science and
Environmental Policy Project
Arlington, Va., Sept. 17, 1993

HEADLINE: Kerala Raises Living Standard Democratically

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your front-page article Sept. 7 raises the question of whether or not there is a link between repression and improvements in the quality of life in China. While China may not be democratic, you point out, life there is better for millions than in the more democratic country of India. 
 But India is a varied country and statistics for the whole nation do not hold for all the individual states. Kerala, in the extreme southwest corner of India, has the lowest per capita gross national product of any Indian state, yet its quality-of-life indicators compare very favorably to China's.
For example, life expectancy is 68; infant mortality, 27 per 1,000; the literacy rate is 90 percent, and there is virtually no female infanticide, which is not the case in China. These impressive facts are the result of far-reaching reforms that have occurred in Kerala, achieved through the organized efforts of its people.
While these successes did not come easily, there was no sacrifice of democracy. Kerala shows that popular participation, the essence of democracy, is a major part of improving life.
 
BARBARA H. CHASIN
Upper Montclair, N.J., Sept. 20, 1993
 
The writer, professor of sociology at Montclair State College, is co-author of "Kerala: Radical Reform as Development in an Indian State."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Poll Finds Florio's Tax Increase Winning Approval in Retrospect

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey, whose political career seemed all but finished three years ago, has taken advantage of a lackluster Republican challenge to revive his reputation as a leader and has even won a surprising degree of acceptance of his 1990 decision to raise taxes sharply, according to a New York Times/WCBS-TV News poll.
With the Nov. 2 vote five weeks from today, the poll indicates that more New Jersey voters approve of Mr. Florio's performance in office than disapprove of it. Forty-nine percent now even say that Mr. Florio, in the poll's words, "did the right thing" in raising taxes by $2.8 billion in 1990. That action was once thought to have fatally wounded his governorship and was the hook on which his Republican challenger, Christine Todd Whitman, has ever since lashed her ambition to unseat him. Voters also tell the polls that the best thing he has done has been instituting stricter gun control. 
 Mr. Florio has seized a lead of 51 percent to 30 percent over Mrs. Whitman among registered voters, the widest Florio lead yet in four recent state-wide polls, three done by other news groups. The results are based on telephone interviews with 804 registered voters conducted Sept. 20 through 26 throughout New Jersey. It has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.
 
Worst Act, but Also Best
 Over all, the picture that emerges from the survey shows a Governor who has come to dominate the terms of the campaign while Mrs. Whitman is still seeking firm footing, and who has been much more effective is sinking his political barbs into her than she has been in hitting him back.
The poll shows that Mrs. Whitman has suffered from each principal charge Mr. Florio has made against her: that she is rich and out of touch with ordinary voters, that she is too close to the gun lobby and that she lacks the experience and judgment to govern.
Mr. Florio, in contrast, shows relatively little weakness on the tax issue that has been the centerpiece of Mrs. Whitman's campaign. While voters said that raising their taxes was the worst thing the Governor did during his first term, they also said that using high taxes to balance the budget was one of the best things he did, just after instituting stricter gun controls.
When viewed with other recent polls, the Times/WCBS-TV News survey showed a swath of soft or undecided opinion that is gradually and perhaps grudgingly hardening in Mr. Florio's favor. Several respondents who spoke during follow-up interviews after the survey was taken said that they had been interested in Mrs. Whitman's views, but had decided to overlook disappointments with Mr. Florio and to stay with the Governor because they felt they knew him, and trusted him to manage the state's economy.
Carol DeGramont of Englewood said she once favored Mrs. Whitman. But, reflecting the movement of public opinion away from the Republican challenger to the Governor, she has all but changed her mind.
"I was going to go for Whitman but I began to read the articles about her and I started to waver," Ms. DeGramont said. "I don't particularly like Florio but I also don't know how responsible Mrs. Whitman is -- I don't really know why she is running."
Mrs. Whitman greeted the results with a vow that her campaign was going to change, and by questioning the accuracy of the Times/WCBS-TV News poll.
"Polls, as I have said constantly, are snapshot in time," she said at a news conference yesterday morning. "Like we said last week, we are going to change things. I don't know how any more accurate that is than the other three polls we've had that saw we are neck and neck."
 
Not All Bad for Whitman
 Indeed, the news in the survey is not all bad for Mrs. Whitman. The results suggest that she could yet improve her prospects by filling in the blanks on questions of her character and program among the 54 percent of voters who said they were either undecided between the two candidates, or might change their minds before Election Day.
Thus, while Mrs. Whitman received no bounce in the popularity rating from her proposal to cut income taxes by 30 percent over three years, a proposal that was released last Tuesday while the poll was being taken, the number of people who regarded her as a person with specific proposals increased by 12 percentage points after the program was announced.
Public opinion in New Jersey, with one of the country's richest and best-educated electorates, is notoriously volatile. Mr. Florio himself learned this lesson during his first race for governor in 1981, when his months-long lead over Thomas H. Kean faded in the final weeks of a campaign that Mr. Kean went on to win.
In the questions of candidate qualities that help reveal a voter's reasons for going one way or another, Mr. Florio consistently outscored Mrs. Whitman on favorable attributes: 59 percent said they believed that the Governor understood the needs and problems of people like them, against 30 percent for Mrs. Whitman. To the question, whether the candidate has offered specific proposals about how to solve New Jersey's problems, 56 percent said Mr. Florio had, versus 33 percent for Mrs. Whitman.
Mrs. Whitman faltered badly on the question of her experience to lead and in the voters' view of her understanding of their lives. In the poll, 48 percent saying she lacked the experience to serve effectively as governor.
Even on the question of whether the candidate can be trusted to keep his word, Mr. Florio, who campaigned in 1989 saying he saw no need for new taxes and then raised them steeply once in office, won the matchup with 48 percent saying they trusted him, against 34 percent for Mrs. Whitman.
Voters were asked: "Looking back on Jim Florio's decision to raise taxes, do you think he did the right thing or the wrong thing for New Jersey?" Forty-nine percent said he did the right thing, while 42 percent said he did the wrong thing. The question was preceded by a statement of Mr. Florio's motives: to eliminate the deficit and to provide school aid. It is unclear how the response would have differed without that preamble.
The most favorable reaction to Mr. Florio came on a character issue the Republicans are particularly hoping to catch him on: honesty. In May, Mr. Florio's chief of staff was forced to resign because of questions involving the letting of state bond underwriting contracts. Although the Governor and his staff have protested that no one in the administration had done anything wrong, state Republicans have made every effort to remind voters that a Federal investigation is under way on the bond issue.
Yet to the question of whether the candidate has the honesty and integrity they would like to see in a candidate, 61 percent of respondents said Mr. Florio did and 35 said the same of Mrs. Whitman.
 
No High From the Tax Plan
 Several commentators said the poll results may have been colored by the events of last week, when Mrs. Whitman presented her tax plan. Although the plan was intended to create a high point in the Republican effort, the generally unfavorable editorial reaction to it, coupled with relative silence from Mrs. Whitman for several days and howls of criticism from the Florio side, turned what might have been an up week into a bad one for her.
"She needed to fill the airwaves with support for her plan, but she didn't," said Janice Ballou, polling director at the Eagleton Institute of Polics at Rutgers University said yesterday. "So there was nothing to fill the void but all the negative reaction to it, with the result that so far, it may have turned out to be more of a minus than a plus for her."
The polling data suggest that Mrs. Whitman has successfully identified herself as an anti-tax candidate without persuading many voters that she could make her tax views stick. In the poll, 36 percent said their taxes would go up in a Whitman administration and 38 percent said they would stay the same, but only 10 percent said they believed their taxes would go down under her.
Steve Oravets, a tugboat captain from Bayonne, explained in a follow-up interview that taxes had faded in his mind as worries over the economy moved to the fore.
"I didn't like the way Florio handled the tax increase and I don't care too much for his blanket policy on guns," he said. "But if Whitman cuts the income tax, isn't the money just going to come out of another pocket, or end up with more deficit that will hurt the economy? Right now we need more people going to work and I don't think her ideas help that."
Mr. Oravets is one of the tens of thousands who voted for Mrs. Whitman as an anti-Florio tax protest in her near upset of Senator Bill Bradley in 1990. This time, he said, he will probably support the Governor.
 
Areas of Weakness
 On the question of overall opinions of the candidates, the poll respondents gave Mr. Florio the best scores, while at the same time revealing areas of weakness that Mrs. Whitman could yet exploit.
Thus, 50 percent of registered voters said they approved of the way Mr. Florio is handling his job as Governor, and 37 disapproved, while 38 percent said they had a favorable opinion of the governor and 32 percent said their opinion was unfavorable.
For Mrs. Whitman, only 15 percent said they had a favorable opinion of her and twice as many, 30 percent, said their opinion of her was unfavorable. But fully 54 percent said they were either undecided or had not yet heard enough about her to form an opinion when the poll was taken.
Throughout the race, both campaigns have been watching for clues to the relative firmness of each candidate's support. The Whitman campaign was buoyed by the last Star Ledger/Eagleton poll, conducted from Sept. 10 through 15, which showed Mr. Florio's support was not as firm among his partisans as Mrs. Whitman's was among hers.
The Times/WCBS-TV News poll, however, found a statistically indistinguishable difference between the solidity of each candidate's support: 59 percent of Mrs. Whitman's backers said their minds were made up, and 57 percent of Mr. Florio's supporters said the same.
 
 
 
HOW PHONE POLL WAS CONDUCTED
 The latest New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 20 to 26 with 1,010 adults throughout New Jersey. Of these, 804 said they were registered voters.
 The telephone exchanged called were sleected by a computer from a complete list of New Jersey exchanged, with each area of the state represented in proportion of its population. The numbers for each exchange were chosed randomly, thus generating both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household one adult was designated at random to be the respondent for the survey.
 The results have been weighted to account for household size and number of telephone lines at a residence, and to adjust for variations relating to race, sex, age and region of the state.
 In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples should differ by no more than 3 percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all adult New Jersey residents.
 The potential sampling error is larger for smaller subgroups. For example, for registerd voters it is 4 percentage points.
 Besides sampling error, the practical difficulties of poinion surveys may introduce other errors. Differences in the wording and order of questions, for example, can cause results to vary.

A front-page article yesterday about a New York Times/WCBS-TV News poll focusing on the New Jersey election for governor misstated the percentage of registered voters who said the Republican candidate, Christine Todd Whitman, lacked enough experience to govern effectively. It was 40 percent, not 48.

HEADLINE: YELTSIN TIGHTENING CORDON OF TROOPS AT THE PARLIAMENT

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Wednesday, Sept. 29

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin severely tightened the cordon around the headquarters of the hostile legislature Tuesday, deploying hundreds of troops with concertina wire and water trucks, and even mounted police, at all approaches to the building.
From a yellow armored personnel carrier across the street from barricades erected by defenders of Parliament, police officers with a loudspeaker demanded that those inside surrender their arms today. 
 Although the gathering of forces and the demand to surrender seemed to suggest an assault on the building might be imminent, none had occurred by 8:30 A.M. (1:30 A.M. Wednesday, Eastern time).
The police ultimatum was not confirmed by the Kremlin or the Interior Ministry, nor was it accompanied by the threat of any specific retaliation, suggesting that the demand might be only another twist in the weeklong war of nerves intended to pry out remaining deputies and their supporters peaceably.
 
Warning About 'Extremists'
 The buildup of force was by far the largest since Mr. Yeltsin dissolved the obstructive legislature a week ago and called for new elections. But Kremlin officials maintained they had no intention of storming the Parliament building, known as the White House.
Vyacheslav Kostikov, Mr. Yeltsin's press spokesman, issued a statement saying any talk of storming the White House was "misinformation" from "a handful of extremists who found themselves politically isolated."
The cordon drew crowds of angry demonstrators, and in the evening one band of several hundred protesters tried to breach the line from a side street. Riot police drove them back, batons swinging, but several thousand more supporters of Parliament joined the fray, building barricades, hijacking two trolley buses to block traffic and pelting the police with debris.
 
And Still More Troops Arrive
 The street skirmishes were over by midnight (5 P.M. Tuesday, Eastern time), but rumbling trucks and buses filled with police officers and Interior Ministry troops lined side streets in all directions. The heaviest concentration was across from the main entrance to the United States Embassy, which faces Parliament.
Witnesses said they heard bursts of gunfire about 1 A.M. No further shots or violence followed. As heavy rain changed to wet snow, the police presence diminished and those on duty eased enforcement, allowing onlookers and the press a closer look at the Parliament.
Interior Ministry officials said the cordon had been tightened because there were still large stockpiles of arms in the building and because about 600 men defending Parliament included some "with evident psychological disorders."
Moscow's Mayor, Yuri Luzhkov, said there were no more than 230 deputies inside the building, of about 650 who converged there last week. The deputies are holed up with several hundred hard-core Communists and nationalists. In an effort to put pressure on the legislators, the Government has cut electricity, heat and water supplies.
Mr. Yeltsin has declared that he was "categorically" opposed to any compromise that included early joint elections for President and Parliament, a proposal that has gained considerable currency.
 
No Choice Is Offered
 The tightened cordon and the police ultimatum marked a distinct intensification of the war of nerves that the President has waged against the defiant occupants of the White House.
Though talk of compromise continued to swirl, the Kremlin gave no sign it was offering anything except surrender to the deputies and their leaders -- the Chairman, Ruslan I. Khasbulatov, and Vice President Aleksandr V. Rutskoi, whom Parliament has appointed acting president.
The police ultimatum early Tuesday came abruptly as a large force of police officers and commandos moved in, sealing all approaches to the White House. Deputies, staff members and reporters were all turned back.
A bright yellow armored personnel carrier with a large loudspeaker was moved into position facing the White House, and at 11 A.M. (4 A.M. Eastern time), the police advised the defenders they had 24 hours to surrender their arms.
The rain drenched the security forces and the protesters. Clusters of people gathered, including deputies demanding to be let in. None were.
Despite the blockade, Mr. Khasbulatov gave a news conference Tuesday to reporters who camped inside the White House or who managed to get in. He denounced the security measures.
"They are trying to turn us into a concentration camp," he said. "It is sheer fascism."
 
Just a Few Words Get Out
 His words reached Muscovites largely through CNN or Western radio stations because Mr. Yeltsin had closed the Parliament's newspaper.
The information blockade has not been total. Conservative newspapers like Pravda and Sovetskaya Rossiya have continued to publish, and other newspapers and independent news outlets have carried coverage from inside the White House. But the blatantly pro-Yeltsin television reports, with a tone reminiscent of Soviet propaganda, have irritated even many of Mr. Yeltsin's supporters.
Outside the two warring camps, calls continued for a compromise. Valery D. Zorkin, chairman of the Constitutional Court, said leaders of several regions had asked to use the Court for a conference on Thursday.
The announcement was notable because the 88 regions of the Russian Federation have become an increasingly assertive political force. The feud in Moscow has spawned a growing number of parallel feuds in the provinces, and local leaders have shown an inclination to take advantage of the crisis to expand their own powers.
The Kremlin's alarm at the restiveness in the regions was evident in a strong statement issued by the spokesman, Mr. Kostikov, opposing a meeting of the Federation Council, an assembly of regional leaders that President Yeltsin proposes transforming into the upper house of a new Parliament.
Taking advantage of the political crisis, Mr. Kostikov said, "some regional leaders are making attempts to channel power away from the center and to the regions. The Federation Council, which allegedly should 'take the situation under its control,' is being used as an instrument for exerting pressure."
While Mr. Zorkin, the Court chairman, has been among the most active in pressing for joint elections, his potential as a mediator weakened Tuesday when 4 of the 13 members of his Court stopped participating in its work to protest his position. If two more justices step aside, the Court would lose a quorum.
The Deputy Chairman of the Court, Nikolai Vitruk, said Mr. Zorkin was seeking to make the Court "an active political force supporting one of the parties to the conflict."
Criticism of Mr. Yeltsin has come not only from the right. An ever louder critic has been Grigory A. Yavlinsky, a reform economist who is the first Russian politician to declare his candidacy for President. He has repeatedly urged Mr. Yeltsin to lift his siege and to call joint elections, and has warned that intransigence could end in violence.
"If August 1991 was described as a tragedy that ended in farce, then it looks like the events of September 1993, beginning as a comedy, could end in tragedy," he said at a news conference.

A Warning From the U.S.
 UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Clinton Administration urged President Yeltsin today to respect human rights in his showdown with opponents in Parliament.
"We've let them know of our concern about respect for human rights," Secretary of State Warren Christopher said at a news conference, a change from his detached public stance.
A senior official, reinforcing the message, said Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering had been instructed to inform the Yeltsin Government that "we are concerned obviously about the prospect of violence."
 
Dispute in Russia: Seven Days of Turmoil
Russia: Seven Days of Turmoil
 
Sept. 21 President Boris N. Yeltsin suspends Parliament and announces parliamentary elections for Dec. 11 and 12. Vice President Aleksandr V. Rutskoi immediately denounces the move as a "coup d'etat" and says he is taking power. Defiant deputies meet and name Mr. Rutskoi acting president. The Parliament Chairman, Ruslan I. Khasbulatov, calls on soldiers to disobey Mr. Yeltsin.
 
Sept. 22 Parliament votes to strip Mr. Yeltsin of his presidential powers. The Constitutional Court rules that Mr. Yeltsin has violated the constitution and can be impeached. Mr. Yeltsin says he will not use force to resolve the crisis, though the Defense Minister, Pavel S. Grachev, says Mr. Yeltsin can count on full support from the armed forces. Mr. Yeltsin appoints Yegor T. Gaidar acting economics minister in addition to his new job as First Deputy Prime Minister.
 
Sept. 23 Mr. Yeltsin announces early presidential elections for June 12, 1994 and indicates he will run for a third term. Unidentified armed men try to break into the Moscow headquarters of the Commonwealth of Independent States armed forces, but the attack is thwarted by guards and police. The Congress of People's Deputies, Russia's supreme legislature, convenes in the Parliament building.
 
Sept. 24 Mr. Yeltsin orders defense and interior ministries to disarm Parliament guards. The Congress of People's Deputies votes to call simultaneous parliamentary and presidential elections by March 1994.
 
Sept. 25 Mr. Yeltsin says Parliament's resistance to his decree is dissolving and it is "at its last gasp." Mr. Khasbulatov says Parliament will set up new base outside Moscow if Mr. Yeltsin drives the members from the capital. Vladislav Achalov, appointed "defense minister" by Parliament, tells deputies two military units are being formed to defend the legislature. Moscow authorities cut off electricity to Parliament, which restores partial supplies with an emergency generator.
 
Sept. 26 About 15,000 supporters of Mr. Yeltsin rally in central Moscow, while several thousand Parliament supporters stage a rival demonstration. Mr. Rutskoi says he will fight to the death if troops loyal to Mr. Yeltsin try to storm the White House, where the Parliament meets. Leaders of about 40 regional councils and nine administration chiefs call for simultaneous elections to the presidency and Parliament.
 
Sept. 27 Mr. Yeltsin rules out simultaneous elections, saying they would leave a dangerous power vacuum and trigger even greater chaos. Parliament is on full alert, convinced government troops are about to storm building.
 
Sept. 28 The Interior Ministry announces it is sealing off Parliament to maintain law and order in the district. The building is surrounded by barricades and razor wire.
