HEADLINE: Vague Mexico Wage Pledge Clouds Free Trade Accord

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 28

 BODY:
As they try to make the case for Congressional approval of a free trade agreement with Mexico and Canada, President Clinton and other supporters repeatedly say the pact will raise minimum wages in Mexico and reduce the country's ability to undercut businesses north of the border with cheap labor.
But by focusing on how minimum wages might rise, the Clinton Administration has put itself in a somewhat awkward position because that particular pledge is not found anywhere in the 2,000-page North American Free Trade Agreement it is meant to support. Nor is it in the special side agreements to the pact, or in Mexican labor law.
 
A Promise by Salinas
 Rather it is a personal promise made by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico that this country's minimum wage -- which can go as low as $4 a day, depending on the type of work -- will be increased in tandem with increases in worker productivity. 
Mr. Salinas's pledge, announced publicly in August on the same day the side accords were announced, was seen as crucial to getting the pact past a worried United States Congress.
But the pledge was so vague, and the issue of measuring productivity so potentially troublesome, that Mr. Salinas is now under pressure to come forward with a concrete plan for lifting the incomes of Mexico's poorest workers.
Mexican officials have said only that their Departments of Labor and Economic Development are working with their National Commission of Minimum Salaries to devise a formula for the increases.
Labor unions say they have reached an agreement with the Government to give bonuses to productive workers in specific industries, but that does not seem to meet the letter of Mr. Salinas's pledge. Beyond that, little is known on either side of the border about what Mexico will actually do.
"Nobody really has a good understanding of what they're going to do," said Mauricio Gonzalez, a partner at a Mexico City consulting company.
If an accurate and reliable format could be worked out, linking productivity to wage increases could go far toward returning the Mexican work force to the standard of living it had before the debt crisis of 1982 brought soaring inflation and a deep national recession. But the average American factory worker is 4.6 times more productive than the average Mexican factory worker, although in some new Mexican plants the rates can be roughly comparable. Still, few believe that Mexico can close the gap quickly.
It is also not clear how Mexico would manage productivity-based increases, or when they would become effective. Mexican officials say it is doubtful that anything could be in place by the beginning of January, when they hope the trade agreement will be signed and in force.
The Mexican negotiators of the pact were careful not to commit themselves to wage parity with the United States. Mexico is going to try only to make up for some of the losses suffered by workers over the last decade, when the buying power of the minimum wage dropped 60 percent.
There is even uncertainty about what Mr. Salinas's pledge actually means. "We will be assured of an effective and permanent improvement of minimum wages now and for the future," Mr. Salinas said in a speech in which he outlined the plan.
Harley Shaiken, a labor economist at the University of California at Berkeley, said, "As a statement of intent it is a preamble, but the devil is in the details, and this has no details."
A United States Labor Department official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Clinton Administration was using Mr. Salinas's pledge because of the "symbolic value" it represented. The official said a new system would have a practical, though limited, effect on shrinking the gap between wages in the United States and Mexico.
 
Clinton Stresses Pledge
 Despite that, the pledge has become a key part of Mr. Clinton's efforts to sell the pact. In a speech in New Orleans this month, the President praised the trade agreement and the side accords -- one on the environment, the other on labor -- that are intended to toughen parts of the original pact, which lowers or eliminates tariffs on most goods traded between the United States, Mexico and Canada.
The side agreement on labor, Mr. Clinton said, "commits the Mexican Government to enforce its own labor laws, and you should know what that really means."
"It means that for the first time in history a government has committed itself to raise the minimum wage as its economy grows, thereby raising the wage structure throughout the country," he said.
But Mr. Salinas's pledge was not enough to quell all complaint. Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, said Mr. Salinas's promise fell short because so few Mexican workers receive just the minimum wage. Last week he said he would vote against the agreement.
 
10 Percent Get Minimum
 According to the Bank of Mexico, the minimum wage now applies to only about 10 percent of Mexican workers, and the Mexican Social Security system reports that only 16 percent of its 8.8 million enrollees receive the minimum wage. But the practice has developed in Mexico of using increases in the minimum wage as the basis for negotiation involving salaries higher than the minimum. Some higher-paid workers, mostly Government employees, would be directly affected because their salaries are calculated as multiples of the minimum wage.
But as in the United States, increases in the minimum wage do not necessarily result in across-the-board increases. In the United States, the minimum wage has been increasing while average wages have fallen.
In Mexico, there are actually 264 minimum wages; each of 88 different occupations has three minimums that vary according to where the jobs are performed. In general, wages are highest in Mexico City and other urban areas, and lowest in rural states.
Minimum wages are set by the National Commission of Minimum Salaries, which is made up of representatives from business, labor unions and the Government. From 1986 to last January, the commission changed the levels 16 times.
 
Government Deeply Involved
 The Government's involvement is an essential part of Mr. Salinas's efforts to tame inflation and keep investors interested in Mexico. Under a set of wage and price controls in effect since 1987, just before Mr. Salinas took office, businesses and unions have kept negotiated wage increases below the level of inflation, while the Government agreed to keep down gasoline and electricity prices while also pumping money into a public works programs called Solidarity.
The program has worked. Inflation is below 10 percent for the first time in 25 years. Despite a slowing of Mexico's economic growth, investment has continued strong. There has even been some recovery in real wages over the last few years. But it has not been enough to compensate for staggering losses of the 1980's. Real wages today are 68 percent of what they were in 1980.
All that has worsened the gap between wages in the United States and Mexico, even though Mexican productivity has been increasing by 4 percent or more each year since 1989. Mexican compensation was 22 percent of United States wages in 1980. It dropped to 7 percent in 1987 and since has risen to 15 percent, according to a report by the Democratic Study Center, a nonprofit academic foundation in Washington.
"We don't expect that in three, four or five years we will have the same minimum salaries as the United States," said Juan S. Millan Lizarraga, secretary of education for the Confederation of Mexican Workers, the largest labor syndicate in Mexico. "But we expect to cut the gap."
Mr. Salinas's pledge, announced publicly in August on the same day the side accords were announced, was seen as crucial to getting the pact past a worried United States Congress. But the pledge was so vague, and the issue of measuring productivity so potentially troublesome, that Mr. Salinas is now under pressure to come forward with a concrete plan for lifting the incomes of Mexico's poorest workers.
Mexican officials have said only that their Departments of Labor and Economic Development are working with their National Commission of Minimum Salaries to devise a formula for the increases.
Labor unions say they have reached an agreement with the Government to give bonuses to productive workers in specific industries, but that does not seem to meet the letter of Mr. Salinas's pledge. Beyond that, little is known on either side of the border about what Mexico will actually do.
"Nobody really has a good understanding of what they're going to do," said Mauricio Gonzalez, a partner at a Mexico City consulting company.
If an accurate and reliable format could be worked out, linking productivity to wage increases could go far toward returning the Mexican work force to the standard of living it had before the debt crisis of 1982 brought soaring inflation and a deep national recession. But the average American factory worker is 4.6 times more productive than the average Mexican factory worker, although in some new Mexican plants the rates can be roughly comparable. Still, few believe that Mexico can close the gap quickly.
It is also not clear how Mexico would manage productivity-based increases, or when they would become effective. Mexican officials say it is doubtful that anything could be in place by the beginning of January, when they hope the trade agreement will be signed and in force.
The Mexican negotiators of the pact were careful not to commit themselves to wage parity with the United States. Mexico is going to try only to make up for some of the losses suffered by workers over the last decade, when the buying power of the minimum wage dropped 60 percent.
There is even uncertainty about what Mr. Salinas's pledge actually means. "We will be assured of an effective and permanent improvement of minimum wages now and for the future," Mr. Salinas said in a speech in which he outlined the plan.
Harley Shaiken, a labor economist at the University of California at Berkeley, said, "As a statement of intent it is a preamble, but the devil is in the details, and this has no details."
A United States Labor Department official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Clinton Administration was using Mr. Salinas's pledge because of the "symbolic value" it represented. The official said a new system would have a practical, though limited, effect on shrinking the gap between wages in the United States and Mexico.
 
Clinton Stresses Pledge
 Despite that, the pledge has become a key part of Mr. Clinton's efforts to sell the pact. In a speech in New Orleans this month, the President praised the trade agreement and the side accords -- one on the environment, the other on labor -- that are intended to toughen parts of the original pact, which lowers or eliminates tariffs on most goods traded between the United States, Mexico and Canada.
The side agreement on labor, Mr. Clinton said, "commits the Mexican Government to enforce its own labor laws, and you should know what that really means."
"It means that for the first time in history a government has committed itself to raise the minimum wage as its economy grows, thereby raising the wage structure throughout the country," he said.
But Mr. Salinas's pledge was not enough to quell all complaint. Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, said Mr. Salinas's promise fell short because so few Mexican workers receive just the minimum wage. Last week he said he would vote against the agreement.
 
10 Percent Get Minimum
 According to the Bank of Mexico, the minimum wage now applies to only about 10 percent of Mexican workers, and the Mexican Social Security system reports that only 16 percent of its 8.8 million enrollees receive the minimum wage. But the practice has developed in Mexico of using increases in the minimum wage as the basis for negotiation involving salaries higher than the minimum. Some higher-paid workers, mostly Government employees, would be directly affected because their salaries are calculated as multiples of the minimum wage.
But as in the United States, increases in the minimum wage do not necessarily result in across-the-board increases. In the United States, the minimum wage has been increasing while average wages have fallen.
In Mexico, there are actually 264 minimum wages; each of 88 different occupations has three minimums that vary according to where the jobs are performed. In general, wages are highest in Mexico City and other urban areas, and lowest in rural states.
Minimum wages are set by the National Commission of Minimum Salaries, which is made up of representatives from business, labor unions and the Government. From 1986 to last January, the commission changed the levels 16 times.
 
Government Deeply Involved
 The Government's involvement is an essential part of Mr. Salinas's efforts to tame inflation and keep investors interested in Mexico. Under a set of wage and price controls in effect since 1987, just before Mr. Salinas took office, businesses and unions have kept negotiated wage increases below the level of inflation, while the Government agreed to keep down gasoline and electricity prices while also pumping money into a public works programs called Solidarity.
The program has worked. Inflation is below 10 percent for the first time in 25 years. Despite a slowing of Mexico's economic growth, investment has continued strong. There has even been some recovery in real wages over the last few years. But it has not been enough to compensate for staggering losses of the 1980's. Real wages today are 68 percent of what they were in 1980.
All that has worsened the gap between wages in the United States and Mexico, even though Mexican productivity has been increasing by 4 percent or more each year since 1989. Mexican compensation was 22 percent of United States wages in 1980. It dropped to 7 percent in 1987 and since has risen to 15 percent, according to a report by the Democratic Study Center, a nonprofit academic foundation in Washington.
"We don't expect that in three, four or five years we will have the same minimum salaries as the United States," said Juan S. Millan Lizarraga, secretary of education for the Confederation of Mexican Workers, the largest labor syndicate in Mexico. "But we expect to cut the gap."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Parts Production Debated in Chrysler Talks

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 28

 BODY:
Facing a strike deadline of 11:59 P.M. Thursday, negotiators for the Chrysler Corporation are trying to fend off demands by the United Automobile Workers union that the company keep making the same proportion of its vehicle parts in-house, thus preserving and possibly creating jobs.
The U.A.W. imposed the deadline on Monday, as a way to focus Chrysler's attention and speed up the talks, union officials said. Both sides said negotiators were likely to agree on a new contract without a strike. 
 In Canada, where the Canadian Automobile Workers are negotiating a separate labor agreement with the General Motors Corporation against a deadline of 11:59 P.M. Wednesday, talks seemed to be progressing after G.M. agreed late Monday to set aside $440 million to support laid-off workers. But G.M. had still not agreed to the basic pattern contract the union negotiated with Chrysler two weeks ago. G.M. also had not formally proposed a wage and benefits package.
"It's unusual for them not to have tabled an economic proposal this late in the bargaining," said Buzz Hargrove, the president of the C.A.W., in a telephone interview from Toronto this evening. Despite the many remaining differences, he added, "It could be done in a very short time."
While Mr. Hargrove said he would negotiate straight through to the deadline, his union, unlike the U.A.W., has a strict policy not to grant extensions. "We either have a settlement or a strike," he said.
At Chrysler, the U.A.W. seeks to replicate an accord it won at the Ford Motor Company two weeks ago. That contract keeps company-paid medical coverage, raises pension benefits for retirees and increases job security funds that pay 95 percent of the wages of laid-off workers.
The pension increases are more of a burden for Chrysler than Ford, since Chrysler has reported an unfunded pension liability of more than $3 billion. But the other provisions are not likely to cause serious increases in the company's labor costs. General Motors, however, is hoping for more relief and is likely to press the union for concessions that will help it streamline its work force.
Rather than call a strike at the deadline, the union negotiators could choose to continue their bargaining, as they did for almost 24 hours past the deadline at Ford. Already, the bargainers' days have begun to lengthen. They stayed at the tables in Chrysler's Highland Park headquarters until about 9 P.M. Monday .
About 54,000 U.A.W. members work for Chrysler, compared with 96,000 at Ford and 265,000 at G.M. The contracts also set benefits for 390,000 retirees and surviving spouses.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Glen Ellen Wines Sold To Heublein

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
Just as many wine drinkers have grown to recognize the taste and value of Glen Ellen products, so has Heublein Inc., a unit of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. of Britain.
In a deal announced late yesterday, Heublein agreed to buy the Glen Ellen and M. G. Vallejo brands from the Benziger family. Neither side would disclose the purchase price nor the terms of the acquisition. 
 The family will retain its 100-acre ranch in Glen Ellen, Calif., as well as its Benziger brand wines, which accounted for fewer than 150,000 cases sold last year, when the Benziger wineries were ranked 12th in the United States. The leading Benziger wines were Glen Ellen, with about 3.5 million cases sold, and M. G. Vallejo, with another 450,000 cases.
The Glen Ellen and M. G. Vallejo wines, combined with Heublein's products, including Inglenook, Almaden and Blossom Hill, will make Heublein the second-leading wine maker in the country, with about 12 percent of the market, said Jack Shea, a Heublein spokesman. Gallo retains a commanding lead, with about a 38 percent share.
 
Succeeded With Pricing
 The Benzigers built their business through the 1980's by selling varietal wines at reasonable prices while wineries with comparable products were selling for more. When Glen Ellen products were first offered, consumers could buy two bottles for as little as $7.
"In the mid 1980's, that was not the place to be," said Marvin R. Shankin, publisher and editor of The Wine Spectator. "They could have gotten squeezed out. But as the economy shifted, wine drinkers began looking in the $5 to $8 range and found for that moderate amount, they could get wines of outstanding quality."
In that price range, Glen Ellen's varieties of chardonnay, cabernet sauvignon, white zinfandel and merlot, among others, helped make the segment the fastest-growing in the industry.
But the competition with Gallo, Robert Mondavi and other wineries continued, pushing the Benzigers into a search for needed cash despite their growth.
For Heublein, the purchase was like drawing to an inside straight. With strong sales in table wines and other liquor products, the company was lacking a visible presence among the more prominent California wines. The Benziger lines, said Robert M. Furek, president and chief executive of Heublein, "fill an important gap in our portfolio."

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN;
Hospitals, Hoping for Simplicity, Generally Welcome President's Proposals

SERIES: The Clinton Prescription: The Impact on Hospitals -- Fourth article in a series

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 28

 BODY:
To find the heart of Huntington Memorial Hospital today, go upstairs from the gleaming efficient emergency room, past the pharmacy and around the corridor to the business office.
There, in cramped cubicles, 75 workers push the mountains of paper that are today more a part of hospital care than surgical gloves. Two of them do nothing but copy medical records all day for insurance companies. Others dun insurers and patients for payment in the hospital's ceaseless battle against red ink -- $10 million in losses last year alone because of indigent and uninsured patients. 
 If for no other reason, hospitals generally welcome President Clinton's proposal to overhaul the health system because nearly everybody would carry basic coverage and hospitals could rely on a regular stream of income. Moreover, hospital administrators hope that the Clinton plan to draft a single uniform insurance claim form would reduce the mounds of paperwork.
"From the hospital's standpoint, everyone would have access to the front door of the hospital instead of just the emergency room," said Dr. Allen W. Mathias, president of Huntington Memorial, a nonprofit private hospital with 535 beds.
But the plan would mean a difficult transition as hospitals deal with a 180-degree turn in economic incentives. As part of large alliances of health providers, hospitals would be under pressure to keep patients out rather than in. This is expected to force mergers of hospitals and many closings.
The effects would vary enormously depending on the type of hospital. The main beneficiaries would be large urban private hospitals with the financial muscle to absorb smaller community hospitals and form alliances with doctors and other providers.
The outlook is less certain for public and teaching hospitals. They have cared for the bulk of indigent patients who would now have insurance that they could take elsewhere for care. But these hospitals would still be obliged to provide emergency and pregnancy care for illegal aliens, who are not included under the Clinton plan.
And specialized hospitals like psychiatric hospitals, already in deep financial trouble nationally, would face still more stress because the plan would allow only 30 days of hospitalization a year. Least affected, at first, would be rural hospitals, because the areas they serve often lack the critical mass of population, doctors and medical services to fit into the structure of "managed competition" envisioned by President Clinton.
 
Plan Would Speed Industry Changes
 But if passed, the Clinton plan would accelerate trends already under way in many parts of the country, trends forced by the widespread adoption of "managed care" by employers to reduce medical costs and by new technology that has reduced the need for hospitalization. To remain competitive, hospitals have begun to merge and to form alliances with other health care providers.
In short, hospitals are accepting a new reality in which they will take a lesser role in the medical world, as no longer the main centers of care but rather as the places where the most extreme illnesses and accidents are treated.
Probably nowhere have the ills of hospitals been more acute than here in Southern California, where nearly one in three people are without medical or hospital insurance, where hospitals are the main source of care for hundreds of thousands of illegal aliens and where there is such an oversupply of hospitals that the typical hospital fills fewer than half its beds on any given day.
Already this year, 18 hospitals in California have shut. And C. Duane Dauner, president of the California Association of Hospitals and Health Systems, predicts that by the year 2000, another 150 of the state's 550 hospitals will be gone, eliminating a third of all hospital beds.
"The Clinton plan will bring that about sooner because it creates greater competition among health plans," he said. "The in-patient census will continue to drop. We do not advocate that every hospital should remain open. There will be closures, conversions, mergers, sharing of equipment."
But Mr. Dauner and other hospital leaders remain concerned about other aspects of the Clinton plan, mainly the proposal to reduce growth in Medicare and Medicaid by $238 billion by the year 2000 to help finance the universal access. "We do not believe that is possible," he said.
Also, they worry about the plan's omission of coverage for illegal aliens apart from emergency and pregnancy care, and about whether teaching hospitals, which receive added reimbursements from the Government for their associations with medical schools, will be able to maintain their teaching function with reduced patient subsidies. Moreover, there is concern about the fate of public hospitals when every person has a health card and can buy insurance that might use private hospitals and doctors.
But the current system is so onerous for most hospitals that almost any change would be relief. "We are in full agreement with 75 percent of the Clinton proposal," said David Langness, spokesman for the Hospital Council of Southern California, representing 240 hospitals in six counties. "Hospitals have been the most vocal of providers seeking reform, because they are in big trouble, losing money hand over fist."
Consider a major urban hospital like Daniel Freeman Memorial Hospital in Inglewood, Calif., which serves a wide area of South-Central Los Angeles and adjoining communities, an area mostly inhabited by low-income people. During last year's riots, it treated 372 injured people, including Reginald O. Denny, the truck driver pulled from his cab and beaten in front of television cameras. Only one fifth of the riot patients had insurance, and the hospital absorbed a $500,000 loss.
"It's great to know everyone will be covered," said Peter F. Bastone, administrator of the 365-bed hospital, which is operated by the Sisters of St. Joseph of Carondelet, a Roman Catholic order based in St. Louis.
Daniel Freeman underscores the distorted reality of urban medicine today: that most people in poor neighborhoods get nearly all their medical care in the most costly and inefficient way -- in the emergency room. Nearly 100 patients a day stream through the hospital's emergency room. A majority need primary, not emergency, care but, lacking insurance, have no other source of care, said Dr. Bayliss B. Yarnell, director of emergency medicine.
Universal health insurance, he said, would permit patients to see doctors before illness turns into emergency. "The emergency room is a very expensive way to deliver primary health care," Dr. Yarnell said. "A lot of these people would not be here if they had a primary care physician."
But just how the new system will be financed is a source of deep worry, particularly since two-thirds of Daniel Freeman's patients are covered by Medicare or Medi-Cal, California's Medicaid program for the indigent.
"Access to the health care system is very laudable," said Daniel P. McLean, president of Daniel Freeman Hospitals Inc., which oversees the Inglewood unit and another smaller hospital in Marina Del Rey. "But how it's going to be paid for, who's going to pay for it and how much providers will get is unclear."
Even before President Clinton made his proposal, the Daniel Freeman hospitals were negotiating affiliations with 11 other Los Angeles-area hospitals. Eventually each hospital would specialize and share equipment and staff, eliminating duplication in cardiac surgery, obstetrics and the like.
"We're going to be paid less tomorrow, and if we don't find a way to do it for less money, we're going to die," Mr. McLean said.
 
Economic Incentives Are Changing
 A few miles away here in Pasadena, a suburb just north of downtown Los Angeles, much the same calculus has been made at the century-old Huntington Memorial, a teaching hospital with ties to the University of Southern California and the University of California at Los Angeles.
Beneath the serene Mediterranean exterior, with its wisteria-covered trellises, the old hospital has been preparing for 21st century realities. Its practices have changed radically with the growing popularity in California of health maintenance organizations, or H.M.O.'s, the kind of group health plans that President Clinton seeks to expand.
The H.M.O.'s pay the hospital a fixed fee annually for every member, not for every visit to the hospital. That makes it is more profitable for the hospital to do as much work on an out-patient basis and to discharge patients quickly.
"The economic incentives have changed for hospitals; no longer does more mean better," said Stephen A. Ralph, executive vice president of Huntington Memorial. "Hospitals have done a poor job of understanding our costs. Now we must, or we will go out of business."
The hospital has already taken steps to reduce costs, including establishing a primary care clinic to divert minor complaints from the emergency room to a nurse practitioner, operating nursing homes, setting up a home-health program and affiliating with a nearby hospital, the Methodist Hospital of Southern California, in Arcadia.
In anticipation of the Clinton changes, it is also forming a new entity to be called the Huntington Medical Foundation to compete against Kaiser-Permanente, one of the original H.M.O.'s, and other major plans, at least in its local territory. The foundation would buy up the practices of primary-care doctors and then market the combined doctor and hospital services to employers, insurers and, presumably, the new purchasing cooperatives to be established under the Clinton plan.
Thus, the hospital would be just one part of a network of providers, putting more emphasis on prevention of disease than on acute treatment. "The stand-alone hospital is in great danger of seeing its patients go elsewhere," said Dr. Mathias, the president of Huntington Memorial.
The hospital hopes that the Clinton plan will reduce the paperwork. In the business office, Jim Farrar, director of patient accounts, supervises a paper empire built of more than 100 different forms, and Carol Bradley, vice president for nursing, estimates that from 30 to 40 percent of nurses' time is spent filling out forms.
A couple of years ago, the hospital spent $2 million for a so-called paperless computer accounting system, but it made only more paper than ever.
 
Optimism About Plan Is Not Universal
 But not all at the hospital are optimistic about the eventual impact of the Clinton plan. Dr. Glenn Littenberg, an internist who is former chief of staff at Huntington, said that while it would help solve the access problem, he worried that medical care would suffer under a system in which networks of doctors and hospitals constantly had to compete for pools of patients.
"When something is driven chiefly by bottom-line considerations, I've got to be very skeptical it will bring the results promised," he said.
The outlook for public hospitals is unclear. For decades, the main burden of treating the indigent and illegal aliens in Southern California has fallen on the Los Angeles County Department of Health Services, which runs six hospitals. Its Los Angeles County/University of Southern California Medical Center is not only one of the nation's premier teaching hospitals but also the largest medical complex in the United States, delivering 40,000 babies a year (110 a day) and serving more than four million out-patients annually. It is well known to television viewers as the locale for the soap opera "General Hospital."
It is difficult to assess the effect of the Clinton plan on such a huge system, said Irene E. Riley, chief of governmental relations for the department. On the one hand, the system stands to lose a certain number of subsidized Medi-Cal patients as they are given health cards and permitted to join regular health plans.
On the other hand, the county system is so overtaxed that it cannot now adequately serve its clients. It is unclear to what extent the Federal Government will continue to reimburse the county for treating illegal aliens, who will presumably continue to use its services since they are not eligible for health cards but are entitled, by law, to emergency and pregnancy care.
Still, the county has volunteered to serve as pilot project for the Clinton Administration. "We are guardedly optimistic," Ms. Riley said. "We want to get the Clinton plan to work for us. If it can work in L.A., it can work anywhere."
NEXT: What the health plan means for the drug companies.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Washington Joins Big 3 Auto Venture

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The White House and the Big Three auto companies will announce today a radical new approach to car technology and Government-industry relations, under which Washington will give Detroit technology that originated in weapons programs, and Detroit will strive to build a car that goes three times farther than current models on the same amount of fuel.
Washington is already working with the auto makers on various technologies, but the new agreement, to be announced at a White House ceremony with President Clinton, Vice President Al Gore and the chief executives of General Motors, Ford and Chrysler, will set a unifying 10-year goal: very high fuel economy that far exceeds the regulatory requirements.
 
'Rewriting the Book'
 "We think it's an enormous breakthrough," Mr. Gore said of the partnership in a telephone interview last night. "The goal has been consciously set at a point that lies beyond what we know how to do with current systems." 
 He added: "Advances like this, a threefold increase in performance, are taken for granted over a 10-year period in the computer industry. Up until now there has been an assumption that only incremental change is possible in an industry like the auto industry. These three C.E.O.'s are rewriting the book."
The chief executives are John F. Smith Jr. of General Motors, Harold A. Poling of Ford and Robert J. Eaton of Chrysler.
A spokesman for the companies, Larry D. Weis, who represents a research consortium of the Big Three called Uscar, said "we have worked together before in bits and pieces," but the new agreement "commits the Government and the companies to sit down in a coordinated effort; it becomes more of a moon-shot kind of program."
Mr. Gore, in language reminiscent of the early days of the space program, painted the latest effort in patriotic colors. "We have a strategic interest as a nation in meeting the goal we've set in this program," he said. "It's an act of patriotism but also an act of good business sense, because I predict this will result in breakthroughs that are likely to position our American auto industry to dominate the growing world market in the next century."
Meeting the goal would also reduce pollution and fuel imports. It is also a way for the Government to try to salvage huge assets threatened with obsolescence by the end of the cold war: weapons laboratories and technologies. It is, in effect, an effort to beat swords into automobile fenders.
A draft summary of the agreement, prepared by the White House, said the technologies that Washington would bring to the table included "super-strong, lightweight materials developed for advanced weapons systems," and advanced capacitors, devices that store electricity, which were built for the Strategic Defense Initiative, known as Star Wars.
The Advanced Research Projects Agency will provide designs for super-efficient motors and fuel cells, and the Army Tank Command will provide "virtual design and prototyping," which are computer-aided systems for moving ideas into factory production faster, the draft said.
 
'Radical Changes'
 Financing for the projects will be split, the summary said, with Washington taking the larger share of the "riskier long-term projects," and the car companies paying for the "projects with near-term marketplace applications."
The long-term goal is to produce cars in about 10 years that are practical and affordable and go three times asfar on a given quantity of fuel as comparable cars do today. But the draft said the "Government and industry engineers recognize that this ambitious goal will require radical changes in the way automobiles operate and that the results are risky and uncertain."
The idea, according to the draft, is to use Federal resources -- including scientists and laboratories that are idle because the development of weapons has been scaled back -- for research in the areas "where risks are so high and rewards so delayed that the U.S. industry could not afford the investment." But the work is not supposed to increase the Government's total research spending.
 
An Electric Component?
 The partnership does not say even broadly how the mileage goal would be accomplished. The mention of capacitors implies that the car would be powered by electricity, at least in part.
The agreement also mentions fuel cells, which are devices first developed for the space program, that combine oxygen from the air and hydrogen from natural gas or other fuels, and produce electricity and water.
There are also short-term goals, including building cars with lightweight materials, which would improve fuel economy without changes in the engines, and the use of materials that can be recycled.

HEADLINE: Country Music Boom Has Nashville Dancing

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NASHVILLE, Sept. 28

 BODY:
Seven months ago Chas Sandford packed up 29,000 pounds of recording gear and moved his studio from Los Angeles to Nashville. But it wasn't country music that drew him here.
"Between crime, riots, gangs, earthquakes, and fires, it's like 'Blade Runner' out there," said Mr. Sandford, comparing Los Angeles to the 1982 film's nightmarish view of urban decay. "I'd say 25 percent of the people I know have moved and a lot of them have come to Nashville, where you don't see graffiti every time you open your eyes, and you don't hear helicopters over your house all the time." 
 The talk of Nashville today was the annual Country Music Association Awards, which in 27 years have grown from a cultural footnote to the three-hour, prime-time network extravaganza that will be broadcast Wednesday. And much like country music's phenomenal growth, Nashville, from its booming health-care industry to the new office towers and L.A. hipsters sprouting along Music Row, is a revealing window on a nation that culturally and demographically continues to move South and West.
 
Big Hair and Health Care, Too
 "I lived in Manhattan for a long time, but ultimately you want to live in a place where life is a little saner," said Evelyn Shriver, a music-industry publicist who moved here eight years ago. "You hear a lot about people going back to churches. People are having kids. Country music reflects their life. As a society, people are grasping for something that's safer because everything else is so nuts."
Nashville, as its boosters tirelessly point out, is more than big hats, big hair and the Country Music Wax Museum & Mall. Its economy is heavily dependent on the nearby auto plants in Smyrna and Spring Hill, state government, education, transportation and a health-care industry that includes 240 companies and controls half the for-profit hospital beds in America. The consolidated city and county has a population of 511,000; the metropolitan area, which one recent study projects will grow by 22 percent this decade, has just over a million residents.
One of the most remarkable things about the country boom is that it has finally won over Nashville, whose staid establishment has historically regarded those in the country music community as benighted hillbilly bumpkins.
But with dollars comes respect, and Nashville is now embracing country music as never before.
Country record sales have increased from $425 million in 1988 to $1.5 billion in 1992. Country became the nation's leading radio format a few years back, growing from fewer than 100 stations 30 years ago to more than 2,200 now.
"Everybody in the music industry here is working at warp 12," said Robert Oermann, a writer and radio personality long active with the music scene. "Every week there's someone new from Los Angeles looking to open an office."
At Americana Records on Music Row near downtown, where record companies are slapping up new office buildings next to offices in converted cottages on streets with names like Chet Atkins Place and Roy Acuff Place, President Tom Kawai has come a good deal further.
"I love country music, but Nashville isn't just about country music," said Mr. Kawai, who grew up in Japan listening to Hank Williams and Lefty Frizzell, and whose Japanese-based company puts together recording and licensing deals in Nashville. "That's why I have a plan to do other categories of music here, like Spanish crossover music or traditional-Japanese-meets-country music."
The Spanish crossover has yet to reach critical mass, but the country boom is being felt throughout Nashville.
"You go into a restaurant or any kind of event of political or social importance, and you will see an awful lot of people that you don't know, that you didn't know existed," said John Egerton, an author and longtime resident. "And you've got to know that these people are mainly New York and Hollywood folk who have joined the ant colony."
 
Discord Amid the Harmony
 In truth, Nashville is hardly exempt from the nation's social ills. Last year, the beating of a black undercover police officer at the hands of city police officers stirred racial tension that lingers. Just this month, in a crime that shook Nashville to its core, a 16-year-old girl, Elysia Coughlan, was robbed and shot to death in a trendy neighborhood near Vanderbilt University after withdrawing $20 from an automatic teller machine.
And some newcomers find culture in Nashville, where gathering places tend to be more like the Pancake Pantry than Spago, a bit bland.
Aside from Music Row, the main impact of the boom is being felt downtown. Once the music industry's home, later all-but abandoned, the southeast part of downtown near the Cumberland River is now seeing a flood of activity as old warehouses are rebuilt into trendy shops, restaurants and a huge country dance emporium.
Since the Opry moved to its suburban digs at Opryland in 1974, its longtime downtown home at 101-year-old Ryman Auditorium has been a rather forlorn museum. Tourists can still gaze at Roy Acuff's elephant-hide shoes and autographed baseball collection and view aged photographs of stars like Jim Reeves, Ernest Tubb and Stonewall Jackson, who, as the saying goes, were country when country wasn't cool.
Now it is being renovated with plans to reopen as a concert hall next June. The City Council in June approved plans for a $100 million downtown arena and hopes to lure an N.B.A. or N.H.L. franchise there. Gaylord Entertainment, which owns both Opryland U.S.A. and the Ryman, plans to link them with 57-foot-long water taxis in an unlikely blend of Venice and Garth Brooks.
 
Gentrifying the Hillbillies
 On Broadway, the ragged strip of ancient record stores, pawn shops, cheesy clubs and music shops that was once the industry's heart, not everyone is thrilled with the big plans.
"I think it's going to get too upscale and kill all the history," said Toby Carr, amid the fringed white boots, oversized beaverskin hats, banjos and guitars he sells at his Toby Carr Music, next to Tootsie's Orchid Lounge downtown. "Nashville hates the old Hee Haw Hillbilly image. When they talk about history they don't care about the music that made Nashville; all they want to preserve is the bricks. It could be wall-to-wall sushi bars for all they care."
But more common is a sense that country's suddenly mainstream image has an indelible demographic logic: people are listening to the suburban country of heartthrobs like Garth Brooks and Alan Jackson for pretty much the same reasons they're moving to Nashville and Charlotte.
"When people think of the good life they don't think about being on Wall Street in Manhattan; they think of having a home and raising a family in a place that's a decent place to do it," said Phil Bredesen, a Harvard-educated, health-care entrepreneur who became Nashville's mayor in 1991. "I think the culture that people admire is no longer the culture of the big cities of the Northeast. It's the culture of places like Nashville."
 
The South Rises
 In fact, there is no shortage of comparably sized metropolitan areas in the South like Charlotte, the Raleigh-Durham-Chapel Hill area of North Carolina or the Greenville-Spartanburg corridor in South Carolina that are doing quite well without the Music City moniker and music industry jobs.
According to the Bureau of Labor statistics, almost a third of the new jobs added in the first quarter of 1993 came in the eight-state Southern region that includes Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina and Tennessee. Using a slightly different definition of the Southeast, Charlotte's First Union bank recently reported that the Northeast and West Coast have lost more than 450,000 manufacturing jobs over the past two years while the Southeast has gained 23,000.
Here in Nashville, some worry that country may soon wear out its formula of hunky young male singers or that developers will repeat the real estate speculation that boomed in the early 80's and crashed a few years later.
But for now, most signals continue to flash green. One newcomer here is the novelist Jay McInerney, whose "Bright Lights, Big City" captured the cultural and pharmacological currents of New York in the 80's. He has since married a woman from Nashville, divides his time between New York and Nashville and is sniffing out the cultural aromas here.
"The zeitgeist," he said quoting the old country music aphorism, "seems to be heading in that direction."

HEADLINE: Salinas to Delay Nomination

BYLINE: Reuters)

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 28

 BODY:
Mexico's governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, in power since 1929, will postpone the ritual unveiling of its presidential candidate until after the fate of the North American Free Trade Agreement has been decided, party officials said today.
The officials declined to discuss any link between the two events, but said the nomination would be announced early next year and not around November as it has been in the past. 
 The unveiling of the ruling party candidate is viewed by most Mexicans as the naming of the next President by the incumbent because such candidates have won every presidential election for more than 60 years.
"The party's timetable is for the early part of next year, and all the comments we'll make will be after the new year," Fernando Ortiz Arana, president of the party's national executive committee, said in an interview faxed by the party to news agencies. There had been speculation that the unveiling would not take place before the new year as the choice of candidate might be affected by the success or failure of Nafta, which is viewed as the key to increasing Mexico's economic growth.
The trade pact, signed last December by the leaders of Canada, Mexico and the United States, is due to go into effect on Jan. 1 but has yet to be ratified by the United States Congress, where it faces strong opposition.
Thew three men believed to lead the list of candidates being considered by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari are Finance Minister Pedro Aspe Armella, Mayor Manuel Camacho Solis of Mexico City and Social Development Minister Luis Donaldo Colosio.

HEADLINE: South African Deal Made By Food Processor Pillsbury

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Sept. 28

 BODY:
Moving quickly after Nelson Mandela, head of the African National Congress, called Friday for an end to trade sanctions against South Africa, Pillsbury said today that it would create a joint venture with a leading South African food company to make and market Pillsbury products there.
Groups that have monitored American trade ties with South Africa said that Pillsbury's move was the first significant investment by an American company in South Africa since the plea by Mr. Mandela. They expect many other deals for marketing ventures and investments. 
 Pillsbury, which is based in Minneapolis and owned by Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. of Britain, said it would make a substantial investment in the factories of its partner, the Table Top division of Foodcorp. It will also transfer the technology necessary for the production of such foods as its Green Giant frozen and canned vegetables and Pillsbury frozen pizzas and cookie dough. The venture, to be known as Pillsbury Africa Ltd., plans to export to neighboring countries from the Table Top plants.
 
'An Exceptional Opportunity'
 "This joint venture provides us with an exceptional opportunity to build our Pillsbury brands in an area with outstanding growth potential," Paul Walsh, Pillsbury's chief executive, said in an official statement.
Pillsbury officials said that the deal had been negotiated in recent months by John R. Spiers, head of Pillsbury's international division, and Dirk Jacobs, chief executive of Foodcorp, but that the decision to go ahead would not have been made before Mr. Mandela's speech.
American depository receipts for shares of Grand Metropolitan closed up 37.5 cents yesterday at $25.50 on the New York Stock Exchange.
The African National Congress's campaign for international sanctions to force the end of apartheid in South Africa led many state and local governments in the United States to shun business with companies involved in South Africa. That in turn pressured more than 200 American companies to divest themselves of operations there during the 1980's.
"We have a lot of calls from companies expressing interest and asking about what state and local sanctions remain in place," said William Moses, senior policy analyst for the Investor Responsibility Research Center Inc., a Washington-based policy research firm.
Mr. Moses said the sanctions had had little impact on many consumer-goods companies that do not have large sales to publicly run institutions like schools and hospitals. Computer products are also widely available in South Africa, he said.
 
Moves Made in Anticipation
 Mr. Moses said his firm's research showed that there had already been a rapid increase in business relationships between American and South African companies this year as South Africa moved toward majority rule. The number of companies that have not directly invested in South Africa but have arrangements to sell their products there jumped to 420 this month from 349 in April, according to the center. The number with actual investments rose to 135 from 120 in the same period.
The figures do not include companies like Pillsbury that are not American-owned. Other Grand Met businesses have continued operating in South Africa throughout the international sanctions, and Grand Met now has more than 1,700 employees there, according to the center. One legal question is whether Pillsbury will be required to make sure that its joint venture follows employment practices specified by the American Government for United States companies doing business in South Africa.
Many of the new investments, like Pillsbury's, are likely to be partnerships, in part because American companies want to see the transition to a majority-rule government completed with some sign that the economy will not be undermined by racial violence.
"We've had teams down there investigating for a year and a half," said Edward Smyth, a spokesman for the H. J. Heinz Company. "The biggest hurdle is finding the right partner." Heinz's main effort at the moment has been in raising money for the South African Free Election Fund, a New York-based charity supporting voter registration for the planned elections in South Africa.
Pillsbury said that its venture, if successful, would lead to more employment in the South African cities of George and Port Elizabeth over a three-year period but declined to estimate how many jobs might result.
"Pillsbury's move will be seen as welcome, but what South Africa really wants is companies to build factories that weren't there before or to reopen those that have closed," Mr. Moses said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Down as Hopes Fade On Cutting the Trade Deficit

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the yen and most other currencies yesterday after a meeting of United States and Japanese leaders yielded few concrete signs of progress toward cutting the American trade deficit.
Gold prices rose. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery closed at $355.40 an ounce, up $1.70 from Monday; gold for October delivery rose $1.60, to $355.40 an ounce. 
 Currency traders said the markets were disappointed that no new initiatives on cutting the trade deficit emerged from a meeting Monday between President Clinton and Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa of Japan.
The yen has climbed about 15 percent against the dollar this year, in part on the perception that the United States Government wanted a stronger yen to help close the trade gap. A stronger yen makes Japanese imports in the United States more expensive, and American exports to that country cheaper.
Adding to the market's disappointment was a Washington Post report saying that Secretary of State Warren Christopher had told Mr. Hosokawa that the Government was not satisfied with the measures Japan has taken thus far, traders said.
"The market mostly thinks U.S.-Japanese relations are kind of sour again," said Win Thin, an economist at MCM Currencywatch, an analytic service. He added that he thought the market was too pessimistic.
The dollar also fell against the German mark, as worry about political upheaval in Russia abated. Investors had abandoned the mark last week on fears that Germany's economy could be vulnerable because of the country's trade and investment ties to Russia.
"Behind everything, point-blank, there was profit taking," he said.
In Tokyo, the dollar settled at 105.72 yen, down 0.55 yen from late Monday. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 105.20 yen, down from 105.90 on Monday. In New York, the dollar finished at 105.00 yen, down from 106.20.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.5135, from $1.5123 late Monday. In New York, the pound finished at $1.5130, slightly cheaper than $1.5135 on Monday.

HEADLINE: Go Personal, Whitman Is Implored

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Sept. 28

 BODY:
Top advisers to Christine Todd Whitman said today that the Republican gubernatorial candidate needed to shift her campaign strategy to an all-out attack on Gov. Jim Florio in response to a poll showing the New Jersey Governor with an unexpectedly large lead.
"Negative campaigns work; it's one of the tragedies of American politics," said Ed Rollins, chief political adviser to the Whitman campaign and a veteran of national campaigns. "Obviously, Florio has been running a very negative campaign and we have to do something about it. I think it is safe to say that if New Jersey voters have forgotten what Jim Florio did to them over the last four years, we are going to remind them." 
 Mrs. Whitman has avoided directly personal attacks against Mr. Florio, hammering away at the $2.8 billion tax increase he pushed through the Legislature in 1990 and attributing the state's sour economy to that. But a New York Times/WCBS-TV poll published today found a surprising degree of acceptance of the tax increases, as well as showing Mr. Florio with a lead of 51 percent to 30 percent over Mrs. Whitman among registered voters.
That sent the Whitman campaign scrambling to reassess its approach five weeks before Election Day.
"There has been a growing body of opinion that you have got to go out and very graphically and very forcibly attack those vulnerable spots," Carl Golden, spokesman for the Whitman campaign, said today. "You really have to go and do it. It isn't necessarily negative campaigning." It's a discussion, he said of "stuff that is already out there, and I think you will see some of that."
 
Plenty of People Undecided
 The poll also indicated great volatility among New Jersey voters, showing that just 46 percent of registered voters said that their minds were "made up," while the rest said they were undecided or might change their minds before the election.
Since the onset of the general-election campaign in June, Mr. Florio has run a hard-edged effort that has kept Mrs. Whitman on the defensive. The Governor, a Democrat, has depicted her as out of touch with voters because of her wealth, assailing her over two tax-sheltered farms she owns, and also as soft on crime.
James Carville, chief political strategist for Mr. Florio's campaign, remarked: "I think the mood around this joint for the next five weeks is going to continue to be as aggressive as it has been in the last five months. If anything, we are going trying to accelerate the pace. But we also expect the intensity of the political blows of Mrs. Whitman to increase."
The New York Times/WCBS-TV News showed that Mr. Florio's personal criticism of Mrs. Whitman had taken root among a majority of voters who gave the Governor much higher marks on questions of honesty and integrity, leadership and trust, despite their lingering anger over the tax increase.
Mrs. Whitman, in spite of what her advisers were saying, gave no indication today that she had shifted her strategy. Ending a visit to Washington, where she attended a fund-raiser on Monday night and toured the Holocaust Museum today, she told reporters that she and her advisers would keep the campaign on its current track despite the poll showing her trailing Mr. Florio.
 
Insisting on the Road Taken
 "What people have to remember are what his policies have done to the state, how badly they're hurt," she said. "They know what they're going to get with him -- more of the same. They have a choice."
Mrs. Whitman said she was not rattled by the poll results or the initial negative reception the public had given to her promise to cut the state budget by nearly $1.5 billion in three years if she is elected Governor. "It is very broad and bold," she said of the tax-cut plan, announced a week ago. "I expect people to be a little bit skeptical."
People close to Mrs. Whitman's campaign said that in private sessions, advisers had told her she must launch a nonstop negative campaign against Mr. Florio in the closing weeks in order to have any chance of winning.
"Christie does not like to be involved in a negative campaign and that's the big question," one informant, a senior Republican official, said. "Everybody knows what needs to be done; the question is will she sign off on it."
A chorus of Republican leaders, shaken by the poll results, urged Mrs. Whitman today to step up the level and intensity of attacks on Mr. Florio.
"You can't get shot at and not shoot back," said Jay Severin, a Republican consultant. "Her current campaign strategy is like an army that has run out of bullets.
"In order to win, this campaign must fundamentally change the way it has operated in virtually every aspect, and it will have to do it overnight," Mr. Severin said. "It's not just that she is behind at this point. That's the easy part. It's why she is behind."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Bell Canada to Reduce Its Work Force by 10%

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Sept. 28

 BODY:
Bell Canada, the largest telecommunications company in Canada, today announced its first big retrenchment in recent years, the result of intensified global competition and the rejection by Canadian regulators of proposed rate increases.
The company, which is based in Montreal and provides telephone and other communications services to 6.5 million business and residential customers in Ontario, Quebec and the eastern Arctic, said it planned to cut its work force by 10 percent, or 5,000 people, in the next few months. 
 For the moment, no layoffs are planned, Robert Kearney, the president of Bell Canada, said in a videotaped address to employees. Cutbacks will be through measures like reduced workweeks, leave-of-absence extensions, voluntary part-time programs and early retirements.
Analysts said they welcomed the move. "They needed to make some drastic decisions in order to achieve any semblance of a reasonable rate of return," said Robert J. Hastings, who follows telecommunications for Richardson Greenshields of Canada Ltd. in Toronto.
 
'Huge Labor Charges'
 "This is what everyone else is doing," added John Ing, the president of Maison Placements Canada, another investment firm based in Toronto. "Bell's labor charges are huge. They have a huge bureaucracy."
Bell Canada had managed to insulate itself from the recession that has overwhelmed much of Canadian industry in recent years and produced unemployment that is 50 percent higher than that in the United States. The unemployment rate in Canada is more than 11 percent.
The move today comes after the recent downgrading of Bell Canada's credit rating and a decision by credit agencies to put the company on a credit watch. "Our nonnegotiable priority must be to effect this reversal in the decline in earnings, or the negative effects will snowball," Mr. Kearney said.
Bell Canada and other provincial telephone companies lost their century-old monopoly in long-distance service last year, a factor that has intensified the competitive pressures on the Canadian giant that once was linked to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
 
A Common Founder
 Both companies were founded by Alexander Graham Bell, who was raised in Brantford, Ontario, about an hour's drive west of Toronto, but lived much of his life in Washington. A.T.& T. at one time owned as much as 49 percent of the stock of Bell Canada. A.T.& T. sold its entire stake in 1975.
Bell Canada is now fully owned by BCE Inc., a holding company based in Montreal, but the indirect pressure from A.T.& T. is behind some of the stepped-up competition faced by Bell Canada.
A.T.& T. owns 20 percent of Unitel Communications Inc., which is based in Toronto and competes with Bell Canada in the long-distance market.
So far unsuccessfully, Bell Canada has asked the regulators to raise the local telephone rates. It had sought a 40 percent increase to offset the revenue losses from the increased competition in long-distance service. As in the United States, long-distance subsidizes local service in Canada.
 
Local Service Compromised
 The new restraint program, Mr. Kearney said, would compromise some local phone service in Ontario and Quebec. "We will do the very best we can with the resources we have," he said.
Bell Canada earned $1 billion Canadian (about $750 million) last year on revenues of $7.8 billion (about $5.8 billion). Earnings have shown little growth over the last 6 or 7 years. In the first half of this year net income was $327 million (about $245 million), compared with $453 million (about $340 million) in the comparable period of 1992.
Bell Canada consulted with its unions before making today's announcement, and the response was restrained. The Canadian Telephone Employees Association, which represents 18,000 clerical and sales employees at Bell Canada, said "the majority of measures announced today are no surprise."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
California Bonds Well Received

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The hunger for yields while interest rates remain low made for a nice deal for California yesterday.
The state, which has yet to put its fiscal problems behind it, sold $800 million in general obligation bonds in a competitive sale won by Merrill Lynch & Company. 
 One measure of the demand was that Merrill Lynch lowered the yield it was planning to bid on the bonds, which run from one year to 30 years, by about 10 basis points between when it began talking to potential customers and the bidding deadline, according to Paul Kuhns, the director of municiapl markets.
Another sign was a comparison of a general obligation deal by California on March 31 and yesterday's offering. In March, the spread between the yield on the California 30-year bonds -- rated Aa by Moody's and A+ by S.& P. -- and triple A bonds tracked by Bloomberg Business News was 29 basis points. For yesterday's offering, that spread had narrowed to about 20 basis points, reflecting the willingness of portfolio managers and others to pay a higher price. Prices and yield move in the opposite direction.
Still, there was one sign that Merrill might have been more aggressive than it had to be. The other bid, from Goldman, Sachs & Company, was for a combined interest rate for all securities of 4.90 percent, a rate enough above Merrill's 4.835 percent to raise questions.
But Mr. Kuhns argued that Merrill could be more aggressive because it would have an easier job selling the California bonds. "We have such a strong distribution system" and many more firms in the entire syndicate that bid with Merrill on the bonds, he said.
But David Johnson, manager of tax-exempt mutual funds at Van Kampen Investment Advisory Group in Oakbrook Terrace, Ill., said the yields on the California issues were too low. He offered to buy some of the bonds from the Merrill lead syndicate, but the lower price he was willing to pay made the yields about 8 basis points higher then the Merrill bid.
David Andersen, the other director of municipal markets at Merrill, said that by late yesterday there was still about $390 million of the bonds in the syndicate. He said that about $150 million of that was in one- to five-year maturities, which some money managers were reluctant to buy because they had very high coupon interest rates, pushing the price unusually high above par, or face value.
For example, the bonds due in 1996 pay a coupon interest rate of 11 percent on the face value of the bond. But the actual yield, after factoring in a price of over $120 for a face value of $100, is 3.40 percent. He said that many funds can not buy bonds when the premium over par is that high.
Mr. Kuhns said that the tone of the market yesterday, with long-term yields down in the morning bidding, and the fact that other deals yesterday offered even lower yields made money managers willing to pay a little more for the California offering. The sharp drop in interest rates on Monday, when the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond dropped below 6 percent again, also pulled down yields.
He said that as the talks with customers for the California deal went on, the yields were also being lowered for a separate competitive issue, a $316.6 million refunding of general obligation bonds from Mecklenburg County, N.C., which are rated triple A. Merrill also won that issue.
As the yields on this sale fell, he said, people looked at California, Although the offering might have been a little more expensive than they wanted, they were willing to pay a little more because the yield was higher.
He said it was the pressure for higher returns, which has already helped drive the yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond below 6 percent, rather than an improvement in the fiscal condition of California that apparently accounted for California's getting a better interest on yesterday's deal than the one in March.
Mr. Kuhns also noted that some of the demand for the California issue came from buyers, like large investment firms, which get no advantage from the tax-exempt status of the municipal bonds. They are called cross-over buyers.
They want the bonds for their potential price performance not the yield. They are betting that the price on a municipal bond will rise faster than the price on a comparable Treasury security.
This has been a popular bet this year, but it has not worked very well because so far yields on Treasury securities have come down faster than those on tax-exempt securities, which means Treasury prices have risen more.
But if a buyer thinks that interest rates are now moving higher, then the cross-over buy might work. If rates do rise, it is expected that the prices of Treasury securities will fall faster than those of municipal bonds.
In the California deal, the bonds were priced to yield from 2.50 percent in 1994 to 5.00 percent for the bond due in 2010 through 2013. The 30-year bond due in 2023 was priced to yield 5.24 percent.
 
Treasury Market
 The prices of Treasury bonds and yields bobbed around yesterday but there was little change on the day. The price of the 30-year bond rose 3/32 as the yield held at 5.94 percent. the yield on the 10-year note ended at 5.29 percent, up from 5.28 percent, and the yield on the two-year note rose to 3.79 percent from 3.78 percent.

LENGTH: 1626 words

HEADLINE: How Demand Surged for Prostate Test

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
DR. JOSEPH E. OESTERLING, a urologist at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., recently polled practicing doctors in his state to ask whether they were using a widely promoted screening test for prostate cancer. Ninety-two percent said they routinely used it on men over 50.
But the blood test, which costs $50 to $80 per patient, has not yet been approved by the Food and Drug Administration as a screening test and no data yet exist to show that it has an effect on long-term medical outcome. 
 The test, known as the P.S.A. test, for prostate specific antigen, also has a high rate of false positive results, meaning that a positive result leads to other, more expensive follow-up tests and treatments to confirm it. Almost 1 in 5 people with high P.S.A. levels does not have cancer, and nearly 1 in 4 with prostate cancer has normal P.S.A. levels.
Some economists estimate it would cost the nation $28 billion a year if all men 50 and over have the test, along with subsequent tests and treatments for those with positive results.
 
Effectiveness of Test
 A study reported this summer in The Journal of the American Medical Association found the test to be twice as effective as a physical examination in finding early cancer, and many doctors and patients are convinced of its usefulness.
But the question remains, in this time of national agony over health care costs, how did an unapproved test with potentially astronomical costs become entrenched as part of the nation's medical system? Despite the lack of F.D.A. approval, the test is recommended for screening by the American Cancer Society and the American Urological Association. But it has not been endorsed for that purpose by the National Cancer Institute or the United States Preventive Services Task Force, a federally sponsored but independent group that draws up medical guidelines.
Doctors and health care analysts say the story of the P.S.A. test's rise to prominence and acceptance shows the power of the pharmaceutical and device industry to create and increase demand for a product. Even doctors who say they are convinced that the test is saving lives say it would never be so popular today were it not for aggressive promotions.
For example, proponents and opponents of the test agree that much of the public demand was elicited by the enthusiastic advertising of the annual Prostate Cancer Awareness Week, paid for by the makers of drugs to treat the cancer and by makers of the P.S.A. test. The ubiquitous public service advertisements featuring celebrities like the baseball star Stan Musial are paid for by TAP Pharmaceuticals of Deerfield, Ill., a maker of a prostate cancer treatment.
The companies also support a patient group, Us Too, which sent a representative to a recent meeting held by the National Cancer Institute to discuss the merits of the test and to an F.D.A. advisory committee meeting last spring to discuss an application by Hybritech of San Diego, a division of Eli Lilly & Company, to market the P.S.A. test as a screening test. The committee asked for more data than the company had supplied and said that if the test received approval, it should be used to screen only men at high risk.
 
Drumming Up Demand
 "To me, the whole issue of P.S.A. testing is, in a microcosm, what's wrong with our health care system," said Dr. Peter Albertson, a urologist at the University of Connecticut in Farmington. "Industry is pumping a lot of money into this and creating a demand for a product."
Urologists benefit because the test has made the prostate "the biggest money-maker for urologists, a large part of a urology business," he said. Hospitals benefit because prostate patients fill many beds. So, he said, even though the test has limitations, "sometimes people don't want to look too hard at a gift horse."
Dr. John Wasson, director of the Center for Aging at Dartmouth College, agreed. Now that the test is so widely accepted, he added, "the scary thing is, this will happen with other tests in the future."
Dr. Oesterling, a proponent of the test who is nevertheless critical of the marketing tactics, explained how the test's makers persuaded doctors to use it. "They marketed the heck out of it," he said. "They went around the country saying, 'Doctor, you need to get a P.S.A. on your patients. Start using it, start using it.' The next thing, patients started coming in and saying, 'Doctor, check my P.S.A.' "
The test detects a protein, P.S.A., that leaks into the blood from the prostate, a walnut-size gland that produces fluid that nourishes sperm. Prostate cancers can lead to high levels of the protein, but so can innocuous enlargements of the gland. Sometimes men have high P.S.A. levels with no apparent cause. The F.D.A. approved the test in 1986 as a way of following the progress of cancer in men in whom the cancer had already been diagnosed. But once a test is on the market, doctors can use it for other purposes, at their own discretion.
Prostate cancer is the leading cancer among men and the second leading cause of cancer deaths among men. After the cancer spreads outside the prostate there is little that doctors can do to treat it. Proponents of the test say that it can find prostate cancers while they are still small and potentially curable.
Opponents say that it has never been shown that P.S.A. screening has an effect on the ultimate outcome of the disease for most men. As many as 70 percent of all men in their 80's have early prostate cancer, but in a vast majority these cancers remain undetected and unthreatening. No one knows which cancers will turn out to be deadly and no one can say whether early treatment with surgery or radiation cures them. And the treatment has its own risks, often resulting in impotence and incontinence.
The P.S.A. test, as Dr. Albertson recalls it, came to prominence in the late 1980's, spurred by several developments. Reports in medical journals about the success of the P.S.A. in detecting tumors brought it to the attention of urologists and other doctors. Then the follow-up test, which had required a hospital visit, suddenly became a quick and easy office procedure when makers of transrectal ultrasound machines began selling them to urologists, complete with a spring-loaded biopsy gun, to obtain tissue samples.
 
'A No-Brainer'
 "Overnight, a procedure that required booking in the hospital became basically a no-brainer," Dr. Albertson said. "It became a test that takes 15 minutes, with no pain, and is relatively risk-free."
At the same time, the marketing of prostate cancer screening began. In 1989, the first Prostate Cancer Awareness Week was held, with a campaign engineered by the New York public relations firm of Burson-Marsteller, and paid for by the Schering-Plough Corporation.
Last year, said Dr. Stephen Rubino, senior product manager at Schering Laboratories in Kenilworth, N.J., the pharmaceutic company paid $1.2 million for this campaign. For this year's campaign, which began on Sept. 20, other companies and the American Cancer Society have joined to share the burden with Schering-Plough, whose share of this year's $240,000 campaign is $100,000. The campaign is under the auspices of the Prostate Cancer Education Council, a group of doctors, health educators and patient support groups.
The campaign has been "extremely successful," said Dr. E. David Crawford, a urologist at the University of Colorado Health Sciences Center in Denver who is head of the education council. Dr. Crawford said that when it began in 1989, the group hoped to draw a few thousand men for screening. Instead, he said: "We had an overwhelming response. Fifteen thousand men came to 91 sites for screening. The next year we had 150,000. The years after that, we had over half a million."
Dr. Stephen Brenner, an internist who has a private practice in New Haven, said that he got many requests for the test, and that he felt he could not refuse to do it, even though he had reservations about its usefulness as a screening tool.
 
'An Avalanche' of Requests
 "It's an avalanche," he said. "It's really snowballed. The overwhelming majority of my male patients are aware of the test. They'll either ask about it or request it." He also worries about malpractice suits. And, he added: "I feel it can be helpful, but I don't know when."
Dr. Brenner said he felt the Prostate Cancer Awareness Weeks were "pretty transparent." He added: "I'm opposed to industry promoting products to patients. I am opposed to demand coming from industry. We ought to have firm scientific evidence that a test is useful before we start using it."
Last year, the American Cancer Society recommended that all men over 50 have an annual P.S.A. test and digital rectal examination. It recommended that men with a family history of the disease or who are black, placing them at higher risk, have the tests every year starting at 40.
JoAnn Schellenbach, a spokeswoman for the cancer society, said the reason for the screening recommendation was that "men were having the test anyway."
"Doctors were doing it," she said. "We needed to spell out some very distinct practice guidelines. That is more useful than debating and riding the fence."
Now, some researchers question whether it will ever be possible to learn if the test saves lives. The only definitive way to do that would be to enroll men in a study, randomly assigning some to have it and others not to and then see which group benefited most. This is a study that the National Cancer Institute hopes to do.
But, Dr. Oesterling said: "That study will never get done. You are never going to find in the United States any more a control group of people who will not get a P.S.A."
