HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
A Serious Look at a Humorous Man

BYLINE: By MARGO JEFFERSON

 BODY:

Will Rogers
 By Ben Yagoda
 Illustrated. 409 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $27.50.
Why is it that certain legends pale after their own time? Will Rogers is known to many today mostly because of the recent and frivolous Broadway musical. You could say that a man who claimed he'd never met a man he didn't like deserves no better. But you could also say, and show, as the journalist and English professor Ben Yagoda ably shows, that a man who managed to get himself liked and listened to by Calvin Coolidge, Dorothy Parker, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Woody Guthrie and H. L. Mencken deserves more sustained analytic attention. 
 Will Rogers was born in 1879, into a generation shaped by the last days of Victorianism and the first days of modernism. D. W. Griffith and Cecil B. DeMille in movies, Scott Joplin and W. C. Handy in music, Rogers and George M. Cohan on the stage and Ruth St. Denis and Isadora Duncan in modern dance: all were determined to fuse modern forms with folk or antique content. Rogers looked back to the Noble Savage and the Frontiersman while looking forward to the stand-up comic as cultural commentator: a Johnny Carson, in Mr. Yagoda's words, with touches of Walter Cronkite, Bill Cosby and Ross Perot.
His biography opens with a cultural paradox: Will Rogers was a cowboy and an Indian. He was the son of wealthy Cherokees, second-generation settlers in the Indian Territory, which became part of Oklahoma. Clem and Mary Rogers were mixed bloods (part white, part Indian), with full rights in the Cherokee Nation. Since Clem had fought for the Confederacy and had amassed 60,000 acres of land along with cattle and wheat holdings, he had nearly full rights in the European-American nation as well.
Will grew up a rich man's son, among white, Indian and black farmers and cowmen. He rode and practiced roping for hours, and he preferred ragtime songs and cakewalk contests to school. When he saw the virtuosic rope tricks of a Mexican vaquero at the Chicago World's Fair of 1893, he fell in love with show business and got his first job in 1903 with a Wild West show that toured South Africa. He was billed as the Cherokee Kid and was recommended by his boss as the "Champion Trick Roughrider and Lasso Thrower of the World."
A year later he played a dying soldier in a re-creation of Custer's Last Stand at the St. Louis World's Fair. Sitting Bull was played by the Apache chief Geronimo, on loan to the show from prison. There is no record of what Rogers thought (he would later say that Thanksgiving was invented by Pilgrims to "give thanks every time they killed an Indian and took more of his land").
Rogers took his rope tricks into vaudeville in 1905, just as the nation was going mad for all things Western. The move from cowboy to comedian came when he began explaining to his audiences, with ostensible casualness, how hard those tricks were. Jokes about tricks that might fail turned into jokes about gags that might fail.
Instead of lassoing cast or audience members onto the stage for a mock interview, he started bringing a newspaper onto the stage, and making fun of its contents in language that paired plain talk (frontier dialect) with hip talk (city slang). Is there a late-night comic who isn't still using every one of these tricks?
"It's not the highest type of work, this acting a fool," he declared in 1925, when he was the top-drawing star of the Ziegfeld Follies. "But it's the best I will ever get."
Bunk, to use one of his favorite words. A few years later he was sending up the nation's social and economic follies in syndicated newspaper columns. He was at his best during the Depression, raising money for drought-stricken states and putting his mouth where his money was.
At his worst, the same man who called J. P. Morgan an outlaw in 1922 called Mussolini the "right" kind of dictator in 1933. The line between folk wisdom and folk ignorance can be pitifully thin: Rogers's world view was, in Mr. Yagoda's words, "common-sense cracker-barrel."
"The cracker-barrel view has a hard time with tragedy (though it does fine with sentiment), with ambiguity, and with evil, and so it was with Will. . . . For the Ku Klux Klan, for Hitler . . . he had only mild gibes."
Part of the Rogers appeal, in fact, lay in an "implicit refusal to challenge the core beliefs of his audience" or to "upset the applecart," Mr. Yagoda writes. In this light it's easy to see why James Agee, writing in 1944 about the hypocrisies of commercial American folk culture, denounced Rogers. But Agee was writing just nine years after Rogers's death. Now, 50 years later, Rogers the innovator can be seen as clearly as Rogers the panderer, and should be no harder to grasp, say, than the fact that D. W. Griffith's "Birth of a Nation" is great cinema and atrocious history.
As a performer, Rogers pioneered a kind of crafty naturalism that John Ford, who directed him in three movies, knew would serve Westerns for the next 30 years. (Joel McCrea, Roy Rogers and Gene Autry were all fans). His portrayal of the rich Western hayseed trying to hold his own in the city was refined by Gary Cooper and refueled by Ralph Bellamy in 30's romantic comedies. And his portrait of the salt-of-the-earth codger, full of "kinders," "sorters" winks and shrugs, was brought intact to television by Buddy Ebsen and Walter Brennan.
But we have entered a realm of highly mixed cultural blessings. So before you are left alone with reruns of "The Beverly Hillbillies" or with your copy of "Ole Rivers," Walter Brennan's hit record about his mule, let us turn back to the Will Rogers of the Jazz Age.
You must picture him in a smart Western shirt and breeches, with a kerchief around his neck and a felt hat angled just so, almost as men wear fedoras. He looks sensational in the 1923 silent "The Ropin' Fool," riding a goat and using two big lassos to rope a horse and rider simultaneously, then jumping in and out of two smaller ropes like a cowboy mastering Double Dutch. Let a cast member of the 1924 Ziegfeld Follies have the last word.
"My moment of delight came at the end," recalled Louise Brooks, who was smart, finicky, 18 and fresh from a tour with the Denishawn Dancers. "Will Rogers and I climbed a ladder to the top of a 15-foot tower set in the middle of the stage. Starting with a tiny noose on his lasso, Rogers would twirl it faster and faster, bigger and bigger, until the rope hissed in a circle around us like an intoxicated snake as the curtains opened and the dazzling spotlight shone upon us."
What New Vaudevillean wouldn't give his eye teeth for a finish like that?

HEADLINE: Jury Duty Is Exactly That -- a Duty

 BODY:
In New York State, foot doctors are exempted by law from state juries. So are embalmers, police, optometrists, lawyers and practitioners in more than a dozen other lines of work. Such a long list makes it hard for courts to line up all the jurors they need at a given time. That's wrong. The list should be repealed.
The under-representation of minorities in jury pools is also wrong. That happens because prospective jurors' names are taken from three lists that do not represent the whole population: registered voters, licensed drivers and the state's mailing list of taxpayers. The Constitution guarantees every defendant the right to trial "by an impartial jury," which the courts have interpreted to mean a jury drawn from a cross-section of the community. The remedy for New York's deficiency is rather simple -- broader lists. 
 The state's Chief Judge, Judith Kaye, and the Chief Administrative Judge, Leo Milonas, have named a special panel to recommend changes in the jury selection process, along with ways to improve the quality of jury life. The panel will report by year's end, but a solution to the under-representation of minorities may come even sooner.
This summer the State Legislature approved a bill introduced by Deputy Speaker Arthur Eve, Democrat of Buffalo, to draw jurors' names from two more lists: people who receive or have applied for welfare payments, and people receiving unemployment benefits. The bill offered a fair resolution to a clearly unfair situation, but was vetoed for technical reasons; it did not, for example, adequately protect the confidentiality of people on welfare or jobless insurance. It is expected that the flaws can be resolved, and the bill enacted.
Politically, the issue of automatic exemption is far more difficult. A bill by Assemblyman Pete Grannis, Democrat of New York City, would eliminate all of the 20 automatic exemptions now embedded in law. It has reached the Assembly calendar this year, for the first time, but there it sits.
There is no grand design to the exemption list. It just grew when lobbyists for various interest groups persuaded the Legislature to exempt them. Those lobbyists, as well as legislators who are lawyers or doctors themselves, are less than enthusiastic about repeal.
Wholesale repeal may sound drastic. It's not. There would still be procedures for individuals to be excused if they convince the court that jury duty would cause undue hardship -- such as having to shutter a one-person shop.
The number of people who claim automatic exemption may not be great, but the message is rotten; it says that if you're a somebody you needn't serve. Jury service is an obligation of citizenship. It should not be open to easy escape.

HEADLINE: In America;
Voodoo Lunch

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT

 BODY:
I was dressed very nicely, thank you, in a sport jacket, neatly pressed slacks and a striped tie. I told the man behind the counter in the Upper West Side restaurant that I wanted a cheeseburger, not too well done, with ketchup.
I also told him that I had no money.
He laughed without showing any amusement and then his face settled into a look of impatience. 
 "I'm serious," I said. "I would like it for free."
"Get outta here," he said, waving his hand, and that was that.
I pulled this stunt a few times, just to see how people would react. A waiter with a heavy Middle Eastern accent said, "Where do you think you are? This is America! Here you have to pay."
I always thought so. But for the past several years politicians have been trying to sell voters on the idea that you can get something for nothing. They seem to be saying that perhaps there is such a thing as a free lunch.
Ronald Reagan was almost religious in his conviction that you could raise revenues by cutting taxes. George Bush, while less devout, held similar beliefs. Nevertheless, during the Reagan era, and while we were reading Mr. Bush's lips, the Government was hemorrhaging money.
Even Bill Clinton campaigned on the idea of tax reductions for the middle class.
With a Federal budget deficit of more than $200 billion, and with state and local governments financially strapped, you would think the politicians had learned something by now.
Enter Christine Todd Whitman, the Republican candidate for governor of New Jersey. Mrs. Whitman is out-Reaganing Reagan. Despite a budget shortfall that could approach $2 billion next year, Mrs. Whitman is proposing the biggest tax cut in the state's history.
In a TV ad she tells voters: ". . . as governor I am going to cut your taxes every year for the next three years, 10 percent each year for most people."
It is a move that is breathtakingly irresponsible.
George Bush called Ronald Reagan's budget proposals in 1980 "voodoo economics."
New Jersey's Democratic Governor, Jim Florio, calls Mrs. Whitman's proposal "voodoo redo."
Mr. Florio was supposed to have been finished politically three years ago when -- at the tail end of the Reagan-Bush era -- he gave New Jersey its biggest tax increase. The Governor's approval rating plummeted and opponents have been attacking him on the tax issue ever since.
But something unusual is happening in New Jersey. A New York Times poll this week showed Mrs. Whitman running well behind the Governor. The voters are not happy about Mr. Florio's tax increases but they seem to be grudgingly conceding that they may have been necessary.
At the same time there is skepticism about Mrs. Whitman's tax cut plan. A tugboat captain was quoted in The Times as saying, "If Whitman cuts the income tax, isn't the money just going to come out of another pocket, or end up with more deficit that will hurt the economy?"
Now might be a good time for politicians around the country to take a look at New Jersey. Mr. Florio exercised tough leadership, both on the tax issue and on a stringent gun control law. He is benefiting from that, and from an opponent who is making promises that few people believe she can deliver.
Elsewhere there seems to be a mortal fear of telling voters -- especially middle-class voters -- that they have to pay for what they get. The President and a majority of both parties in Congress seem to believe that we can bring the nation's fiscal problems under control and establish a system of universal health care without the middle class having to ante up in any significant way.
Hillary Rodham Clinton was on Capitol Hill yesterday, testifying on health care. "There are so many lessons to be learned," she said.
She could have said the same thing about poverty or crime or homelessness, or about the problems of employment or education. All are difficult problems and none will be solved if the middle class just takes a pass.
The lesson to be learned from New Jersey is that politicians do not have to hide the truth -- even tough truths -- from the electorate.

HEADLINE: Essay;
On Dying Hard

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
At the Battle of Albuera in 1811, the wounded Col. William Inglis, commander of the 57th Foot Regiment, cried out to his troops: "Die hard, men, die hard!" Since that victory, the Middlesex regiment has been called "the Diehards."
Diehards today are in ill repute, sometimes deservedly so. In the besieged Parliament building in Moscow, cut off from food, water and electricity, an infuriated Aleksandr Rutskoi and a haggard Ruslan Khasbulatov lead a band of Communist apparatchiks defying the Russian President's order to surrender. 
 They are dying hard for the cause of a return to a command economy, centralization of power, gulags, oppression, militarism, imperialism, employer mandates, the whole discredited Socialist works. If the last-ditch defenders of the Brezhnev era were to win, Russia would lose.
But Mr. Rutskoi's diehards intend to provoke the K.G.B. and military units surrounding them into storming their citadel, giving them a chance for political martyrdom. At that moment, world opinion would recoil; President Clinton would have to dissociate himself from President Yeltsin; and across Russia's 11 time zones, a legend of "Rutskoi's last stand" would take root.
Why? Because bravery is admirable. The 200 or so legislators who have slipped out of the embattled Parliament to take advantage of job offers from the Yeltsinites are cowardly opportunists. The remaining diehards, suffering for their repugnant cause, know that they draw from the most grudging democrat at least a moment of admiration.
And they know that their stand, if they can induce Mr. Yeltsin's troops to blaze away, will be remembered in history. Oliver Cromwell shouted to a Parliament unwilling to commit regicide, "It is not fit that you should sit here any longer!" In the ensuing "Pride's purge," a Cromwellian colonel arrested 96 reluctant legislators, leaving a "rump Parliament" to behead the King.
That's the stuff of history; centuries from now, Russian students will learn about Yeltsin's own defiance of coup plotters atop a tank, and -- if today's diehards get their wish -- of the last stand of the brave apparatchiks in Russia's rump Parliament (slyly supported by the displaced Mikhail Gorbachev).
The cameras are in place; the cordon of troops is tightening; the last-ditch bravery of a few is ready to go on display; the only thing missing for history-making is the blunder of impatient authority.
We all saw what happened when authority grew impatient with demonstrators at Tiananmen. Students demonstrating for democracy are not to be equated with bureaucrats demonstrating for Communism, but sympathy will be on the side of those on the receiving end of bludgeons.
We have diehards for a better cause elsewhere. Many Bosnian patriots (usually described with distaste as "Muslim nationalists") dare to demand two-fifths of their former country rather than the one-third dictated by the U.N. They want some "cleansed" Muslim areas back before they surrender most of Bosnia to Greater Serbia and Greater Croatia. And they are willing to continue fighting for some national viability against the odds, despite being denied arms to defend themselves by John Major and Francois Mitterrand.
Those dumb diehards, say the world's imposers. Don't they realize they've lost, they're going to get killed, and -- even worse -- on camera, making us uncomfortable? Don't they know how to be good losers?
Old diehards like Rutskoi clung to their beliefs or power-hunger in the hope of historic vindication beyond the grave. New diehards in Bosnia and Kurdistan have grasped the idea that the hardness of the public dying might force others to prevent it.
If Bosnia's patriots insist on fighting on, would the American President not ask the U.N. to lift the embargo? If he does, would John Major cast the veto -- as he once threatened Clinton with doing -- that would end the Anglo-American special relationship? If new Bosnian arms level the fighting field, would the Serbs and Croats not offer a more honorable peace?
That's the way new diehards think. It's gutsy, and Americans have a claim on the quality: "I die hard," George Washington reportedly said on his deathbed, "but I am not afraid."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Palestinians to Get $2 Billion In Pledges of Aid for Self-Rule

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29

 BODY:
Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip will receive pledges of about $2 billion in aid to bolster their economy from more than three dozen countries -- including a multimillion dollar pledge from Israel -- at an American-organized sponsors' conference in Washington on Friday, Administration officials said today.
In the aftermath of the recent agreement between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization, Washington organized the conference to provide tangible evidence that the accord will improve the lives of the Palestinians in the occupied territories and defuse the attraction of groups like Hamas, the Islamic militant organization. 
 The United States, the European Community, Japan and Scandinavia have already signaled they would pledge more than $1.4 billion in aid over five years, these officials said, in varying proportions of direct grants, loans and other forms of assistance. Israel's decision to contribute to the Palestinian fund marks one of the historic paradoxes. Once bitter enemies, the two are now pledged to cooperate.
 
Saudis' Commitment Unclear
 On the other hand, a question mark surrounds the position of Saudi Arabia, which over the years has contributed billions of dollars to the P.L.O. But the Saudis cut off aid to the P.L.O. when its leader, Yasir Arafat, backed Iraq in the Persian Gulf war of 1990-1991. After the Israeli-P.L.O. accord, President Clinton asked King Fahd of Saudi Arabia to give his support, and he told the President that even though he still bore a grudge, he would help the P.L.O. out.
So far, however, the Saudis have not signaled the size of any contribution that they might make, although American officials said they hope Saudi Arabia would make a major pledge.
Officials involved in planning the 38-nation conference said Israel would make a direct contribution of about $25 million as the participants seek to give the Palestinians quick, tangible benefits from their agreement with Israel, which sets the stage for local Palestinian self-rule in the occupied lands, starting with Israeli withdrawal from the Gaza strip and the West Bank city of Jericho.
American officials said today that they would provide $500 million in grants and aid to the Palestinians over the next five years, a significant increase from the $250 million over two years that Washington pledged last week.
Administration officials said President Clinton had ordered the State Department and Treasury, the two departments that organized the conference, to make sure the aid produced rapid and visible results in the West Bank and Gaza to demonstrate that the peace accord was making a difference.
 
Pressure to Raise U.S. Pledge
 As host of Friday's gathering of ministers from the United States, Europe and several Arab countries, the Administration has come under significant pressure, from within and without, to put up more money so that its pledge would not be overshadowed by other countries, such as the European Community's pledge of $600 million over five years.
American, Palestinian and World Bank officials said the aid would be used to help set up a new civil administration in the Gaza Strip and West Bank, pay police salaries, help the poor, build housing, and finance investment in public services, like schools and sewers.
Officials from the Palestine Liberation Organization said this week that it was not yet clear what institution would receive and disburse the aid planned to help the 1.7 million Palestinians in the occupied territories.
 
Development Authority Set Up
 United Nations aid organizations already active in the territories are expected to distribute the aid over the next month or two. In interviews this week, American, Palestinian, and World Bank officials said a possible vehicle to handle aid long-term is the Palestine Economic Development and Reconstruction Authority, which was set up by P.L.O. officials this month.
This Friday's meeting will aim not just to win pledges, but to coordinate aid and technical assistance, and press the P.L.O. to build institutions and economic bodies that can handle a large flow of aid. The donor countries are eager for the Palestinians to develop an administration that knows how to budget, enforce budgetary discipline and prevent corruption.
American officials said they now anticipate overall aid of $400 million or more flowing to the Occupied Territories annually -- officials say at least one half of that will be loans, the rest being grants. That is considerably more than the level the World Bank originally said was needed in a study it completed shortly before Israel and the P.L.O. signed their peace accord.
Ram K. Chopra, the World Bank's director for the Middle East, said in an interview that the Palestinians need aid of $400 million to $475 million a year, well above the bank's previous estimate of $300 million a year. He said the bank's original study did not take into account the need to finance a civil government or the prospect that tens of thousands of Palestinian refugees would return to the area as a result of the peace accord.
"Now we see they will need money for a police force and for a civil administration," Mr. Chopra said.
The original World Bank estimates were just for basic investments in sewers, health care, education and other areas to satisfy the Palestinians' basic needs. Unlike estimates in the original report, the new, higher estimates also anticipate some relief for the poor and some foreign aid to finance new housing.
American and Palestinian officials agree that it is important that the Palestinians feel quick economic gains to help defuse militancy in the Gaza Strip and West Bank.
"Any improvement in the economic situation will be felt by Hamas, too," Yousef Sayigh, a senior economic adviser to the P.L.O., said at a seminar here on Tuesday. "They have to feed their children, too."
In an interview today, the Israeli Finance Minister, Avraham Shochat, said an end to violence was vital. "If there is terror, knifing and shootings, no one is gong to invest there," he said.
Mr. Shochat said Israel would transfer some of the tax revenues it receives from the occupied territories to help finance the Palestinian civil administration. Such a move could provide several hundred million dollars to the Palestinians over the next decade, and economists say this could significantly reduce the need for foreign aid.
Reacting to criticisms that Israel has taken a patronizing approach to the Palestinians, Mr. Shochat said, "We don't want to impose ourselves on them, but we do want to help."
Israeli officials said they planned to open their markets further to Palestinian products, especially by gradually removing barriers to farm goods from the Occupied Territories.
American officials said that in addition to the offers by Washington and the European Community, Japan has pledged $200 million over two years, while the Nordic countries have pledged $150 million over an unspecified number of years. Canada, India and several Persian Gulf nations have also indicated that they would contribute.
In addition, World Bank officials are organizing a $75 million emergency package to provide technical assistance and help get a Palestinian civil government off the ground.

HEADLINE: Murdoch in Accord With Craft Unions On Reopening Post

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON

 BODY:
After a flurry of behind-the-scenes activity, Rupert Murdoch said yesterday that he was willing to return, once again, to publishing The New York Post.
The price was capitulation by the production unions whose members, for a time, supported a strike by the New York Newspaper Guild, which represents news, advertising and circulation employees. 
 After a daylong series of talks prompted by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Mr. Murdoch reached a new agreement with the leaders of the production unions under which they pledged that their members would return to work if Mr. Murdoch resumed management of the newspaper. The agreement set the stage for a bitter confrontation today between strikers and nonstrikers that could test the viability of labor unions in the New York newspaper industry as never before.
 
Persuading Murdoch
 Last night, Howard J. Rubenstein, a spokesman for Mr. Murdoch, said the leaders of the Allied Printing Trades Council, the umbrella group of all newspaper unions except for the guild, helped persuade Mr. Murdoch to return to the management of The Post by assuring him that their members would return to work despite the strike. He said the newspaper's nonunion editors would prepare to put out Friday's paper.
"He decided to give a last chance to the unions to do what they promised to on Monday and didn't do," Mr. Rubenstein said. He added that Mr. Murdoch appeared persuaded that "cooler heads will prevail" among production workers, who had seen Mr. Murdoch prepared to eliminate their jobs by closing the paper. Mr. Rubenstein said he was confident they would now cross the guild picket line that they had refused to cross on Monday.
George McDonald, head of the Allied Printing Trades Council, said yesterday that the unions came to terms because the rank and file were "concerned about their jobs."
"I know there were some guys who didn't want to cross," he said, referring to the picket line set up by guild members on Monday night. "They'll cross tomorrow night."
The president of the striking guild, Barry F. Lipton, whose union was isolated by yesterday's agreement, said he remained confident that the individual members of the production unions at The Post would respect his union's fight and would refuse to cross the picket line.
"I know we'll be out here," Mr. Lipton said on the picket line outside The Post's South Street headquarters, "and I think we'll have significant support."
Mr. Lipton was also critical of Mr. McDonald's moves to cooperate with Mr. Murdoch. "It's a disgrace that a person who purports to be a labor leader would assist in the attempt to kill a union," he said.
But the mood among some of those involved suggested that the leaders of the production unions were desperately searching for a way to satisfy Mr. Murdoch and manuever their own members past the guild picket lines.
 
Message From Murdoch
 One person involved in the talks, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said union leaders had received a message delivered through intermediaries who appeared to be speaking for Mr. Murdoch. The message was that Mr. Murdoch would return to run the newspaper only if it was clear that he had prevailed.
"This is not about money," the person said. "It is not about job security. It is about who wins."
The guild represents 287 employees. The heart of the guild's dispute with Mr. Murdoch is his insistence that he be able to dismiss guild members -- one group at a time for each of four months -- as his executives review their usefulness. The guild has proposed a program of voluntary buyouts and an impartial review procedure.
But Mr. Murdoch insisted on the sole power to review guild employees and carry out dismissals without paying severance. The guild said it could not remain a union and permit its members to be dismissed in such a manner.
The leaders of the production unions have had a wary relationship with the guild in recent years. That relationship turned poisonous last winter when Mortimer B. Zuckerman took over The Daily News and, in effect, dismissed more than 170 guild members in a single night.
The production unions had already made separate pacts with Mr. Zuckerman at that time, as they have now at The Post. Already nursing other slights by the guild in other confrontations, the production unions at The News said the guild had been reckless in failing to reach an agreement and they refused to support the guild.
When a similar situation presented itself at The Post under Mr. Murdoch, the leaders of the production unions miscalculated, believing their members would cross a guild picket line or, perhaps, that that the mere threat of crossing the lines would keep the guild from calling a strike in the first place. Some of The Post's production workers would be able to work at other papers if The Post folded.
Mr. Murdoch's threats to dismiss guild members, and his unwillingness to honor severance commitments that would have given out-of-work Post employees some economic security, however, meant that many guild members believed they had little to lose by striking.
But when the guild essentially called the bluff of both Mr. Murdoch and the production unions by going on strike Monday, it had one advantage that people involved in the situation say was underestimated by leaders of the other unions. With only 700 employees, many of whom have worked together for decades, members of the various unions knew each other well.
Some Post guild members had family members in the composing room. Some had lifelong friends from the coffee line. In the end, it was those ties, rather than loyalties from inter-union or industry battles that ruled emotions, and the guild showed unprecedented clout in enforcing a strike.
In a new confrontation today, if there is one, those loyalties will be tested again.

At left was Richard Hubert of the machinists' union. (Kim Garnick/The New York Times) (pg. B4)

HEADLINE: Dinkins Goes on Offensive Over Giuliani's Views

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
With the underbrush of the Democratic runoff for New York City comptroller cleared away, Mayor David N. Dinkins went on the offensive yesterday, broadcasting his first critical television commercial attacking Rudolph W. Giuliani's past stands on abortion, and squaring off with his challenger over the volatile issue of the city's affirmative-action program for minority contractors.
Together, the Mayor's moves highlighted the candidates' battle for the support of three vital constituencies -- women, liberal Jews and Hispanic voters -- as the race moved solidly into a new phase: direct confrontation. Mr. Giuliani responded by accusing Mr. Dinkins of negative campaigning intended to confuse the voters.
 
1989 Revisited
 By reviving Mr. Giuliani's public reservations about abortion from the 1989 mayoral race, even though the Republican-Liberal candidate has long since said he unequivocally backs abortion rights, Mr. Dinkins sought to reopen the gender gap that prevailed between them four years ago but has virtually disappeared in recent polls. 
 At the same time, Mr. Dinkins seized on Mr. Giuliani's comments reported in The Daily News yesterday that, if elected, he would press to end the Dinkins administration's goal of allocating 20 percent of city contracts to businesses owned by minorities and women. The program was created after a study found that such businesses constituted 25 percent of the concerns operating in the city but only 7 percent of city vendors.
 
'Bad Social Policy'
 Mr. Giuliani called the program, which went into effect last year and for which no statistics are yet available, "bad social policy," and his spokesman said yesterday that he instead favored community development banks financed partly with city pension funds as a way of providing access to capital for minority-owned concerns. Polls have shown that some traditional liberals, Jewish voters in particular, have long opposed such set-asides.
But Mr. Dinkins, appealing to another important swing constituency, disagreed.
"At about 5:30 this morning, I read that and I was shocked," he told reporters at City Hall as he accepted the endorsement of a black firefighters group. "I think when the Latino community fully understands what I have already done and what his positions are on things like residency, Civilian Complaint Review Board and our program for minority and women-owned enterprises, I think that the sands will shift greatly."
Mr. Dinkins spent the morning after the runoff stumping with his party's newly chosen nominee for comptroller, Assemblyman Alan G. Hevesi, and Mark Green, its choice for public advocate, in the heart of the predominantly liberal Upper West Side, and he pitched hard to cast his contest against Mr. Giuliani as a struggle between Democratic and Republican policies and values.
 
Party Values
 He hammered away at the theme of party values in his new 30-second commercial, in which a narrator cites Mr. Giuliani's statements in 1989 that he believed the landmark abortion ruling of Roe v. Wade should have been overturned. "Can we elect a man who's fought against everything we stand for?" the ad concludes.
Mr. Giuliani, who like many other Roman Catholic politicians has expressed personal reservations about abortion while saying he would uphold existing laws that allow it, ultimately came out four-square for abortion rights in his last campaign and has taken pains to make sure his position is understood this year.
"The Mayor has to reach back four and a half years to confuse voters in this negative ad campaign," said Mr. Giuliani, who campaigned in the middle-class neighborhood of Ridgewood, Queens, and got the endorsement of a Democratic political club there. "I am pro-choice and I have clearly and consistently stated that position during the last campaign and today."
Mr. Giuliani accused the Mayor of trying to obscure the city's record on providing adequate hospital care and access to safe abortions for poor women, issuing a statement saying that the denial of full accreditation to a number of city hospitals had "undermined the city's pro-choice policies on abortion."
For the Mayor, it was a day of courting every possible vote as he raced from the Upper West Side, back to City Hall and then off to the World Trade Center and on to the Lower East Side for meetings with Hispanic New Yorkers and the Federal Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Henry G. Cisneros.
Mr. Dinkins, who has been fending off harsh attacks from the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, also took pains to show he sympathizes with the officer on the beat, stopping by the Fairway produce market on the Upper West Side to commend Nicholas Antonelli, who helped catch a bandit there Sunday night. On learning that Officer Antonelli was planning to be married at the City Clerk's office yesterday afternoon, Mr. Dinkins offered to perform the ceremony in his office instead, and he did.
 
'The Burgermeister'
 As Mr. Dinkins stood outside the market, surrounded by television cameras, a German tourist came up to him and demonstrated the benefits of incumbency, exclaiming, "I know you, you're the burgermeister!"
The Mayor also began broadcasting another commercial, stressing his efforts to keep racial peace, highlighting a headline from The New York Post after the Los Angeles riots: "Mayor praised for keeping calm as riots hit nation."
Of all the back and forth, however, perhaps the greatest potential for a hot-button issue lay in the dispute over the set-aside program. Mr. Giuliani's spokesman, Richard Bryers, said he had long believed the program was ineffective and might be unconstitutional, though Mr. Dinkins began it only after conducting a lengthy study of the city's contracting records in order to comply with Supreme Court decisions that such programs are permissible only when they seek to rectify demonstrated patterns of past discrimination.
"In the past, programs like this haven't been very effective," Mr. Bryers said. "Our approach to empowering minority-owned businesses focuses on enterprise zones and neighborhood community development banks since the real dearth for minority businesses is not access to city contracts, it's access to capital."
Michael E. Schlein, chief of staff to the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, Barry F. Sullivan, said the program had just passed its first anniversary in August and that statistics for the percentage of such companies awarded contracts under it were still being compiled and would be released soon. But he said 1,900 companies had already been certified as owned by women or minorities and eligible to compete.
"We are proud of this program and are right on target where we wanted to be," he said. "I think this is a very, very clear difference between these two candidates, and we hope New Yorkers will choose between them because we think we'll win."

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN;
A.M.A. Rebels Over Health Plan In Major Challenge to President

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29

 BODY:
The American Medical Association urged doctors today to lobby patients to oppose central elements of President Clinton's health plan, including Federal regulation of health insurance premiums and cuts in the growth of Medicare and Medicaid.
At a political education conference here and in documents sent to all doctors across the country, leaders of the A.M.A. punctured the spirit of bipartisan euphoria that has been hovering over the plan since Mr. Clinton presented it in a speech to Congress last week. 
 The association said some parts of Mr. Clinton's plan, like the proposal to guarantee health care for all Americans, were good for patients.
But in a letter to 670,000 doctors and 40,000 medical students, leaders of the association said they would "activate an unprecedented national network of physicians" to persuade Congress to make substantial changes in Mr. Clinton's proposal. Hundreds of doctors, organized by the association, took their case to Capitol Hill in a lobbying blitz this afternoon.
The doctors do not have a veto over legislation but are expected to wield considerable influence in Congress because many are prominent in their communities and contribute to political campaigns. The association itself has a $7 million budget for lobbying.
 
Debate Over 'Prescription'
 Dr. Lonnie R. Bristow, chairman of the association, said: "The President has offered the country a prescription for what ails our health care system. While we agree with his general diagnosis, we disagree with some of his treatment decisions. He's prescribing some pretty stiff, new and untried medicine. We are worried that no one really knows what the side effects are going to be."
Until now, the association's tone had been conciliatory, as it worked quietly behind closed doors to influence Mr. Clinton's proposal. The Administration has swung between seeking the cooperation of the A.M.A., whose opposition has proved fatal to a long series of health care proposals, and preparing to do battle with it.
The A.M.A.'s tone became more aggressive today as members focused on details of the Clinton plan. The doctors said their positions reflected their patients' interests, not just their own economic interests.
At today's conference, doctors booed and hissed Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, when she told them of the President's proposal to limit medical malpractice lawsuits, a proposal the doctors see as inadequate.
While vowing to be constructive, the doctors criticized crucial parts of Mr. Clinton's plan to hold down health costs and reshape the medical system. Administration officials rejected the criticism but said they would work with doctors toward a compromise.
In the letter to the physicians, Dr. Bristow and Dr. Joseph T. Painter, the president of the A.M.A., said, "We have serious reservations about the President's proposal because it would limit choices by patients and physicians, undermine the quality of medical services and lead to Federal control of medical education and the physician work force."
 
No Doctor on Board
 The association said it "unequivocally opposes a national health spending budget," which Mr. Clinton proposed. The association said "it is unacceptable that no place has been reserved" for a doctor on the National Health Board, the body Mr. Clinton would establish to supervise the new health care system. It asserted that the Clinton plan was biased toward managed care and against traditional fee-for-service medicine, under which doctors receive a separate payment for each service. It complained that "physicians will be given financial incentives to provide less care."
By some accounts, the A.M.A. lost influence in the last decade, as more than 80 groups representing various specialties lobbied for themselves. But Mr. Clinton has unintentionally generated new interest in the association among doctors who look to the organization as their champion and protector in a showdown over the future of medicine in America.
The 290,000 members of the A.M.A. account for 43 percent of the nation's doctors. In the early 1970's the association represented 70 percent of the doctors.
The association provided doctors with information and arguments they could use to answer to patients' questions. The answers are not reassuring.
one question is, "Will costs be controlled in a way that doesn't interfere with my medical care?" The answer: "Cost controls may decrease your ability to choose and get some kinds of medical services. A national budget limit for health care will be set. The Government will restrict premium increases. This may lead to rationing."
Another question asks: "Will I still be able to see my own doctor? Will I have to pay extra? And will my doctor and I be free to decide how to treat my illness?" The answer: "You will be able to see your doctor if you choose a plan your doctor is in. If you want to see a physician outside your plan, you will pay more, and in some cases it may be the entire amount. Some plans may put economic interests ahead of medical interests."
The association said it was "adamantly opposed" to some parts of the plan, "staunchly opposed" to others and "deeply concerned" about some. Dr. Shalala said the President's plan was still a work in progress, and she thanked the doctors for the privilege of working with them.
Among the doctors expressing concern today was Dr. Joe P. Anderson, president of the Memphis and Shelby County Medical Society, in Tennessee. "When you start talking about controlling private fees and private expenditures, that's something new to this country," said Dr. Anderson, who reported that he had had many friendly debates with his son, Kevin Anderson, a spokesman for President Clinton.
In the 1960's, the American Medical Association fought the creation of Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly, saying it was an "irreversible step toward the complete socialization of medical care."
The association, intransigent before passage of the Medicare law in 1965, cooperated with the Government to carry it out. Medicare now accounts for a substantial portion of doctors' income. In its analysis of Mr. Clinton's proposals, the association said reductions in Medicare reimbursement were unacceptable and threatened access to care for elderly people.
Mr. Clinton is proposing to cut the projected growth of Medicare by $124 billion, or 10 percent, from 1996 to the year 2000. He says all the savings will be used to finance new benefits for the elderly, including coverage of prescription drugs and some long-term care. The President is proposing to cut $114 billion, or 16 percent, from the amounts that would otherwise be spent in Medicaid, the fast-growing program for low-income people.
The Clinton plan would probably shift income from medical specialists to general practice doctors. While it would limit the fees of many doctors, it would guarantee some payment for uninsured patients who now pay nothing for their care.
The association has taken more liberal positions since Dr. James S. Todd became executive vice president of the organization in 1990. The doctors' group irritated President George Bush and his White House staff with insistent calls for Federal action to guarantee access to health care for all Americans.
In "Health Access America," a proposal advanced in March 1990, the association said the Government should require employers to provide health insurance for all full-time workers and their dependents.
Secretary Shalala complimented the doctors today by telling them: "Your goals and principles are remarkably similar to our own. In fact, we stole them from you."
Dr. Shalala said President Clinton was a new Democrat and did not want "a centralized bureaucratic health care system run from Washington." But the A.M.A. said that was precisely what Mr. Clinton had proposed.
In their letter to all doctors, Dr. Bristow and Dr. Painter said, "We are troubled by the degree of centralized regulation" in the Clinton plan. Dr. Bristow said the plan threatened to separate the heart from the soul of American medicine by "forcing a bureaucrat or an accountant to stand between patient and physician."

(Michael Geissinger for The New York Times) (pg. A22)

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN;
Drug Companies Feeling Pressure of Clinton's Plan To Keep Their Prices Down

SERIES: The Clinton Prescription -- Fifth article of a series: The Impact on Drug Companies

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Exchanging verbal thunderbolts with the companies that make prescription drugs, President Clinton has denounced high prices that force some sick and elderly Americans to skip meals to pay for medicine.
His proposals for revamping the medical system would fundamentally reshape the playing field for drug companies, pressuring them to hold down prices and in some ways treating them as much like a crucial social service or public utility as private profit-seeking businesses. 
 For their part, the drug makers say the President is unfairly singling them out. They assert that his proposals would cripple research budgets, delaying the discovery of cures for scourges like AIDS, cancer and Alzheimer's disease.
Drug company executives say their products save both money and lives by helping to avert expensive hospital stays and surgery. But critics say the pharmaceutical industry took advantage of patients and payers for years by raising prices at more than double the general inflation rate in the late 1980's and early 1990's.
The companies insist they have turned over a new leaf and are already holding down prices. They say this is partly because they are under pressure from health maintenance organizations and insurance discount plans.
Under attack by Congress and the President and his wife, Hillary, 17 large drug makers have promised to keep their price increases, on average, in line with the consumer price index.
Pharmaceutical executives say they are pleased that the Clinton plan would add an estimated 70 million people to the 174 million who already have insurance coverage for drugs. Drugs would be included with the basic insurance benefits that all workers would get.
Also, for the first time, the Federal Medicare program would pay about 80 of the cost of prescriptions for the elderly and disabled; at present the program pays nothing toward prescriptions except for patients in hospitals. For the President, this is an important way to secure support for his health plan among wary elderly people.
 
Wall St. Skeptical About Drug Benefit
 But Jerome R. Brimeyer, a securities analyst at Lehman Brothers, questioned whether Congress would approve the drug benefit. The benefit would add $14 billion to $20 billion a year to Medicare, he said, making it harder for the President to deliver on his proposal to sharply curtail annual increases in Medicare spending.
Under the Clinton plan, drug prices would come under attack on at least these four fronts, fundamentally altering the ground rules for an industry that until recently has often charged whatever the market would bear:
*A new National Health Board could investigate "unreasonable" drug prices, requiring a company to bring in its records if the price of a drug was higher in the United States than abroad.
*Drug companies would have to return to Medicare a rebate of 15 percent of their average nationwide price for each drug paid for by Medicare. Industry analysts said such rebates would cost the industry $1.5 billion to $2.25 billion a year.
*The Secretary of Health and Human Services could bargain down the prices of new drugs before Medicare agreed to pay for them. If the companies resist, Medicare could refuse to pay for these drugs. Doctors would need permission from a Government official to prescribe, for Medicare patients, drugs deemed unreasonably costly.
*Most Americans would be expected to join health plans that typically offer financial incentives to use only the lowest-priced drugs. And by limiting increases in health insurance premiums, the Government would force insurers to keep reducing all costs, including those of drugs.
 
Industry Wants To Rely on Competition
 Drug company executives argue that the Clinton proposals are really price controls, which they insist do not work. They said prices should be kept low by competition, not by bureaucrats. But critics noted that some companies had long exploited the strong demand for patent-protected drugs by setting high prices.
G. Kirk Raab, chief executive of Genentech Inc. of San Francisco, one of the most successful biotechnology companies, said the price contraints "could slow down or eliminate the volume of research" by making it harder for young companies to raise money from investors. Genentech's products include genetically engineered human growth hormone and a drug that dissolves blood clots after heart attacks.
Investors supply at least 80 percent of the working capital for biotechnology companies, and there are more than 1,000 small biotechnology companies, of which 235 have sold stock to the public. But the biotechnology industry still has only two dozen drugs to its credit and 130 more awaiting approval by the Food and Drug Administration.
Genentech, which has spent more than $100 million seeking a vaccine to prevent AIDS, is one of only three companies currently working on an AIDS vaccine, Mr. Raab said.
"If eight wise people or Secretary Shalala is going to judge the price, my board of directors is not going to be very enthusiastic about my spending a lot of money on AIDS vaccine," he said, referring to Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
But critics like Senator David Pryor, Democrat of Arkansas, say that many big established pharmaceutical companies have spent years pouring research dollars into products that largely duplicated already available drugs. The Food and Drug Administration said that only 40 percent of the new drugs approved last year were a significant advance over existing ones.
Indeed, managed health care groups exploit competition among similar drugs to push prices down.
Although the drug companies expect to spend more than $10 billion on research and development this year, pharmaceutical experts say they may spend as much as $11 billion on promotion and marketing.
The Administration's criticism of the drug companies is already having a financial effect. Many investors have apparently decided that the days are past when pharmaceutical companies could routinely boast of double-digit increases in profits every three months.
"Mere talk about price controls has squeezed $120 billion out of drug and biotechnology stocks," said Ray Egan, a senior vice president of the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, a large diversified health care company. He was referring to the drop in prices of the stocks as worried owners sold their holdings.
And a recent survey by Ernst & Young, the accounting and consulting firm, found that more than half of even the larger biotechnology companies do not have enough capital on hand to keep them going for two years.
Henry Termeer, chairman of the Genzyme Corporation, a biotechnology company, said that as few as 1 in 20 new drugs tested would succeed. "The one successful drug has to pay for my total investment," he said.
 
Special Drugs For Rare Disorders
 Genzyme, based in Cambridge, Mass., developed a treatment for Gaucher's disease, a rare inherited disorder causing anemia and bone pain that affects only a few thousand people. The Genzyme drug, which is extracted from human placenta tissue, costs $50,000 to $100,000 for a year's supply for each patient. Those taking it "can live a normal life," Mr. Termeer said.
The drug "took 10 years to develop at a cost of $170 million," he said.
Mr. Termeer noted that biotechnology companies worked on "unmet medical needs: treatments for AIDS, cancer, heart disease, Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, cystic fibrosis." He added: "They are entirely dependent upon investments by institutions and individuals. Society only pays when a new drug is successful."
The established companies say the Clinton proposal for rebates on Medicare drugs is especially worrisome. Fred Telling, a vice president of Pfizer Inc., a large pharmaceutical company that makes several widely used drugs, said the rebates "would be significantly damaging to the industry."
Industry executives said elderly people currently consumed at least 20 percent of the $50 billion in American-made drugs each year. They said it was impossible to guess how much the volume would jump if Medicare paid most of the costs.
 
Regulations Draw Criticism
 Proposing to limit both the Government-paid drugs and the rebates, Dr. P. Roy Vagelos, chairman of Merck & Company, the world's largest drug maker, said that only Medicare patients who are needy should receive the proposed new drug benefit. Then, he said, the companies should supply those drugs at the same reduced prices that they currently charge the state Medicaid programs for low-income people. Under a 1990 Federal law, the Medicaid rebates cost the companies about $1.5 billion a year.
Mr. Telling said drug makers agreed with the President that competition was the best way to control costs. But he said they were "concerned that beneath its broad outlines, the proposals contain elements that are highly regulatory."
Dr. Vagelos said the companies would try to persuade Administration officials and legislators to ease the controls on drugs. "The good news is that the Administration says it is willing to consider changes," he said. But recalling the industry's failure to stop the President from recommending broader Government purchases of vaccines earlier this year, he said he was "not optimistic."
Expressing similar concerns, companies that make medical devices like heart pacemakers and hip joint replacements say they are also worried that the Clinton program may stifle innovation. When health care plans judge the cost-effectiveness of new technology, they may not provide the opportunity for it to evolve, said Dr. Glen D. Nelson, vice chairman of Medtronic Inc., a maker of medical devices.
NEXT: The insurance companies.

HEADLINE: U.S. Pact to Return Inmates To Havana Alarms Emigres

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 29

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration, in secret talks with the Government of Fidel Castro, has agreed to hand over to Havana some 1,500 Cubans held in Federal prisons, spreading waves of alarm among Cuban exiles here.
On the streets of Little Havana, there was concern over what could await the prisoners once they are returned to jails in Cuba. But even more widespread were the fears that the deal announced by the Justice Department late Tuesday, the first of its kind in nearly a decade, might signal the start of a broader rapprochement between the United States and Cuba. 
 "We are only lending credibility to the Castro regime when we reach this kind of an accord with him," Julio Estorino, a director of a major exile group, the Association of Cuban Municipalities in Exile, said in an interview today. "At a moment when he is experiencing his worst crisis and the people are in the streets throwing stones, this is like a gift to him."
Under Tuesday's agreement, the United States plans to repatriate up to 50 of the Cuban prisoners each month during the next two and a half years. The deportees are to be Cubans who arrived in the United States as part of the Mariel exodus of 1980 and were later convicted of committing felonies in the United States.
 
Signs of Softer Line
 Officials did not say when the deportations would begin. Prisoners can appeal deportation orders to the Immigration and Naturalization Service.
Tuesday's agreement follows several other signs that both Washington and Havana want to diminish the tensions that have existed between the two countries for more than 30 years. This month, for instance, in a reversal of its policy of noncooperation, Cuba handed over to American authorities a pair of drug traffickers who had eluded an Army helicopter and fled into Cuban airspace.
For its part, the Clinton Administration has quietly eased restrictions on travel to Cuba by American citizens and twice let Cuba know of plans to hold military maneuvers in the area. It has also proposed a revenue-sharing deal on phone calls between the two countries that would generate millions of dollars in hard currency for Mr. Castro's cash-starved Government.
In addition, Cuban security agents, at the invitation of the Justice Department, testified last month before a Miami grand jury that was considering criminal charges against a Cuban pilot who commandeered an airplane with 52 passengers and flew to freedom here. Today, in what was viewed as an attempt to soften the impact of the repatriation agreement, the Justice Department announced it was dropping the case against the pilot, Carlos Cancio Porcel.
 
Helping Castro When He Hurts
 Since the collapse of the Soviet Union, the Cuban economy has gone into a sharp decline, with shortages of food and fuel forcing many people to spend much of their time foraging for supplies. In addition, fears of violence or even civil war are rising, with a Cuban Air Force defector saying at a news conference here Tuesday that the military has been told it may have to fire on Mr. Castro's civilian opponents.
In such an atmosphere, "anything that smells of agreement smells foul" to exile groups convinced that Mr. Castro's fall is imminent, said Lisandro Perez, director of the Cuban Research Institute at Florida International University here. "This thing with the prisoners is criticizable not so much on content, but simply because there are negotiations at all," he said.
In 1980, an estimated 125,000 Cubans, nearly all legitimate refugees, fled the island as part of a huge boatlift. In 1984, Cuba agreed to accept the return of criminals it had deliberately mixed in with the refugees, in return for which the United States said it would accept 3,000 political prisoners and issue up to 20,000 immigration visas to Cubans each year. But Cuba backed out of the accord the next year to protest the Reagan Administration's decision to begin radio broadcasts to the island through Radio Marti.
When, late in 1987, the State Department announced that Mr. Castro had agreed to accept repatriation of more than 2,700 Cuban convicts, inmates known as "Mariel felons" took over two Federal prisons in an uprising that lasted two weeks. In August 1991, Cuban inmates at the Federal prison in Talladega, Ala., seized 10 hostages in an effort to avoid deportation. They were subdued when a Federal SWAT team stormed the prison.
Despite the uprisings, more than 1,100 Cubans have been deported.
 
Separating Cuban Inmates
 In addition to the 1,500 prisoners affected by what the Justice Department is formally calling "expanded repatriation of Mariel Cuban felons," there are 400 Mariel Cubans in Federal prisons and about 2,300 more in various state and local jails. The Justice Department said these convicts "will not be immediately affected" by Tuesday's accord. But it ordered that all Cuban nationals in medium- and maximum-security prisons be separated from the general inmate population until further notice.
Relatives of prisoners protested the agreement outside a prison here today. Robert L. Boyer, an immigration lawyer here who is closely involved with the Mariel issue, described the mood among the relatives as one of hysteria, and Spanish-language radio call-in programs here were filled with frantic calls from other Cuban exiles fearful they also might be deported.
Trying to reduce those growing concerns, Attorney General Janet Reno, who was State Attorney here when the Mariel influx occurred, sent Lula Rodriguez, a Cuban-American aide who is from Miami, to explain the new agreement to exiles here. Moving from one Spanish-language radio station to another throughout the day, Ms. Rodriguez argued that the United States would benefit from ridding itself of dangerous criminals whose incarceration costs up to $25,000 per person a year.
The Justice Department has also sought to play down the pact's political importance. "This action is a result of periodic reviews to discuss ongoing implementation of the 1984 migration agreement," it said in a statement.
But exile and human rights groups were skeptical. "This is a step towards normalization of relations in the immigration area, and that may have broader implications," said Arthur Helton of the Lawyer's Committee on Human Rights.
Rafael Penalver, a lawyer who helped mediate the 1987 prison uprisings, said he was worried about the prisoners who had already been repatriated to Cuba.
"Basically, the earth has swallowed them up," Mr. Penalver said. "Some of the relatives who have called the Cuban Interests Section in Washington have even received the answer that the deportations have never taken place."

HEADLINE: New Index of U.S. Factory Activity Climbs

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29

 BODY:
A new index intended to forecast activity in the nation's factories by giving special attention to inventories moved up slightly in September, but growth is likely to remain sluggish, the sponsors said.
A decline in inventories in the manufacturing sector "has come to an end, removing one source of contraction for the overall economy," said Michael Evans, creator of the Apics Business Outlook Index. 
 "But the components of the index that would ordinarily point to a substantial turnaround in business activity in the months ahead have not yet registered those gains," he said.
The index, similar to the Federal Reserve's tabulation of capacity utilization, is based on confidential data supplied by more than 100 members of the American Production and Inventory Control Society.
Most of the September rise in the index, to 51.0 from 48.6, occurred in its future conditions component, driven by an unusually small decline in the ratio of inventories to sales. The current conditions component was mixed, with shipments showing a gain and employment declining.
Although he did not release the index until today, Mr. Evans, a Washington consultant, has calculated it since January with what he called promising results.
The respondents supply monthly information about their level of shipments, new orders, unfilled orders, employment, inventory stocks, actual and desired inventory-sales ratios, production for the current months and production plans for the next three months.
Unlike some other gauges, the Apics index takes account of the magnitude of responses, not just their direction, Mr. Evans said. It also weights the responses by company size.

HEADLINE: Company News;
Mercedes Selects Alabama Site

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 29

 BODY:
After World War I, textile manufacturers began moving south to be nearer their suppliers -- the cotton fields of Alabama, South Carolina and other balmy states.
Now auto makers are making a similar pilgrimage, building plants by those old cotton fields to take advantage of cheap land, skilled industrial workers and the proximity of many auto parts manufacturers. The latest to make the move is Mercedes-Benz, which will build its first automobile assembly plant in America in Tuscaloosa County, Ala. 
 The selection of Alabama, scheduled to be announced on Thursday by officials of the company in Tuscaloosa, comes after a five-month search that pitted 30 states, from Georgia to Nebraska, against each other in a bidding war.
 
Jobs for 1,500 Workers
 The $300 million plant, which will produce a new four-wheel-drive sports utility vehicle, will employ 1,500 workers and create thousands of other jobs in related industries.
Mercedes-Benz plans to produce 60,000 vehicles at the plant -- about a third as many as the average American assembly plant makes.
The plant, which is scheduled to begin production in 1997, will be built on 1,000 hilly acres of pine forest about 11 miles east of Tuscaloosa. The city of 80,000 people is about 50 miles southwest of Birmingham and is the home of the University of Alabama. Foreign companies like British Steel and JVC already operate manufacturing plants in or near the city.
Officials of the company declined to discuss their decision today, but they confirmed that Mercedes-Benz had picked Tuscaloosa. Local government officials who brokered the deal sketched its outlines.
"It's a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for the citizens of Tuscaloosa County," said Judge W. Hardy McCollum, the chairman of the Tuscaloosa County Commission. "It will change Tuscaloosa County dramatically, but it will also change the state of Alabama."
Someone's image is likely to change because of the deal. The question is whether the Mercedes-Benz marque, associated in the minds of many Americans with exacting German craftsmanship, will acquire the grittier associations that come with Tuscaloosa, or whether Tuscaloosa will acquire some of the glamour of Mercedes-Benz.
Mercedes-Benz, like BMW and Volkswagen, has slipped in the United States in recent years, as the value of the German mark has climbed, making German products more expensive, and the Japanese have introduced high-quality imports like Acura, Infiniti and Lexus.
The United Automobile Workers union plans to try to organize the Mercedes-Benz plant. But unionized or not, Mercedes-Benz is likely to have much lower labor costs in Alabama than in Germany, because of the weak dollar.
To fend off the union organizers, the company would have to offer hourly wages comparable to the roughly $17 received by most U.A.W. assembly line workers. Today BMW announced that workers at a plant it is building in Spartanburg, S.C., would start at $12 an hour, rising to $16 an hour within 24 months.
 
A Nest of Suppliers
 The region selected by Mercedes-Benz is particularly attractive to auto makers because a large number of manufacturers produce everything from tires to shock absorbers to fuel injectors in plants along Interstate 85, between Atlanta and the Virginia state line. Chrysler, Honda and Mitsubishi, along with several smaller manufacturers, operate components plants in Alabama.
"Basically, people are coming in and wrapping skins around these auto parts," said Bruce Yandle, an economist at Clemson University in Clemson, S.C. While Mercedes-Benz will be the first auto maker in Alabama, BMW is in Spartanburg, and the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company already have assembly plants near Atlanta. Thomasbuilt and Freightliner have assembly plants in North Carolina.
Mercedes-Benz will be importing many parts -- including engines -- and exporting about two-thirds of the plant's production, so a good transportation infrastructure was important. A railroad line touches the new site, an interstate highway runs by it and the port of Mobile is about 200 miles away.

HEADLINE: Clinton Held Ready to Order Standard on Recycled Paper

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
In an apparent victory for environmentalists over the paper industry, the White House is said to be leaning toward an executive order that would direct Federal agencies to purchase office stationery and other paper with at least 20 percent of its content recycled from trash.
Such a Federal move is expected to provide a powerful stimulus for recyling efforts by setting a standard that might also be adopted by state and muncipal governments and by corporate buyers of paper seeking a good environmental image. Expanded use of recycled paper, moreover, could also help create a larger market for the tons of paper that cities and towns collect each year in recycling programs. 
 "If they do 20 percent, it will do more for recycling in 6 months than the environmental community was able to accomplish in 20 years," said Allen Hershkowitz, a solid-waste specialist with the Natural Resources Defense Council in New York. "The cities have been pleading for a definition."
Although the White House order was not signed or announced yesterday, people in Washington and elsewhere familiar with the discussions said yesterday that the Clinton Administration had apparently decided to rebuff pleas by the paper industry that the level of recycled material go no higher than 10 percent.
But the paper industry was mounting a vigorous counterattack yesterday after reports arose about the proposed terms of the order. Barry Polsky, a spokesman for the American Forest and Paper Association, the leading industry trade group, said last evening that "we are still talking to the White House" and declined to comment further.
The Federal Government buys less than 2 percent of the 22 million tons of printing and writing paper produced in this country each year, a market with a total value of about $20 billion. But a Federal standard could have a far-reaching influence. Until now, there has been widespread disagreement over how much reclaimed content is needed to label paper "recycled" and over the types of paper to be re-used.
 
30% by End of Decade?
 People familiar with the matter say the 20 percent content level will become effective at the end of next year and rise to 30 percent near the end of the decade. In addition, to qualify, the paper will have to have been previously used and reclaimed from garbage and will not include the paper-mill scraps the industry wanted to include in the definition. Environmentalists argue that only by removing paper from trash can the paper industry relieve the burden on landfills, where paper and cardboard are the largest single component.
In a statement issued yesterday as the issue was still in doubt, Sharpe James, the Mayor of Newark, who is chairman of the United States Conference of Mayors, said the 20 percent standard "represents a significant improvement over earlier proposals."
"Cities must have a market for every ton of recyclables collected," Mr. James said. "Today, those markets are so weak that the viability of many of our recycling programs is threatened."
Environmentalists do appear to have lost on a least one issue in the debate -- their proposal that the Government not buy paper bleached by chlorine or chlorine compounds. Chlorine has long been used to brighten paper, but environmentalists have argued that use of the substance leads to toxic emissions, including the family of chemicals known as dioxin.
Paper industry officials have argued that dioxin emissions have been greatly reduced in recent years and that it would be a heavy economic burden for them to convert mills based on chlorine bleaching to alternative methods, like ones using oxygen and ozone.
President Clinton promised to issue an executive order urging Federal agencies to increase their purchases of recycled goods in his Earth Day speech last spring. Because the recycled-paper standard is expected to be the only one in the order that sets a specific percentage, environmentalists and groups from the paper industry have been arguing for months over the content level and the sources of supply. The debate culminated in a White House meeting of the various factions on Monday.
According to peoples close to the discussions, Mr. Clinton's economic advisers were the chief opponents of the stiffer recycling standard, fearing a loss of jobs in the forestry and paper industry. But Mr. Hershkowitz noted that the collection and separation segments of recycling were labor intensive and tended to be in cities that generate the largest amounts of trash.
"We're talking thousands of inner-city jobs here," he said.

HEADLINE: Puerto Ayora Journal;
Galapagos Burden: Goats, Pigs and Now People

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PUERTO AYORA, Ecuador

 BODY:
An afternoon stroll down Charles Darwin Avenue captures the rapid evolution of Homo sapiens in the Galapagos.
Ecuadorean rap music blares from the Blowout Bar; an Otavalo Indian peddles Andean wool ponchos outside a new pizzeria, and at a souvenir kiosk tourists pick through T-shirts, including one praising an endemic bird species: "I Love Boobies." 
 "This town is filling up with bureaucracy and burglars," grumbled Jack Nelson, a California native who owns the Hotel Galapagos. "When I first came here in the 1960's, it was just a wooden schoolhouse on a street of sand."
The human population of the Galapagos has grown from fewer than 3,000 in the early 1960's to about 14,000 today. Two decades ago this isolated archipelago 600 miles west of South America's mainland was declared a national province of Ecuador, a move that threw open doors to unrestricted immigration from the continent.
 
Water in Short Supply
 Providing economic sustenance to colonization, tourism started with a handful of annual visitors in the 1960's, swept past a Government target of 25,000 visitors in 1982, and in 1990 reached the current plateau of 40,000.
"Before, we used to get two hours of water a day -- now we get half an hour of water every two days," Jorge Sotomayor, a resident of a neighboring island, San Cristobal, said of water faucets that stand dry in his house.
But more than physical limits to growth protect this arid chain of 19 volcanic islands. The Galapagos National Park blocks human settlement from 97 percent of a wilderness archipelago once known as the Enchanted Isles.
The Galapagos, a laboratory for studying biological evolution, has occupied a special place in the hearts of scientists since 1835, when Darwin arrived here aboard the Beagle. After years of pondering what he observed on the islands, the naturalist wrote "Origin of Species."
 
Without Fear of Man
 For millions of years, water currents sweeping off South America's western shoulder made the trip to the Galapagos a one-way voyage for beast and flower.
In 1535, when an expedition led by Tomas de Berlanga, Bishop of Panama, made the first known human visit here, he found a strange world where birds and animals had evolved completely without fear of man. Today, 90 percent of the reptiles, 50 percent of the land birds and 45 percent of the higher plants can be found only on these islands.
With the cold Humboldt Current washing an island group that straddles the Equator, the Galapagos is the only place in the tropics inhabited by fur seals. Its birdlife ranges from flamingos to penguins. Its landscape ranges from humid marshes to mile-high volcanic peaks.
"Where else can one find, all in one location, relatives of the sunflower that have evolved into trees, gulls which forage at night, lizards which feed on seaweed beneath the ocean surface, tortoises which grow to gigantic proportions, or cormorants which have lost the ability to fly?" Alan White and Bruce Epler wrote in a guidebook for the Charles Darwin Foundation, a private research group based here.
 
Tortoises Bounce Back
 Today's tourist invasion seems benign compared with the festivals of slaughter sponsored by earlier human visitors.
In the 1700's, British and American whalers discovered that Galapagos giant tortoises could survive for more than one year in the hold of a ship without food or water. Stacking live tortoises like casks of brandy, the whalers seized an estimated 200,000.
After three decades of work, the Darwin Foundation has restored the giant tortoise population to about 13,000.
The whalers soon discovered that the islands' fur seals were easy prey. "For years, people thought that the Galapagos fur seal was extinct," said Luis Die, a Spanish biologist and tour guide here. "Then a small band was discovered in the 1930's. Now there are 40,000. The population has fully recovered."
In the mid-19th century, human colonization started, bringing a new threat to the ecosystem: imported, domesticated animals. Convinced that food supplies would never arrive from the mainland, prisoners serving sentences in Galapagos penal colonies fostered wild populations of goats and pigs. Additional populations were started by fishermen wanting to find fresh meat when they visited remote islands.
The latest surge in human colonization has brought a surge in new species: rats, cats, cows, donkeys and dogs. "In the past 10 years, 100 new fauna species have been introduced," said Chantal Blanton, an American ecologist who directs the Charles Darwin Research Station here. "In the previous 200 years, there were only a handful of new species introduced."
 
Calls for a Curtain
 From scientists to politicians, a consensus is growing that a curtain should drop on the 20-year experiment with unlimited Galapagos immigration.
"There is no more land, there is no more drinking water, the topsoil is thin," Raul Flores Viteri, the sole Galapagos member of Ecuador's Congress, said in an interview in Quito.
This fall Mr. Flores plans to submit to the Congress a constitutional amendment that would allow Ecuadoreans to freely travel and to freely choose their residence anywhere in the nation, "with the exception of Galapagos Province."

Tourists shared a beach with several sea lions on Espanola Island. (Elizabeth Brooke for The New York Times)
