HEADLINE: WOMEN PAY PRICE FOR BEING OBESE

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
Women who are fat suffer enormous social and economic consequences, a new study has shown. They are much less likely to marry than women of normal weight and are more likely to be poor and to earn far less.
Fat men are also less likely to marry than men of normal weight, but they seem just as well off financially, the researchers found. 
 The findings are from an eight-year study of 10,039 randomly selected people who were 16 to 24 years old when the research began. It is the first study to document the profound social and economic consequences of obesity by following a population for years.
The researchers, led by Dr. Steven L. Gortmaker of the Harvard School of Public Health, said discrimination against obese people might account for their results.
Fat women were disproportionately found in lower socioeconomic classes, and some researchers say this is because poor women are more likely to eat fat-laden food and junk foods and to get less exercise than richer women. But, Dr. Gortmaker and his colleagues wrote, "our data suggest that at least some of this relation may be a socioeconomic consequence of being overweight."
 
Who Is Obese?
 The study, being published today in The New England Journal of Medicine, defined obesity as the top 5 percent of people on an index in which weight is related to height. A typical obese woman in the study was 5 foot 3 and 200 pounds; a typical man was 5 foot 9 and 225 pounds.
The study found that fat women were more likely to lose socioeconomic status independently of their families' social status or income and independently of how well the women scored on achievement tests when they were adolescents. The fat women were 20 percent less likely to marry, had household incomes that were an average of $6,710 lower and were 10 percent more likely to be living in poverty.
The effects of obesity on men were more modest. The most significant finding was that obese men were 11 percent less likely to marry.
But comparisons among all men in the study at various heights with those a foot shorter found that the shorter men were 10 percent more likely to live in poverty and had household incomes that averaged $3,037 less. Previous studies have found that taller men seem to have an advantage in the business world.
Some investigators said they hoped that the findings would wake up the medical community and society to abiding prejudices that can sour the lives of fat people.
 
Moral to the Study
 The results should be "a clarion call," said Dr. Albert J. Stunkard, an obesity researcher at the University of Pennsylvania who was the co-author of an editorial on the findings in the same issue of the journal.
Discrimination against fat people, Dr. Stunkard said, "is the last fashionable form of prejudice." He and others said fat people were too often derided as gluttonous slobs who could be thin if they really wanted to. This attitude, Dr. Stunkard said, is used to justify rampant discrimination. But it is particularly unfair, he noted, because study after study has shown that virtually all obese people cannot permanently reduce and that their weight is not their fault. "Blaming the victim," he said. "That's what it is."
The researchers said discrimination against fat people was so profound that Congress should consider extending legal protection to them.
Some fat people said the findings reflected their everyday experiences. Frances White, the president of the National Association for the Advancement of Fat Acceptance, said that employers were often prejudiced against fat women, like herself, but that they were seldom direct.
"Most of us find that this sort of discrimination is very covert," she said. "It's much like racial discrimination. Nobody wants to own up to it."
Ms. White, who lives in San Francisco, recently got a job as a membership coordinator at a local Public Broadcasting System. For two and a half years before that, she worked at temporary jobs, looking for something more permanent.
 
Change of Heart
 "I have a wonderful resume and years of experience," Ms. White said. "I can write a resume tailored to each job that is absolutely perfect." She said prospective employers often would be enthusiastic about her application until they saw her.
She said employers would call her and say: "You're exactly what we want. When can you come in?" But, she said, things often changed when she walked into an office for an interview.
"All of a sudden, they would get this look on their face," she said. " 'Oh, you're Frances White.' Then they'd give me a cursory interview and say, 'We're thinking of going with a more entry level person,' or 'We're re-thinking our staffing needs.' "
Dr. Susan C. Wooley, an obesity researcher and co-director of an eating-disorders clinic at the University of Cincinnati, said that she hoped that the new study would alert people to the plight of obese women but that she feared it would not. The problem, she said, is that many people believe that the women could be thin if they really wanted to.
Dr. Wooley said she feared that people would conclude that the new data showed "how important it is to treat obesity." But she said: "They still won't get it. You can't solve social problems by trying to alter victims."

HEADLINE: First-Half Economic Growth Exceeds Earlier Estimates

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29

 BODY:
The economy limped through the first half of 1993 at a fractionally stronger pace than was thought earlier, the Commerce Department reported today. Corporations posted record profits and inflation was dormant.
In another report, the Agriculture Department said farm prices jumped 2.1 percent in September from a month earlier because of a large increase in orange prices. 
 National output expanded at a 1.9 percent annual rate in the second quarter -- a little better than the 1.8 percent estimate a month ago -- after a feeble gain of eight-tenths of a percent in the first quarter. For the first six months of 1993, the economy grew at an annual rate of 1.3 percent.
A month ago, the department estimated that the nation's total output of goods and services, measured by gross domestic product, or G.D.P., had grown at a 1.8 percent rate in the second quarter. It revised that upward because of stronger consumer spending and more business investment than first thought.
 
 
Weakness in Trade
 The improvement from these two sources of economic strength was partly offset by trade weakness. Exports grew less strongly than originally estimated, and imports shot up more rapidly.
Robert Dederick, an economist with the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, said, "This is an economy that is plugging along fairly nicely at home, but so much of our growth is being dissipated by going into imported goods."
 The White House predicts that the economy will expand 2 percent in 1993. To meet that target, the output of goods and services must grow at a 2.7 percent annual rate in the closing six months of the year, Commerce Department officials said.
In its farm prices report, the Government attributed the surge in orange prices, to $10.52 a box from $5.44 in August, to a decline in supplies of California Valencia oranges. The decline is a seasonal quirk, an analyst for the Government said.
"Without the large change in orange prices from August to September, the All Farm Products index would have been unchanged," the Government said.
Lettuce, wheat and apple prices also rose in September. Soybean, egg, cattle and corn prices all declined.
Compared with a year earlier, farm prices were 4.3 percent higher.

All dollar amounts are in billions at seasonally adjusted annual rates. Percentage changes are from the previous quarter at seasonally adjusted annual rates.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Mazda Now Sees $300 Million Loss

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 29

 BODY:
In the latest sign of a rapid deterioration for Japan's once mighty automobile industry, the Mazda Motor Corporation said today that it expected to lose $300 million this fiscal year, a deficit almost three times larger than it had projected four months ago.
The company attributed the larger loss forecast to declining sales in Japan and Europe, and to the rise of the Japanese yen against the dollar, which has made Japanese products more expensive in the United States. 
 Mazda said it would cut its Japan-based work force by 3,000 people, or 10 percent, over three years through attrition and reduced hiring. It also said it would close an assembly line at its Hiroshima plant, further cut capital expenditures and eliminate the dividend on its common stock.
With today's announcement, Mazda becomes the second of Japan's five largest auto makers to plunge deeply into the red, following the Nissan Motor Company. Even Toyota, the largest and strongest company, has said it could have a small operating loss this year if the currency exchange rate stays near 100 yen to the dollar.
Japan's auto industry, which saw almost unbroken growth since World War II, is now in a protracted slide. Production is running close to the level of 1984. And the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said this week that exports in August dropped to a 14-year low, partly because auto makers are shifting production out of Japan.
Other Japanese industries are also finding the ground sliding out from under them because of the strong yen and a domestic economy that seems to be getting weaker. On Tuesday, the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, Japan's largest consumer electronics company, revised its sales and profit forecasts for the year sharply downward.
Mazda has some special problems. It is still paying for a factory in Hofu that was opened last year and is still not at full capacity. Analysts say Mazda is also burdened with five separate dealer networks in Japan; Mazda, however, says the separate dealerships are an advantage.
The company said that for the fiscal year ending in March it expected a loss of 32 billion yen, or $304 million. Until today the company had been forecasting a loss of 12 billion yen, or about $114 million. In the last fiscal year the company posted a profit of 2.6 billion yen, or $25 million.
Despite its woes, Mazda said it would not lay off permanent employees, although some managers were in for a change they might not have bargained for. Some 500 office workers at a time will be sent to work on the assembly lines for three months. They will replace contract laborers who will be dismissed, a spokesman said. An additional 1,000 office workers will go to sales and service.
The Hiroshima-based company now expects to sell 455,000 cars and trucks in Japan in the fiscal year that ends next March, down from 462,000 last year and 25 percent below the company's peak of 600,000 vehicles in the fiscal year that ended in March 1991. In May, Mazda had forecast an increase in domestic sales to 470,000 units this year.

HEADLINE: Albany to Let Insurance Law Cover Partners

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Sept. 29

 BODY:
Reversing a 54-year-old policy, the Cuomo administration today lifted New York State's prohibition against providing family health insurance that covers the domestic partners of homosexuals and unmarried heterosexuals.
The ruling, which had been sought for years by advocates for gay and lesbian rights, opens a new and untested market for the insurance industry in New York, among private companies and local governments. It also provides a major political opportunity for Mayor David N. Dinkins, who may now be able to grant insurance benefits to the domestic partners of city employees. Such a move would almost certainly energize gay and lesbian supporters in Mr. Dinkins's re-election campaign against Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate. 
 Mr. Dinkins said in a statement that the ruling "eliminates a major obstacle" to the settlement of a lawsuit filed against the city in 1988 by the Lesbian and Gay Teachers Association. The teachers charged that it was discriminatory for the city not to provide health coverage for their domestic partners while allowing coverage for the spouses of married teachers and other city employees.
The Mayor's counsel, George B. Daniels, said Mr. Dinkins would also seek to negotiate insurance coverage for domestic partners with other unions of city workers. "The Mayor's made it clear that this isn't just about settling the gay teacher's case," Mr. Daniels said. "It's a benefit that should be available to all city employees."
 
Opponents Question Cost to Budget
 If New York City establishes health benefits for its employees' domestic partners, it will join at least a dozen municipal governments around the country. They include those of San Francisco, Seattle, Boston, West Hollywood, Calif., Ann Arbor, Burlington, Vt., Berkeley and Minneapolis.
Opponents of insurance rights for domestic partners question whether the cost would place an unmanageable burden on the New York City budget. But city officials and gay and lesbian lobbyists said that other cities had not encountered such costs.
In Seattle, for instance, insurance fees for coverage that includes domestic partners amounts to only 1.3 percent of total health insurance costs for city employees, said Sally W. Fox, Seattle's benefits manager. She said that 476 of the city's 10,000 employees were signed up for domestic partnership benefits, and that an estimated 70 percent of them were heterosexuals.
Mr. Daniels said the city was working on projections of the potential cost. Since Mr. Dinkins signed an executive order allowing domestic partners to register with the city earlier this year, 1,300 couples have registered, Mr. Daniels said. Only 150 of them include a city employee.
Until today, the State Insurance Department had interpreted the state's insurance law, which was written in 1939, as allowing family health coverage primarily for employees, their spouses and their children. It had ruled specifically that domestic partners were not covered by a clause in the law allowing coverage for "other persons chiefly dependent upon" an employee "for support and maintenance."
 
'Appropriate Circumstances'
 In 1989, James P. Corcoran, then the Insurance Superintendent, ruled that such a change would be "wholly antithetical to the Legislature's purpose." His successor, Salvatore R. Curiale, repeated that stand in 1990.
But after reconsidering at the request of Mr. Dinkins and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Mr. Curiale ruled today that domestic partners can be covered "under appropriate circumstances, without a showing of complete, unilateral economic dependency." Although the state controls the kind of insurance that companies may offer, he said the state cannot require coverage of domestic partners.
Mr. Curiale wrote in a letter to Mr. Cuomo that "a showing of mutual interdependency would be sufficient under the law to permit coverage." He said that interdependency could be demonstrated by factors like "common ownership of property, common householding, shared budgeting, length of the relationship, etc."
He did not specify how the department would ultimately define a domestic partnership. But he said he would work with insurance companies and gay and lesbian representatives "to fashion a set of criteria that would make them sufficient to protect companies and encourage them to make the coverage available."
Mr. Curiale did not specify why he changed course. His spokesman, John Calagna, said he had been influenced by the Mayor's decision to allow domestic partners to register and by a 1989 ruling of the State Court of Appeals. It said a domestic partnership could be defined as a family for the purpose of determining the inheritance of a rent-controlled apartment.
But gay and lesbian advocates said the decision also clearly had a political motivation. It enabled Mr. Cuomo to provide significant -- and cost-free -- help for Mr. Dinkins five weeks before Election Day.
Mr. Dinkins won enthusiastic backing from gay and lesbian groups when he ran for Mayor in 1989, largely because he promised to provide insurance coverage and other standard benefits to the domestic partners of city employees. Since his election, he has said his hands were tied by the state's insurance law. Although he established the domestic partners' registry this year, gay and lesbian supporters have expressed disappointment in the Mayor for not fulfilling his pledge on the insurance issue.
Mr. Curiale's decision also may rally gay and lesbian support for Mr. Cuomo if he runs for re-election next year. One possible Republican opponent, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, was seen as playing to gay New Yorkers earlier this year when he expressed support for allowing homosexuals in the military.
 
'Cuomo Helping Cuomo'
 "This is definitely Cuomo helping Dinkins, but it's also Cuomo helping Cuomo because he has not been able to deliver a gay-rights bill," said Dick Dadey, the executive director of Empire State Pride Agenda, a gay-rights lobbying group.
Mr. Cuomo said today that he did not make the decision for Mr. Curiale. But he said he was "quite content with the result."
Most of the speculation about the potential demand for the new insurance is centering on municipal governments, because they will presumably be under the most immediate pressure to provide it. Insurance executives said that their activity in the new market would depend on demand from employers, and they doubted there would be a spontaneous surge to fill the new niche.
One health maintenance organization, Oxford Health Plans of New York, already has filed an insurance department application to provide coverage for domestic partners. David B. Snow, the company's executive vice president, said the filing was made at the request of a large corporate client, which he would not name. He said his company had not had many other requests.
Kevin Heine, a spokesman for the Prudential, said: "As long as employers and health insurers can develop a reasonable definition of what constitutes a domestic partner, then we would provide coverage. But it's really client-driven. We have not seen a big demand for it."

HEADLINE: Her Manner Controlled, Holtzman Gazes Ahead

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Elizabeth Holtzman says she may run again. She may teach first or practice law and accept an appointive post in government, which is how her public career began.
But yesterday, hours after suffering her third electoral loss and the first in which voters rejected her for a job she had vigorously campaigned to keep, Ms. Holtzman seemed remarkably equanimous. 
 Only a few months ago, Ms. Holtzman had seemed certain to be re-elected as New York City Comptroller. And it was uncertain whether her demeanor yesterday, in contrast to how she handled two other losing campaigns, was for appearance's sake as she prepares her resume and contemplates future political opportunities.
She said she was not just rationalizing, but had genuinely reconciled herself to the freedom of a defeat.
"I learned that in my days in the South, as a civil rights worker," the 52-year-old Ms. Holtzman maintained. "I didn't realize how dangerous it was, that you could lose your life. If I had, I wouldn't have come. Then, when I came to Congress, I knew the party organization would be out to get me, so I worried about the political implications of this vote, or that. And then I said, let's just try to do the right thing.
"You have to be willing to give things up, but they can't take your life away," she said. "In Solzhenitsyn's 'The First Circle,' the character in the gulag finally became unwilling to compromise with the system. They punish him further. But he's free."
 
Would the Past Be Prologue?
 Given her refusal, for years, to publicly concede the 1980 United States Senate election to Alfonse M. D'Amato, and the acrimony of last year's Senate primary against Geraldine A. Ferraro, some doubters wondered on Tuesday night how she would handle her lopsided loss to Assemblyman Alan G. Hevesi of Queens in the city's first runoff primary for comptroller.
Ms. Holtzman took them by surprise. She was poised -- becoming teary only when she recounted the odyssey of her grandparents and parents, coming to America for economic and political freedom.
She was sanguine, even upbeat as she evoked the spirit of Lou Gehrig's Yankee Stadium farewell more than half a century ago, saying how lucky she had been to have spent more than two decades as an elected official. And, with what her critics had called Liz Holtzman's disease seemingly in remission, she was gracious.
Only once did she betray bitterness as she basked in a Brighton Beach man's verdict that she had more integrity in her little finger than all the city's other politicians had combined. "I think," she said yesterday, "there are some people who are honest."
She seemed sanguine, too. Just after midnight Tuesday, as she sipped champagne from a fluted glass with a rosebud bobbing at the bottom -- the trademark drink at the Yaffa Tea Room, a funky TriBeCa restaurant where she consoled a score of close friends and colleagues -- she told a reporter that it would be premature to print her political obituary.
"It's not over," she said, smiling.
Later yesterday, fielding phone calls in the Municipal Building, she said her immediate priority was a vacation.
But she repeated that her loss did not represent a defeat for integrity, civil rights, the rights of women and other values she had championed. "I know I will continue to stand up for them and for you, the people of this great city, no matter where I am, no matter what I'm doing," Ms. Holtzman said, afterward adding pointedly, "whether in or out of government."
Her term as comptroller expires on Dec. 31. Then what?
"This campaign's been exhausting on top of a campaign last year that was exhausting," she said, perfectly attired in a navy blue tattersall suit and fingering a paper coffee cup. "I don't, for the moment, want to be thinking of any more campaigns. I've practiced law, I've taught. There are a lot of options. and I intend to explore them."
Including an appointment in the Clinton Administration?
"First I have to pay off a loan," she replied, the irony conscious.
She had personally guaranteed the $450,000 loan her Senate campaign was granted by Fleet Bank in the closing weeks of the '92 primary. Seven months later, Fleet Securities, a sister company, was named by the comptroller's office as one of 23 co-managers of city bond offerings. Ms. Holtzman maintained that she played no role whatsoever in choosing Fleet Securities.
"The controversy over the bank loan obscured discussion of everything else -- my record, my vision for the future," she said yesterday. "It became the all-consuming issue of the race. I would say, with some hesitation, the sole issue."
Even in her home Assembly District in Brooklyn, a borough she had represented in Congress and served as District Attorney, the voters were unforgiving -- in part, because she was hoist by the petard of high ethical standards she had consistently set for herself and to which she had relentlessly held other officials.
 
No Mercy on Bookshelf, Either
 The Macmillan Dictionary of Political Quotations includes three references to Ms. Holtzman, all in the category of nicknames: "Ice Lady," "Liz the Lion Killer" and "Virgin Liz." But Ms. Holtzman maintains that her image as a rigid, intense, loner is merely "a media construct."
(Before the primary, she became weepy while discussing her political career and walked away from a television interview, only to return moments later and explain gamely that she had not been fortified that day with her regular morning cereal. An unwrapped 10-pack, boxes of assorted cold cereal, now adorns a coffee table in her office.)
"I'm lucky," she said. "It was a fluke that I got into Congress. I was young, a woman, going against the establishment, not from a wealthy background. I am still the youngest woman ever elected to Congress."
Her loss this week, she quoted supporters as saying, represented "a backlash against strong women" -- although one very strong woman, Ms. Ferraro, whom Ms. Holtzman verbally eviscerated in last year's Senate campaign, was pulling for Mr. Hevesi.
"I said I had put that Senate race behind me, but it's clear that she wasn't able to," Ms. Holtzman said, alluding to Ms. Ferraro. "For me, politics and government aren't about personal issues."
She might have gone further had she stayed in Congress, and she suggested that her political independence might have proved costly. It was worth it, she said.
"I have to look in the mirror at night -- you bet," she replied. "I'm not saying the price was justified, but you have to be prepared to pay it."
Twenty-three years have elapsed since her first campaign, for Democratic state committeewoman. "In order to have a shot at winning," she recalled, "I had to challenge the law that listed incumbents first on the ballot. It was Holtzman vs. Power, and Power lost. All powers have been miffed ever since."
On Tuesday, too, the challenger won; the incumbent was Ms. Holtzman.

HEADLINE: OPEC Accord Hurts Transportation Stocks

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
Oil stocks soared and transportation issues plummeted yesterday, as OPEC announced limits on oil production that meant good news for fuel producers and bad news for users.
The Dow Jones transportation index sank a sharp 16.25 points, or 1 percent, to 1,637.53, after the announcement by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Although the announcement was made fairly late in the New York trading day, preliminary reports had moved the market strongly. 
 Oil prices on the New York Mercantile Exchange rose on the agreement, with November crude oil gaining 71 cents, to $18.67 a barrel. Analysts said the new pact was good for OPEC because it showed that the group could iron out some disagreements.
 
Dow Industrials Up 0.28
 The rest of the stock market was lackluster, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing up 0.28 point, to 3,566.30, and the Standard & Poor's 500 index finishing down 1.42, to 460.11. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 277.8 million shares, up from 243.4 million on Tuesday.
The Nasdaq composite closed off 0.49, to 763.17, ending a four-day streak of record highs. Analysts attributed the drop to a selloff in technology stocks, which had a strong run-up in recent days. The American Stock Exchange index closed at 457.65, up 0.53.
Among the oil gainers were Anadarko Petroleum, up 5 1/8, to 47 3/8; Atlantic Richfield, up 4 1/4, to 116 1/8; Chevron, up 2 1/2, to 97; Amoco, up 2 3/8, to 57 3/4; Amerada Hess, up 2, to 54 1/4, and Exxon, up 1, to 66 5/8.
Among the transportation losers were UAL parent of United Airlines, down 3 5/8, to 141; Delta Air Lines, down 1 1/4, to 52 1/8; Federal Express, down 7/8, to 62, and Consolidated Freightways, down 3/4, to 15 5/8.
 
Technology Issues Off
 Robert G. Freedman, chief investment officer for the John Hancock Mutual Funds in Boston, said the day saw "profit taking in technology stocks."
"I'm not sure the day really told us anything other than that traders were in there moving from sector to sector and taking profits," he said.
Traders also appeared to be looking ahead to third-quarter earnings reports for some guidance because the general economic news is mixed, he said.
Among the technology stocks that suffered were Micron Tech, down 4 3/8, to 55 3/8; Texas Instruments, down 2 3/4, to 76 5/8, and Applied Materials, down 5 5/8, to 72 7/8.
Paramount Communications rose 1 5/8, to 79 3/8, on news that Blockbuster Entertainment, the video rental chain, had agreed to invest in Viacom as part of Viacom's offer to buy Paramount. Viacom sank 1 1/2, to 59 1/2, while Blockbuster dropped 1/8, to 29 1/8. QVC Network, Paramount's other suitor, rose 1/8, to 59 5/8.
Taubman Centers, a real estate investment trust that owns shopping malls, dropped 3/4, to 14, after the company announced that it would not meet cash-flow projections because of rising vacancy rates.
Braintree Savings Bank in Braintree, Mass., announced that it was discussing a possible merger but did not name the other company. Braintree's stock rose 4, to 16 1/2.

HEADLINE: Florio, on Stump, Pledges $1 Billion in Business Aid

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Sept. 29

 BODY:
Seeking to offer a counterproposal to the economic plan unveiled last week by Christine Todd Whitman, the Republican gubernatorial candidate, Gov. Jim Florio promised today to make nearly $1 billion available in state-backed business loans and investments over the next four years.
"There's no pie in the sky in this. No promises. No ledger sheets that don't add up," said Mr. Florio, who took to the stump to tout his plan to expand the Economic Development Authority, a state-run agency that guarantees bank loans for business. 
 Mr. Florio said that his plans for the authority were only a slice of his economic blueprint for the state over the next four years. But it provided a large enough target for the Whitman campaign.
"I don't consider that an economic recovery plan; it is more like the Economic Development Authority's annual report," said Carl Golden, spokesman for the Whitman campaign. "It does not go to the issue of the state budget. It does not go to the issue of budget cutting or raising taxes. Distributing the E.D.A. annual report is a woefully pitiful response."
 
Groping for Political Ground
 Polls have shown that the economy and jobs are among the major concerns for New Jersey voters, and Mrs. Whitman and Mr. Florio have maneuvered furiously over the last week to gain political ground on the issues.
While Mr. Florio broke no new ground with his Economic Development Authority plan, his choice of a fairly limited program enables him to contrast himself with Mrs. Whitman, whom he has accused of promising far more than she can deliver. Mr. Florio's program also gives her very little to shoot at.
Mrs. Whitman released her economic blueprint on Sept. 21 and spent the last week challenging Mr. Florio to do the same. Trumpeting a plan drawn up by a group of fiscal, tax and business advisers, Mrs. Whitman promised to cut taxes by nearly $1.5 billion, pare the size of state government and to create 450,000 new jobs over the next four years.
But Mrs. Whitman has refused to give specifics about her economic plan, opening the way for nearly daily attacks from Mr. Florio and generally caustic criticism from newspaper editorial writers in the state.
 
No Specific New Ideas
 Mr. Florio has not put forth any specific new ideas, either. Instead, he has pointed to his record over the last three years. He has cited public works projects such as the Atlantic City Convention Center and a 20,000-seat expansion of the Rutgers University football stadium, tough enforcement of environmental laws (which he said helped spur a business boom at the New Jersey Shore) and the Economic Development Authority.
The Economic Development Authority is one of the major pillars of Mr. Florio's economic plan. Since he took office, the authority's financing has grown from $95 million in 1990 to $579 million in 1992. President Clinton borrowed some ideas from the authority while putting together his program to provide community loans for small businesses, the Federal Community Development Banking and Financial Institutions Act of 1993.
Mr. Florio said that over the last four years it had invested more than $1 billion in financing in more than 500 projects and had created nearly 30,000 jobs. Authority officials say the default rate -- bad debts that the taxpayers ultimately have to pay -- has been less than 4 percent, which they say is much lower than the comparable rate at commercial banks.
"The Economic Development Authority was idling in neutral when we took office," Mr. Florio said. "Today it's in high gear and there are entrepreneurs all over the state who can tell you how much thye have been helped."
Over the next four years, Mr. Florio said his administration through the E.D.A. would provide $50 million for one-year small business loans at interest rates of 3 to 5 percent, and $10 million for local development agencies to finance small business loans of $10,000 to $50,000; $800 million for a statewide loan pool for small to medium businesses and a pool to enable them to trade in the public bond market; $100 million to help New Jersey businesses obtain financing to sell overseas, and $25 million for a public schools loan assistance program.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long Bond Price Falls; Yield at 5.99%

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Volatility continues to be the only constant in the bond market, as traders and investors await some surer signals on the pace of economic growth and speed of inflation.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 25/32 yesterday, and the yield flirted with 6 percent, but finished at 5.99 percent, up from 5.94 percent on Tuesday. The prices of Treasury notes fell across the board. 
 In the 15 trading days since the 30-year bond yield reached a 25-year low of 5.86 percent, the yield on the 30-year bond has jumped as high as 6.12 percent and as low as 5.94 percent on Tuesday. But the volatile swings have yet to indicate whether traders and investors have decided that the rally was over and abandoned the hope for lower long-term interest rates.
Michael H. Strauss, the chief economist at Yamaichi International, said the recent downswings in prices of Treasury securities have indicated that the rally, which followed on the heels of President Clinton's election victory, was over. "It doesn't look like retail," he said, referring to money managers, "is willing to buy on the dips here."
 
Sturdier Growth Rate Expected
 One reason, he said, was that he expected the economy, which grew at an annual rate of about 1.3 percent in the first half of the year, to move to a sturdier 2.8 percent pace in the current quarter and possibly 4 percent in the fourth quarter.
But other analysts said they still expected longer-term interest rates to fall lower, breaching the 5.86 percent, 25-year low reached on Sept. 8, and touch 5.75 percent. But that bet hinges on the Labor Department report on employment in September, due a week from Friday, and the August Consumer Price Index, which is to be released the following Tuesday, showing that growth is still slow and inflation is at 3 percent.
In trading yesterday, the absence of significant news left traders and investors to do their trading on information of a second-tier nature. A jump in oil prices, which rose 71 cents, to $18.67 a barrel for the November contract on the New York Mercantile Exchange, helped prompt some selling, Mr. Strauss said, because it dimmed the hope for more declines in oil prices that would further reduce inflationary pressures.
 
OPEC Decision has Impact
 The price rise was in response to the agreement on the production limits reached at the OPEC meeting in Geneva.
Mr. Strauss also said the reports of a big player in the bond futures market betting that prices would fall and yields would rise also put some pressure on bond and note prices.
The Commerce Department revision in its growth estimate for the gross domestic product in the second quarter had little impact on trading. The new estimate is 1.9 percent, after an adjustment for inflation, up from the estimate of 1.8 percent a month ago.
But Mr. Strauss said a bigger reason was the growing realization "that the economy is doing significantly better than it did in the first half of the year."
He said some investors were selling because they feared some of the economic reports scheduled for today and tomorrow would be strong enough to begin to suggest that the economy was moving ahead at a pace that would mean little chance for a further slowdown in inflation. If that is the case, the argument for lower long-term rates is harder to make.
 
Help-Wanted Index Rises
 The personal income report due today, he said, should show an increase of about 1 percent in August, after a decline of two-tenths of a percent in July.
He expected new home sales, also due today, to be up 9 percent and the index of leading economic indicators, due tomorrow, to rise about a percent.
The report yesterday that the Conference Board's help-wanted index rose to 104 in August, from 100 in July, also added to the selling. "We are not booming," Mr. Strauss said, "but clearly we have better economic numbers than we have seen in the past."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Companies Will Meet Health Costs With Higher Prices and Lower Pay

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
WHO will pay for national health insurance? Why business, of course, President Clinton assured the nation. Under the White House plan, most employers would be required to write checks for 80 percent of the cost of a generous package of medical benefits for employees and families.
But many economists think the President has it exactly backward: Of all the possible candidates, corporate America is least likely to be stuck for the buck. One way or another, they say, the cost of employer-mandated health premiums will either be passed forward to consumers in the form of higher prices, or backward to workers in the form of lower wages. 
 And while there may be admirable political reasons for preserving what Uwe Reinhardt of Princeton University calls "the myth that someone else will pay," linking insurance to employment is likely to have side-effects that range from irritating complexity to flagrant inefficiency.
The plan calls for employers to cover 80 cents on the premium dollar charged to members of each "regional health alliance." This premium would be "community rated" -- that is, unrelated to age, medical history or health-threatening personal habits. It would vary only with the size of the worker's family and the number of family members who are employed.
How then would it be possible for employers to dodge their legal share of the bill? One route, suggests Barry Bosworth of the Brookings Institution, would be for corporations to raise their prices. This, he argues, is what happens when business costs are broadly (and uniformly) increased by a government mandate like an increase in Social Security taxes.
Forward shifting may not work, though. If, for example, producers compete directly with importers who are unaffected by the insurance mandate or if consumers are unwilling to buy as much at the higher price, some of the extra costs must come from another pocket.
Thus stockholders may initially suffer a squeeze on profits. But the mobility of capital, the global flow of funds to investment with the highest returns, makes it virtually impossible to trap capital for long: Either jobs must be pared, or labor must pick up the tab. In the 1980's, Mr. Bosworth says, much of the increase in employer-paid health insurance costs came out of pension benefits.
Where mandated cost increases hit businesses more selectively (as may prove the case with the Clinton plan) employers are apt to go directly to labor for the extra money. Jonathan Gruber, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, found that maternity benefits mandated in the 1970's were matched "roughly dollar for dollar" with cuts in wages for the young, married employees likely to claim the benefits. Over all, researchers believe that about three-quarters of mandated labor benefits are passed back to workers, with the rest passed forward to consumers.
So employers will not pay. Does Mr. Clinton's Big White Lie -- one that virtually every noneconomist probably believes -- really matter?
On the plus side (assuming one expects more good than harm to come from universal, community-rated health insurance), it has generated powerful allies for the Clinton plan within organized labor. And it will probably help win over the majority of middle-income Americans, who will not worry that their own health care costs will rise.
One the minus side, the myth has driven the Administration to cut a variety of side deals to placate business interests who think they will pay. To win over the small-business lobby, corporations with fewer than 50 employees whose workers average less than $12 an hour will not be obliged to shell out the maximum 7.9 percent of payroll in insurance premiums. Thus a fast-food outlet owned by McDonald's will apparently be expected to pay considerably more than a separately incorporated McDonald's franchise. "This will prove a bonanza for business consultants," Mr. Reinhardt predicts.
By the same token, the plan offers a safety valve to corporations with more than 5,000 employees: the option to bypass the regional health alliances and insure their own workers. Mr. Reinhardt says this could generate a welcome bonus in efficiency -- the huge regional health alliances are likely to be quagmires of bureaucracy. But it would also undermine the "we're all in this together" ethos of community-rating by giving big companies the chance to shed health costs by employing younger, healthier workers. According to Mr. Bosworth, a 55-year-old worker costs five times as much to insure as a 25-year-old.
An appealing alternative to employer mandates is individual mandates. Washington could oblige everyone to buy community-rated private health insurance, or pay an equivalent income tax surcharge. Those who could not afford the full premium could be subsidized by Uncle Sam.
The political catch is that Americans would be confronted with the reality that people, not corporations, pay for health insurance. "With health care reform," Mr. Gruber reluctantly concludes, "the best may be the enemy of the good."

HEADLINE: Like-New Romper, Worn Only on Weekends by Tiny Librarian

BYLINE: By DEBORAH HOFMANN

 BODY:
CHILDREN tend to outgrow clothes and belongings long before they wear them out, creating a vast pool of gently used garments, furniture, toys and books. For parents who need to keep up with the costly cycle, and for parents who need to dispose of barely used wares, there is a satisfying solution: resale stores.
Such stores typically sell used items for less than half their original retail prices, and they work on consignment, giving a percentage of the profit to the client. 
 Bargains may range from $150 infant gyms, selling for about $20, to $80 car seats, for $35. Many parents who resent being implored to buy the latest fancy toy relent happily when that toy is available used, at a fraction of its original price. Growth spurts often require the purchase of a second parka in the same winter; a secondhand parka won't pose half the hardship.
Party clothes, often worn just once, are a bargain, too. Dresses with a $200 price tag when new are resold for less than half that. Blue blazers can be had for under $36, about one-third the going rate on Madison Avenue. Sizes usually range from newborn to 14. Carriages are often only a few months old, their upholstery well cleaned, the hubcaps polished. Cribs are usually less than two years old.
Resale shops have no problem finding merchandise to sell. Parents eager to make a little money flock to the stores. They usually make appointments and are asked to show at least 10 items a visit. Clothes must be in style, clean and in season. No scratchy woolens. No kilts.
Merchant and client compile a list of items and agree on the selling price of each. The client generally gets a check for 40 percent of the sale price. Whatever does not sell quickly is marked down further. Eventually, unsold items can be retrieved; more often, clients let stores donate unsold merchandise to charities.
People consign new items, too -- gifts that could not be returned to distant stores (a second Monopoly game, piggy bank, mobile or car seat). Heirlooms are offered for resale when people run out of storage (or relatives to give them to).
Because items are used, potential buyers should check nuts and bolts and seams carefully. Look for stains. Some stores allow you to take a garment home to try it on the child.
Resalers market aggressively. "My competition is not other resale stores -- it's the Gap," said Carla Freedland, who opened Good-Byes Children's Resale Store 11 months ago, at 230 East 78th Street (Third Avenue). If an item doesn't move, she explained, she does what Gap does: "It's marked down once and gone. People don't want to come and see the same dress they saw last time. It's depressing."
In addition to selling clothing, Good-Byes has a maternity boutique and is the only Manhattan children's resale shop that regularly features furniture.
Just browsing is fun. The 400-square-foot store is immaculate, spare and well lighted. Garments are carefully pressed and displayed on plastic hangers. Shoppers sip coffee or cocoa, brewed at the register, and munch from the pretzel and M & M dispensers. In the only resale store that accommodates them, children play with blocks and crayons in a play area.
In a typical week, a mint-condition Brambilla unisex reversible down-filled parka, made in France, with a cotton shell and leather trim, sold for $20 (it costs $150 new). Hand-knit snowsuits, many never used, were $18 t0 $50. And Patagonia fleece jackets, at $20, sold for less than half their original cost. A Maclaren double stroller went for $195; an Inglesina carriage and stroller set, used by one infant for six months, $250; a bassinet on wheels, $25; a portable crib, $45; and a stationary crib, $200 -- all about half the retail price. Books sold for $1 and less.
Sometimes, used may be better than new, for example a hand-me-down layette perfectly shrunk, its cotton fibers silkily softened for newborn skin. And at Good-Byes, soft Baby Gap T-shirts are about $5 (new ones on sale at Gap are $7 when first marked down, $4 on second markdown).
After 30 days, items are marked down 20 percent; after 60 days, 50 percent. After 90 days, items are given to the Children's Aid Society.
Second Act Children's Wear, 1046 Madison Avenue (80th Street), is 32 years old, the senior children's resale shop in Manhattan. "My business has grown as families have shrunk," said Joan Blake, the current owner. "We play an economic role that big families once provided for one another: hand-me-downs."
Thousands of garments are displayed on wire hangers on racks in three cramped rooms. Pants of all sizes topple out of boxes. Plan to devote hours rummaging for gold; you may find a $300 shearling coat for $50.
Donna Goldberg has been consigning her sons' sports equipment and Ralph Lauren clothing here for 10 years. "There were no cousins," Mrs. Goldberg said. "A rummage sale was not the way to match these things with kids who need them. Resale is a great way for a family to recycle."
There's an emotional component, too, she added: "With that passing on of something of your child's, you pass on its history, extend its life, in a real and emotionally satisfying way, to one who looks for it, cares and wants it."
Ralph Lauren Polo shirts, $38 to $56 at retail, are $10 to $12 at Second Act. Tennis rackets are $10 to $45. A hockey uniform with helmet and shoulder pads typically sells for $75; skates, $30. A unisex English coat made by Lighthouse, originally $500, in size 6, recently sold here for $175.
Socks are $1 a pair; loafers, party shoes and winter boots are all less than one-third the price of new ones. Sebago loafers are $15; Maraolo black patent-leather party slippers, $110 new, are $20. Games are half-price. After five months, items are discounted a further 25 to 40 percent.
Once Upon a Time, 171 East 92d Street (Third Avenue), accepts "nearly everything," said Ronnie Mann, the owner. That includes stuffed animals. The store, 30 feet long and 12 feet wide, is crammed to the rafters, with about 200 garments of every type -- pants, shirts, dresses, tops -- on display.
New end-of-season leftovers of Liberty of London dresses, generally $130, sell for $50 here. "Rarely are shoes more than $14, or boots more than $16, even if they're still in the box," Ms. Mann said.
A Bonpoint dress, $275 new, might be $60 here. An ornate white satin brocade party dress, size 6, designed by David Charles and originally priced at $325, sells for $85. A cherry red Lans coat, normally $275 to $325, sells for $65. Gap cotton sweaters, $28 new, are $8 to $12 here.
While girls' apparel dominates, boys' staples can be found. Navy blue blazers by Polo Ralph Lauren or Brooks Brothers are $36, less than one-third the retail price new. Gray flannel slacks by Gant are $8; with a Benetton label, they're $14.
A final bit of advice: Don't try to cut a deal with shop owners. They're parents, after all. Whining will get you nowhere.
"Someone who asks, 'You want $120 for this?' or 'Look at all I'm buying; can't you throw in a shirt free?' I firmly remind them, 'This is not a flea market,' " Ms. Blake said.
Following are some stores in Manhattan that sell used children's clothing, equipment and toys. Rules and hours tend to be flexible. Call ahead to see what items are accepted
FIRST AND SECOND COUSIN , 142 Seventh Avenue (between 10th and Charles streets); 929-8048. Monday through Saturday from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M.; Sunday, noon to 6 P.M.
GOOD- BYES CHILDREN'S RESALE STORE , 230 East 78th Street; 794-2301. Tuesday, Wednesday and Friday from 11:30 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Thursday to 7 P.M.; Saturday, 10 to 5 P.M., and Sunday, noon to 5 P.M.
KIDDINGAROUND , 68-70 Bleecker Street (between Broadway and LaFayette Street); 598-0228. Monday through Thursday and Saturday, 11 A.M. to 7 P.M.; Friday until 8 P.M. and Sunday until 6.
ONCE UPON A TIME , 171 East 92d Street; 831-7619. Monday through Saturday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.
SECOND ACT CHILDREN'S WEAR , 1046 Madison Avenue (80th Street); 988-2440. Tuesday through Saturday, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.

HEADLINE: Zita Johann Dead; Actress, 89, Played The Mummy's Love

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
Zita Johann, a stage and film actress who played Boris Karloff's love interest in "The Mummy," died on Friday at Nyack Hospital in Nyack, N.Y. She was 89 and lived in Orangeburg, N.Y.
The cause was pneumonia, said a friend, Rosemary Franck. 
 Miss Johann was born near Temesvar, Hungary, now Timisoara, Romania. She moved to New York City with her family when she was 7 and appeared in high school productions. After applying to the Theater Guild for work as an understudy, she immediately won roles in touring productions of "Peer Gynt," "The Devil's Disciple" and "He Who Gets Slapped."
She made her Broadway debut in 1924 in the Theater Guild's production of "Man and the Masses." Other leading roles followed, in "Machinal" (1928), "Tomorrow and Tomorrow" (1931) and other plays.
 
To Hollywood and Back
 In 1931 she played the wife of a steelworker who succumbs to drink in "The Struggle," the last film by D. W. Griffith. Most memorably, she played Helen Grosvenor in "The Mummy" (1932), whom the Mummy takes to be the vestal priestess for whom he conceived a forbidden passion 3,700 years earlier.
After appearing in "Tiger Shark" (1932), "Luxury Liner" (1933) and "Grand Canary" (1934), she returned to New York to act in the theater. She appeared in "Panic" (1935), "Flight Into China" (1939), "The Burning Deck" (1940) and "The Broken Journey" (1942).
During World War II, she raised money for war-related charities and organized shows for American soldiers on their way overseas. In recent decades, she worked with disturbed children and gave private acting lessons.
Her three marriages, to John Houseman, the director, John McCormick, an agent, and Bernard E. Shedd, an economist and publisher, all ended in divorce. She had no children.
